{"source": "Considering that the SM57 was introduced to the world in 1967, a year after the Shure SM58LC Shure SM58 Vocal Microphone, I guess the 58 gets Batman status, relegating the 57 to that of Robin"}
{"source": " But that's not really a fair assessment considering the 57 and 58 were developed at the same time, and except for the 58's acoustic foam lined cage pop screen, the two mics are identical electrically"}
{"source": "The SM (Studio Microphone) 57 was designed to begin it's life in a recording studio, as a dynamic microphone used to mic the ever increasing volume of rock and roll amplifiers, drum kits, etc"}
{"source": " In that capacity, it had no use for the pop screen of it's cousin the SM58, still one of the most sold vocal mics in the world to this day"}
{"source": " So the SM57 slimmed down and even though it's still a fine vocal mic, you'll see it used mostly mic'ing instruments, which it excels at"}
{"source": "One of it's long time and most important roles has been the official podium mic for the White House"}
{"source": " A pair of SM57's is always seen on various White House podiums for press conferences and there is even a VIP bundled kitShure SM57 VIP Dual Microphone Kityou can buy for this exact type of use"}
{"source": "The SM57 is an extremely rugged mic, built to tough standards and can take lots of road abuse"}
{"source": " That's one of the things that makes it popular with touring bands and sound companies"}
{"source": " And on top of that, it's just a great sounding mic for the price"}
{"source": "There is a Performer SeriesShure Beta 57A Microphonethat looks very similar to the SM57 but the Beta 57 has a different mic capsule and transformer and sounds different"}
{"source": " So make sure you try before you buy"}
{"source": "Bottom line is the Shure SM57 is one tough road mic that sounds awesome and is not overly priced"}
{"source": " A best value for sound companies, home studio recordists and touring musicians"}
{"source": "It is not a bad mic for the price ( If you want a real good one with studio quality mic it would cost over 600 bucks) but it is no comparison to a studio mic since I have worked in a recording studio"}

{"source": "How do you review an SM58?? I've used these most of my life, and will continue to"}
{"source": " Very durable, I got this to replace the same, a 20 year old, rusted / dented grill 58 :) I also use a D5 (AKG - same price) and a line 6 wirelesss, but the 58 is always reliable first choice or backup"}
{"source": "The first rule of microphones is that, \"No one microphone is perfect for every purpose"}
{"source": "\"  Rule two is, \"Experiment with different mics in different applications to find your signature sound"}
{"source": "\"  I've used Shure SM58's along with their ancestors and relatives back to 1968"}
{"source": "  I primarily used them for broadcasting and recording spoken word content but I have used (and still do use) them for singing some back up vocals"}
{"source": "The SM58 does one thing well and that is vocal performance when used very close to the mouth for public address use"}
{"source": "  Some people, me included, actually sound better and more comfortable in a live performance setting when using another mic, the Shure SM-57"}
{"source": "  The SM-58 is a very good vocal mic and for some people probably the best choice"}
{"source": "  For example, anyone who can not resist putting the mic right up against their lips while singing will probably want the SM-58"}
{"source": "  People with softer or weaker voices will want the SM-58"}
{"source": "The SM-58 is highly directional and has a noticeable yet manageable proximity effect (which means the bass increases the closer you get"}
{"source": ")  This mic does not pick up well from much over 8 inches away"}
{"source": "  The reason so many singers think you are supposed to shove microphones practically inside your mouth is because the ball type Shure vocal mics require you to get them very close or they don't sound right"}
{"source": "  On the other hand, the SM-57 sounds best several inches away from the user's mouth and works fine up to 12 inches away"}
{"source": "  While the SM-58 is certainly the number one professional PA vocal mic, there are precious few other uses for it because it has a colored sound with a prominent frequency response boost in the upper midrange plus a sound source has to be very close before it is picked up clearly"}
{"source": "  It works ok for conga drums and the like, but the SM-58 is about the last thing you'd want to use to mic a sax or guitar"}
{"source": "  Personally these mics are not the best for my mic technique or the basic nature my voice, but for some people they sound great"}

{"source": "  However for other people the SM-58 works better"}

{"source": "  If you have a very deep voice, the SM-58 might be the second best choice after the SM-57 which has a better low frequency response"}
{"source": "One certain advantage of the SM-58 is the excellent gain before feedback capability"}
{"source": "  This mic can be turned up louder than almost any other mic without that annoying PA squeal"}
{"source": "  Another advantage of the SM-58 is that it is still available (at a slight extra cost) with a built-in on/off switch"}

{"source": " use it all the time"}
{"source": "In the immortal words that John Cameron Swayze used when hawking his Timex watches during the early days of live television, the Shure SM58 Vocal mic fits perfectly into that same category"}
{"source": "Before I found a career as a film and television sound recordist and mixer, I played in rock bands and did live sound mixing"}
{"source": " One of the very first mics we truly fell in love with was the SM58"}
{"source": " Introduced by the Shure Brothers Company in 1966, the SM58 quickly rose to become the industry standard in rugged road mics that actually sound good to the ear and are nearly indestructible"}
{"source": "The mic capsule is of cardiord (heart shaped) design which helps reject sound from either side"}
{"source": " There is a 4K bump in it's frequency which helps vocals cut through stage noise"}
{"source": " Construction is rugged, frequency response is 50 to 15,000 Hz, and the capsule sits internally on a foam shock mount to help isolate it from handling noise"}
{"source": "We used to joke about the SM58 in that if you needed a hammer and you couldn't find one, just grab one of these, they are that tough"}
{"source": " I've seen some of these on the road that you couldn't believe still worked, but they did and sounded great"}
{"source": "The cage style pop screen gives the SM58 not only it's distinctive look, one that influenced many other mic brands from the day it was introduced, but it's part of the functionality"}
{"source": " Internally lined with a layer of acoustic foam, the cage helps keep vocals pops from getting to the dynamic mic element"}
{"source": " As a frame of reference, theShure SM57LC Shure SM57 Cardioid Dynamic Microphoneis the same exact mic and capsule, but without the pop screen"}
{"source": "Shure also sells a Performer series mic, theShure Beta 58A Supercardioid Dynamic Microphonethat looks almost identical to the SM58 but uses a totally different mic capsule and transformer and has a different sound so try before you buy"}
{"source": "The Shure SM58 is still considered the industry standard of live performance mics today and for the price, they really are a good deal"}
{"source": "I made the mistake of thinking I could save forty bucks and get by with the Shure PG-58"}
{"source": "  I'm no vocalist but occasionally need to do announcements or accommodate a guest vocalist through an instrument amp (rather than a P"}
{"source": "A"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": " Whatever the reason, the PG-58 simply doesn't have sufficient gain or oomph to be of much use with the Roland Cube / Peavey amps I try to employ it with (I use a 1/4\" adapter with the XLR connector that comes with the mic)"}
{"source": "  When I borrow a Shure SM-58 mic from someone, the difference is instant and dramatic--it's a far more efficient (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": " louder) mic, producing a full, clear sound, and without additional pre-amplification, demonstrating why it's the most popular microphone in the world"}
{"source": "  For five bucks extra, I can't fathom a reason for avoiding the SM-58S, the version with an on-off switch"}
{"source": "  It's a small price to pay for quick solutions to feedback or the unwanted pick-up of \"private\" comments by indiscreet band members"}
{"source": "  And even if you're an instrumentalist, it may be wiser to select the SM-58 over the SM-57"}
{"source": "  The former mic is a little more ostentatious, but it's also slightly more adaptable, and the screen can filter out a certain amount of wind noise and unwanted non-musical sounds"}
{"source": " Above all, the SM-58 has proven itself to be the Sherman tank of microphones, simply unparalleled for ruggedness and durability"}
{"source": "[I see a review cautioning the consumer to be wary of \"this seller"}
{"source": "\"  Perhaps a good point unless it's in reference to Amazon Prime, which is the Shure SM-58 of commerce: competitive prices, no postage, easy returns"}
{"source": "  But anyone who returns an SM58 probably had no business buying it in the first place"}
{"source": "  They are the populous drones of the industry, invariably purchased by professionals who know first-hand what they're getting--reliability and virtual indestructibility"}

{"source": "This is a well made, low noise and low cost cable"}
{"source": " Unless you make a lot of money with your recordings, this will do just fine!"}
{"source": "Everyone develops personal preferences over time for one reason or another"}
{"source": "  I have a personal preference for the XLR ends with the really fine threaded plastic cap on the outside (first to slide down the cable) with a 4 legged gripper underneath that slides next down the cable and pinches down as you tighten the plastic outer cap into the metal housing with the solder contacts causing the gripper to strain relief most cable diameters"}
{"source": "  Unfortunately that design isn't used here, but I chose to award the 5 star rating for value because you get 15' of good quality shielded cable with 2 XLR ends (M and F) for well under $1/ft"}
{"source": "As for pinout it's straightforward, pin 1 is tied to the metal grip and shield and connects between both ends, while pins 2 and 3 are run isolated between both ends"}
{"source": "  The end design chosen uses the single set screw connector (the tiny one that gets lost so easy if you need to take it apart) and the rubber bumper design on the back which I haven't had the best of luck making quick changes in the field with, however for interconnecting equipment on a temporary basis these cables are an important starting point of any audio engineer's kit because they will be used not if but WHEN the need arises"}
{"source": "Another favorite of mine is the 6 pack of 3 foot male to female cables which do use my favorite XLR ends mentioned above, which amazon will rush you:GLS Audio 3ft Patch Cable Cords - XLR Male To XLR Female Black Cables - 3' Balanced Snake Cord - 6 PACK- these are very easy to open an end, change phase, lift ground, or input someone's oddball source signal"}
{"source": "  Having 6 on hand means you won't quibble over cable costs before the show starts and that channel will be in the final mix"}

{"source": "As several of the previous posters astutely mentioned, 'you will need a noise gate to use this pedal'"}
{"source": " I completely agree with that"}
{"source": " And it will sustain your notes"}
{"source": " It will actually raise the volume to make them sustain"}
{"source": " But you will have extraneous hiss when the guitar is not playing to cover it up"}
{"source": " The only way to get rid of this hiss is to use a noise gate"}
{"source": " I use the NS-2 when I use my chain of pedals"}
{"source": " That said, this pedals has some wonderful uses"}
{"source": " Every note will have the same volume"}
{"source": " You can hit the chord as hard as you like or as softly and it will play at the same volume"}
{"source": " You can set it to sustain for days"}
{"source": " Again, you will need a noise gate"}
{"source": " There is nothing transparent about THIS compressor as there is almost all of my other compressors, but none of them are as \"ACTIVE\" as this one"}
{"source": " Perhaps that's the price you pay for what this pedal can do"}
{"source": " I recommend messing with it quite a while"}
{"source": " You can do some incredible funk, jazz, metal vibes out of it"}
{"source": "It really pains me to give anything but a 5-star review to a BOSS product, since I'm such a big fan of their product line and build quality overall"}
{"source": "  Those compliments apply equally to the CS-3 Compression Sustainer"}
{"source": "  And it does do the job reasonably well without me having to worry about putting a less-reliable brand in my signal chain"}
{"source": "However, there are some minor issues with this pedal that you need to know"}
{"source": "  The two most common complaints that I see are that it adds \"noise\" to your amp and that it changes the tone a bit"}
{"source": "  The former complaint is probably true, though if you're enough of a hobbyist to use a Compression Sustainer, you're probably already contemplated using a noise gate/suppressor, such as the BOSS NS-2"}
{"source": "  Problem solved"}
{"source": "As for the latter complaint (changes tone), that's also true, but it's not necessarily a bad thing if you LIKE the tone that results"}
{"source": "  The whole point of the CS-3 is that it's supposed to cut out the extremes of your tone and sustain it"}
{"source": "  This can result in a muddy, \"neutered\" tone, though you can play with the TONE and other settings to help it"}
{"source": "  I also find that with the settings all at 12 O'Clock, the output is too quiet compared to other pedals at default settings"}
{"source": "Really, while BOSS pedals are considered to be \"expensive\" compared to many of the other effects out there, the CS-3 should really be viewed as a \"budget\" or \"entry level\" compressor, when you consider that most of the quality compressors are either in rack units or something like a Keeley Compressor costing north of $200"}
{"source": "  The best thing you can say about the BOSS (even compared to the similarly-priced MXR options) is that the CS-3 gives you a great deal of control over your compression for a reasonable price"}
{"source": "  The biggest negative of the pedal, in my opinion, is that the resulting sound might seem a little too"}
{"source": "compressed"}
{"source": "But there are a lot of things you could do with a CS-3, and it works best paired with other pedals (chorus, delay, some distortions) that you're trying to smooth out"}
{"source": "  Ultimately, it's a pedal that could have been better, though there aren't too many significantly better alternatives until you get north of $100 anyway"}
{"source": "As a pro musician, I am always on a quest for better tone to expand and comply with different gig situations"}

{"source": " It's a Boss, it's solid - and a great price"}
{"source": " Remember, this is overdrive - not distortion"}
{"source": " For distortion, look at other Boss pedals"}
{"source": "I have several overdrive pedals, some of which are much more expensive than the BOSS SD-1"}

{"source": " Plus my amp is a Twin Reverb so it too has tremolo"}
{"source": " If you are unfamiliar, tremolo modulates the volume as if turning it up and down rapidly"}
{"source": "The Boss TR-2 is the simplest of the three stompboxes to operate, with three controls: \"Rate\" of modulation, \"Depth\" of modulation (how much does the volume vary), and a \"Wave\" shape (jagged, square, or somewhere on a continuum in between)"}
{"source": " Unlike the other Boss stompboxes I own (CE-5 & PH-3), the TR-2 does not seem to compress sound so that it seems like you're \"playing in a fishbowl\" (as another reviewer puts it)"}
{"source": "The \"Wave\" control is what gives the unit its sonic versatility, so it is a nice feature to have"}
{"source": " Most tremolos have it, but not all"}
{"source": " For the price, it can give you a decent set of classic tremolo sounds with nothing too crazy"}
{"source": " It is the unit that Tom Morello uses on \"Guerilla Radio,\" and it does well with tremolo classics like the Smiths \"How Soon Is Now?\" I hear no volume drop problem like other reviews suggest, and this is something I am sensitive to because I generally turn modulations on/off over the course of a song rather than leave them on full time"}

{"source": "  Just be sure to tug on it after you put your strap on to make sure it's on right"}
{"source": "  I've struggled with the C clip in the past, but what are you going to do?  It's a one time thing when you first install, so it's no biggie"}
{"source": "I was very disappointed in both the quality and engineering of this product"}
{"source": " A work-around for the main issue follows the review"}
{"source": " The flaws that bother me in order of significance are:1) Quality: Very weak soft-metal screws"}
{"source": " Using minimal force and a well aligned driver there was some damage to the screw-heads on all 4 that I worked with"}
{"source": " 2 of them rounded out so much that I was afraid they would be hard to remove later, causing me to run to the hardware store for higher quality replacement screws"}
{"source": "2) Engineering : The instructions recommend, and the screws (the ones that come with the straplocks) are designed for a #2 Phillips screwdriver"}
{"source": " However, a standard #2 driver is too big to fit into the strap-buttons"}
{"source": " So you are likely to have to choose between grinding down a screwdriver to fit, or using a #1 which will increase the impact of the first problem above since it is the wrong tool for the job"}
{"source": "3) Engineering : The point of connection for the strap is 5/8th of an inch out from the guitar"}
{"source": " The strap button has a radius about 3/16ths of an inch"}
{"source": " Therefore any lateral stress (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": " weight of the guitar) is magnified by more than 3x due to leverage pulling outward on the screw"}
{"source": " A 9 pound guitar would be applying a constant 27 to 30 pounds of force on the screw and the wood around it (half that when the weight is distributed evenly on two strap buttons of course)"}
{"source": " Get a little too active on stage and the level of force could go way higher"}
{"source": "Realistically, if the screws weren't total crap, this might have been a 3 or 4 star review"}
{"source": " Once you deal with the fact that a normal screwdriver won't fit and get the things properly installed, it would probably work out for most people"}
{"source": " So if you are stuck with a set, here's what I recommend:Go to a hardware store and buy #6 x 1\" oval-head stainless steel replacement screws"}
{"source": " Note that these won't fit properly, but they are the closest match and can be modified"}
{"source": " (They are 21 cents each at my local stores, and would have cost Dunlop maybe 10 cents more in bulk than what they paid for the crap screws that come with this"}
{"source": ")Put the screw into an electric drill (pointy end in) so the screw head is rotating smoothly when you operate the drill"}
{"source": " Run the drill while using a file or a belt sander to take a fraction of the diameter off the screw head"}
{"source": " It doesn't need much"}
{"source": " I used a belt sander and it took about 20 seconds each"}
{"source": " While you are at it, file down a cheap #2 screwdriver so it will fit into the strap button"}
{"source": "Install with the new screws as normal, and recommend that your friends try a different brand!"}
{"source": "Sorry, I don't like these as they're just too big"}
{"source": " They stand out too much"}
{"source": " They do work and they're effective but they are too pronounced"}

{"source": " Apparently my Behringer speakers were not accurately reproducing that fequency range and I was EQing that range badly to compensate"}

{"source": "  The sound is bright, but lacks a fullness found with some of the heavier strings such asMartin MSP4150 SP Phosphor Bronze Acoustic Guitar Strings, Light-Medium"}
{"source": "The custom light are easier to play and have a bright tone to them, but can make a guitar sound like a cheaper model compared to the Light-Medium"}
{"source": " Some disadvantages to the thinner strings are that they can limit your dynamics"}
{"source": " If you strum harder, they are more stretchy and the tuning will be less consistent, changing the tone for the same reason a \"bend\" would"}
{"source": " If you play at a fairly consistent sound level you can expect more of a bright sound than a resonant one"}
{"source": "On the other hand, compared to some other brands with more of a dampened sound, the brightness can make an instrument sound quite good"}
{"source": "Depending on your style, these might be a good choice"}
{"source": " If you are used to playing a solid body electric with a lighter feel to the strings that make medium strings uncomfortable, these might seem more at home"}

{"source": "Planet Waves humidifiers are simple to use and a great product to guard against drying your guitar and causing splitting"}
{"source": " Dampen the sponge, squeeze out excess water, insert the sponge into the holder and the holder between hte strings"}
{"source": " Check on it every few days and keep the sponge damp"}
{"source": " Couldn't be any easier"}
{"source": " I use them all winter long in my guitars"}
{"source": "It's nothing special"}
{"source": "  No frills, just a simple concept that works"}
{"source": "  It's important to maintain humidity in your instrument, especially in a dry climate like west Texas"}
{"source": "  The evaporation rate will depend on the amount of humidity in the air where you store your instrument"}
{"source": "So, when you first start using it, you have to be diligent to check the sponge regularly to ensure that it is still moist"}
{"source": "This compact humidifier is easily filled with an included plastic syringe"}
{"source": "  If you don't over-fill, it will not drip, and you can simply place it in your case instead of the usual sponge"}
{"source": "I have an electronic indoor/outdoor thermometer that shows relative humidity and a whole house humidifier"}
{"source": "It is interesting to see just how quickly relative humidity changes inside and outside with that electronic thermometer"}
{"source": "The whole house humidifier pumps out about 3 gallons of water a day into a 1500 sq ft house during the fall and winter keeping the indoor humidity around 47%"}
{"source": "This makes the house feel warmer and makes my breathing easier"}
{"source": " Makes the whole house safer for the Martins"}
{"source": "Now you can use a little in the case humidifier like this to help with humidity, but I think you really need a whole house solution and a monitor system"}
{"source": "A sponge in a zip lock bag with a few holes works well too"}
{"source": " Just don't get water on the wood"}
{"source": "And don't forget to take the silica gel packs out of the little accessory compartment in the case"}
{"source": " Many guitars come shipped with these and their job is to remove humidity from the case"}
{"source": "All the better acoustic guitar shops I go to have a big humidifier running in their showrooms"}
{"source": "I thought I would throw my two-cents in about the new design and effectiveness of this soundhole humidifier"}
{"source": "After making a few homemade case humidifiers out of things like a travel butter container with many holes drilled into it and a sponge, I started thinking about how some of the cases separate the body cavity from the neck & headstock cavity inside the guitar case and not allowing the humidity to flow freely to all areas, especially the body where it is needed the most"}
{"source": "Even though I was getting acceptable humidification in the case I was concerned about the body being dryer in comparison so I went ahead and splurged the 8 bucks on these"}
{"source": " (I actually bought three of them"}
{"source": ")I crank the gas heat up in the house in the winter and A/C in the summer, keep my guitars inside their cases and inside a closet"}
{"source": " The humidity drops quite low, but the sponges remain moist for several days before I can no longer fight the urge to re-wet them"}
{"source": " lol"}
{"source": "Two great tips in one:Use a regular, more dense sponge, thicker like the ones at the dollar store"}
{"source": " Cut them to size and stuff them in!Throw away the sponge when it starts to get yucky and don't worry about distilled water, unless you want to"}
{"source": " I can't argue using very pure water compared to the possibly toxic crap that comes out our faucets, but for one dollar you can get a boat load of them after you cut them to size, and toss them away without any regard when needing replaced"}
{"source": "Don't worry about the &#34;thing&#34; hanging in-between your strings"}
{"source": " It will not damage anything unless you get the sponge  too saturated and it leaks"}
{"source": " I will either squeeze the excess water out, or shake the container with the sponge inside until I am satisfied that it won't drip"}
{"source": "The humidifier will not cause any stress or damage to your strings by spreading them when you wedge this inside your soundhole"}
{"source": "If you ARE rough, careless, thoughtless, or stupid, you could possibly knock this loose and have it rub or fall out, but I would be more worried about the guitar and what it would take for this to happen"}
{"source": " This would be more extreme to the guitar than the humidifier or any harm it could cause"}
{"source": "The top snaps on by squeezing the sides to release little tabs that stick through the top cover"}
{"source": " The sponge inside is quite small, and there isn't too much room for a much larger sponge"}
{"source": " The device is simple and fairly solid"}
{"source": " Treat it gently and it will last forever"}
{"source": " You can easily clean the inside or run it through a dishwasher"}
{"source": " If you give the inside a quick rinse every few fills, I'm sure it would be a decade before anything &#34;built up&#34; to require extensive cleaning or replacement"}
{"source": "Keep an eye on it for the first few days and then weeks to get a feel for when you should be re-wetting the sponge"}
{"source": "Try to keep the sponge moist when it's dry"}
{"source": "I strongly suggest getting an Oasis case humidifier, (or similar) mini sized about 1&#34; X 4&#34; costing around 17-20 bucks"}
{"source": "This will take any guesswork out of the equation and give you fairly accurate readings inside your guitar or instrument case"}
{"source": "Remember, too much humidity can cause your acoustic guitar to warp"}
{"source": " Too dry and it will shrink and crack, split the soundboard (top) also leaving the edges of the frets sticking out like the backbone of a fish and quite abrasive!If you spent more than one hundred dollars on your guitar and live where it gets cold and/or dry, you would be negligent (if not careless) to spend the pittance to make sure your 'baby ain't thirsty', or worse"}

{"source": " This has a replaceable sponge, you take it out, soak it and squeeze out excess then put it back in container, would say it gets more humidity out"}
{"source": "This is a simple humidifier for guitars with a round sound hole"}
{"source": "  It would not work for an f-hole archtop or other types of instruments such as mandolin or ukulele"}
{"source": "  Inside the sturdy plastic case is what appears to be an ordinary kitchen sponge"}
{"source": "  If you use distilled water (as recommended) it should last quite a while"}
{"source": "  The top comes off with a gentle press on the sides"}
{"source": "  The dry sponge can be a little difficult to remove with fingers but tweezers or needle nose pliers work perfectly"}
{"source": "  Don't push it all the way in after moistening and you won't have a problem"}
{"source": "  I drip a little distilled water on the sponge, squeeze out any excess, and the assembled case pops in easily between the D and G strings, suspended in the middle of the sound hole"}
{"source": "  They can't be seen in the photo but there are small ridges on each side that hold the top in place against the strings"}
{"source": "  I've never had one of these move from where I left it"}
{"source": "If the sponge isn't dripping wet you should never have a problem with drops of water in the guitar or case"}
{"source": "  When the humidity is very low (30% or less) the sponge dries out in 2 to 3 days even if the case isn't opened"}
{"source": "  As with most humidifiers of this type you will have to check every few days"}
{"source": "If you have ever had a crack appear in the top of favorite guitar (or don't want to see one) use a guitar humidifier!  Especially during the winter - heating a house tends to drop the indoor humidity below safe levels (between 45% and 60% is ideal for most guitars)"}
{"source": "  Air conditioning can do the same"}
{"source": "  For especially valuable guitars it would be worth buying a hygrometer to keep in the case but for most guitars having one in the room where you keep you guitar(s) is okay"}
{"source": "  For many reasons it's always best to keep your guitar in a case or gig bag when not in use"}

{"source": "The Pignose is not the world's best travel amp, or portable amp, or practice amp"}
{"source": " It's not very good for vocals, it's inefficient, what with its 40-year old design, and it distorts way too easy"}
{"source": " There are far better amps for most purposes from Boss and others that deliver a lot more clean volume, thanks to modern class-D amp technology, and a variety of digital effects to boot"}
{"source": "BUT"}
{"source": " there is one area where the Pig prevails"}
{"source": " If you're looking for the sound of a big overdriven amp in the studio, or miked on stage, the Pignose will give you that sound for less than the cost of one good quality overdrive pedal"}
{"source": " By opening and closing the box, you can get a range of cabinet sounds from the open-back Fender to the classic Marchall sealed cab, and everything in between"}
{"source": " Frank Zappa recorded a lot of his guitar parts using nothing but his SG running into a Pignose, and he got fantastic sounds"}
{"source": "Beyond that, it's cool looking, reasonably rugged, and even has pegs that allow you to hang it from a guitar strap"}
{"source": " Every rocker needs one"}
{"source": "The previous reviews are pretty accurate, though I would add that when the Pignose cabinet is closed, it can often sound rather boxy"}
{"source": " It sounded much clearer and cleaner when it was opened a couple of inches"}
{"source": "As for using pedals with it, it will take distortion to a degree"}
{"source": " It reaches a point, if pushed too hard, at which the definition of the distortion will begin turning mushy and shrill"}
{"source": " You can use a distortion + overdrive to decent effect, especially if you are running a cleaner sounding OD like a Tube Screamer"}
{"source": " I don't think it would do so well with a Bad Monkey, for example, though, which has more dirt in the tones it produces"}
{"source": " I don't have a fuzz box (not yet, but have one on order), but I think most fuzzes will sound like crap unless you use a relatively cleaner, sweeter one like the Red Witch Fuzz God or the Seymour Duncan Tweak Fuzz"}
{"source": " Otherwise, you will hear too much ground asphalt in the sound"}
{"source": "My wah wah, a Morley Power Wah, was almost useless with it"}
{"source": " The limited frequency response of the 5\" speaker made it sound overly throaty on cleans and when I put the boost in the shrillness would show itself again"}
{"source": "A chorus pedal sounds totally sweet on it, but a phaser, in my case, a Phase 90, just destroys the sound"}
{"source": " A flanger is also not really advisable"}
{"source": " You can use delay, just not with very rapid repeats"}
{"source": " Putting a compressor in front of your clean signal would probably make it more manageable for the Pignose' speaker"}

{"source": "I purchased this key on a whim"}
{"source": "  When it arrived the instructions were not clear, but I sat the dial to #2, loosened all of the lugs on my floor tom and went around my lugs using opposing lug patterns, and tested the first cut of tuning"}
{"source": " Too loose and deep, so I increased the setting to #3 and repeated"}
{"source": "  Almost the sound I wanted, so I used a regular key and went an eighth turn using the same pattern"}
{"source": "  Perfect"}
{"source": "  I then started on the next largest tom, working back to the smallest"}
{"source": "  Using the #3 setting plus an eighth turn I got my toms 1/2 octave apart"}
{"source": "Next I worked on my snare drum, starting with the snare side, then the batter side"}
{"source": " I used #4 on the batter side and #5 on the snare side, and managed to get the crisp, yet warm, sound I wanted"}
{"source": " The bass drum came next - I set the batter side tension 1 notch below the resonant side and achieve a great tuning"}
{"source": " From there I went back and set the resonant sides of each of my four toms one notch higher than the batter side and marveled at the perfect tuning I attained"}
{"source": "This is an easy device to use - with the lever facing you move it to the left, loosen all of your lugs, then tighten each starting with one or two"}
{"source": " When the lever clicks and moves to the right position you have reached the torque setting"}
{"source": "  Test, increase a notch if necessary, and repeat until you get the sound you want"}
{"source": " Set the resonant heads either one notch higher or lower to make sure the batter and resonant heads do not cancel each other (and to your desired sound), and you will have a perfectly tuned set"}
{"source": "I'll never go back to tuning by ear!  You'll be amazed by the results if you tune with this key, and don't forget to write down your optimum settings"}
{"source": "This is my second 4 way switch and it won't be the last"}
{"source": " The four way gives you an added combination of neck and bridge in series, which gives a fatter tone than position 2 and more output than positions 1,2,or 3"}
{"source": " I am very pleased with the &#34;new sound&#34; of my tele"}
{"source": " The wiring diagram is very easy to understand and the install is pretty easy if you have a soldering gun"}
{"source": " (don't forget to lay down some newspaper to protect your guitar finish from solder)"}
{"source": "This switch does work, but you should look before you leap"}
{"source": " The switch travel is greater than it is for a standard 3-way switch, and if you use the common Fender replacement control plate (or one that was only intended for a 3-way switch, it may not fit"}
{"source": " You could fairly easily alter the plate, but if you want the cleanest look possible you may want to investigate a new control plate"}
{"source": "Recently, I was building a Telecaster project"}
{"source": "  A friend recommended using the 4 way switch instead of the stock 3 way switch"}
{"source": "  This allows you to have the three positions normally found on a Telecaster,  bridge only,  bridge + neck in parallel, and neck only"}
{"source": "  It also adds the ability for you to add a setting with the bridge and neck pickups in series"}
{"source": "The result of this added position is that you get a higher volume output from the guitar than in the regular bridge + neck position and  a slightly higher top end output"}
{"source": "  This is clearly a case of &#34;your mileage may vary"}
{"source": "&#34;  I've been used to the traditional 3-position switch on my other Telecasters"}
{"source": "  I'm a bit indifferent to this mod"}
{"source": "  If I was building another guitar, I would probably use this switch again"}
{"source": "  It does what it is supposed to do and it is within a couple dollars of the 3-way"}
{"source": "  However, I would not change out a working 3-way switch for this"}
{"source": "  For me, the added benefit just isn't worth the effort"}

{"source": "The biggest question I ask about these cables, are they worth the premium charged above more normal cables? The key to me is the lower end 100 series Monster cables,Monster S100-I-12 Standard 100 1/4-Inch Instrument Cable (12 Feet)"}
{"source": " The answer is mixed, and depends on what you are looking for"}
{"source": "The cable ends are very heavy, they are metal and do unscrew"}
{"source": " In some ways this is probably good, they feel good in your hand plugging and unplugging"}
{"source": " The jacks are gold plated and look like they would last a lifetime"}
{"source": " On the other hand, the series 100 plugs are a molded plastic end, with a good bit of flex to them, and they are lighter weight"}
{"source": " So the choice is, heavy, shiny gold; or light weight, gray/black? For me, I like the heft of these cables"}
{"source": "Construction-wise these are likely lifetime cables"}
{"source": " Check out the pictures I've posted"}
{"source": " The metal housing screws into the jack"}
{"source": " There is an O-ring to seal the top portion of the threads"}
{"source": " Inside the wires are soldered solidly to the jack, and then the whole thing is cast in solid acrylic or plastic"}
{"source": " Unless you run over this end with a truck or pulled really really hard like tug of war, the wire is never separating from the jack"}
{"source": " I don't think the actual 1/4 inch jack is any sturdier than other jacks"}
{"source": "Sound is excellent"}
{"source": " They are clear clean cables"}
{"source": " Are they better than the 100's? Oh maybe a tiny bit"}
{"source": " Maybe a little clearer, cleaner sound"}
{"source": " But it isn't a huge difference"}
{"source": "Bottom line, for gigging, probably go with the 100's"}
{"source": " The jack ends will get stepped on at some point and they are cheap enough to replace"}
{"source": " For practice or in your house, these are probably the way to go"}
{"source": " They do look particularly good plugged into a Marshall half stack"}
{"source": "These cables are not outrageously over priced like everything else Monster Cable"}
{"source": " Study different one quarter inch jack cables and you'll see these are priced very close to everyone else"}
{"source": " This is not the case of the HDMI cables at the big box store for fifty times what you should pay for them"}
{"source": "These cables work very well at transmitting sound"}
{"source": " So why only three stars? Well, these are far from the most well thought out instrument cables you will find"}
{"source": " These are stiff, thick, and heavy"}
{"source": " While that's good for most analog cables, these cables are so stiff and heavy that, for instance, a portable tuner or a small stomp box might easily be moved around just by having one end of this cable in there"}
{"source": "With so many amps having plastic jacks these days, you have to wonder what kind of stress these cables might be putting your amp jacks and pickguard-mounted output jacks under if these cables can fling a tuner around just by being plugged into one"}
{"source": " I mean, let's face it"}
{"source": " You never know what will happen at a gig"}
{"source": " Sometimes you're playing with a 12 foot cable when you should have a 18 foot cable"}
{"source": " A cable shouldn't come out because of a gentle pull, but if it's between the cable falling out and it moving a bass head around or you tripping on it, you want the cable to fall out"}
{"source": " If everything you have is heavy or Velcro'd to the ground, this isn't a problem, but it is for me"}
{"source": " I feel like when you're playing with these cables, you're worried about stepping on the cable not because you want to pull it out, but because it's seriously like a trip wire out there"}
{"source": "Lastly, these plugs are huge"}
{"source": " That's not really a problem if you play a Strat or a Tele, but what about a P-Bass or a J-Bass where the plug comes out at a right angle from the body? This is going to stick out a lot, and to loop it around your strap, it's going to be a huge, stiff, cumbersome loop"}
{"source": " I know people often buy 90 degree plugs for those kinds of instruments, but most normal straight plugs do just fine"}
{"source": " So yeah, if you like to move around on stage, get more flexible cables"}
{"source": " You'll thank me"}
{"source": "These cables are just poorly thought out"}
{"source": " They'd work great as patch cords, or keyboards, drum machines, from pedal board to amp (as long as you have a metal jack)"}
{"source": " Monster has a cable that costs half as much but works twice as well for actual instrument use, and at that price, Pro Co cables are also excellent, and they have brand name plugs, as well"}
{"source": "These aren't my first set, I can't count the amount of Monster 1/4 cables I bought and own"}
{"source": " None has ever failed me so far"}
{"source": " Highly recommend these!"}

{"source": "I've used D'Addario strings for many, many years without problems - both acoustic & electric"}
{"source": "  I've tried these coated strings in the past, and I actually prefer them to Elixir because they feel more like regular strings - the wrap is coated, rather than a sheathe being placed over the entire string, like on Elixirs"}
{"source": "Do they last longer?  Probably"}
{"source": "  Even when I'm in situations where I'm gigging regularly I rarely change strings more than every few months, just because I don't see the need"}
{"source": "  I think the main benefit to coated strings is if you have guitars that you can't play regularly the strings won't corrode"}
{"source": "  But these sound great and feel fine, and the're the least expensive coated strings I've found"}
{"source": "  I've always found D'Addario quality to be great"}
{"source": "Good strings, though in 1 use I didnt notice any significant improvement over the standard Diaddario phosphor bronze strings"}
{"source": "I've been using these strings for about eight years, and I also use them on my two Taylor's (814-CE & I use the mediums on my 710) I agree with the other reviewer in saying they are the best sounding coated string out there"}
{"source": " I still use Martin strings once in awhile, but these strings last and improve in sound as they get a few hours of play on them"}
{"source": "Actually I own three other acoustics other than my two Taylor's and right now they're all strung with EXP's"}
{"source": " I know people want different sounds from their strings, but I find these to be bright with a great bottom on them, unlike the Elixirs which I find to be unbearably bright with a weak bottom end"}
{"source": " These strings sound great with great dynamics on them"}
{"source": " Even on my Laguna Grand Symphony (slightly larger than a Grand Concert) they pump out the lows and sparkle on the highs"}
{"source": " These on my Grand Auditorium do the same thing, they produce the sound I demand and make a real positive improvement over the other coated strings I've used"}
{"source": "The Mediums on my 710 have an endless bottom end and still have great range on the mid's and treble"}
{"source": "As I said I still use Martin Phosphor Bronze strings once in awhile, but honestly these strings hold up extremely well and sound great"}
{"source": " Darn near as near to an uncoated string that you're going to find"}
{"source": "I tried the EXPs on my Gibson L4 archtop because I play jazz single lines, small chord comping, and full chords more than I do on a Martin OM-1 and figured I'd get a better overall feel for tone and response"}
{"source": "For years I've played Martin Phosphor Bronze mediums on both guitars and that's my reference: The D'Addario EXP lights show their difference mostly on the bass end where they're a good 7 mm thinner"}
{"source": " The high E and B are 3 mm less and I can feel it but not enough to bother me"}
{"source": " All things being equal I prefer heavier strings for tone but I play instruments I don't trust with truly heavy gauges"}
{"source": "The first thing I noticed is considerably less \"new string clang\" compared to both the Martins and D'Addario's regular phosphur bronze strings which I've used in the past and still use for mandolin"}
{"source": "While still a long way from sounding broken-in, the EXP strings sound as though they've had several days of good use"}
{"source": " As a kid I perspired much more and would just rot strings like you wouldn't believe - on a humid summer day I could get rid of that clang in a hour"}
{"source": "The tension on the EXP's feels very comfortable and considerably more flexible than the 7 mm difference should account for"}
{"source": " I like to bend strings on acoustic in certain contexts, which can be tough with tight strings; the EXP's feel very easy - not electric guitar easy mind you, but fine for acoustic"}
{"source": "The other quality that's noticeable is sustain"}
{"source": " The strings I took off weren't completely dead and I wasn't expecting a dramatic difference, but it's noticable across the board, especially on small chord comping on three or four strings at a time"}
{"source": "The tone also feels a bit more balanced across all six strings, but this is admittedly very subjective: I play with differently shaped and thicknessed picks for different recording contexts; some generate more percussive pick noise than others; sometimes I want it, other times no"}
{"source": " The response of the EXPs sounds very consistent to my ears"}
{"source": "I've had them on for a couple of weeks now, playing fairly regularly"}
{"source": " Some of the initial clang is gone but the (desired) bright lively tone has not degraded noticeably"}
{"source": "I suppose the real test of the EXP coating is how they sound beyond the point where other strings begin to sound dead"}
{"source": " Maybe I'll update this review down the line, but for me, it's a false question because if the strings don't sound and feel good in the short term, who cares if they last forever!"}

{"source": " Ultimately, I preferred the Nanoweb Phosphor Bronze the best, but the EXP16 are cheaper and the difference didn't warrant the extra cost, so I decided to stick with these for now"}
{"source": "  I wasn't a fan of the Alchemys because of their rough texture and high tension"}

{"source": "Frankly, I'd never heard of a \"pop filter\" until my popping p's and b's came into consciousness at the same time that this device popped into my field of view on an Amazon web page"}
{"source": "  I'll bet that a couple of layers of women's nylon stockings would be just as effective, but this contraption pretty much purges your elocution of the offensive phonemes (they're called \"plosives\")"}
{"source": "  I'm still hearing the \"s\" phonemes (sibilants) along with some guttural artifacts (\"back\" vowels prefaced by an \"h\" that ignite a momentary gargling effect), but this filter doesn't purport to be able to do anything about those buggers"}
{"source": "As for the price, after seeing the gooseneck, the base, the generous-sized screws, etc"}

{"source": "I use my Shure SM7B mainly for podcasting and voice work and it performs extremely well in those applications"}
{"source": "  I also use aHeil PR-40 Dynamic Studio Recording Microphoneand you can check out that link for my review on that item"}
{"source": " Both microphones are dynamic microphones and both give my voice a very warm, natural feel"}
{"source": "One thing, well actually two things, the Shure SM7B has that the Heil PR40 does not is a set of two switches"}
{"source": "  One for bass rolloff and one for mid-range emphasis / presence boost"}
{"source": "  While both of these switches can be useful, I prefer to keep the mic flat and let any outboard processing / EQ handle adjustments that need to be done"}
{"source": "  If you don't have outboard processing, both of these could be helpful to you as the bass rolloff really does help keep low frequency noises (for example, someone bumping the table) to a minimum and the presence boost does help certain voice ranges cut through the mix a bit better"}
{"source": "When I reviewed the Heil PR-40 I said that it was the best bang for the buck out there and the Shure SM7B may be changing my mind a bit"}
{"source": "  While the PR40 is about $70"}
{"source": "00 cheaper than the SM7B here on Amazon at the time of this review considerations must be made to the fact that most PR-40 users will want to use a shockmount (about $100) and pop filter / windscreen ($15 - $60) to get the best results out of the microphone"}
{"source": "  With the SM7B the shockmount is built into the microphone and does a surprisingly good job and Shure includes two different foam windscreens (one for normal use and one for ultra-close up use) with the microphone"}
{"source": "  So the bottom line is the Shure SM7B with all the accessories is probably going to be less than the Heil"}
{"source": "Another thing worth mentioning is that like the Heil PR-40 the Shure SM7B is built like a tank"}
{"source": "  It is a heavy microphone and in my opinion just looks very cool whether it is mounted on a boom or on a desk stand"}
{"source": "  Both microphones perform about the same as far as rejecting any off-axis sounds and both are excellent microphones for voice and podcasting applications"}
{"source": "The SM7B takes a little more to drive it than the Heil PR-40, so you'll want to make sure that you have a decent mixer / pre-amp that can handle the microphone"}
{"source": "The bottom line is the Shure SM7B is a very high quality microphone and I would highly recommend it"}
{"source": "  If you're comparing it to the Heil PR-40 most likely the thing that will make the difference to you will be the aesthetic differences and the price because the performance of these two is very, very close"}
{"source": "You are looking at what I consider to be the best friend a voice ever had"}
{"source": "  During a 40 year broadcast and voiceover career I have used (or been forced to use) every other large diaphragm studio mic on the planet along with the Shure SM7B and it's predecessors the SM7 and SM5"}
{"source": "Large diaphragm dynamics have some notable advantages over condenser microphones for voiceover work and solo vocalists in multi-track studio work"}
{"source": "  I've used over the years the Sennheiser MD421, EV RE20, EV RE27N/D, Shure SM7B, Shure SM7, Shure SM5 and most recently tried a Heil PR-40"}
{"source": "  Sometimes this was not of my own selection, but I just used what was available"}
{"source": "  Of the lot the Shure SM7B is my favorite of the ones still available"}
{"source": "  The SM7B is a better shielded SM7 and the SM7B of today has a better shock mount than the old SM7 or earlier SM7B"}
{"source": "  The shielding in the B model minimizes RFI from computer monitors, florescent lighting, radio transmitter proximity, etc"}
{"source": "  The SM7 was a redesign of the SM5"}
{"source": "  I consider the SM5 to have been the very best vocal dynamic microphone ever created but it hasn't been in production in ages"}
{"source": "  I have used a few ribbon microphones that were also pretty good such as the RCA 77DX and RCA 44 but they were not as good as the SM5 or SM7 or SM7B"}
{"source": "Today's SM7B is the best non-condenser vocal microphone still in production"}
{"source": "  Stop looking and buy one"}
{"source": "  You will not find a better microphone for voice work whether singing or spoken word"}
{"source": "  It has a very controllable proximity effect, something that is missing from the EV's"}
{"source": "  I can play a SM7B like a violin, the others I just don't seem to have nearly as much proximity effect to toy with for dramatic impact"}
{"source": "Everything that is good about condensers for voice work is in an SM7B while everything that is bad about condensers for voice work isn't"}
{"source": "DJ's change jobs a lot and I got tired of finding the EV RE20 & RE27N/D mics or the Sennheiser everywhere I went, so I bought my own SM7B"}
{"source": "  I never liked the EV's or Sennheiser much and didn't ever feel like they were much of a tool"}
{"source": "  The Heil PR-40 is pretty good but doesn't have any on-board EQ options"}
{"source": "  For recording not having the EQ is probably no big deal as you can tweak it in post production but for live radio you can't do much of that"}
{"source": "The SM7B is a tool for skilled vocal talent, so if you are trying to make a novice sound good you might do better with an RE27N/D but for someone who actually knows how to really work a microphone over then the SM7B is only dynamic large diaphragm mic I know of that can deliver everything a real voice artist has to give"}
{"source": "  The reason is that this microphone is designed for one thing, voice work"}
{"source": "  The others are more versatile, but the SM7B is \"THE VOICE\" microphone and that was all it was intended to be"}
{"source": " It has however found secondary duty as a bass cab microphone and it is pretty good at recording some very loud and boomy sound effects, but it is primarily a vocal microphone"}
{"source": "Of all the instruments that have ever been recorded or broadcast, the human voice is the most complex and difficult to capture reliably"}
{"source": "  That is one reason vocals sound good on a $4,000 tube condenser microphone, since it can capture all the complexity, inflection and multi-frequency overtones of the human voice"}
{"source": "  Unfortunately even these very best condensers also pick up lots of things you didn't intend and also have at least a trace of self generated noise"}
{"source": "  If you are doing a dry voiceover you can't hide the hiss of a condenser under something else"}
{"source": "  With the SM7B you don't have to"}
{"source": "Even for singing this microphone is sort of a secret weapon that kids calling themselves \"Recording Engineers\" today are usually totally ignorant about"}
{"source": "  They figure anything short of a multi-thousand dollar tube condenser microphone is inferior for studio vocals and this microphone proves them wrong"}
{"source": "If you want a good all around microphone, this is NOT it"}
{"source": "  If you want the best dynamic vocal microphone, here it is"}
{"source": "  As others have mentioned the output needs a decent preamp but works with all the pro studio gear I've ever connected to it"}
{"source": "  I think if you have some cheap USB interface then you will want to put another preamp in front of it and that will make it far more usable for recording whispers"}
{"source": "  Most real studio preamps are a good match for it"}
{"source": " I've plugged it into some real junky mixers and had it work too"}
{"source": "  You need at least 60 dB of gain, the spec sheet actually says 59"}
{"source": "  70 dB would be better"}
{"source": " Lots is made of the \"LOW OUTPUT\" of -59 dB but it isn't all that much less than the Shure SM58 which is -54"}
{"source": "5 dB! -4"}
{"source": "5 dB isn't much at all for any decent mic preamp"}
{"source": "  But again most of the \"one-box-solution\" USB interfaces with built-in mic preamps is probably going to need some help as they were designed with the hotter output of a condenser in mind"}
{"source": "The Shure SM7B comes with the built in shock mount in the stand mounting and yoke attachments"}
{"source": "  Every other large diaphragm dynamic has a shock mount made for it but it costs extra"}
{"source": "  They all need an external windscreen but only the SM7B comes with one! I got mine 10 years ago when it still came with two windscreens"}
{"source": "  It has a nice metal case for storage/travel"}
{"source": "  I think now they just come with one windscreen which is the bigger one Shure calls the A7WS but still come in the metal case"}
{"source": "  I use the smaller windscreen mostly and Shure calls them the RK345 and their distributors still carry them"}
{"source": " The smaller windscreen makes the microphone more open and airy for me and I'd suggest getting one of the RK345's, but that is the only accessory you'll need to add"}
{"source": "  The windscreens are held on by some little Velcro tabs but easily interchanged"}
{"source": "  They are also very durable for foam screens"}
{"source": "On the back end of the tube is a round plate you remove with a hex key and under the plate are multiple EQ adjustments for Flat/Bass Rolloff/Presence Boost settings that you can fiddle with to get the sound you like best"}
{"source": " You can just leave the plate off if you want"}
{"source": " This is easily the most EQ flexibility of any large diaphragm dynamic"}
{"source": "So I'm just adding my two cents worth here and joining the others who pretty much all agree this thing rules for voice work"}
{"source": "  I should have written this review earlier but wanted to try the new Heil PR-40 first to make sure I was still an SM7B guy and it took a while for the Heil tryout to happen since I didn't want to actually buy one"}
{"source": "  I still am an SM7B guy"}
{"source": "  I would give it 4"}
{"source": "5 stars but it won't let me do that, since there is nothing better right now in the class I rounded it up to 5 stars, but the SM5 was actually a bit closer to a 5 star vocal mic"}
{"source": "So I am a big fan of the SM57 Microphone as a vocal mic due to its ease of recording and good sound quality"}
{"source": "I have a bunch of the Large Style Condenser Microphones (Rode NT1-A, AT2020, SP C-1) and they are clear, but so sensitive that it's difficult to get a solid performance and mix without them either clipping or picking up everything in the room"}
{"source": " So if you're like me andlike to let go a bit when you sing, you should try a Dynamic Mic for the wide range and forgiveness they can giveyou when you belt a little"}
{"source": "I did an A / B test against the SM7B I just bought and the SM57 (I love) for vocals - with the exact same processing chain, cable, settings, etc"}
{"source": " and just switched the mics out"}
{"source": " I sung the same passage as well, and I have to say - the SM57 sounds muddy in comparison to the SM7B"}
{"source": " If I didn't have this new microphone I would still like the SM57, but the Genni is out of the bottle now"}
{"source": " so not going back"}
{"source": " The SM7B is clear and sounds sweet in comparison and still handles the vocal sound dynamics very well"}
{"source": "DYNAMIC SINGERS ( Rock, Jazz, GOSPEL, OPERA )= If you have the budget get this SM7B and if you don't, buy the SM57 until you do have the budget"}
{"source": "QUIET SINGERS (ACOUSTIC , FOLK ) = If you sing softly all of the time you really don't need one of these dynamic mics, and would be better off with the standard Large Condenser mics as listed above"}
{"source": " Of those type, I like the Studio Projects C-1 Best I think, but they are close"}
{"source": "I can't do more than underscore the endorsement of this mic by the previous reviewer (FOX)"}
{"source": "  If you haven't started in the mic-collecting business, trying every trendy dynamic and condenser mic in the hundred dollar range and below, you might actually save some bucks by cutting directly to the chase and going for this one"}
{"source": "  I've always wondered why I can't reproduce the sounds of our local NPR outlet, and I finally realize it's because they have the Shure SM7B and I don't"}
{"source": "It enhances the voice with depth and richness and filters out the pops and unwanted percussives (face it, those separate pop filters are cumbersome to use)"}
{"source": "  It's very directional and \"selective\" (rejecting room ambience and background noise), so it's perhaps not the ideal mic for all applications"}
{"source": "  But for announcing, broadcasting, vocal performance and vocal recording, I don't see how anything could possibly equal let alone surpass it"}
{"source": "What you need to know about this mic:1) This mic is very directional"}
{"source": " You must keep your mouth in the sweet spot at all times for best results"}
{"source": " Pulling back an inch gets into tinny muddy territory, and an inch too close makes for a strong proximity effect"}
{"source": " I found that a palm's width from the tip of the mic works best"}
{"source": " As long as I keep my mouth there, the results are predictable and good regardless of the room I'm in"}
{"source": " Also if the mic is aimed too low on your face (like at the lower lip or chin) you'll sound like you have a stuffy nose"}
{"source": " Aimed too high (like at the bridge of the nose) sounds sneering and nasal"}
{"source": " Right at the upper lip works well for me"}
{"source": "2) The bass cut and presence boost are convenient"}
{"source": " Use a plastic thing like a guitar pick to switch them, as metal will scratch it"}
{"source": " I've played around with the switches and in the end both set to flat was best"}
{"source": " Initially I thought the presence boost was a good idea, but in a mix it made my vocals too honky in the upper mids"}
{"source": " Flat's where it's at"}
{"source": " Flat sounds most natural"}
{"source": "3) Being a dynamic, it won't sound as open and airy as a condenser might"}
{"source": " Though it takes EQ well, and you can EQ that in"}
{"source": " If you remove the foam and use a pop filter, you do get more highs, but after working with that for a while I realized it doesn't always sound right, seems to unbalance the highs above 5k toward sibilance a little too much, but it might work for you"}
{"source": " After using it for a few years, I learned that starting with a bad mix that is too bright or blaring and then adding in the SM7B on vocals causes the mic to appear dull and muffled, but really it's the mix that's the problem"}
{"source": " Whereas if I start with the vocal sound and make it clear and natural, and build the mix around it, the mix turns out to have a natural sound that's not too bright or dull either"}
{"source": "4) Yes, it rejects room sounds more than a condenser, but not gobsmacked amazingly so"}
{"source": " It rejects what's behind and to the side, but in front it's pretty sensitive"}
{"source": " So if you're singing with an echoey room behind you, it will pick that up"}
{"source": " So don't think this will make you sound like you're in a dead control room, unless you actually are in one"}
{"source": " Hang some blankets or acoustic foam behind you and you're set"}
{"source": " Being that it records about twice as dry as a condenser, it takes reverb pretty well in a mix, meaning you can add reverb and delay without having your vocals drop too far away and undefined in the mix"}
{"source": "5) So what does it sound like? The sound is *very* natural and true to my voice"}
{"source": " It truly is a vocal mic first and foremost"}
{"source": " That plus the dry/up-close characteristic are this mic's top selling points"}
{"source": " It works fantastically on death metal growls and clean singing atop sparse/acoustic/clean backgrounds"}
{"source": " It does have slight color in the mids; I agree with the frequency response chart indicating it has a slight scoop 400-900Hz, slight boost 1000-2000Hz, but it's still natural sounding despite that"}
{"source": " The color is tailored to the voice: reduce the honky boxy mids, accentuate the main vocal intelligibility range"}
{"source": " That's one reason why this mic is considered \"flattering\" on vocals"}
{"source": " It still has body though, definitely not a thin sounding mic"}
{"source": "6) This thing is heavy and rugged"}
{"source": " The capsule is surrounded by this truncated cone-like metal screen enclosed on all sides"}
{"source": " The screen is like the kind you see behind microwave oven doors"}
{"source": " What I like about this mic is that I can throw it inside a bubble mailer or wrap it in a scarf for storage and not have to worry about crushing or damaging it, and it doesn't need a big case like some condensers and especially tube mics do"}
{"source": " So it's actually compact in practice and quick to set up with one of those detachable mic adapter mounts"}
{"source": " Even without the adapter, it has a convenient free rotating collar to screw it onto a mount/stand so that you can hold the mic in place while screwing it down"}
{"source": "7) This mic needs 50 dB gain for loud singing, 55-60dB for quiet singing, 65-70dB for whispering"}
{"source": " Make sure your preamp is designed for at least 60dB of clean gain"}
{"source": " Some cheaper USB interfaces only go up to 35dB"}
{"source": " If your interface lacks the juice, no worries, get yourself a CloudLifter and it'll add 25dB of nice clean gain and it's phantom powered too"}
{"source": "Overall, I would prefer a condenser in a good room since it allows me to move a little more without coloring the sound, and because it has a more openness and air compared to this one"}
{"source": " But since my room isn't perfect, this will do"}
{"source": " The biggest pros are that it's natural sounding and that even with reverb and delay it stands out in a mix"}
{"source": " It's especially good on spoken voice, as it was designed for, since unlike a condenser the SM7B does a very good job of not picking up as many mouth clicks, mouth noises, and background hissing"}
{"source": "In the end, if I had to get rid of all my mics and keep only one for vocals for the rest of my life, it would be the SM7B"}
{"source": " Mainly because I know I can conveniently use it anywhere, anytime, and get reliable good results"}
{"source": "EDIT 2014:  Forgot to say, when you listen to mic shoot-outs on the net, often times the tip of the SM7B will be positioned the same distance as the condenser"}
{"source": " This is a problem because the SM7B's diaphragm is actually back a few inches"}
{"source": " So the condensers will be closer to the talent (or lack of talent) than the SM7B in such cases, causing the latter to sound more duck-ish, honky, un-detailed, or thin due solely to distance factors, and is thus not characteristic of the intrinsic mic color"}
{"source": " In shoot-outs where the proper distance was used, you'd be surprised how much the SM7B sounds like a good condenser"}
{"source": " It really does"}
{"source": " Of course it may be missing air (or conversely, be less prone to sibilance) but as I said below you can *easily* EQ that in, since this mic takes EQ very well"}
{"source": " Seriously, a 2dB shelf in the highs"}
{"source": " Another thing I wanted to add, is that the gentle bump in the 1k to 2k region (for vocal definition) that his mic has, can sound slightly honky or strident or blaring depending on some sources, but again you can EQ that down a bit"}
{"source": " And finally, when Shure says this mic has a flat response, that's not true, it has color and the frequency response charts show it"}
{"source": " Yet, the color gives it a larger than life natural sound on voice, so it sounds natural even though it's not completely transparent and honest"}
{"source": "I bought this compression pedal to give my leads a little extra oomph and it does just that"}
{"source": " When playing hammer-ons and pull-offs, sometimes it can be difficult to get them to sound as loud as the rest of your picking, but not when using this pedal"}
{"source": " It amplifies your quieter sounds and levels off the louder ones to give a smoothe sound"}

{"source": "First of all, I use this as more of a 6 band EQ using the lower and highest more for LP and HP filters"}
{"source": "  The middle four have the most dramatic effect on the tone"}
{"source": "  You can also use this as boost box, using the gain and volume sliders"}
{"source": "  The box is solid and fairly easy to manipulate on stage, but I tend to set and forget"}
{"source": "In reviewing other posts maybe these bullets may be helpful"}
{"source": "-If you turn your gain way up, you will have hiss"}
{"source": "  Period, this holds true for any effect box or amp that has a gain on it that I have been exposed to"}
{"source": "  Have a reason for upping your gain, if it is to add volume consider doing this on your guitar or amp"}
{"source": "-EQ is to ENHANCE your tone, not create it!  A Strat cannot be made to sound like a Les Paul and vice versa"}
{"source": "  Your tone is made up of many, many variables"}
{"source": "  The resulting tone can be SHAPED or COLORED by adding or subtracting certain frequencies"}
{"source": "  That is the function of an EQ, nothing more"}
{"source": "  IT can range from dramatic to very subtle"}
{"source": "  Very small changes can have large effects"}
{"source": "  Small bumps in the higher range really enhance the harmonics I am able to produce"}
{"source": "-I tend to put the EQ in much later in my effect chain, but feel free to experiment"}

{"source": "  This thing gives you plenty of room to get the stand out of the way without making an annoyance of itself"}
{"source": "  The other thing I like is that the elbow where it adjusts has teeth that interlock, so you're not just tightening a joint and relying on friction - as those are the kind of things that eventually fail once the tightening bolt gets tired"}
{"source": "Anyway - no reservations about this one"}
{"source": "  A dead-simple idea that works great"}
{"source": "One thing I love about this extension bar is it will fit over the relatively large diameter down tubes on my hi-hat stands"}
{"source": " I use anOn Stage Microphone 13-inch Gooseneckto connect to the bar, then I attach either aNady DM70 Drum and Instrument Microphoneor DM80 microphone"}

{"source": "We live in an age of endless boutique guitar effect pedals"}
{"source": "  One could make a very expensive hobby of collecting only high dollar dirt pedals"}
{"source": "  It's not unusual to see an online review and think a pedal sounds good then find out that it costs $150, $200, $250, $350"}
{"source": "whatever"}
{"source": "  There are a LOT of really expensive distortion/OD pedals out there"}
{"source": "I've had my Bad Monkey for about 7 years, after hearing good things I took a chance and gigged with it for many years"}
{"source": "  I rarely use a lot of gain on most pedals, just because those fuzzier tones can easily get lost in the mix"}
{"source": "  I generally use the Bad Monkey for mid-gain crunch tones, and for that it's just fantastic"}
{"source": "Having two tone controls makes all the difference"}
{"source": "  This pedal is Tubescreamer-esque, but not as midrange-heavy as a TS"}
{"source": "  Anyway, this thing sounds great"}
{"source": "  Excellent classic rock and lead tones"}
{"source": "The things it WON'T do: 1) a clean boost"}
{"source": "  It has plenty of output, but there's always a little bit of dirt in the signal, so it can't be used as a pure clean boost"}
{"source": "  2)  it won't clean up when you turn your guitar down"}
{"source": "or at least not much"}
{"source": "  No dialing in a crunch tone then turning down your guitar volume for a clean rhythm tone"}
{"source": "  I have a Barber LTD which does that beautifully"}
{"source": "But, despite those limitations, the Bad Monkey is awesome"}
{"source": "  At the very least it can be a great \"throw in your case to take to a jam\" pedal, but it's worth having on your pedalboard, as well"}
{"source": "I've had this pedal for about five years"}
{"source": "  I own a bunch of other overdrive pedals, including the Boss SD-1, TS-9, a Klon clone, and a bunch of DIY pedals"}
{"source": "  The Bad Monkey is cool for a couple of reasons"}
{"source": "  First is the bass and treble controls"}
{"source": "  Most overdrive pedals only have one tone control, the Bad Monkey lets you sculpt both the highs and lows"}
{"source": "  Second is the mixer out"}
{"source": "  Not everyone will appreciate this feature but it allows you to jack the pedal into a mixer or audio interface with a \"speaker sim\""}
{"source": "The gain sound is ok, but what I do is use it as a boost by diming the output and turning the gain all the way down which slams my tube amp giving me a natural tube overdrive"}
{"source": "  This pedal will work best with a tube amp but some people may dig the gain tone on a solid state"}
{"source": "It's built like a tank"}
{"source": "  Can't go wrong for the price, IMO"}
{"source": "This is purely an overdrive pedal, not a distortion pedal"}
{"source": "  It increases the gain and dirties your tone, but it does not actually distort your sound"}
{"source": "If you're a metal or hard rock player, don't buy this"}
{"source": "  It's better suited for country, soul, R&B;, blues, or even jazz players who want to boost their volume and umph when they're doing a solo"}
{"source": "  For that it's excellent, especially considering its very low price"}
{"source": "And despite its very low price, it's very solidly built"}
{"source": "  It's like a brick"}
{"source": "This update is to point out that I've only used the Bad Monkey pedal with tube amps: A Fender Blues DeVille 4x10 and a Line 6 Spider Valve HD100 MK II running into an Ampeg 4x12"}
{"source": "  I have no idea how it'll sound with a solid state amp"}
{"source": "  But it sounds great with a tube amp"}
{"source": "This update is to point out that I finally tried it with a solid state amp and it sounds pretty darn good"}

{"source": "  Makes my crappy Behringer amp sound"}
{"source": " almost good"}
{"source": "If you listen or read what many pro guitarists and techies have to say about DigiTech effects pedals, they'll tell you to stay away from them"}
{"source": "except for this one"}
{"source": "  That's because the DigiTech Bad Monkey Tube Overdrive is an incredible value that could go head to head with any pedal made by BOSS or the $100 TS-9 Tubescreamer"}
{"source": "In fact the TS-9 Tubescreamer is the pedal the Bad Monkey is best compared to"}
{"source": "  This is not meant to be a heavy distortion pedal with endless game - it simulates and overloaded tube amp that adds crunch and a little gain to an otherwise clean tone"}
{"source": "  Notes will sing and chords will really crunch, especially in blues and classic rock"}
{"source": "  But since the pedal works well as a level/gain boost, I've heard of guitarists turning on the Bad Monkey in conjunction with other distortion effects, to really push them to new levels"}
{"source": "But the best feature of the Bad Monkey by far is the two-band EQ"}
{"source": "  Virtually any distortion pedal has a \"Tone\" control that will make the tone darker or brighter"}
{"source": "  But since one band EQ basically takes away bass to add treble (or vice versa), you may not find the sound you want"}
{"source": "  That's what's so great about the Bad Monkey - if you feel like your tone is too weak, you can fatten it up"}
{"source": "  If it's too muddy, you can add treble"}
{"source": "  And you can make those changes without compromising the parts of the tone that you like"}
{"source": "Construction is extremely durable - die cast metal, and probably heavier than a BOSS pedal"}
{"source": "  The switch is more similar to a BOSS than an Ibanez pedal, but I find that easier to use"}
{"source": "If you're a beginning player or a player on a budget, this would be an outstanding pedal to own, along with a more traditional high gain distortion pedal"}
{"source": "  There's really no need to spend the extra money on a Tubescreamer, if that will prevent you from buying something else you need for your gear"}
{"source": "  But even for player where money is not an object, don't overlook the Bad Monkey"}
{"source": "  It might just be the only tube overdrive pedal you'll need"}
{"source": "This pedal is beyond loud"}
{"source": " It's to the point where if you crank this pedal with a 15 watt amp with an 8&#34; speaker, you will get noise complaints from the end of your neighborhood"}
{"source": " To match it up with the clean tone that I get out of my amp, I have to set the level in between 1 and 2"}
{"source": "The BAD MONKEY overdrive pedal does not produce \"Crazy Train\" metal distortion"}
{"source": " It isn't made to, and thus if you buy it for that sound you're off target"}
{"source": " (If that's the sound you want, I recommend: DigiTech TL-2 HardWire Metal Distortion Extreme-Performance Pedal"}
{"source": ") What the BAD MONKEY produces is delicious, bluesy overdrive at a highly competitive price (it currently sells for $49"}
{"source": "95 here at Amazon)"}
{"source": " Unlike so many overdrive/distortion pedals, the BAD MONKEY has independent (and sensitive) dials for treble (\"high\") and bass (\"low\"), and using them can greatly affect the resulting sound; they are by no means token dials"}
{"source": " In particular, the bass dial can be used to increase bass to an amazing degree (especially when using double-coil pickups); it's easy to achieve a \"fat\" sound with this pedal"}
