{"source": "I am a professional musician, keyboard player, and keyboard collector (mostly vintage poly analog, but also a ton of mono phonics, modulars, and built your own kit units (shrugging, ambik-) etc - not that that has a lot to do with a pedal, however, I do live the life of a person surrounded by keyboard instruments that I use to make my living"}
{"source": "  have purchased every brand and style of pedal (for the purpose of this, we'll stick with sustain"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": "Compared to other units, it is heavier than most and I find the point where sustain engages to be just about right comparing electronic to acoustic"}
{"source": "  It is just an on/off switch, so no half modeling here,The only reason I gave this unit 4 stars instead of 5 is because Yamaha decided not to include a polarity switch and alienate perhaps 20% of the market who will get home and , if they hadn't thought to check, may be stuck wi a pedal that sustains when not being used and stops sustaining when pressed"}
{"source": "  A backward sustain pedal is not fun"}
{"source": "  Many manufacturers include a simple polarity reverse  switch that would eliminate that potential headache"}
{"source": "These days, most keyboards have the option to switch polarity internally either thru a global bemusement or by sensing whether the pedal is engaged at startup and adjusting accordingly (never press the sustain pedal while turning your keyboard on, you may very well cause an issue you don't expect and are confused by - turning on and off again without the pedal depressed will clear everything up in those cases"}
{"source": ")So - build quality, excellent"}
{"source": "  Durability - excellent (I've had a bunch of cheaper pedals - used on stage - break  at the switch point or at the jack), this Yamaha endures"}
{"source": "  Design - some older pedals used to have a flip out rubber footrest that was supposed to make the pedal more secure- I don't see that much anymore, but, so long as you aren't on glossy hardwood, this will stay I place with no issue"}
{"source": "I've read a few reviews that give this pedal a bad rating because of what appears to be a change in a global setting on a keyboard, or something similar,  All a sustain pedal consist of is a momentary contact switch, engaged when contact is made by depressing and completing the circuit, and disengaged when the pedal is released"}
{"source": "  There are no electronics - so - if it doesn't work, there are three points to look at 1) unscrew the jack and be sure that the wires coming from the pedal are all  connected to the metal posts inside the housing"}
{"source": " There are usually two wires of differing color"}
{"source": "  if one is disconnected, the pedal will cease to function (and, in rare instances, cause the keyboard to sustain all notes indefinitely"}
{"source": "  This is easily corrected with a soldering iron and a bit if solder - jacks are points of strain so it isn't inconceivable that a wire could come disconnected"}
{"source": " 2) The switch itself it either out if adjustment or is damaged"}
{"source": "  The switches in the Yamaha pedals are of good quality and unless you received a faulty part, would be unlikely to wear out with normal use"}
{"source": " I have, however, needed to take the pedal apart and made an adjustment"}
{"source": "  this was easy and a quick fix, even with limited tools"}
{"source": "  The third option is 3) the keyboard has had a change in a global setting causing the pedal t operate in reverse"}
{"source": "  This can be corrected by consulting your owners manual and reading whether your keyboard has a software polarity &#34;switch&#34;, if it senses on startup, or if you pedal simply stopped working altogether - doing nothing At all - it is #1 or 2 or a problem with the jack on the keyboard (HIGHLY unlikely,,but I've seen it happen"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": " Hopefully this helps some who have posted questions"}

{"source": "This is nearly identical to theGuardian Cases CG-020-B Bass Guitar Caseat about half the cost"}
{"source": " However, there are some issues with this case as well as limitations"}
{"source": "First the issues: while the covering appears to be stitched on, it is - for the most part - glued on, and if the case is left in a hot, unventilated space like a car for prolonged periods the covering will start to life at the edges"}
{"source": " On the other hand, someone who takes care of their gear is probably not going to leave their instrument in a hot car (or garage or other storage space) for prolonged periods"}
{"source": " However, you should be aware of the issue, if for no other reason than to remind you that if they case suffers, imagine the effect on your bass"}
{"source": "The limitations are simple: the case, while a hard shell design, is not as strong as one made from ABS plastic"}
{"source": " The top is relatively flimsy as are the sides"}
{"source": " This is not a show stopper if you use the case for home storage and occasional gigs, but if you have a heavy road schedule, and especially of you are not personally loading and unloading the band's gear, this case will not afford you the protection of an ATA-style case"}

{"source": "This is an ingenious clutch that engages when you step on your hi-hat pedal, but will drop to the closed position when you hit the lever on the top"}
{"source": " This allows you to either ride closed hi-hats when using both bass pedals, yet return to normal hi-hat playing when the music calls for it"}
{"source": "Be aware that this clutch has only two positions - open and fully closed"}
{"source": " However, there is a way to work around this if you like partially open hi-hats in the closed position for a sizzle sound"}
{"source": "  I did a work around by placing a spring on the hi-hat stem, with metal and felt washers on the top of the spring, which gives me that opening when I drop the cymbal to closed"}
{"source": "  There was a lot of trial and error finding the right spring because each cymbal pair has a different height when mated together, and I was looking for a tiny fraction of an inch opening"}
{"source": "  Too small or low a tension a spring and stickwork chokes the sound"}
{"source": " Too large or stiff and you will not get the sound"}
{"source": "  However, this is all personal preference, and many drummers ride a fully closed hi-hat anyway, which makes this clutch perfect out of the box"}
{"source": "Regardless of your hi-hat style, if you are using a double bass, this is a \"must have\" accessory"}
{"source": " Gibraltar's model is solid, heavy duty, and engages and disengages perfectly every time"}

{"source": "  You can buy with confidence"}
{"source": "I left my trusty Manhasset behind on a job and was about to replace it when I came upon this alternative offered by Amazon"}
{"source": "  As banged up as a Manhasset can get from week-end warriors like me who simply throw it on top of everything else in the backseat before the long ride home, I've never had one fail on me over the past 40+ years"}
{"source": "  There's nothing on the stand that the user can even adjust, yet all of the moving parts always seem to retain just the right amount of tension, preventing 5-10 pound folders from lowering the top half or causing it to dip forward"}
{"source": "  But the \"rub\" is their non-adaptability"}
{"source": "  The feet on the base are permanently attached as is the upper tray holding the music"}
{"source": "  Consequently, these ubiquitous, well-proven stands can sometimes be a challenge to pack in a crowded van or sedan, especially with a couple of keyboards, amps, instrument stands, and other requisite gear on board"}
{"source": "This is where Amazon's On-Stage Music Stand becomes attractive (of course, it doesn't hurt that it costs less than a Manhasset)"}
{"source": "  It permits you to fold up the legs to a position parallel with the shaft as well as to completely remove the upper shelf that holds the music"}
{"source": "  Consequently, it's much easier to find a convenient place--whether in the trunk or on the floor of the back seat--for packing the stand"}
{"source": "  Simply \"slide\" it into position"}
{"source": "The drawback--apart from durability issues that some reviewers have warned about (be careful not to over-tighten those set-screws!)--is that this thing is heavy"}
{"source": "  Frankly, I was expecting a lightweight stand, at least compared to my old Manhasset, but if you've owned or been around the latter, the first thing you're likely to notice with the stand pictured here is a palpable, substantial addition in weight"}
{"source": " At the same time, with the moving parts and the set screws (topped by plastic, rotating, serrated wheels), the On-Stage stand doesn't give me the same amount of confidence in its durability as did the Manhasset--in other words, I'm very less likely to become careless with it and simply toss it on top of the gear-pile after a long, exhausting 4-hour gig"}
{"source": "Bottom line: the On-Stage appears to be a good value--a truly heavy-duty stand (in most respects) that'll do extremely well as a practice stand in a studio or living room and that packs up conveniently for traveling jobs"}
{"source": "  But don't expect it to lighten your load or, simply because it's heavier, to last longer than a Manhasset"}
{"source": "If you do a lot of traveling and don't plan to put one of those 1000-page piano folders on the stand, there's at least one truly lightweight (albeit plastic) stand that's worked out really well for me (perhaps needless to say, some haven't--they fall apart or they're so ingeniously designed that it takes 15 minutes simply to disassemble them and put them back in their unforgiving, pint-sized cases)"}

{"source": "D'Addario Strings are not my usual strings, I have always used GHS and Ernie Ball Strings"}

{"source": "After tons of experimenting, I settled on the EXL116 for D standard and E flat standard"}
{"source": " I've tried 10-52 but the top is a little too floppy for D and that makes notes sound out of tune if you don't press the string just right"}
{"source": " Also tried 11-56 and while that gives a real solid and full rhythm tone, the attack is too rounded due to the pick taking longer to travel over a wider string"}
{"source": " That reduces articulation"}
{"source": " So while you get a fuller sound with the 56, you get more dynamics and attack with the 52, and the latter makes metal rhythms sound heavier"}
{"source": " You can EQ fullness into a rhythm track, but you can't add in pick attack and greater dynamics"}
{"source": "Tension wise, at D standard 11-56 is ideal but 11-52 is doable"}
{"source": " Sound wise, 11-52 has been best for my metal recordings and that's why I'm sticking with the EXL116 set from now on"}
{"source": " I also replaced the G string with a 20 gauge wound for better sounding power chords"}
{"source": " And compared to Ernie Balls, D'addarios start off less bright but maintain their brightness longer, thus a more even and predictable response over time"}

{"source": " BOTTOM LINE: IF YOU WANT A PHASER THAT DOESN'T ADD SIGNIFICANT DISTORTION, AVOID THIS INCARNATION OF THE PHASE 90"}
{"source": "The MXR Phase 90 is a classic stompbox popularized by Eddie Van Halen"}
{"source": " At present, I own an MXR Phase 90, a Boss PH-3 Phase Shifter, and a Line 6 MM4 Modulations Modeler (with a few phaser patches), so I can compare these three units"}
{"source": "The Phase 90 has a single \"Speed\" control that sets the rate of the phase, so it is simple to use"}
{"source": " If there is a single knob, that is a good indicator that the manufacturer feels pretty good about the sound of the unit"}
{"source": " In this case, I agree"}
{"source": "The MXR Phase 90 is by far the cheapest of these three units"}
{"source": " In my opinion, it also gives the best sound within its capabilities, and actually seems to boost the volume slightly"}
{"source": " The Boss PH-3 gets a slight volume drop but it is workable, and the Line 6 MM4 has a volume drop that for me is hard to use on a guitar pedalboard because I usually don't leave modulations on for an entire song, but turn them on/off in different sections (unless its a chorus)"}
{"source": "Of the three, the Phase 90 has the least versatility"}
{"source": " You can imitate the Phase 90 sound on both of the other units (the Line 6 MM4 does a slightly better job) and both the PH-3 and MM4 have more sonic possibilities"}
{"source": " Also, the Boss PH-3 will give a lot more spacey extremes than the Phase 90 which stays in a \"normal\" range"}
{"source": " But again, of the three the MXR Phase 90 sounds the best of the three at what it can do"}
{"source": "Bottom Line:(1) A classic pedal at a great price(2) Great sound & slight volume boost(3) Simple to use(4) Limited sonic possibility, \"safe\" or \"normal\" guitar sounds (no crazy extremes)(5) Beautiful bright orange color, you can't miss it(6) Compact size does not eat up pedalboard space"}

{"source": " The nut should be replaced with one that spaces the strings across the fingerboard just a little more"}
{"source": " The action may be lowered by shaving the bridge saddle very carefully, and just a little at a time"}
{"source": " This work will cost as much as the guitar cost if you take it to a luthier, but if you can do it yourself, will improve the playability of the instrument"}

{"source": " You place the cloth next to a string, then hook your little finger under and pull up so the cloth surrounds the lower surfaces, sides and top of the string, then pressing it in around the string slide up and down the full length a couple of times, then repeat on the remaining strings"}

{"source": "My guitar has an Ebony hard lacquer finish, meaning very glossy and shiny"}
{"source": " I have been playing thisguitar for about a year now and it had a lot finger smudges on the body's front and back and BACKof the neck"}
{"source": " I was able to get most of the minor finger smudges off"}
{"source": " When going after the moreresistant multiple smudges the polish cloth would spread it around and left most of the problem onthe finish"}
{"source": "What I discovered about this cloth, even with increased elbow grease, is that it has it's limitations"}
{"source": "So, if your guitar is reasonably clean and the smudges are fairly new this cloth is dynamite and takesthem right out"}
{"source": " If the body oils have been there for awhile, probably collecting dust, then you willneed some type of cleaning liquid to help you break up the old fuzzy oils on your instrument"}
{"source": " Pleaseuse any liquid sparingly when applying it to the surface of your instrument"}
{"source": " Do not put a liquid directlyonto the surface of your instrument"}
{"source": " You should put the cleaning liquid onto the cleaning cloth firstthen apply it"}

{"source": " It doesnot leave scratches or any marks when used without a liquid"}

{"source": "First of all, let me say, from some of the pictures I have seen posted of this Pop Filter, when put on a Yeti mic stand, the clamp will fit on the stand as pictured"}
{"source": " This is a design flaw, not with the Pop Filter, but with the Yeti stand, as this filter has been around long before the Yeti came out"}
{"source": " Blue, or a clever do it yourself person, could easily fix it, by drilling more holes into the side of the clamp mount"}
{"source": " Then you could move it forward and simply screw the side mic mount screws into the stand"}
{"source": " There are many great pictures of other clever fixes, as well"}
{"source": "  Since I have mine hanging upside down, on a boom stand attached to a Blue Radius Shock mount, this is not an issue for me, but I will say it is a problem Blue should fix"}
{"source": " (I have written an addendum on the bottom, for a great fix"}
{"source": ") Other brands of filters will give the same, if not more problems"}
{"source": " I am not going to knock any stars off, because I'm reviewing the filter itself, which is superb and how it works for me"}
{"source": "Now for the meat"}
{"source": " This is a studio grade, high quality product, all metal, except for the two tightening knobs"}
{"source": " The dual screen design eliminates any plosives, P's and B's for example, better than any screen I have used so far"}
{"source": " This is especially true when, the screen distance is about an inch from the Yeti capsule screen, and you are 4 to 6 inches away from the unit itself, which I have found to be the Yeti's sweet spot in the Cardioid pattern"}
{"source": " Next the silk screened Blue logo also helps you find the sweet spot, if you place it in front of the capsule area"}
{"source": " I like the idea of a metal screen, especially if you are transporting it, you won't have to worry about snagging,or runs, as you do with the cloth filters"}
{"source": " Speaking of old cloth filters, I have a Neumann, which is about 12 years old, a very nice screen as well, but it does not cut the pops as well as the Blue, especially if you get closer to the mic and screen"}
{"source": " Also when reading copy, or maybe music, I can see over and through the Blue filter, much better than the round 6 & 1/4 inch jobs Like the Neumann"}
{"source": " You can contort the neck of the filter in any position easily, cheaper filters I have used in the past, will creep back into unwanted positions, the Blue behaves"}

{"source": " Or so the historical theory goes"}
{"source": "Gradually nickel wrapped steel strings and then pure nickel strings came back into vogue as playersbegan searching for the old vintage sound"}

{"source": "I bought a Glaesel Bridge & this Glaesel rubber mute together"}
{"source": " I bought this because it was cheap and had so many good reviews"}
{"source": " The mute fits the bridge fine, but compared to a brass mute (which of course works VERY well) this mute seems to do absolutely nothing"}
{"source": " There is almost no discernible difference in playing the violin with or without this mute on"}
{"source": " Also, the mute can affect your playing so certain notes screech or stutter or produce other undesirable noises"}
{"source": "If You want or need a mute for practicing quietly (as many of us do), I suggest you buy something else"}

{"source": "I consider this mute completely useless since it does not do anything at all"}
{"source": " It does *not* mute or lower the volume of any violin in any noticeable way"}
{"source": "I'm not sure how much I can say about a mute"}
{"source": " It's easy to put on and take off, and it does its job"}
{"source": " It mutes the violin to a reasonable level"}
{"source": "  I used an SPL meter at a distance where a sustained open G string gave a reading of about +2db"}
{"source": " With the mute, it dropped to -6db"}
{"source": " I then tried a Yamaha silent electric violin (unplugged) and from the same distance, it barely registered"}
{"source": " I recalibrated the meter so the muted acoustic violin read about 1db, and the Yamaha read about -6db at that distance and setting"}
{"source": "So it won't make your instrument completely silent, and from a purely subjective perspective, it seemed to bring things closer to the silent violin, perhaps seeming about 10 to 20% louder had I not measured it"}
{"source": "With accessories, tonal quality is typically important"}
{"source": " But with a mute, you expect it to deteriorate"}
{"source": " Surprisingly, there was still a lot of tone left, especially compared to the unplugged electric, yet there were no buzzes or other horrible artifacts introduced"}
{"source": "You can't expect this to give great sound or complete silence, but it won't disturb the neighbors or their dogs, and it won't make the instrument sound dead"}
{"source": " This is about 15 times cheaper than the cheapest silent violin, and the latter will probably sound worse"}
{"source": " It's not the ultimate solution for quietness but it lets you stick to your instrument of choice"}
{"source": "This pedal is solidly built, and works as advertised"}

{"source": " I bought one Behringer XM8500 then two more a couple of months later planning to use them as rehearsal microphones for a geezer band start up about 5 years go"}
{"source": "  However, we actually have used these for vocals at some live performances when the sound tech's personal SM-58's are busy at another job"}
{"source": "  I honestly think we sound about the same either way and maybe a little clearer with the Behringers"}
{"source": "  At one time Alice Cooper and his band were using the Behringer XM8500's, however they may have moved on now for all I know"}
{"source": "These are not Shure SM-58 clones even though they appear to be cosmetic knockoffs"}
{"source": "  They have a slightly hotter output and a more flat response to my ears while the Shure's have a more pronounced lower mid boost that makes the male voice sound bigger and sometimes more distorted if not eq'ed correctly"}
{"source": "  They are an ideal backup vocal microphone since the Behringer behaves like a compromise between a microphone tailored for a male voice and a microphone tailored for a female voice and actually works well without heavy eq"}
{"source": "  It also is if anything more versatile than the SM-58 as it can be useful as an acoustic instrument pickup microphone working for anything that you would ordinarily use an SM-57 to pick up"}
{"source": "  It doesn't overload easily, has a high output and a tight pattern with about the same feedback rejection as the SM-58"}
{"source": "  It has a reasonably decent blast filter, so if using it for outdoor instrument pickup you don't have to add a windscreen"}
{"source": "  Another strength of these is durability"}
{"source": "  My 3 have sustained numerous drops, a couple of falls happened while boom stand mounted so not only did the microphone fall but the weight of the boom stand was behind it adding more mass to the force of the fall"}
{"source": "  No damage at all to any of them!  I used to cringe when they fell or got dropped but now I just shrug"}
{"source": " One weak point about these is they are more sensitive to handling noise, but on the stand handling noise is no issue"}

{"source": "  Its a solid state head on top of a vertical cab of two 14\" speakers"}
{"source": "  On its own, you can use the gain and distortion knobs present on the amp to get a decent sound, but with his Les Paul it still sounded oddly dark"}
{"source": "  We put the Rat in front of it and with some fiddling got that perfect AC/DC style overdrive out of it"}
{"source": "I think the main reason I love the Rat so much is not only the great tone and its sheer indestructability, but the filter knob"}
{"source": "  Normal tone knobs allow you to focus more on bass or treble, but usually if you boost one, you cut the other"}
{"source": "  The filter is more of a high end roll off, you can darken or brighten your tone accordingly, but when you DO go brighter, you still have the same bottom end"}
{"source": "  It doesn't CUT the bass out"}
{"source": "  So even with a more treble heavy sound, you still have a fuller rounder tone, it doesn't thin out so much"}
{"source": "Its really an excellent pedal"}

{"source": "what more do you want?Turn upside down, squeeze hard, use your &#34;man&#34; level strength and soon the tip will darken, apply liberally to your fret board in a back and forth motion"}
{"source": " IMMEDIATELY wipe your fret board clean just to take the wet look away"}
{"source": " Let sit for a few hours then dry rest of the way rubbing with cloth"}
{"source": "It's okay to soak the wood as long as it's momentary"}
{"source": " Don't saturate the fretboard and walk away, wood absorbs oil, too much oil absorbed = fretboard wood becoming swollen and buckling, losing shape and flatness"}
{"source": " Not a good situation"}
{"source": "Lemon oil isn't like other oils, it isn't very slippery and kind of makes things grabby"}
{"source": " It's oil but it actually works more like a solvent, cleaning things and making them sqeaky clean"}
{"source": "like your frets"}
{"source": "hint hint"}
{"source": "Just be sure to buff off all the excess and put a little string lubricant on your frets before you re-string and you'll be a happy camper"}

{"source": "DI bass is the worst"}
{"source": " Just really, really awful"}
{"source": " Every ordinary DI box I've tried yields this thin, cheap treble sound that does not present my bass in its most flattering light"}
{"source": " So when I started playing live weekly, I just hauled my bass amp around to each gig, because it was out of the question that I would rely on a weird sounding DI box to carry the day"}
{"source": "I live in Phoenix"}
{"source": " I made it through about two months of lugging a monstrous bass amp across town in 115 degree weather before I decided there had to be another way"}
{"source": "When I first got this pedal, I would run it parallel with the amp, terrified to rely entirely on this little box for my sound"}
{"source": " After a few performances, I let go and left the amp at home"}
{"source": " The Bass Attack pedal did not disappoint"}
{"source": " Ever since, I just bring a bass and this pedal"}
{"source": " Running straight into the board through this thing delivers a magnificently huge bass sound"}
{"source": " I don't miss the amp at all"}
{"source": "I did spend an entire evening the night this pedal arrived, just tweaking knobs until it was perfect"}
{"source": " You'll want to dial in exactly the right sound for your bass, and some of the settings I tried were less than ideal for my instrument"}
{"source": " But once I got it locked in, I've never touched the knobs again"}
{"source": " I just plug in and everything sounds magical"}
{"source": "I'm using this as a DI box for recording"}
{"source": " It does some compression, overdrive, EQ'ing, notch EQ'ing, and excite-ing all in one pedal"}
{"source": " So compared to the original bass signal, you get this clear, deep, punchy sound that fits right into a mix"}
{"source": "The Bass Attack sounds a lot like a SansAmp Bass Driver but at 1/3 the price"}
{"source": " One difference is that it has an additional \"Shape\" knob, which is a lot like the ISF knob on Blackstar products, and is a notch filter"}
{"source": " The other difference is that the SansAmp uses tougher chassis and components, so would last longer for the gigging musician"}
{"source": " But don't take me wrong, the Bass Attack uses a solid metal chassis and doesn't feel cheap at all"}
{"source": "The Harmonics knob adds some overdrive, and gets kind of farty when turned up 100% but sounds pretty good at 75-90%"}
{"source": " It doesn't do that high gain super gritty/fizzy distortion though, for that you could connect a distortion pedal to the parallel output, or duplicate the track in your DAW and add a distortion plugin"}
{"source": "This pedal is very versatile"}
{"source": " I found that the Shape knob is indispensable; it takes the place of a mid control"}
{"source": " For example, by notching (reducing) the boomy 60-130 Hz region and turning up the level, you get plenty more mids"}
{"source": " The treble and bright control seem very similar to each other, one seems to amplify the 4k region, the other the 5k but that's just an estimate"}
{"source": " By keeping both of those around 10 o'clock and the Shape control beneath 115 Hz, I can get a solid, deep, yet mid-full sound for a metal mix"}
{"source": " Thus anyone who thinks this pedal is all bass and treble and no mids, ought to try settings along those lines"}
{"source": "Another good feature is that this pedal can run on 48V phantom power"}
{"source": " As in, no adapter or battery needed when recording direct or running to a mixer"}
{"source": " In conclusion, for recording, you can duplicate the SansAmp sound that you hear on a lot of albums using the Bass Attack, and tweak it further via the Shape control"}
{"source": " And yes, the various button pushes get you four different sounds total, but I prefer having both buttons on"}
{"source": " Then in my DAW I only throw on an extra compressor and it sounds great"}
{"source": " This pedal is a steal for no frills bass DI recording"}

{"source": " Bought this to adapt the mike plug to 1/4\" jack so the mike can plug into a regular amp for the grandkids to \"karaoke\" with"}
{"source": "Useful for connecting mics to a guitar amp or directly into a computer's mic jack"}
{"source": " The 1/4\" side tends to become a bit loose after a while, not sure if it affects performance though"}
{"source": "The Shure XLR Female to Male 1/4\" Adapter is simply another one of those fix it gadgets that a sound mixer has to have in his kit"}
{"source": "I've got a bag of them and they work just like they are supposed to"}
{"source": "Now this one as pictured is the mono version, which you would use to take a balanced or unbalanced mic down to an unbalanced 1/4\" jack"}
{"source": " If you need to keep a balanced feed or if you are running stereo or two channel in a single cable, this adapter will not work for you"}
{"source": " You'll need the TRS (tip, ring, sleeve) balanced version of this adapter"}
{"source": "I purchased this to interface the XLR plug on a Sennheiser E825-S mike with the input on guitar amplifiers"}
{"source": " it seemed to work very well in this role"}
{"source": " It was well-constructed, with all the connecting points working precisely and securely"}
{"source": "Somewhat after the fact, I started worrying about whether I should have instead gotten an adapter with impedance matching capabilities"}
{"source": " I'm hardly a professional technician in this area, but I did do enough research to figure out a good working answer: Lo-Z (low impedance) microphones (say, 1,000 ohms or less) generally do not have to be matched to solid-state amplifiers, which are likely to have Hi-Z (high impedance) inputs in the range of 10,000 ohms"}
{"source": " These amplifiers ae generally designed to accommodate a 10:1 impedance ratio (load to source)"}
{"source": " I calculated the signal loss of such an arrangement in the range of 0"}
{"source": "83 decibels, which is incidental"}
{"source": "This corresponds to what my ears tell me: this adapter works just fine without impedance matching"}
{"source": " I can't say for sure whether that also holds for tube amps but will update my review if I have a chance to find out"}
{"source": "UPDATE: since I wrote my initial review, I have discovered that Pyle seems to have a problem securing its connectors properly with set screws"}
{"source": " If you purchase this item, I suggest you have a micro-screwdriver set handy so you can tighten everything up before you discover to your chagrin that a loose set screw has gone missing or caused your connector to fall apart"}

{"source": "This is a XLR connection phantom powered mic, which is pro and best"}
{"source": " So it requires a phantom powered XLR input, which all pro equipment provides and is standard on most home recording audio interfaces"}
{"source": " Which you should really purchase along with this, if you haven't already, because for around $100 you'll improve your recording and playback and have a preamp and monitoring, you'll find one by searching audio interfaces"}
{"source": " I have a RolandRoland TRI CAPTURE Audio Interfaceand a Focusrite I use just for playback in my office and den but they work well and you don't need Avid HD's to get started"}
{"source": " Audio interface is just another name for an external sound card but will provide the proper input and gain meter"}
{"source": " Getting your interface away from the electronically noisy computer has been SOP since the dawn of digital"}
{"source": " I see that small USB mixers are available which would be another option"}
{"source": " Don't try an adapter on it, it won't work, as this needs power through the cord to charge the field effect transistor, but power supplies are available and after that adapt however you want"}
{"source": " It doesn't come with the cord, what a surprise! Quality cords will cost about half the price of this, but a $15 version will probably do for most"}

{"source": "This type of mic is excellent for overhead, acoustics, amps or brass and of course vocals, really most recording needs, having a less uni and more omni, cardioid directional pattern than stage mics hyper pattern it's better suited to recording"}
{"source": " Just understand you can't get too loud near it or you'll overdrive it since it's designed for up to screaming vocals, so back off with loud amps and brass, which also means you need a quiet place for recording because it'll pick up your AC ducts and your neighbor's TV"}
{"source": " That, is a good thing, what's bad is you trying to do good recording in a noisy environment, so don't blame a mic for your extraneous room noise"}
{"source": " You can't just use a different microphone or noise gates or processors of any kind, just quiet, anything else is a pail on a sinking ship because this is an acoustical, rather than electronic, signal to noise ratio"}
{"source": " A 10db pad will reduce output but doesn't affect the diaphragm and its input and acoustical foam won't help, that's not even its purpose, I suggest reading this on acoustics and foam, music"}

{"source": "Now pay no attention to the descriptions of how it sounds, I won't tell you because how it sounds to me on my system won't apply to you and your system and that goes for all audio, descriptions are worthless, only unplugging one piece of gear for another matters"}
{"source": " This is important, all audio equipment either accurately reproduces or doesn't, the recording cannot sound better than the source, so a microphone can only reproduce sound more or less accurate than a different microphone"}
{"source": " Accurate or inaccurate, not good or bad, there's a difference"}
{"source": " It's during the mix that you make it better or different from the original sound"}
{"source": " Apply these same thoughts to your home stereo, saying instead, playback cannot sound better than the recording and that's why accuracy is important in your monitors"}
{"source": "So search out any info you don't understand and don't expect to be a competent engineer without years of schooling, training and having worked in a professional setting"}

{"source": "If you've never played flatwounds, you might be surprised to discover that they far outlast round wound strings"}
{"source": " That's because what kills the sound of strings is gunk from your fingers and the air getting in between the windings and damping the vibration"}
{"source": " Back when guitar strings were more a lot more expensive, it wasn't that unusual to remove strings, boil them, and put them back on"}
{"source": " Some electric bassists still do this"}
{"source": ") With flats, the gunk doesn't get in between the wraps, and if you don't break a string you can play a set for months"}

{"source": "Does the job of removing dust from you records without harming it"}
{"source": " The handle folds down when not in use to protect the bristles"}
{"source": " Over all a nice product"}
{"source": "This brush is used to remove static electricity and light dust from records before each playing"}
{"source": " This is not a deep cleaning, dust or dirt removal brush; it is a compliment to record cleaning solutions like this excellent liquid cleaner by Last (LAST PC Power Cleaner 3/4 Oz"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": "The brush is super simple to use, with the album on your turntable, hold it at roughly a ninety degree angle for about two revolutions, and then sweep it off the LP"}
{"source": " No fuss, no muss, no fooling around"}
{"source": " Never touch the carbon fiber with your fingers"}
{"source": " When there is visible dust on the fibers, give the brush a good flick by rotating the handle across the fibers"}
{"source": " After each use, rotate the handle around to cover the fibers"}
{"source": " If you press the brush too hard against the album, or do the deep dive sharp angle trick, fibers will be broken off the brush"}
{"source": " Just press lightly against the rotating LP, sweep the brush off the LP, and all will be wonderful with this brush"}
{"source": "This brush is sold under many different brand names, ClearAudio, AudioQuest, and Thorens"}
{"source": "The brush comes with no instructions for use, an odd omission"}
{"source": " Maybe there is an assumption that the brush is so easy to use, instructions would be redundant"}
{"source": "Audiophile or not, this brush is a must have for anyone that still loves analog recordings"}
{"source": "This is a great addition to any stereo system today, assuming you still use your turntable"}
{"source": "  Two passes with this brush will clean up any of my records and get them ready for play, free of any annoying pops or clicks"}
{"source": "  It won't save a dirty record, you'll have to buy a cleaning solution for that, but this brush will easily take care of dust, hair, and other particles that get attracted to your LPs during regular use"}
{"source": "  As another reviewer suggested, I do the first pass with the brush going with the record, as if I was spreading out paint or something like that, and that gets most of the surface particulate free"}
{"source": "  The second pass is with the brush going directly against the motion of the record, and this cleans out the dust from inside the grooves of the record"}
{"source": "  After that, your record will sound brand new again!There are definitely more comprehensive cleaning and maintenance options, but none that are this easy and this cheap"}
{"source": "Seems to get a bit of dust up off the surface of the record, but frankly, the old Discwasher type with the fluid does a much better job"}
{"source": "  Better yet is to clean your records well with warm water and dish soap (and a new paint brush), then rinse them well and dry with a clean micro fiber cloth"}
{"source": "  Just try not to get the labels wet"}
{"source": "This is everything you need in a record brush"}
{"source": "  The bristles are the perfect quality and softness to get all the dust that sits between the lines of the record"}
{"source": " Highly recommended!"}

{"source": "As musicians, sometimes we find just the right sound or feel with a piece of equipment and it changes everything taking our performance to a new level"}
{"source": "  For me it happened when I found just the right sound & feel from my Taylor acoustic guitar, the right vocal mics, the right mixer, my Bose L1 Model II, etc"}
{"source": "Today I had one of those finds"}
{"source": " After years of being somewhat dissatisfied with every capo I've encountered I discovered the perfect capo for me: the G7th Performance Capo"}
{"source": "  I'm not kidding - it was one of those finds"}
{"source": "  As an acoustic guitar player / vocalist, obviously, I have to play all of my songs in the right key for an optimum vocal performance"}
{"source": "  This means occasionally relying on a capo to get just the right key with just the right chord shape/structure"}
{"source": "  Unfortunately, some of my songs had \"weak\" spots (sending them to my \"B\" list) courtesy of the combination of a \"weaker\" chord for me (due to physical limitations) & the reduced sustain & tonal quality resulting from using a capo"}
{"source": "  This dissatisfaction has had me on a \"capo quest\" which ended today when I found the G7th Performance Capo"}
{"source": "The first thing I noticed when I used the G7th was the improved sustain over every other capo I've used"}
{"source": "  All of those \"weak\" spots in my songs totally disappeared"}
{"source": "  I quickly dusted off several songs that were on my \"B\" list & found the improved sustain & tonal quality allowed me to move them to my \"A\" list"}
{"source": "I have no problem with the weight of this capo (others have pointed out that it is heavier) I can't detect any change in balance when handling my guitar (I play sitting on a guitar stool with the guitar resting on my leg - perhaps someone standing using a guitar strap might notice a slight difference in the balance"}
{"source": ")  I love the \"self-ratcheting\" feature of the G7th"}
{"source": "  I thought from some reviews & videos I watched that I'd have to pinch-down on the open end fairly firmly for a secure hold - this was NOT the case"}
{"source": "  I think the G7th has just the right width & density of foam under the top bar:  a) providing more \"friction\" to hold this capo in place;  b) playing a role in very effectively dampening the strings; & c) possibly being more gentle on the strings than a more narrow/harder foam or rubber top bar, thus having less impact on tuning"}
{"source": "I did find one slight negative about this capo which I was able to quickly overcome"}
{"source": "  The end of the top metal bar (on the open end of capo) is slightly more \"squared-off\" than the end of the bottom piece (which in contrast is rounded off)"}
{"source": "  It may be just the way I play some chords, but my hand was contacting that squared-off end of the top bar & was getting irritated - so I simply turned the capo around with the open end facing me (versus facing the floor) & the surfaces contacting my hand were far smoother - thus, zero  irritation"}
{"source": "  This was nothing new to me - I have had to do this with other capos"}
{"source": "Others have commented on the cost of this capo"}
{"source": "  For me, the cost of this capo was nothing compared to the many thousands of dollars I've spent finding just the right guitars, PA's, mics, & other equipment / accessories"}
{"source": "  I almost can't believe it only cost me $40 to make such a difference in my sound"}
{"source": " The G7th Performance Capo is priceless !!!Overall, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this capo - if you're like me - this could be a very inexpensive way to take your performance to the next level !!! {"source": "I bought these to replace the stock machine heads that came on my Hondo II \"The Paul\", which I bought in 1980"}
{"source": " The stock ones were loose, lots of backlash in the worm gears, and the guitar kept going out of tune even after the strings were fairly stretched out but still new"}
{"source": "They went in easily, if you follow this hint( if your machine head holes do not need to be enlarged, disregard this hint)- The holes for the old machine heads on the Hondo II were 0"}
{"source": "305\" in diameter, and these new Grovers need a 0"}
{"source": "390\" diameter hole"}
{"source": " So I had to find an accurate and clean way of enlarging the holes"}
{"source": " It's almost impossible to use a drill, even in a drill press, without splintering the wood on both surfaces of the headstock"}
{"source": " I read online suggestions about using a round wood file, and reamer, etc"}
{"source": " So what I did was first use a threading tap( for metal screw threads) which at the bottom had a 0"}
{"source": "290\" diameter, and at the top had a 0"}
{"source": "375\" diameter"}
{"source": " This is a standard 3/8\"-24 threading tap"}
{"source": " I chucked the tap into my battery-powered hand drill, set to low speed, and used the threading tap to cleanly and carefully enlarge the headstock holes to 0"}
{"source": "375\" in diameter"}
{"source": " Then I used a tapered reamer, from both sides, to enlarge the holes to the required diameter"}
{"source": " Quick, clean, easy"}
{"source": " If you have a different size enlargement to make, use the appropriately sized taps and a tapered reamer to get the holes to 0"}
{"source": "390\" diameter"}
{"source": "Another hint which you should follow is to replace only one machine head at a time, like when changing strings"}
{"source": " You don't want to take the tension off the neck and mess around with the truss rod"}
{"source": " At least I don't want to!Now the guitar stays in tune, and is easier and more accurate to tune"}
{"source": "A very worthwhile upgrade! Zero backlash in the worm gears on the Grovers, beautifully chromed and smooth as silk"}

{"source": "  Generally, Dampits can be used over and over for years"}
{"source": "  Sometimes the rubber becomes discolored, sometimes the rubber rips near the end of the Dampit, but basically this is a very workable way to maintain at least a minimum amount of humidity in and around your instrument, something that is especially important during the winter months when artificial heat zaps the humidity out of the air"}
{"source": "  This is the first instrument-specific Dampit product that I've ever purchased and it seems to work exceptionally well"}
{"source": "  In addition to the standard Dampit, there's a sound-hole cover"}
{"source": "  In case it is not clear just how it works, the clear sound-hole cover has a short string with a loop on the end"}
{"source": "  You simply attach the Dampit to the loop and it hangs inside the guitar"}
{"source": "  My first impression is that it does an excellent job of keeping some needed humidity in the body of the instrument, something very important on a solid-top classical guitar"}
{"source": "  I would recommend this over the standard Dampit because the sound-hole cover is so convenient (hopefully it will continue to keep me from having to fish around inside the guitar for a runaway Dampit) and seems to keep the humidity focused in an area that is especially in need of it"}
{"source": "  A must have if you keep your acoustic guitar in an environment that gets much below 40-50% humidity"}
{"source": "It's hard to really describe what this pedal does-  It doesn't distort, flange, echo, or produce a chorus"}
{"source": "  I'd heard it described as making your amp sound like someone had thrown a blanket off of it"}

{"source": " It sounds like it uses a touch of reverb and a dash of the higher end of the mids to make cleans sound more sparkling"}
{"source": " But you should also be able to get the same sounds out of a Hughes and Kettner Statesman 40 or 60 watt amp, too, just running it straight"}
{"source": "To me, from what I have heard, it adds nothing to those who use a fair amount of distortion in their music"}
{"source": " It definitely doesn't add any more fatness"}
{"source": " So my overall impression is that what this box provides is the same thing that some people swear they get out of copper bracelets for their arthritis or feeling better with an increased Vitamin E regimen"}
{"source": " In other words, this is a matter of what is in your head and how suggestable you are"}
{"source": "Most musicians already use EQ and reverb and by careful tweaking of those two things you can obtain what you think you're getting out of this pedal, I think"}
{"source": "I'm not going to do any explaining about the \"science\" behind how this pedal works"}
{"source": " I'm just going to focus this review on how the pedal affects your tone"}
{"source": " This definitely isn't a boost, and it's also not an eq, the BBE sonic stomp is a uniquely functioning pedal"}
{"source": " To the ear, it serves to add clarity, depth, and body to your tone"}
{"source": " Essentially, this pedal allows you to get the most out of the tones your amp is already producing"}
{"source": "The lo contour knob doesn't \"increase\" the amount of bass produced by the amp"}
{"source": " Rather, it tightens up and generally increases the depth of the bass (and low mid) tone"}
{"source": " To the ear this may sound at first like the bass has been increased, but it hasn't"}
{"source": " You're just hearing all the bass tone that was there in the first place, that was jumbled up as the signal went from your guitar to the amp"}
{"source": "The process knob really just focuses on the treble and high mid frequencies"}
{"source": " These frequencies can often be very unpleasant and grating to hear, and the sonic stomp sort of evens and smooths out those tones so they are clearer and less harsh"}
{"source": "That's not to say that you can't dial in some very aggressive and cutting highs if you play lead metal or something; indeed, it'll make those searing lead tones even better"}
{"source": "Now, I gave this product 4 stars not because I've had any issues with it or haven't been in any way unsatisfied with it; but rather because it's really a fairly subtle effect"}
{"source": " At first I almost couldn't tell a difference between having it on and off"}
{"source": " With time I've been able to better recognize and appreciate the impact that it has on my tone, but it doesn't make a \"night and day\" difference"}
{"source": "I recommend this pedal to someone who already has a tone that you're happy with, and just want to make it even better"}
{"source": " This pedal won't make a cheap 15 watt solid- state combo sound like a tube half-stack"}
{"source": " It won't make you love your tone when you were completely unsatisfied with it before"}
{"source": "In conclusion, though I definitely wouldn't put this pedal into the \"must have\" category, it definitely improves the quality of my tone"}
{"source": " This is a pedal that I leave on all the time, as it improves both clean and distorted tones"}
{"source": "This pedal adds that \"I don't know what\" to your sound"}

{"source": "The three 'back-rest' fold outs are static, attached to a center ring, and you \"can\" adjust them independently a *little up and down*, but not to compensate for such a length difference between a bluegrass banjo and a mandolin"}
{"source": "  However, the mandolin is a really lite thing, so I suspect it will be fine just hanging there by the peg head without a 'back-rest' as long as the stand isn't jostled around"}

{"source": "Now a word about open back banjos, if you are considering this stand"}
{"source": " First off, no, I was not going to rest the coordinator rod against the 'back-rest' (just seems like a bad idea)"}
{"source": "  What I ended up doing was adjusting the 'back-rests' so the resonator of the bluegrass banjo rested about an inch up from the bottom, allowing the open back to rest on the other side ON TOP of the rest, along the lip of the banjo rim, at the edge of the rest foam where it begins to curve out and down"}

{"source": "  As you might expect, it's a pretty boxy sounding little amp, more reminiscent of 60's portable transistor radios than a double stack Marshall"}
{"source": "  But it did the two things I wanted it for"}

{"source": "What is this amp exactly? My guess is that Danelectric took the circuitry for its overdrive stompbox, added a 1-watt amplifier circuit, and put the whole shebang into a retro case"}
{"source": " The result is quite appealing"}
{"source": " And the overall look and feel is one of quality"}
{"source": " The case is solid albeit plastic"}
{"source": " The three controls (volume, tone, and overdrive), while not detented, have the smooth control that you tend to get on better components"}
{"source": " The input 1/4-inch jack and the mini jack headphone output are all solid"}
{"source": " Someone in Danelectric had a sense of humor in touting the unit's \"leather\" strap, though"}
{"source": " It is more decorative than useful"}
{"source": "If you can operate an overdrive stompbox, then you know how to work this amp"}

{"source": "00 and get something that is a real deal, I hope this helps with your decision about purchasing one"}
{"source": "I don't have a classical guitar, but I just got an inexpensive but really fun steel string guitar with a non-radiused fingerboard"}
{"source": "  I've also got over a dozen capos (don't ask!) but all are for radiused fingerboards"}
{"source": "The fingerboards of most steel-string guitars--electric and acoustic--are radiused, that is, they are not flat"}
{"source": "  They have a gentle curve to them, so gentle that many wouldn't notice it unless they looked closely"}
{"source": " Look up \"fingerboard\" in the Wikipedia for an excellent discussion and Google images for diagrams and pictures"}
{"source": "Even though the curve is gentle, if a fingerboard is radiused, a capo must be curved, too, or the outside strings would not be pressed down properly and would buzz"}
{"source": "  If a fingerboard is flat, like a classical guitar's, the capo must be flat, too, or the center strings will not be pressed down properly and will buzz"}
{"source": "If you're not sure whether your guitar's fingerboard is radiused, slide a ruler between two frets"}
{"source": "  If it lies flat, then so is the fingerboard"}
{"source": "  If it rocks, the fingerboard is radiused"}
{"source": "I REALLY like this capo because of the way pressure is adjusted by turning the tension screw"}
{"source": "  This makes it possible to exert just the right amount of pressure--not tool little, which would cause strings to buzz, and not too much, which would cause the instrument to go out of tune"}
{"source": "As others have noted, its one drawback is that it can't be clamped to the headstock when not in use"}
{"source": "  But for that, I'd replace most of my capos with radiused versions of this capo"}
{"source": "  HIGHLY recommended!"}
{"source": "The only instrument this works well on is my Yamaha guitarelele which has nylon strings, for steel strings I want more pressure, I advise getting the NS Capo that is not \"lite\",  I prefer that one above this model"}
{"source": "A Little History:I have been a guitar player for forty-odd (some of them, VERY odd) years"}
{"source": "  For the first thirty of them, I tuned by ear - starting by guessing at what a low E sounded like, then tuning the other five strings by fretting, listening and tuning"}
{"source": "  I could never understand why the tuning often sounded perfect for one chord, yet remained `off' for others"}
{"source": " it took quite a long time to get it right"}
{"source": "  Then, about ten years ago, I thought I had figured it out"}
{"source": "  The problem (I thought) was that my guesses at a true \"E\" were off - so I got myself an \"E\" tuning fork (320 cycles) and used it to tune the first string"}
{"source": "  Then, I did as I had always done - fretted and tuned the other five"}
{"source": " Not much better as a result - kept having to tune and retune for quite a while to get all chords to sound right"}
{"source": "  During those years, I tried tuning all six strings to (what I believed was an accurately tuned) piano as well as by ear to tones available online"}
{"source": "  Nothing gave me better tuning on the first try"}
{"source": "  Then, I saw an ad for a Chromatic Tuner and lightening struck"}
{"source": "The Realization:There have been many -  each of which has led me closer to what I have now - near perfect tuning on the first go `round!  First off, I realized that when we say \"E\", that is not just one note"}
{"source": "  It is a range of literally hundreds - perhaps even thousands- of specific tones"}
{"source": "  The same is true for every note"}
{"source": "  This is akin, I guess, to the realization as a child, that no matter how many shades of `blue' are in a box of crayons, the chanced of having the precise shade you want for a specific drawing are rare"}
{"source": "  Purchasing my first Chromatic Tuner (a CT440, manufactured by SwitchMucic and sold through MusiciansFriend"}
{"source": "com) moved me a long way along the continuum of learning and accurate tuning"}
{"source": "  However, that tuner had at least two limitations"}
{"source": " Firstly, it's construction is rather light and flimsy - it works OK, but has a second limitation that conaused me to buy the Korg (for about the same price)  That is that the Korg has a built in tone generator and speaker allowing the option of tuning that way rather than having only the single option of having tones made by the instrument read and metered back to you"}
{"source": "  Both tuners have plug-in for electric instruments, and, so far as I can tell, their accuracies are similar"}
{"source": "  I prefer the Korg for the reasons I have mentioned"}
{"source": "  Additionally, the Korg can be manually recalibrated for special tuning needs - and `remembers' the original tuning/tones so you can return to it for more `standard' usage"}
{"source": " A nice, extra piece of flexibility"}
{"source": " The LCD meter is easy to read and colored lights tell you, right away, whether you are sharp, flat (and by how much!) or right on!As a point of surprising interest, the tuning fork I had used for years turns out to be profoundly FLAT! A shock to me - given that I had grown up learning that tuning forks gave off perfect tones! I have saved it as a reminder that all things are not what they are promoted to be"}
{"source": " I guess the round pitch pipe that Ms"}
{"source": " Sweeny used to tune up the class in the 5th grade was probably not quite as precise as she would have presumed!And Finally:This is a marvelous little (and inexpensive) device - well constructed, accurate and flexible to allow for many different tuning need situations and circumstances"}
{"source": "  I assume that there will be still higher places for my `learning curve' in this area to rise to - but for right now, this is it"}
{"source": "  I am using it, regularly, on all my stringed instruments (two six-string Martins, a twelve string Epiphone and a frailing banjo"}
{"source": "  The time it saves tuning the 12-string alone makes it more than it's own price!)If you have not discovered Chromatic Tuning (maybe I really WAS the last one to discover these things!?), I suggest you do so immediately and spend your time enjoying the pleasures of making music rather than sitting in frustration trying to adjust the tunings by ear so it sounds `really' right"}
{"source": " Perhaps people with `perfect pitch' can do very nicely without a Chromatic Tuner - I am not one of them"}
{"source": " Are you?"}
{"source": "This is a nice little tuner"}
{"source": " It is small, easy to read and use"}
{"source": " It has a non-backlit LCD display of an analog VU style meter, with extra marks at plus and minus 20 cents, and red LEDs that light when a tone is sharp or flat"}
{"source": " It has a green LED and large mark for being on target"}
{"source": " It has a built-in mic for acoustic instruments, and a mono 1/4 inch phone jack for electric instruments"}
{"source": " It has an active tone you can switch on for tuning, but that is only adjustable over the narrow range of 410-480hz"}
{"source": " It uses a pair of AAA size batteries that you pop the whole case open to change"}
{"source": " If you have any vision problems, the display might be an issue"}
{"source": " The LCD is about 1 1/2 inches long and 3/4 of an inch high, and, like all non-backlit LCD displays, has a narrow viewing angle and reflection issues"}
{"source": "I wanted this for tuning didgeridus that I was making, and it works adequately for that"}
{"source": " The one thing it is lacking that disappointed me is a frequency or octave readout"}
{"source": " As it is, it gives you the note and cents sharp or flat, but does not give an octave number or frequency of the sound"}
{"source": " So, you know you are tuned to a C, you just don't know exactly which C it is"}
{"source": " Probably not much of an issue if you are tuning a regular instrument, but in some cases would be very handy to know"}
{"source": " I suppose with more training and experience, I could learn to tell that by ear"}
{"source": " (What? Learn a skill! Isn't that asking a bit much?)I suppose for an inexpensive tuner, that is the trade-off, but it does detract from the usefulness of this tuner for my purposes"}
{"source": " Other than that, it seems to work well"}
{"source": " It is consistent, easy to use, and compact"}
{"source": " I consider it about average in value - it does the basics well but is missing what I consider an important function in such a device"}
{"source": " I may be expecting too much for the price, as I have not done an exhaustive study of tuners and their specs"}
{"source": " Having the octave feature would make it 4 stars for me instead of three"}
{"source": "In any case, if you don't need to know the actual octave or frequency but just the accuracy of the notes you are tuning, this works quite well, and is not very expensive"}
{"source": "I've had two of these tuners"}
{"source": " They are well known among bass instrument players for being able to lock in on the lowest pitches better than most other tuners"}
{"source": " They're durable and have a long battery life"}
{"source": " Unlike most other tuners, in noisy environments they don't lock in on higher pitches before lower ones, again a plus for low instrument players"}

{"source": " I swear I was done in 20 minutes!! The board looks awesome with all the cables cut to perfect length"}
{"source": " These cables are dead silent and the connectors are high quality"}
{"source": " The supplied cutting tool works as described and the only thing you need is a small-tip, flathead screwdriver with a medium size handle so you can firmly drive the locking screw into the cable for the final step"}
{"source": " I could have saved some money if I had just bought these first instead of a bunch of random length patch cables"}
{"source": "The good thing about the Cable Station is you can make your own cables at custom lengths so you can have a neater pedal board without the need to solder the connections in place"}
{"source": " All you have to do is cut the cable flush, insert it into the \" plug with a twisting motion, and then turn the setscrew on the side of the plug until it is tight"}
{"source": "As a benefit, if there is a shorting of the signal all you need to do is find the offending cable, remove the plug, cut the cable, and insert the end back into the plug"}
{"source": "Great right?Well, not really"}
{"source": "As far as reliability goes, nothing can really replace the connection that is properly soldered"}
{"source": " With the money you spend, you could easily get a decent soldering iron, some old cable, and some cheap plugs from Radio Shack and practice"}
{"source": " In the end, you can by bulk cable and connectors and make them as needed"}
{"source": "I have used this product and had to re-cut several cables at different times but only to cables that have been constantly moved around"}
{"source": " The other ones that are more permanent haves not given me trouble, but I have experienced problems in the past"}
{"source": " Always have a few spares that have been tested"}
{"source": "Another annoying thing is that they give you more cable than connectors, I would think 15 connectors would be more sufficient"}
{"source": "Is it easier than soldering? Yes"}
{"source": "Are they reliable? For the most part, yes"}
{"source": "Will I continue using the product? Yes, because I usually have spares"}
{"source": "Why do I use them then? I'm lazy"}
{"source": "This is from the Cleartone cables website about gold connectors:Don"}
{"source": "t waste your money if you are being asked to pay extra for gold plated connectors"}
{"source": " The thin soft gold (5-10 microns) "}
{"source": "flash"}
{"source": " plating looks cool, but scrapes off easily and the brass aterial underneath stops you from seeing that the gold has worn off! The brass eventually  tarnishes and causes crackling when the plug moves or twists in the socket contacts"}
{"source": "It is true that gold is a very good conductor of electricity when mated with a gold plated socket"}
{"source": " But the sockets inside your guitar amplifier and guitar are not usually gold, so there can be virtually no benefit to gold plated plugs"}
{"source": "I am a tech as well as a guitar player"}
{"source": " I also have spent time in the past Teaching soldering"}
{"source": " But these cables seem to be well made with good solderless connections"}

{"source": " All I know is I have Hand Soldered Special plugs with Good Cable to only have them break with use and I expect the same with these especially in a high use situation where they are plugged & unplugged often"}

{"source": "[Later: The mic is indeed the Behringer C-1, but Amazon has provided it with the description belonging to the C-1U"}
{"source": "  Unlike Amazon's description, this is not a mic that comes with USB plug, phantom power, and computer connectivity"}
{"source": " And, of course, none of the advertised \"included\" computer software programs is included"}
{"source": "  It's a conventional studio mic that requires connection to a regular amp / P"}
{"source": "A"}
{"source": " with an XLR jack and phantom power"}
{"source": " It will NOT connect to the USB port of a computer without an expensive adapter and a preamp with phantom power"}
{"source": "  Moreover, Amazon's form thus far is denying a refund and offering only replacement--presumably for another mic just like this one! If you want the described mic, Amazon is showing it from a different vendor--at about 30 more plus S&H"}
{"source": ";]The Behringer C-1 mic is the best condenser mic I've used for the money, its large diaphragm capable of reproducing some of the rich and deep sonorities of the costly, high-end mics at the radio station (NPR) where I occasionally work"}
{"source": "  However, Behringer makes a distinction between the C-1 and the C-1U"}
{"source": "  The description on Amazon fits the C-1U, not the C-1"}
{"source": "  So one way or another, 50% of the purchasers of this product are likely to be surprised and disappointed"}
{"source": "Indeed, the C-1U is a phantom-powered mic that doesn't require phantom power, which it derives from the USB port of a computer"}
{"source": "  Moreover, the mic not only saves its owner the bother of a pre-amp with phantom power but it also makes unnecessary a costly (and time-consuming) XLR to USB adapter"}
{"source": "  It's ready to go--just plug it into your laptop and start recording"}
{"source": "  (I use Sound Studio, but the included free software--Audacity--works practically as well"}

{"source": "  They ring nicely"}
{"source": "  I find that coating bronze strings with a good string cleaner, like Dunlop 65 Ultraglide, can help you avoid the dirty fingers and get much more life from the strings"}
{"source": "The J74's are sort of the default string that mandolin dealers put on their instruments"}
{"source": "  They are bright and brassy when new, and give a decent punch to the sound"}
{"source": "  However because they are bronze, they can discolor your fingers and they tarnish pretty quickly, especially in the summer when your fingers are sweatier"}
{"source": "  Also, since they are round-wound, they are harder to fret than a flat-wound string and harder to shift up and down"}
{"source": "  But the people who like them change them often, like once in 30 days or so, or whenever they play a gig, to get that nice bright brassy punch for when they are new"}
{"source": "  This is because they get to a point where you have to work harder just to get the same volume, being less elastic, and less lively"}
{"source": "  One thing is sure, that the J74's are loud and zingy, and that's why dealers put them on their mandolins"}
{"source": "  Some folks move to the heavier J75's to get even louder and fatter woof on their chops"}
{"source": "  The J74's are brighter and more aggressive than flatwound strings and cut through when you're in ensemble work"}
{"source": "  Just make sure to change them often to get the best performance"}
{"source": "D'Addario strings have become the favorite for all my guitars, and now my two mandolins"}
{"source": " Consistent quality and good tone and volume have made me loyal to the brand"}

{"source": "To change out harps bite down on your harp, use your hands to depress the tabs on either side and then pull your head back sliding the harp out as you do, to insert a new one place your harp in your mouth, depress tabs and use your mouth to center the harp in between the plates, when it is in position release tabs making sure not to get your lips caught between the harmonica and the plates as they pinch shut"}

{"source": " Now, I'm definitely not one of those who automatically dismiss the quality of Chinese made products"}
{"source": " I have, in fact, many musical items of surprisingly good quality made there"}
{"source": " This item however has some of the good, AND some of the more stereotypical problems of Chinese goods"}
{"source": " Pros: Cheap"}
{"source": " Sturdy"}
{"source": " And unlike some reviewers, I love the taller height"}
{"source": " Far far better for you ergonomically not having to stoop and scrunch your neck and windpipe"}
{"source": " I also like the tighter springs, though that does take a little getting used to"}
{"source": " But the secure feel of your harp is worth the slight extra effort"}
{"source": " Now, the Cons: It's true what others have said: the plastic neck tube smells"}
{"source": " Not as bad as some have said, but an annoying chemical smell is definitely noticeable"}
{"source": " I cut that off and got a big wide replacement tube at TAP Plastics for a buck (make sure the one you get is wide enough to slide over the bends in the neck loop bar thingee - I got the 1/2\" diameter)"}
{"source": " 2nd and perhaps bigger problem is that the metal is NOT bent evenly"}
{"source": " Mine was distinctly taller on one side than the other, and the neck loop was WAY off"}
{"source": " I did my best to bend all parts to even, but the flat metal part is tough to shape"}
{"source": " The reason I didn't return it is that I figure most of them are equally uneven: I just picture a bunch of poor souls slaving away bending these suckers by hand, with little or no machine help to ensure consistency"}
{"source": " With the work I did on it myself, it works fine and is now fairly even, and like I said, the taller height is just about right for me"}
{"source": " It's just annoying that some of the most basic expectations aren't met (like holding your harmonica at an even height on both sides)"}
{"source": " All this said, the bottom line is that I prefer using this OVER my German made Hohner holder because it's better ergonomically (taller), holds my harp more securely, and the traditional dual butterfly nut design just works far better and with less effort than the \"nouveau\" single butterfly nut design of my more expensive German Hohner"}
{"source": " Knowing what I know of its drawbacks, I'm still tempted to pick up another as a back-up or spare"}
{"source": " It's a great deal if you're willing to do a little work on it"}
{"source": "Yes, this pedal is plastic, the switch is not the most durable feeling, and the knob placement is annoying"}
{"source": "  At less than $15, you need to be able to look past these things"}
{"source": "  I've had a higher failure rate with the Dunlop Cry Baby and that thing is built like a cinder block"}
{"source": "  This pedal actually sounds pretty good when used as intended"}
{"source": " Which is to say, this pedal does a nice job in overdriving the preamp tubes in your valve amplifier"}
{"source": "  No brutalz here unless you already have a good amount of gain going"}
{"source": "  No overdrive pedal lives up to it's potential running into a solid state (even modeling) amplifier"}
{"source": "  It's just not what they are really intended to do and they end up sounding buzzy"}
{"source": " Some have complained about RF interference with the use of the FAB pedals (getting radio signals through your amp)"}
{"source": "  I have had that happen with pedals costing 5x the price of the FAB- particularly when running a long pedal chain"}
{"source": "  Based on tone alone, this pedal can overdrive your tube preamp as well as most anything out there under $100"}
{"source": "  Check out the YouTube review of this pedal by a guy that goes by 'intheblues'"}
{"source": "  I believe he uses a DRRI with a strat, and this pedal sounds GREAT"}
{"source": "  If you did a blind test between this pedal and an overdrive costing north of $100 you may be surprised- particularly if your other gear (amp and guitar) are halfway decent"}
{"source": "  What I did note though, was that this pedal has a wee bit more gain and a little less treble than my other TS type pedals"}
{"source": "  That doesn't make it worse or better- just different"}
{"source": "  The 'mid-hump' is actually less pronounced than in a tubescreamer, which is a good thing IMHO"}
{"source": "  There are already enough tubescreamer clones on the market!  It will not perform miracles on lousy sounding guitars and amplifiers"}
{"source": "  Incidentally, the pedal plays well with other dirt boxes"}
{"source": "  Since it isn't true bypass, you will likely get some tone suck if you run a bunch of these in your chain, but if the rest of your pedals have decent bypass you will be fine"}
{"source": "  Lest you mistake me for a novice fanboy with no point of reference for my review- I've been playing guitar since 1979 and have used 'vintage' dirt boxes since before they were vintage and overpriced"}
{"source": "  I am years past caring about the brand and all about getting good sounds from simple gear"}
{"source": "  YMMV-"}
{"source": "Depending on the amp and guitar you have, this pedal is going to either really be great or be a bummer"}
{"source": " It sounds terrific with my fender strat (single coil) Danelectro (lipstick pickups) on my solid state amps, giving them a warm tube like overdrive"}
{"source": "It sounds terrible on my tube amp and my vintage silvertone amp, it really sounds aweful with my 1980's Kramer, loaded with humbucker pickups"}
{"source": "You'll either love it or hate it! That will decide mostly on the type of guitar and amp you use, it's a different pedal with every combination"}
{"source": "This pedal is remarkable for useful tones"}
{"source": " The sound may not be for everyone, but i already have a Boogie for the really metal like distortion"}
{"source": " I needed something that was different but still usable, and I feel this pedal fills the bill"}
{"source": "  The low price tag didn't hurt my feelings either"}
{"source": " This is a win-win buying decision as far as I am concerned"}
{"source": "I use this on my mandolin, it is easy to use once you have the trick of it, first this thing has a long end with eyelets on it (that the other reviewers fear will scratch the neck of their instruments), and a short end (designed to prevent said scratches)"}
{"source": " To use place the capo on your strings with the short end facing you, use your left thumb to hold it in place with the short end dangling just below your thumb, next loop the long end over the back of the neck using your right hand to pull it under the neck and then up toward your thumb, this will trap the short end under the long end and prevent the long ends eyelets from touching your instruments neck, now just rotate your left thumb out of the way so you can buckle the strap in place and you are all set"}
{"source": "I prefer this capo over the other 2 I have because it is so tiny, barely  bigger than the first two joints of my pinkie, and yet it does the job it was designed for, its small size means I can toss it in my mandos hardcase storage box and forget about it till I need it"}
{"source": "The only downside to this is that the elastic will eventually stretch to where it will no longer work, but then again at 5 bucks you can't have everything"}
{"source": "It's very small"}
{"source": "  It's a fabric stretchy capo, the old type, that's quite difficult to stretch and make stay"}
{"source": "  It's made with an end that you stretch the fabric over to connect to hold the capo, but the end isn't very long and I don't trust it to stay while playing for long"}
{"source": "  I'll keep it as a spare, just in case, anyway"}
{"source": "Love that I didn't have to assemble this stand!  Just had to unfold it"}
{"source": " Was easy to adjust and is very stable"}
{"source": " It's nice to be able to sit down at keyboard without having to worry about bumping it"}
{"source": " Also seat fits perfectly under it when not in use"}
{"source": "This is certainly a heavy duty stand!  It weighs quite a bit, is made of solid metal, and I would not hesitate to think it could hold quite a bit of weight"}
{"source": "  However, while it seems stable side-to-side, the spread of the legs does not taper much at all from top to bottom, and I believe it would fall over quickly if bumped from the front or back"}
{"source": "  This makes me nervous for live performances or close quarter practices"}
