{"source": "  The front-back spread on the legs is a little too narrow for stage applications, but having room underneath for pedals is a huge improvement over the more-common 'X' stand"}
{"source": "Got these to stop the pegs from slipping in my cheap new violin"}
{"source": "  Added a couple drops, and it worked like a charm"}
{"source": "  A must buy for anyone buying a cheap starter violin"}
{"source": "Wow, this works!  At first, I was a little wary about using the liquidThe Original Peg Drops by Ardsleyon the pegs for apprehension from the warnings that came with the product"}
{"source": "  Being my own bumbling teacher, there was a fear I could damage the finish on my rather inexpensive instrument"}
{"source": "  However, I needed help tuning a couple of balky pegs, so I closed my eyes and blundered ahead (that's just a figure of speech; for I was careful, using the stuff for the first time)"}
{"source": "  With care, cotton and a small rag (torn off my moth eaten underwear) I went ahead, willing to try anything"}
{"source": "  I even removed the strings from the pegs (only one at a time - starting with the inner one first), put the drops on the proper peg locations and restrung the string"}
{"source": "  Tuning then became a breeze"}
{"source": "  To think I used up a great glob of practice time, not fiddling, but tuning"}
{"source": "  Bop! Could'a had a veggie drink!"}
{"source": "These drops are not just a convenience"}
{"source": " In my opinion they are a neccessity for beginning violinists"}
{"source": " If you are reading this wondering if you should consider buying this product to stop your tuning pegs from slipping, or to make them turn smoother and in less dramatic tuning jumps, the answer is yes"}
{"source": " Buy this, it does work, and it works very well"}
{"source": "Even though the instructions said to put a drop on two different places on each peg, I wanted to go light just in case, so at first I only put 1 drop on each peg"}
{"source": " I didn't know what to expect and you can always put more on, but too much could be a bad thing"}
{"source": " Also, each instrument is different, each peg is different"}
{"source": " I had one very stubborn peg, while the others were just the normal level of obnoxious about slipping"}
{"source": " You may only need 1 drop on some pegs and the reccomended 2 drops on the others"}
{"source": " I had new strings on, which of course are going to take forever to stretch out and will need constant tuning"}
{"source": " I did not remove the strings, I just loosened the pegs a little and pulled them out a tiny bit, one at a time, then put the first drop on the spot where the peg would make contact when put back in (on the tuning head side of the peg, the part you actually turn)"}
{"source": " I put the 2nd small drop on the dead end of the peg (not the end you turn)"}
{"source": " Be careful when applying that you don't get more than 1 small drop at a time"}
{"source": " This stuff spreads out over time, a tiny drop goes a long way"}
{"source": " One bottle should last you a very long time"}
{"source": "What to expect: With one drop the effect is immediate"}
{"source": " You will notice the pegs turn smoother and hold their position much better"}
{"source": " After playing for awhile I decided to put a 2nd drop on each peg (as suggested by the included instruction sheet)"}
{"source": " This helped them all to stay in place even better than before"}
{"source": " The pegs now also turn smoother and easier and I can tune much easier than before, in smaller more accurate adjustments, and the strings actually hold the tuning for much longer than before"}
{"source": "Great product"}

{"source": "Behringer makes quality products - I purchased the excellent C-1 Condenser Microphone, and replaced the 302usb with the Xenyx 802 mixer board"}
{"source": "When I researched items for a simple home recording setup, I saw all of the positive reviews for this smaller mixer, and read the item description here on Amazon and the Behringer website for the C-1 mic included what turned out to be a misleading statement about how it would work with any of the Behringer phantom-powered mixer boards"}
{"source": "That was incorrect information - this board receives power only via USB and doesn't provide adequate phantom power for condenser mics (48v)"}
{"source": "When I setup the return of this board to Amazon, I informed of the error, and the appear to have acted very promptly on it, as the item description for the C-1 on both websites now includes an explicit statement about the need for 48 volts"}

{"source": "This device works"}
{"source": "  Here's what it does"}
{"source": "  You plug an electric bass into the pedal's instrument input and then you can plug a second standard instrument cable into the pedal's high impedance output jack and then plug that one into a bass amp"}
{"source": "  You also can connect it to a low impedance microphone preamp via the 200 Ohm low impedance XLR jack out"}
{"source": "  You can use just the high-impedance output or just the XLR output or you can use them both simultaneously"}
{"source": "  When the \"footswitch\" is off it functions transparently with no tonal modification at all just like a direct box"}
{"source": "  When the \"footswitch\" is on an LED light activates and the tonal boost and tube emulation functions are on"}
{"source": "  I put \"footswitch\" in quotes because I use fingers to push it, but leave it on all the time for my personal purpose"}
{"source": "  When you insert a plug into the instrument input jack the unit powers on, so if running on battery be sure to unplug the input when not actually using it"}
{"source": "Some other functional comments about it"}
{"source": "  It runs on 9 volt batteries or a 9-volt power supply"}
{"source": " I used batteries for a while but switched to an ac adapter"}
{"source": "  Battery life isn't super but satisfactory"}
{"source": "  Still if using it a lot, I suggest using an AC adapter"}
{"source": "  When the battery starts going it sounds awful, but you could put it into bypass mode to finish the set"}
{"source": "  Also when the \"footswitch\" is off and the LED is not lit, this thing functions as a straight XLR ouput direct box for anything you plug into it"}
{"source": "  You could patch the output of an acoustic electric guitar or the output of an electric guitar pedal board to it and use that to feed a mixer for recording direct which is a very handy feature for the home recording hobbyist!  The amp emulation and tone controls are wrong for anything other than electric bass, so just use it as a direct box with the tone/emulation circuit off for anything except bass"}
{"source": "The controls are all rotary knobs except the Ground-Lift switch which is a slide switch"}
{"source": " The controls left to right, top row to second row are:  DRIVE, TREBLE, BASS, LEVEL, PRESENCE, GROUND LIFT SLIDE SWITCH and BLEND"}
{"source": "Taking each control one at a time to understand what they do is important because they are not all logically placed"}
{"source": "  The DRIVE knob adjusts the amount of gain similar to cranking the input stage control of the tube preamp and here is where you can get something like the tonal thickness (or edge) of overdriven tube tone"}
{"source": "  Basically this part of the circuit injects variable harmonics and some of the more pleasing distortion out there for this purpose"}
{"source": "  There is no ACTIVE/PASSIVE pad switch or extra active input jack on this pedal so if you have an active bass then you will not have to turn the drive knob up as much to get the tone you want"}
{"source": "  The TREBLE knob is a + or - 12db boost and cut of upper frequency tones"}
{"source": "  The BASS knob is a + or - 12db boost and cut of the lower frequencies"}
{"source": "  12 o'clock is flat (or zero db boost or cut) on both the treble and bass knobs"}
{"source": " The LEVEL knob is the master volume control and all it does is control the output volume with no tonal coloration"}
{"source": "  The PRESENCE knob boosts the upper frequency range harmonic content for more attack in your tone"}
{"source": "  The Presence knob isn't a midrange control, but does boost the upper mids"}
{"source": "  The GROUND LIFT switch only effects the XLR output jack and it should be left \"OFF\" unless you hook it up and there is hum"}
{"source": "  Then you can turn the Ground Lift \"ON\" and it might help eliminate the hum issue"}
{"source": "  However it is better from a safety standpoint to remedy this by eliminating the electrical ground loop conflict that is causing the hum"}
{"source": "  The BLEND knob controls the amount of tube emulation injected into the pedal's output with all the way to the left being none, 12 o'clock being 50% and all the way clockwise being 100%"}
{"source": "CONS:  Very little bass gear, or anything else, is \"PERFECT\" these days"}
{"source": "  Behringer gear has more build issues in general across most of their product line because using Chinese parts and labor is how they keep costs down"}
{"source": "  Designed in Germany but built in China means you get Chinese components and Chinese build quality while the specs look pretty enticing"}
{"source": "  For example at the first battery change the battery clip self-destructed as part of the clip's terminal stayed stuck to the battery having pulled completely out of the clip"}
{"source": "  This was a Duracell battery, the standard for pedal batteries"}
{"source": "  Went to Radio Shack and got replacement battery clips and fixed it with a new clip by soldering wires from the new clip to the stripped wires cut away from the old clip and taping up the solder joint"}
{"source": "  I've never used this as a stompbox because the switch looks like it will break if you lean on it hard"}
{"source": "  Construction is all plastic"}
{"source": " The casing is very durable but based on previous experience with plastic switches on stomp boxes I know not to use my size 13-D foot on it"}
{"source": "  The Treble and Presence knobs on mine will generate hiss and noise when set very high which may not be noticeable at all on a vintage type bass amp with no tweeter but becomes glaring when using a full range amp and cabinet or when using the XLR output for recording or a PA feed"}
{"source": "  Basically I set the Treble and Presence to the point where I hear hiss start, then back off until it goes completely away because that is the functional limit"}
{"source": "  Hiss is no issue in bypass mode because the preamp is off"}
{"source": "  The jacks, other than the XLR, are the plastic box jacks that are soldered direct to the circuit board of the pedal, These type jacks are noted for causing problems, especially after rough use so take it easy with them and they should last a very long time"}
{"source": "  This unit lacks any dedicated MIDRANGE knob but the Presence knob does seem to boost upper mids and treble simultaneously"}
{"source": "  Some people who use this pedal as a stage-tool use it as a solo or \"scoop\" switch for slap & tap solos so the presence, bass and treble boost are basically all you need for a solo switch anyway"}
{"source": "PROS:  First and foremost the price is almost too good to be true when you consider the price for anything else with similar features, but keep in mind that it has durability issues so be gentle with it and it will last indefinitely"}
{"source": "  This isn't a Tech 21 NYC Bass Driver by any means, but works in a similar fashion to one"}
{"source": "  I have a Tech 21 Bass Driver Deluxe that I use at gigs"}
{"source": "  The Tech 21 sounds better but costs about eight times what the Behringer cost"}
{"source": "  I use the Behringer at home and save that wear on my pedal board at home"}
{"source": "  If I didn't have the Tech 21 unit I might take this unit to gigs, but it probably will last way longer the way I keep it setup at home all the time"}
{"source": "  I especially like this unit when used with small rehearsal/practice type combos"}
{"source": "  Many of these smaller combos have passive type tone circuits that basically are at flat when the tone is cranked wide open and this device really makes these little amps sound more serious"}
{"source": "  Part of the beauty of an active bass is the tone boost capability you don't get in a passive bass and if you have a passive bass this can make it sound more like an active bass with the treble and bass boost in front of the amp"}
{"source": "  It is also useful for boosting a signal in front of a longer cable run to the backline, say anything over about 18 feet"}
{"source": "  For recording the XLR direct out is very useful and the XLR direct out can also be used to feed the PA at a gig if your amp doesn't have a XLR direct out"}
{"source": "How I use this device:  I have my bass guitar plugged into the input and use the XLR output to connect it to a microphone mixer"}
{"source": "  The output from microphone mixer is patched into a Turtle Beach Santa Cruz soundcard in an XP computer"}
{"source": " I can then record using the computer's recording software, practice solo or I can play along to recorded music using headphones"}
{"source": "  With headphones I can play as loud as I want anytime that I want without disturbing anyone"}
{"source": "  Most computer speakers are very inadequate for electric bass, so I recommend headphones instead of your typical desktop computer speakers"}
{"source": "  You can buy better computer speakers that are capable, but they will cost about the same or actually more than a decent bass guitar practice combo amp"}
{"source": "  Quality headphones cost far less than quality powered computer speakers that are bass guitar capable"}
{"source": "Having owned this pedal for about 4 years and knowing what I know about it, I would buy it again"}
{"source": "  I would strongly recommend it as a home recording/practice tool but my recommendation as a stage tool is not as strong"}
{"source": "  For home use it is fine"}

{"source": " You might be tempted to compare EZDrummer to its bigger and better brother: Superior Drummer 2"}
{"source": "0, made by the same company"}
{"source": " Superior Drummer is superior to EZDrummer, but is a little more tedious and more suitable for musicians who want an exact close-to-life sounding virtual instrument"}
{"source": "There are ways to improve the off-the-shelf sound quality of EZDrummer immediately"}
{"source": " YouTube has plenty of video tutorials on this, but what you want to do is open up your Digital Audio Workstation (Pro Tools, Cubase, etc), and set EZDrummer for multi-track output"}
{"source": " From there you'll be able to tweak the different outputs EZDrummer has as if you were in a studio and had 7 mics at your disposal"}
{"source": " Most high-end professional studios use about 10 mics to capture everything on a drum kit, and so 7 virtual mics is nothing to scoff at: Kick Drum, Snare Top and Bottom, Toms, Cymbals, Overhead, and Room"}
{"source": " Once you have each of those outputs running, you can perform individual EQs to change the tone dramatically"}
{"source": " Adding a touch of distortion/gain and room reverb will make the stock kit sound REALLY close-to-life"}
{"source": " In reality, once you have additional instruments layered and everything mixed and balanced, it only takes a trained ear to tell that it's a virtual kit"}

{"source": "When I first installed these tuners my guitar would still go out of tune"}
{"source": " Mainly the second to the last string at the bottom and I later learned it was the wrong tuner and the string tree was too blame"}
{"source": " Sometimes I just don't pay attention to the obvious;)It turned out that there are 3 short tuners and 3 long ones"}
{"source": " The long ones go on the top 3 strings, the short ones the bottom 3 strings, get that because I had them on incorrectly"}
{"source": " And even worse, I was using the string tree which is the part that holds down the 2 bottom strings"}
{"source": " The string tree(google guitar string tree and you'll see one) was actually making the strings not stay in tune with the locking tuners"}
{"source": " I know silly but I was not paying attention"}
{"source": "The reason you use the short tuners for the bottom is so the guitar will stay in tune! The string trees get in the way and when you whammy the strings go out of tune"}
{"source": " Please take a note of that"}
{"source": "Overall a good product"}
{"source": "i got two sets of these tunners, my jackson and fender guitars stay way better in tune now, i love them"}
{"source": "These locking tuners are perfect for any Strat or Tele"}
{"source": " I have an American Strat and an American Tele that both came with fairly decent non-locking tuners"}
{"source": " I also have a Carvin and two Paul Reed Smith guitars that came with locking tuners"}
{"source": "they are certainly worth having"}
{"source": " Fenders (at least American-made ones) are very easy to swap out tuners for these"}
{"source": "the holes are already there, there's no need to drill holes for screws, everything is so easy you have to do it yourself"}
{"source": " I've swapped out the tuners and have never looked back"}
{"source": "the only question is what to do with the non-locking Fender tuners I have now!"}

{"source": " the pegs line up, so they drop right in"}
{"source": " Remember "}
{"source": " the E-A-D are that tall capstans and the G-B-E are the shorter capstans "}
{"source": " it all works out"}

{"source": " The amp knobs they use get in the way of the tremelo bar"}

{"source": "Excellent product at a righteous price"}
{"source": " Helps my guitar stay in tune"}
{"source": "Changed the saddles at the same time and the sustain is much better"}
{"source": "SUMMARYIf you aren't using locking tuners, you're wasting time when you restring"}
{"source": " They are just faster and easier"}
{"source": " Overall, this is a really nice convenience upgrade on guitars and it's not very expensive to do"}
{"source": " Fender uses these on the American Deluxe, and once I got one, I had to have these on the rest of my stratocasters"}
{"source": " Because they save time restringing, you are more inclined to restring frequently, which means you sound better"}
{"source": " (Fresh strings can do a lot for your sound!)I've put these on several guitars I have, and always appreciate them when changing strings"}
{"source": " At instalation be aware these are staggered height tuners so be sure to put them in the correct holes (see below)"}
{"source": " These are drop in replacement tuners for most modern MIA and MIM Fender Stratocasters and Telecasters that use a Shaller style tuner"}
{"source": " Fender makes these relatively cheap now in chrome, although I wish they would make them affordable and available in a gold finish"}
{"source": " I've seen also seen nickel and black, and they make gold but hard to find and rather expensive (something like $120 a set)"}
{"source": "FUNCTION/PURPOSEI think people believe these somehow give you more stable tuning or something but that is actually not their purpose"}
{"source": " Proper use of a traditional non-locking tuner is just as stable"}
{"source": " Some folks don't actually understand how to properly use traditional tuners and they don't get stable tuning as a result because they use too few or too many wraps and don't string it correctly"}
{"source": " For those folks, these will elimiate the resulting \"pings\" and such"}
{"source": " But their intended purpose is to speed string changes"}
{"source": " I believe that some folks confuse locking tuners with a locking nut in that respect"}
{"source": " A locking nut quite definitely makes for more stable tuning, and that's why you always find them with Floyd Rose tremolos which are made for dive bombing"}
{"source": " But locking tuners are not really for that purpose"}
{"source": "FIT AND INSTALLATIONRegarding fit, these have 2 little pins on the backside"}
{"source": " If you are considering a replacement, make sure you get tuners that are the right size and configuration for your guitar so you don't have to drill the back of the neck, the tuner bores in the headstock, or use inserts"}
{"source": " If you want to use these but don't have the little alignment holes, Stewart Macdonald makes a small drilling jig for drilling those holes"}
{"source": " It's expensive (about $40) but not as expensive as messing up your neck or breaking the tuners when you tighten them down on ill fitting mounts"}
{"source": " It is nearly impossible to drill those alignment pin holes correctly without a jig, and even with the jig, easy to be slightly off"}
{"source": " These fit most newer FENDER stratocasters and tele's, both american and MIM and will be a drop in replacement with no muss and no fuss in most of those cases"}
{"source": "Pull one of your existing tuners out and look at it before you change"}
{"source": " If you have a squier or a knockoff you may want to measure the headstock bore and remove a tuner to look at the back mount"}
{"source": " Maybe buy and inspect, with the knowledge you might have to return them"}
{"source": " There is usually an exact fit drop in replacement locking tuner that can replace your standard tuner so if this isn't it, look for one in the same brand as what is on your guitar now"}
{"source": " Be aware different tuners also have slightly different holes bored for the main peg hole"}
{"source": "Typical neck bores for tuners (by brand) are shown on the warmoth site at ["}
{"source": "]These are the holes that warmoth uses on custom necks when fitting tuners of various brands:- For Fender/Shaller tuners, its a two step bore, with the main portion being 25/64\" and the rest at 11/32\""}
{"source": "- Vintage style tuners use 11/32\"- Gotoh and Grover use a two step 13/32\" to 11/32\"- Sperzel uses 25/64\"- Planet waves uses 13/32\"Of course, if you are mechnically inclined, have the tools, and don't mind potentially drilling additional holes in your neck, you can almost fit any tuner you want on any guitar"}
{"source": " Sometimes that means using inserts or bushings, or drilling a hole for a tiny backmount screw, or for alignment pins in different locations"}
{"source": "but the best answer is to use a tuner that is a drop-in replacement"}
{"source": "When installing, be sure to look at the height of the pegs on your old and these new tuners"}
{"source": " These are not all the same length -- they have staggered heights - 3 long and 3 shorter"}
{"source": " (I think I have also seen some sets that are 4/2 but these are 3/3"}
{"source": ") Put the long ones in the E-A-D string holes, and the shorter ones in the G-B-HighE holes"}
{"source": "These replaced the stock tuners on my Squier Deluxe Stratocaster and were NOT a drop in fit"}
{"source": " There are two pegs on the tuners that didn't line up with the holes from my stock tuners in the headstock and required me to drill additional holes"}
{"source": " I was somewhat expecting this thou so no starts taken away"}
{"source": "These make string changes so easy and I love the ratio of these tuners"}
{"source": " Because they are staggered I was able to ditch the string trees as well"}
{"source": "Unfortunately, these tuners require drilling to fit my Squier Strat"}
{"source": "They look very similar but the two pins are approximately 1/16th of an inch further out from the shaft so I'm going to have to drill new holes in the headstock to use them"}
{"source": " Worse, the holes will actually touch the edge of the existing stock holes so, I'm going to have to fill them, first"}
{"source": "The quality of the locking tuners looks great!I only wish that they'd show a diagram with the specs written on it so that I could have known that these don't fit my guitar!"}
{"source": "Now all I have to do is install these on my Burswood Strat Copy"}
{"source": " I know I'm gonna have to drill holes for the locating pins I may even have to drill the tuner holes also"}
{"source": " Look forward to getting those crappy, loose, un-smooth, original hardware tuners off this thing"}
{"source": "July 20, 2012:Just installed these Fender locking tuners on my Strat"}
{"source": " Didn't have to drill the tuner holes, they were the perfect size"}
{"source": " Placed all the tuners in the headstock lined them up with a straight edge and just pressed each tuner very firmly into their hole (with the locking part screwed in tight so as not to damage them) and  very lightly and carefully tapped them with a small rubber mallet to mark my drill points"}
{"source": " Then with a small magnifying glass and using a punch I made a center punch mark (just using pressure by hand with the punch since wood is soft) on each indent that the tuner made"}
{"source": " Set my drill depth with a piece of tape on the drill and was done in less than 15 minutes"}

{"source": "  At higher volumes one has to take care with the equalizer to reduce bass and midrange, and also use the anti-feedback button, to avoid a \"muddy\" sound from too much (distorted?) bass"}

{"source": "  It just so happens that it's a functioning amplifier you can plug into and practice with also?  The component actually used to make the amplifier are cheap, yet are put together in a convincing way"}

{"source": "  The \"grill cloth\" over the speakers is a nice facade for the hard plastic facing that protects the speakers"}
{"source": "  Actually, while the amp is cheap, it's also fairly durable"}
{"source": "  In fact, I just dumped it off my desk reaching over to write this review, and it seems to be working fine"}
{"source": "  (Phew!)  It should also be noted that this amp is powered either by a 9V battery or a 9V DC adapter (a BOSS pedal supply adapter will work, for example)"}
{"source": "  While the battery option is obviously nice for portability, the red \"ON\" light seemed noticeably dimmer with 9V's, and I can't say how long the battery will last"}
{"source": "  If you plan to have it in one place most of the time, the adapter is the preferred way to go"}
{"source": "SOUND - The concept of this amp is pretty ridiculous if you think about it - a one watt output with TWIN 2\" speakers"}
{"source": "  Given that each speaker is smaller than the \"tweeter\" on a large stereo speaker, you won't be surprised at all to hear that there's virtually no bass in the sound"}
{"source": "  It sounds like a poor 10W solid state amp, only shrunk down to a few inches"}
{"source": "  At the same time, that's kind of a remarkable feat for a miniature amplifier, and it puts out a fair amount of sound"}
{"source": "  I opted for the Mini Tone Master over some other options because it actually has a fair range of tones"}
{"source": "  Low Gain/High Volume produces pretty good clean tones, and with humbuckers and the gain turned up, it can get a bit raunchy"}
{"source": "  Unfortunately, the tone control either does nothing, or behaves completely irrationally"}
{"source": "  I haven't figured out which yet"}
{"source": "  I had it at \"5\" most of the time, but it didn't seem to cut much treble as I turned it up"}
{"source": "  Actually, it got the brightest around \"7\", and then almost became more muffled beyond that"}
{"source": "  But again, for a $40 mini amp, my expectations were not that much to begin with"}
{"source": "  I do like the four knobs, and the decision to make the power knob the same size as the other knobs was a subtle touch that prevents the cheaper feel of an on-off flat toy switch"}
{"source": "I expected the speaker to overdrive/break up if you pushed it too hard, and not in a \"tube-like\" manner"}
{"source": "  That wasn't necessarily the case, but there are other problems"}
{"source": "  Something internally rattles after the volume goes above \"4\", and it's not the speaker being overpowered"}
{"source": "  This is a common issue with cheap amps, and I might even pop it open to see what is rattling around"}
{"source": "  And the sound quality isn't objectively \"good\" by any means, but it is good enough to play amplified electric guitar and to hear the basic characteristics of your instrument and playing style"}
{"source": "ALTERNATIVES - The primary reason I rated this 4* instead of 5* really isn't any of the issues above (I am happy with the amp), but it's limited usefulness compared to the many alternatives for home/quiet practicing"}
{"source": "  My favorite of these, by far, are the Vox Amplugs, which are headphone jacks stylized after different famous amplifiers"}
{"source": "  The sound quality those things pump into your headphones is of far greater quality (and volume/fullness) than anything this mini amp could do"}
{"source": "  Also, they are offered at $40 or $50, so it's simply a better value"}
{"source": "  Another alternative is to plug into a smartphone and practice with software"}
{"source": "  While sound quality and volume are often a problem with smartphone apps, the possibilities for effects, modeling, and recording are endless"}
{"source": "If you think about recent improvements in small size Bluetooth speakers, you realize that the sound quality on a device of this size could be far better than what the Mini Tone Master offers"}
{"source": "  At the same time, those speakers can cost up to $200, and premium sound quality was never the point of this amp"}
{"source": "  Your opinion of it will depend on your expectations, but if you don't take it too seriously, it's a cool little device"}

{"source": "This Sam SP01 can be easily modded for use with the Oktava MK319"}
{"source": " I found instructions through a google search"}
{"source": " The metal piece on the bottom of the mic holder must be removed"}
{"source": " Instead of hammering it out, I used two screwdrivers to pry it out"}
{"source": " That leaves a nice hole which is just a little too small to use"}
{"source": " Using my dremel tool, I was able to enlarge the hole just a bit"}
{"source": " As a guide the piece you remove fits in a small groove"}
{"source": " You must file down the sides til the groove is almost not visible"}
{"source": " Then your Oktava will fit just fine"}
{"source": " This mod is not easily reversible so keep that in mind before starting"}

{"source": "com, I'll try to answer any questions you might have about the EHX Pocket Metal Muff Pedal"}
{"source": " This pedal is the model of simplicity; a volume control, a distortion control, and a switch that changes the amount (or lack thereof) of mid-scoop"}
{"source": " That's doesn't leave much room for tone tweaking, so \"tweakers\" beware! That being said, Electro-Harmonix did a commendable job of pre-setting useable treble and bass tone levels that should only require minor tweaking of your amp's eq to get it right where you want it"}
{"source": " Playing through my Fender hotrod deville amp, I was immediately shocked at how good this pedal sounded"}
{"source": " The bass was powerful and chunky, great for heavy metal palm-muting riffs; the treble had a good bite but it wasn't harsh; and all three midrange modes sounded great, depending on the application: Want just a flat midrange for a punchy tone? Just leave the mid-switch on the flat setting"}
{"source": " Want a slightly scooped midrange tone for a good all-round metal tone? Move the switch down to the low mid-scoop mode"}
{"source": " Do you want to play Master of Puppets by Metallica? The high mid-scoop mode is calling your name"}
{"source": " This pedal offers quite a bit of distortion, but I was amazed to find that even at the higher distortion levels, my tone remained clear and defined"}
{"source": " It didn't turn into a plastic-y, fuzzy mess like most distortion pedals *cough* metal zone *cough* will"}
{"source": " I will mention that this pedal isn't the best if you're looking for a more modern metal tone"}
{"source": " You won't get a slightly fizzy, ultra-gain (think Slipknot) sound out of this pedal"}
{"source": " Rather it offers a very crunchy, defined roar more characteristic of the pre-dual rectifier mesa boogie amplifiers"}
{"source": "In conclusion, I give this pedal 5 stars because it does what its designed to do very well; this version of the metal muff line isn't designed to be highly versatile and \"tweakable\" in and of itself; get the metal muff with top boost pedal if you want a 3-band eq and a boost function"}
{"source": " This pedal is designed to be a very simple, small box of pure classic metal tone, and that's exactly what it accomplishes"}
{"source": "Within just three seconds of using the Electro-Harmonix Pocket Metal Muff Pedal, I knew it was a winner"}
{"source": " It delivers thermonuclear distortion and is ultra-easy to use"}
{"source": " Although it doesn't have a tone dial, it doesn't need one"}
{"source": " And I say that after trying it through a small tube amp (15w), a small digital amp (40w), a guitar with humbuckers, and a guitar with single-coil pickups"}
{"source": " The closest it has to a tone dial is the scoop switch just above the on/off switch"}
{"source": " As its name suggests, this allows one to choose how much the mid tones will be \"scooped"}
{"source": "\" It has three settings (no scoop to maximal scoop), and all sound great"}
{"source": " Fans of sustain will love this box, for it delivers seemingly everlasting sustain"}
{"source": " The pedal is extremely small, which most would regard as a plus"}
{"source": " I bought this after watching a professional-looking YouTube demonstration of it"}
{"source": " It more than lived up to my expectations"}

{"source": " and even my bass"}

{"source": " and do NOT expect 2 instruments to sound perfect together, but for indoor practicing and intimate small crowds, this amp will impress you"}
{"source": " Every musician should have one of these around"}
{"source": " Money well spent!"}
{"source": "Hearing ourselves the way we sound to others is of the essence in music"}
{"source": " This small, acoustic Behringer Ultracoustic AT108 amplifier gives the musician/singer the needed outside feedback to get things sounding right"}
{"source": "No one hears themselves the way they sound to others"}
{"source": " This simple reality must be understood and somehow corrected for by anyone recording music"}
{"source": " This is why performers in the studio wear headphones while recording and why a small acoustic amplifier is a necessary piece of gear for an acoustic guitar playing, singing song writer"}
{"source": " The Behringer Ultracoustic AT108 acoustic amplifier more than does the job"}
{"source": "As the owner of eight completely acoustic guitars, I thought a lot for years about trying amplification"}
{"source": " I probably never hesitated with ambivalence about any other purchase in my life"}
{"source": " Much to my delight, together with a passive, inexpensive hole-mounted pick-up (the Seymour Duncan SA3SC Woody) , an inexpensive Audio- Technica vocal microphone and this Behringer AT108, I can hear a fullness and richness that actually makes good instruments sound even better!At least as importantly, it allows me to hear myself more the way I am heard by others who will not hear me, as I do in part, from the resonations inside my skull"}
{"source": "One of the most universal and predictably shocking experiences anyone who records their own voice is struck by is how different it sounds when recorded than it does when they are singing or speaking it"}
{"source": " The mechanics of this ubiquitous situation are not difficult to fathom"}
{"source": "To hear what those listening hear, you have to arrange things so as to hear the sound coming TO you, not FROM you"}
{"source": " That is where an amplifier comes in handy"}
{"source": " It aims your own sound back at you so you can hear something a lot closer to what an audience would hear"}
{"source": "When we 'hear' ourselves without any external amplification or direct audio feedback, we are 'hearing' a combination of the sounds being processed through our ears as well as those vibrations and sounds that are created by the vibrations in our heads"}
{"source": " The people who hear us, only hear us through their ears"}
{"source": " The two experiences are not the same"}
{"source": "To discover how we really sound to others, we can go about it two ways"}
{"source": " First, we can go ahead and record ourselves then listen and be astounded at how different we sound from how we thought we were sounding while recording, or we can put our practice through electronics - either through an external amplifier or through headphones, so that we can hear ourselves more closely to the way we will be heard by others"}
{"source": "As an acoustic guitar player, I recently invested in a small, specifically acoustic amplifier, the Behringer Ultracoustic AT108, and have found the results to be simply astounding as I can now, for the first time, practice my songs until they sound the way I would like them to sound to others before recording them"}
{"source": "For a small amplifier that successfully replicates, electronically, the deep richness of an old tube acoustic amplifier, this Behringer AT108 provides amply volume for both the instrument and separate input voice, along with a three section equalizer, to provide the self-accompanying guitarist with the sound of what s/he really sound like to others"}
{"source": " It can, initially, be a rather shocking experience!Technically, this AT108 is at the low end of the famous Behringer line"}
{"source": " Although the company is based in Germany, this box is built in China to their specifications"}
{"source": " Solidly built and encased in a brown vinyl wrapping, it sports:- 15 Watts of Power amp output,- An 8\" dual-cone full-range loudspeaker with 4 Ohm impedance and a powerrating of 20 Watts,- Inputs for an instrument (1/4\" TS mono connector,) a microphone ( BalancedXLR) and for CDs (1/4\" TRS stereo connector,)- A headphone output connector ( 1/4\" TRS stereo connector, and- Three (Low, Mid and High Range) frequency controllers"}
{"source": "The unit measures approximately 13 X 14 X 7 inches, weighs just over 11 pounds and is easily portable"}
{"source": " It comes delivered with 13 feet of instrument ready plug-in cabling"}
{"source": "Finally, to answer a question I had that caused me to hesitate for years before buying a small acoustic amp, it does NOT make an acoustic guitar sound, in any way, like an electric guitar"}
{"source": " The sound is that of a deepened and amplified acoustic"}
{"source": " The natural tones are enhanced, not rendered tinny or 'electrified"}
{"source": "'It is at home in a room when you are alone practicing or on a stage in a small venue"}
{"source": " The 15 amps pack a wallop and it can blast pretty loudly for its petite and easily portable configuration"}
{"source": "At a current on line retail of somewhere between $75 - $95, an entire enhanced world of acoustic playing, practicing and listening is now open to me"}
{"source": " The Behringer AT108 just might turn out to be one of the smartest investments I have ever made on behalf of my acoustic guitar playing, singing and recording"}
{"source": "I have played, listened to, and used audio amps for over 4 decades, and while I haven't owned every name brand amp on the planet, I do know my way around them well enough to spot a good deal when I see one"}
{"source": " This is a nice little practice amp for electrified acoustic guitar, with an input for a mic (XLR - no phantom power) and a CD player or other audio source"}
{"source": " It also has a headphone output (1/4 inch)"}

{"source": " of American-produced materials (unlike silk and steel strings by a famous American guitar company whose name starts with \"M,\" which are assembled south of the border); (2) on the negative side, they cost more than M-----'s silk and steel strings; (3) in general, silk and steel strings squeak more on position changes than straight steel strings, especially more than flat-wound acoustic strings; (4) the tone is very nice and mellow, sort of a cross between flat-wound steel strings and nylon strings; (5) the D'Addario folk set is very easy on the fingers and therefore are ideal if you play a lot, or if you primarily play a fairly light gauge electric string and only acoustic on occasion; (6) they really work best for finger picking (whatever you do, don't use metal finger picks), and are less effective than steel strings for flat picking"}

{"source": "The Boss AC-3 is a serviceable acoustic simulator"}

{"source": " The AC3 does that job"}
{"source": " Although it has several modes, the Jumbo mode seems to be most useful"}
{"source": " Played through a carefully EQ'd amp, you can get a tone comparable to a plugged in acoustic electric with very bright settings"}
{"source": " There is an audible hiss, less noticeable plugged direct into PA, noticeable plugged into a good, clean tube amp, out of control with humbuckers or solid states"}
{"source": "The key to using this pedal is using it correctly"}
{"source": "First and foremost: use single coils"}
{"source": " Tested with a Les Paul with Burstbucker Pro's, the hiss was overwhelming"}
{"source": " Played with an American Deluxe Strat with N3 Noiseless pups in the 3rd position, it actually performed very well on a crystal clean channel"}
{"source": "Point two - any form of gain will create a ton of hiss"}
{"source": "Point three - tube amps perform infinitely better than solid state amps (tested through a Frontman 212 and Vox Pathfinder vs an Orange Tiny Terror and Fender HRD)"}
{"source": "The AC3 is not a set it and forget it pedal"}
{"source": " Based on the volume of the amp and the room you're in, you will need to tweek the EQ to find that tone"}
{"source": " I've read that you can use an EQ pedal to get the same tones, I haven't found that to be the case"}
{"source": " If your use for this pedal is to cover acoustic parts in a pinch, or in my case as the only guitar player, to switch from acoustic to electric parts quickly, this is a great fit"}

{"source": "I own two Hercules GS302B stands for my electric guitars, and I couldn't be happier with them"}
{"source": " When I needed an acoustic stand I turned to the Hercules GS301B and have no regrets"}
{"source": " At the forefront of my purchasing decision was the safety of my guitars"}
{"source": " Not only do stands have to hold guitars securely, they shouldn't harm the finishes of the instrument"}
{"source": " Unfortunately many stands will harm the nitrocellulose lacquer on many higher-end guitars; since I have two guitars of this nature, protecting them was of the utmost import to me"}
{"source": " Fortunately these stands protect most nitrocellulose finishes, and I have never had problems with mine"}
{"source": " The stands themselves (both varieties) fold up to be very compact if you need portability, and support the guitar very securely"}
{"source": " I don't gig with these guitars, so portability was not paramount to me, but stability was: these stands are extremely stable and are very sturdy (mine reside on a carpeted floor, and I have never had any issues with them tipping over"}
{"source": ") Some people may not love the yellow and black \"bumble bee\" coloration, but I actually find it whimsically industrial"}

{"source": " If I need another guitar stand, it's a good bet I will buy another Hercules"}

{"source": " Just pop it open"}

{"source": "The Behringer UCG102 device is an aging (yet affordable) piece of hardware that offers the intriguing option of plugging your guitar directly into the USB port of a computer"}
{"source": "  This opens up a number of possibilities for recording or simply for playing with headphones"}
{"source": "  For the budget player, it could be argued that a mere $32 investment unlocks a world of free amp modeling and recording possibilities"}
{"source": "However, while the actual hardware is compact and seems function properly, there are some significant problems here"}
{"source": "  First and foremost, there is the problem of getting the device to work, getting the software to recognize it, and configuring it to run without significant \"latency\" (which is a delay effect where you don't hear a played note immediately when it's played, which can make monitoring anywhere from frustrating to impossible)"}
{"source": "  The UCG102 runs on an ASIO driver"}
{"source": "  They include an older version with the software, and you can snoop around online and find other options"}
{"source": "  But that doesn't mean it will necessarily work with your software, or work well if it does"}
{"source": "  For example, Audacity is a popular \"freeware\" program you can use to record and mix audio files on the computer"}
{"source": "  I've been told that Audacity doesn't work with ASIO drivers, and when I got it to record, the latency issues rendered it unusable"}
{"source": "You do receive two other software options with the device"}
{"source": "  The first is energyXT2, which I believe includes a license for the compact version"}
{"source": "  In theory, this program should work like Audacity and contains a number of amp models and effects, in addition to drum and bass track loops"}
{"source": "  However, I have had little luck figuring out how to monitor and record with this program"}
{"source": "  I'm sure it CAN work, but if you need a computer science degree to figure it out, that's really not ideal for a budget product"}
{"source": "The second item is a trial disc with Guitar Combos by Native Instruments"}
{"source": "  So far, this has been the most impressive of the options offered"}
{"source": "  You can demo three different amp simulators (Vox, Fender, and Marshall) and then enter a code to unlock one of the three"}
{"source": "  I like that it gives you an interface similar to a real guitar amp, which allows you to dial in some realistic tones"}
{"source": "  It's also the only program I've been able to get the headphone jack to play through both ears in (there are problems with recognizing mono vs"}
{"source": " stereo)"}
{"source": "  I adjusted the sound quality to get latency down to 8 miliseconds, which is just into the range where I don't notice it as a problem"}
{"source": "  Still, while the models sound good, I'm not sure how often I would bother plugging into my computer just to do basic playing and recording"}
{"source": "Shortly after ordering this device, I discovered that my sound card has a blue \"line in\" audio jack on the back"}
{"source": "  By running a simple 1/8\" to 1/4\" audio cable from my pedal board to the sound card, I can do direct recording, which is monitored through my computer speakers (no latency) and sounds great"}
{"source": "  Even better, this method works through Audacity and allows me to record and layer tracks"}
{"source": "  If the UCG102 worked as advertised, it would be a more convenient way of doing this, but I simply can't recommend it for most people"}
{"source": "  I feel like there's \"4-star\" potential somewhere in this device, but I doubt I'll ever have the patience to unlock it"}
{"source": "  3 stars"}
{"source": "I thought I was buying the 10 footer and realize I ordered the 5 footer too late"}

{"source": "The manufacturer has done a good job on this cable, but the user is responsible for two things (this addresses complaints I see in other reviews):1) Take care of your cables"}
{"source": " The right angle plug side is much stronger than the straight plug side; this is by design"}
{"source": " Take good care of your cables and it should last you quite a long time"}
{"source": " This includes taking the time to store them for use"}
{"source": "2) Make sure you know what length you need for a cable"}
{"source": " The shorter the cable, the better for studio use"}
{"source": " It reduces signal travel time and potential for interference (though these cables are shielded so the latter concern is moot)"}
{"source": " If you need a longer cable, buy a longer cable"}
{"source": " Don't buy what is advertised as 5' cable and then write a negative review when you really needed a 15' cable"}

{"source": "CONS:  There's a learning curve and you will need the manual to know stuff like how to change amp models; manual is a pdf file; hard to keep track of preset tones on the unit (though you can rename and re-arrange them with the software); presets based on famous songs don't always sound right; minor background hum; uses 4 AAA's in a few hours and the manual says don't use rechargables (though it doesn't say why); for legal reasons, the unit uses generic amp names (check the manual to match the amp model names to the amps they're based on); with everything plugged in the whole setup becomes a little unwieldy; doesn't sound as nice as a good pedal and a Marshall half stack (no kidding, right? {"source": "- Like most pedals - the knobs are super small and not easily controlled with a toe, and the settings are hard to see"}
{"source": " My favorite pedals have large knobs, well marked settings you can see from a distance, enough space between the knobs to set one without bumping another, and in the best cases, enough space, size, and durability for the knobs to be tweakable by a foot or toe bump"}
{"source": "Suggested Redesign, \"Super Vibrato\" or \"Vibrato II\"1) Change to a metal case2) Lose the Rise control altogether3) put the latched/unlatched modes on a 2nd stomp switch so you can stomp to go between modes4) Increase the size of and space between the other two controls -- put large \"foot controllable\" knobs with high visibility knobs"}

{"source": " Back and sides are cherry with only a light stain, and the binding is dark"}
{"source": " The top is natural cedar"}
{"source": "As dreadnoughts go, this one is very comfortable to play sitting down"}
{"source": " It appears to be based on the Martin outline, but with a slightly rounder lower bout and a narrower upper bout"}
{"source": " Weight is pleasantly light, and the semi-gloss finish is comfortable to the touch"}
{"source": " Players with broad fingers will appreciate the wide fingerboard, but those with small hands should consider the \"\"Slim\" version, with a neck 0"}
{"source": "08\" narrower at the nut"}
{"source": "Sound is what really counts, however, and this Canadian dreadnought has nothing to be ashamed of there"}
{"source": " The maker has the good sense to ship the instrument with high-quality, fresh strings, allowing the new owner to appreciate the notable bass and clear midrange as soon as it is tuned up"}
{"source": " Overall, it falls within the classic dreadnought tone category, with good volume"}
{"source": "Buying a guitar online saves money but leaves setup to the buyer"}

{"source": "  It's a compromise between a more standard acoustic neck width and a classical guitar neck width"}

{"source": "  Some players who are more used to a more traditionally narrow neck might not appreciate this attribute of the guitar"}

{"source": "When I purchased this pedal from a local music store I wasn't even looking for a double pedal set, but for a replacement for the pedal that came with my Tama Stagestar kit"}
{"source": "  During my quest for a pedal that had the feel I wanted I sat behind a Pacific drum kit that had these pedals"}
{"source": " At first I ignored the second bass pedal and played a bit with just the right pedal and hi-hat"}
{"source": "  I liked the feel of the right pedal and was about to ask if the store had it in a single pedal configuration when I decided to see what it was like playing double"}
{"source": " Wow - it immediately expanded my range and opened up a plethora of possibilities"}
{"source": "This pedal is nearly infinitely adjustable, especially cam rotation, spring tension, and beater offset"}
{"source": "  Most of the adjustments require a hex wrench, which is fairly standard for most modern single and double pedals"}
{"source": " The left side slave pedal has a full floorplate, and the linkage rod that connects the right and left pedals will not bind at any angle I have tried"}
{"source": "  There is a slight lag on the left pedal, which is normal for any double pedal configuration, but you'll quickly compensate for that as you get used to a double pedal if you are moving from a single pedal"}
{"source": "Before I purchased this particular model I tried out Tama's Iron Cobra, Pearl's Powershifter and a Gilbralter Avenger"}
{"source": "  I did not like the stiffness of the Iron Cobra, but did like the Pearl and Gibraltar pedals"}
{"source": "  It finally came down to either this or the Gibralter, which was slightly smoother, but significantly more expensive"}
{"source": "  I opted for best value without sacrificing performance or quality and am thrilled with this pedal"}
{"source": "If you are moving from a single to double pedal configuration I strongly recommend that you give this one a serious look"}
{"source": "  More importantly, try out this pedal in a local store and compare it to other double models - selecting a bass pedal is a personal decision with many more factors than price, features and quality"}
{"source": "  It has to feel right"}
{"source": "  In addition, you will find that you will be using the double bass more than your hi-hat, which means that you will need to compensate"}
{"source": "  For that I recommend the Gibraltar hi-hat drop clutch (ASIN B0002F73YY), which will allow you to engage and disengage your hi-hat with ease"}
{"source": "  I have my hi-hats set for a slight opening in the normal closed position, but stepping on the hi-hat pedal - using the clutch - puts it in full play position"}
{"source": "  Tapping the lever on the clutch closes them again"}
{"source": "  This clutch is a perfect companion to a double bass pedal!"}

{"source": " Both are great"}
{"source": "First off, this is a great, classic pedal that has shaped the tones of rock and blues artists all over the musical map"}
{"source": "  It's actually a reissue of the pedals Ibanez made in the 1980's, though there's some debate over whether or not  the modern circuitry retains all of that original tone"}
{"source": "  In my opinion, unless you're being purposefully picky or have the most elite of trained ears, you would never be able to tell the difference"}
{"source": "  The construction is sturdy (metal and actually heavier-feeling than a BOSS pedal)"}
{"source": "  The LED light, for some reason, is difficult to see from an angle, but that's largely an irrelevant gripe"}
{"source": "But let's be clear what a \"Tube Overdrive\" pedal is and isn't"}
{"source": "  This is NOT a distortion petal like the Boss DS-1 or Metal Zone (MT-2)"}
{"source": "  It is also not a \"fuzz\" pedal like you would hear on a Jimi Hendrix song"}
{"source": "  It is not meant for heavy rock/metal/grunge type music"}
{"source": "  If you need heavy distortion to mask sloppy playing, the TS9 is not for you"}
{"source": "What it DOES do, however, is to boost the signal at the front end, which essentially results in a more dynamic done with additional gain"}
{"source": "  This can result in a very midrange-heavy \"blues\" tone (Stevie Ray Vaughan used it quite a bit), or even a nice \"crunch\" overdrive tone (AC/DC) for rhythm work"}
{"source": "  Some guitars use it simply to boost their signal without adding a bunch of additional gain"}
{"source": "  It also works well with other distortion pedals for that purpose"}
{"source": "Long story short - the Ibanez TS9 Tubescreamer really is one of the more versatile pedals you will use - just don't expect it to create every range of sounds you need right out of the box"}
{"source": "  For a cheaper alternative, consider Digitech's surprisingly good \"Bad Monkey\" overdrive pedal, which is half the price and gives you more control over tone"}
{"source": "  I've also compared this to BOSS's BD-2 Blues Driver, which is an excellent, but very different style of overdrive"}
{"source": "  (The BD-2 has a much hotter output and is more aggressive; the Tubescreamer is more subtle and works in the midrange while retaining your underlying clean tone and responding to picking style)"}
{"source": "  If you start with a good amp and guitar setup, the Tubescreamer will sound great"}
{"source": "  It won't completely transform your tone, but it will give your current tones a boost, make those solos really sing and those rhythm chords really crunch"}
{"source": "I bought this unit for a friend, and I could compare with others overdrives I already have"}
{"source": " I think the MXR Badass Custom Modified Overdrive or Way Huge Green Rhino are better choise"}
{"source": "I've owned a TS808 since I purchased it used in the 80s for around $20"}
{"source": "  Yes, this is a great overdrive"}
{"source": "  This pedal has many famous users and it has been used on many iconic recordings"}
{"source": "  Pair this with a strat and run it into an amp on the verge of breakup - now you're in tone heaven"}
{"source": "  But the plain truth is this:  there are tons of pedals out there now that do what this does - and they do it for a fraction of the cost of the 808 reissue"}
{"source": "  This was the original but by no means the last word in overdrives"}
{"source": "  I own a boatload of other dirt boxes and while this one is iconic it's not the most transparent or versatile"}
{"source": " There is a 'mid hump' in the EQ of this pedal that either sits well with what you are playing or it doesn't"}
{"source": "  I'm glad I own mine but I don't think I'd shell out what they are charging these days for the reissue"}
{"source": "  If I am not mistaken both the TS9 and the TS7 can be modded to this circuit with less than 25 cents in parts and about 15 minutes of your time"}
{"source": "  If this pedal came in under the $100 mark it would be more deserving of five stars"}
{"source": "  I really hate to burst anyone's bubble but SRV's tone was really in his fingers"}
{"source": "  And so is yours ;)"}
{"source": "Years ago I owned an original edition TS808; I loved that pedal and used it for years on stage"}
{"source": "  Eventually I sold it many years later, but I always missed that pedal, so I decided to give this reissue a try"}
{"source": " My verdict: Awesome - It sounds just like I remember"}
{"source": " The TS808 just has that 'certain something' that really brings out a nice smooth overdrive sound, especially when it's to enhance the overdrive sound you may already have"}
{"source": "I have only used one of these with a hybrid tube amp and a solid state but I hear that it will work with either tube or solid state amplifiers"}
{"source": " It really gives my amplifier a warm overdriven sound"}
{"source": " This pedal can be used to boost your guitar sound during solos or certain guitar parts"}
{"source": " This pedal has three preamp settings: Ts9, Hot, +, and Turbo"}
{"source": " It's great for solos and warm blues or rock rhythm guitar"}
{"source": " One nice thing about this is it responds well to how soft or hard you pluck the strings"}
{"source": " For example: if you set on the \"Turbo\" setting and pick with your fingers it will clean up nicely"}
{"source": " If you pluck hard it will make a smooth distorted sound"}
{"source": " If you want a metal sound, then I recommend the Metal Zone by Boss/Roland"}
{"source": "BOSS MT-2 Metal Zone Overdrive Distortion Pedal"}
{"source": "To start, as the full name of this pedal would indicate, this pedal is for tube amps"}
{"source": " I can't comment on how it'll sound for a hybrid, and my experience is that it's definitely not for solid state"}
{"source": " Distortion pedals go much better with solid state"}
{"source": " Further, tube screamers aren't meant to take your tube amp from clean to high gain; again, that's what a distortion pedal will do"}
{"source": " Tube screamers in general are designed to drive your tubes a little harder,and are most commonly used as a solo boost"}
{"source": " Tube screamers are in the category of \"overdrive\" pedals, and like the name would indicate, they're meant add a little extra \"over\" an already \"driven\" amp, but in a more natural, smooth, organic way then a distortion pedal would"}
{"source": "HOWEVER, the Ibanez TS-9dx does more than your typical tube screamer"}
{"source": " The extra knob that switches between ts9, +, hot, and turbo mode adds a whole lot of tone and use options"}
{"source": " Let me expound:I play hard rock and metal through a Bugera 1990 head (basically a Marshall JCM 900)and cab with celestion vintage 30 speakers"}
{"source": " While that amp does have a fair amount of gain and bass on tap, it's not quite enough to accurately get more modern tones unaided"}
{"source": " A standard Ibanez TS-9 or some other knock-off tube screamer will not be able to get an amp like mine into more modern, heavier tones, because standard tube screamers also slightly cut bass and add some mids, again, to help solos cut through the mix"}
{"source": " But the extra knob on the ibanez ts9dx solves this problem"}
{"source": " By switching to +, hot, or turbo mode, the pedal adds bass and a little extra gain incrementally"}
{"source": " I like the \"+\" setting the best"}
{"source": " So the way I use this pedal is that I'll set my amp for my standard crunchy rhythm tone with the gain on the amp already fairly high"}
{"source": " Then, for the songs that utilize a little heavier sound, I'll kick on my ts9dx, with the drive pretty low (9 o'clock), volume at 12 o'clock, tone about 1 o'clock, and + mode"}
{"source": " With these settings it increases the bass and general thickness of my tone, and adds a little gain and volume"}
{"source": " So it's basically like adding another channel to my amp"}
{"source": "I will add one detail that might make or break this pedal for you: tubescreamers in general, and certainly this Ibanez ts-9dx, add mid-range to your tone automatically"}
{"source": " And you can't dial it out"}
{"source": " The regular ts-9 mode adds some low mids, and a little more high mids"}
{"source": " The other modes add more low mids in particular, which in part contribute to the overall \"thickness\" to the tone, which can be great"}
{"source": " But if you're after a scooped mid sound, say for metal, then I would only recommend this pedal as a solo boost, where the mids will help cut through the mix"}
{"source": "In conclusion, it's probably safe to say that most people who buy tubescreamers are probably playing blues of some sort and are just looking to boost their volume and maybe add a little dirt"}
{"source": " And yes, this pedal will do that"}
{"source": " So will the BBE greenscreamer, behringer tube overdrive,mxr distortion plus, Boss SD-1, digitech bad monkey, or several other ibanez tube screamer pedal variations"}
{"source": " But by adding the turbo-mode options, the Ibanez TS-9dx will work for the hard rock and metal players (depending on the exact style) in a way that these plethora of other options won't"}
{"source": "Consider the distortion sound of Cream, the Doors, and ZZ top"}
{"source": "  That buzzy, psychedelic type sound is what this pedal does"}
{"source": "  Unfortunately, that's about all it does"}
{"source": "  However, if you want to have the perfect \"break on through\" guitar intro sound, this is absolutely the pedal for you"}
{"source": "  Quality-wise it's awesome, and if I needed that sound I would definitely own one again"}
{"source": "  I got rid of mine to purchase some other gear that served a wider variety of functions, and honestly I haven't missed it, because I'm not in a Doors cover band or anything"}

{"source": "The Little Big Muff does one thing spectacularly well: it delivers massive fuzz-plus-sustain"}
{"source": " For that purpose, it's excellent, both in sound and construction (it feels like a metal brick)"}

{"source": " If a great fuzz pedal is what you want, this is a superb choice--and, so far as I know, the best one for its price"}
{"source": " If the price is still too much for you, consider the ModTone Fuzzer, which is about as good but substantially cheaper (at least as I write this)"}
{"source": "I own several Electro-Harmonix pedals and overall I like the brand (even though the owner appears to me to be a sexist pig clown boy in many of his YouTube videos)"}
{"source": " Of those I own, two of them are the smaller versions of the GIGANTOR classic E-H pedals, one of them being the Little Big Muff"}
{"source": "First of all, if you have no idea of the difference between fuzz, overdrive, and distortion you should look into it before you buy anything"}
{"source": " These effects are used in different musical styles and produce different sounds, so your choice will depend on what exactly you plan to do"}
{"source": " Do some research by looking on YouTube, looking at Dave Hunter's book on effects, and testing them out at a store"}
{"source": "If you are looking for a basic fuzz box, the Little Big Muff will give you nice sound similar to (if not the same) as that of the Big Muff Pi, depending on the exact year/model you have"}
{"source": " I think the tone is great, but as with most basic fuzz boxes, there are only so many different sounds that you can get out of them"}
{"source": " It is simple to use though, and it makes a lot of noise"}
{"source": "As a bonus, these don't take up a lot of pedalboard space compared to the Big Muff Pi, yet will give the same tone"}
{"source": " It is great for punk, alt rock/grunge, and classic hard rock like Hendrix and Black Sabbath"}
{"source": "I also have a germanium (red) Dunlop Fuzz Face Mini, another good small version of one of the classics, and the Fuzz Face mini that gives you the most low end emphasis of the three (the blue silicon and aqua Hendrix models boost treble more)"}
{"source": " To quickly compare it to the Little Big Muff regarding sound, the Fuzz Face does not have a tone control, but I think it gives a better control over the fuzz saturation"}
{"source": " While the Little Big Muff will give you more control over the tone (EQ), like many EHX pedals it goes from zero to crazy rather quickly"}
{"source": " In this case when you begin turning the Sustain, it is not long before you are in very fuzz saturated zone"}
{"source": " As you increase the amount of saturation, you get more sustain but less control of the dynamics so all your pick attacks begin to sound the same"}
{"source": " So, I'd say while both the red Dunlop Fuzz Face Mini & the Little Big Muff are good tools, each comes with its own disadvantages"}
{"source": "Though some E-H units come with power supply, this one does not and you will need to get one unless you like changing batteries"}
{"source": " Although few pedals come with power supplies, I think its lame not to include them and you will need to factor it into the cost of the unit"}
{"source": "If you are into looking at pretty pedals on your board, then you might be able to find a prettier fuzz box than the stark and dreary industrial-looking Little Big Muff"}
{"source": " I like pretty things, but the sound of this unit is too good to pass up and it is a great tool to have in your kit"}
{"source": "Bottom line:(1) Gives the classic Big Muff fuzz sound(2) Does not eat up pedalboard space like the old GIGANTOR models(3) Noisy (not always in a good way) when on, but has true bypass when off(4) Has tone control (EQ), but the \"Sustain\" saturates very quickly so you get less fuzz control (limits dynamic control of your picking)(4) Simple to use, but limited sound palette(5) Decent price, but power supply sold separately(6) Bleak appearance (not shiny, colorful, or sparkly)"}

{"source": " To the point where its non-existent"}

{"source": " the rest will just play as if the effect was off"}

{"source": "The three modes can be accessed via a switch on the right side of this pedal"}
{"source": " The two fuzz modes (in my view) don't perfectly emulate any one pedal, but are extremely useful nonetheless"}
{"source": "FUZZ 1 is a creamy, midrange filled sound"}
{"source": " It doesn't get too bright, until the TREBLE knob is pushed past 3 o' clock"}
{"source": " This fuzz could make even anemic single coils sound rich and thick"}
{"source": " With humbuckers, it's actually quite clean in silences until the gain is past about 2 o' clock"}
{"source": " I love the way this fuzz sputters when notes and chords decay"}
{"source": " It seems to work best with power chords (root-5th note), and single notes"}
{"source": " If you play complex chords, you'll hardly notice them; if you try to play them, use as little gain as possible"}
{"source": "FUZZ 2 is more in line with the Big Muff"}
{"source": " It has a scooped midrange, which makes things sound dark and sinister"}
{"source": " With the increased bass and treble, complex chords work slightly better here"}
{"source": " This fuzz also has more sustain than FUZZ 1, so it buzzes longer"}
{"source": " This makes it great to use alongside a guitarist that's using a looser sounding high gain tone that isn't necessarily fuzzy"}
{"source": " (Head era KoRn comes to mind for me"}
{"source": ")The third option is ultimately what made my purchase worthwhile"}
{"source": " BOOST"}
{"source": " This mode is a clean boost with a flat midrange level"}
{"source": " It actually distorts a little, but that's only after cranking the EQ and GAIN knobs all the way up"}
{"source": " The resulting buzz does sound a bit like a slightly overdriven non-master volume amp (or a master volume's clean channel fully cranked)"}
{"source": " Still, throughout most of its gain and volume range, BOOST does a good job of staying clean"}
{"source": " This would be great for pushing an amp into overdrive, or extending the gain of a heavily distorted sound"}

{"source": "Okay, this pedal is very versatile for an overdrive"}

{"source": "  I have not tried this pedal with any other guitar besides my Strats"}

{"source": "The best way that I can describe the sound of the OCD is Quality and Character"}
{"source": "As a Clean DriveWhen you uses this pedal with less drive as a clean boost for your tube amp, you will notice that it delivers a very strong character from your guitar and is very sensitive to your dynamics while playing"}
{"source": "As an OverdriveI have loved the Ibanez TS9 because it allows a strat to keep a vocal type of midrange while having singing trebles"}
{"source": "  When you add drive to the TS9, it retains those characteristics which is why it is the industry standard for strat guitarists who want to keep their stratty character and get the quality sound of a tube amp"}
{"source": "The reason why the OCD is my preferred pedal over the TS9 is that it does not let the low end distort as early"}
{"source": "  The TS9 allows you lower notes to distort earlier and seems to then amplify the signal"}
{"source": "  The OCD gives you the fattest low end with tons of tone"}
{"source": "  If you like blues or hard rock, you will notice that this feature is exactly what you wanted to give your playing a really strong character"}
{"source": " You gain boldness and when your low end does gain some crunch, it is the biggest baddest tone that you could dream of"}
{"source": "I use this pedal with my HSS strat and through a blues Jr III and use the clean boost for the coolest clean tone ever"}
{"source": "  It allows your playing dynamics to drive the amp, not some arbitrary clipping from your pedal"}
{"source": "  When I am playing heavier blues or rock stuff, I just turn up the drive and have the boldest and highest quality sound that I have ever played with"}
{"source": "The HP/LP switchShifting into HP is almost like a gain boost"}
{"source": "  I have heard it described as switching from an American Fender-y sound (LP) to a British Marshall-y sound (HP)"}
{"source": "  I guess this is a decent description"}
{"source": "  I have found that I get a thick ballsy sound in the LP and I don't lose any quality in the HP"}
{"source": "  It feels like you get a boost in your midrange"}
{"source": "To conclude, I would have to say that this pedal is the perfect mix of ballsy overdrive with quality tone"}
{"source": "  If you have a quality amp and a quality guitar, there is no reason to try and save $30 by buying an Ibanez TS9 or TS808 or TS9dx"}
{"source": "  This pedal will make you a lot happier than those will if you like to keep your low end intact and not allow it to break up too early making it whimpy"}
{"source": "I picked up this pedal used along with DS-1 Keeley modded distortion pedal not entirely knowing what to think"}
{"source": "  Long story short, the mod DS-1 is getting returned and I'm keeping my Fulltone OCD"}
{"source": "First, a word about the negative reviews"}
{"source": "it tells you something when a small handfull of people completely trash something, but the 13 other reviews (as of Sept"}
{"source": " 2012) were all 5-star reviews"}
{"source": " It tells me that the people who ripped on the tone of the pedal didn't know what the pedal was before they tried it"}
{"source": "  And anyone complaining about the price - this is a hand-crafted pedal that is extremely well constructed (the inside circuitry is pristine) and built to last for decades"}
{"source": "  I think the ratings should reflect quality first and foremost"}
{"source": "Now, let's talk about how the pedal sounds!  It's marketed as an overdrive/distortion"}
{"source": "  I had a lot of people try to steer me away from it because I indicated I was looking for a distortion pedal, but I was actually quite surprised at how much gain and sustain the pedal has"}
{"source": "  It is much more an \"overdrive\" in the sense that it keeps the tonal characteristics of your guitar and amp, but boosts the level in gain in a very full, rich sound"}
{"source": "  The sound has a lot of \"bass\" to it, but unlike a Tubescreamer (TS-9), it's definitely not \"muddy\""}
{"source": "  In fact, if you're tired distortion pedals sounding tinny and weak on a combo act, this might be exactly what you need"}
{"source": "The battery is accessible behind 4 hand screws and moderately involved to get to, but an AC adapter is really the way to go"}
{"source": "  It's a standard plug like you find on BOSS and Ibanez pedals, but you can use a 9V or 18V"}
{"source": "  I've read some reviewers say that 18V gives you more headroom, while some actually prefer the 9V sound"}
{"source": "  Honestly, I tried both and didn't discern any difference - it probably only matters at very loud volumes with cabinets"}
{"source": "Finally, there is an LP/HP switch, and it's really a matter of preference and setup how you use it"}
{"source": "  I've been mostly using the LP setting, which has plenty of output but avoids the shrill highs that I hate"}
{"source": "  But in a live setting (or to use it as a boost for soloing), the HP setting could be quite useful, as it is designed the emphasize the mids and highs to \"cut through\" the other instruments on stage"}
{"source": "If I had to summarize this pedal, I would describe it as a Tubescreamer you can rock with"}
{"source": "  Which is not to say that it's \"better\" than the Tubescreamer, necessarily, but it definitely has a larger range of gain and tone"}
{"source": "  Put this on your pedalboard and you may find yourself using it as your go-to for rhythm/chord sections, soloing, or both"}
{"source": "I've never been much of an effect pedal guy; lots of batteries and cables when I can just get a good tone direct into my Fender tweed"}
{"source": " I've recently conceded to using more effects and have gone, quite frankly, hog wild on new gear"}
{"source": " This is the best of the pedal purchases I have made so far, it's not quite the MXR sound I was going for but there's definitely something here"}
{"source": " The boost works very well for lead work and really ups the sustain on my Strat"}
{"source": "Just two controls, one for volume, one for compression"}
{"source": " My only concern is that the knobs feel like they could be much more sturdy, I haven't pulled them off yet but I would guess the pots have plastic posts as opposed to metal ones"}
