{"source": "  In any case, even though I recently picked up the Sony PCM-D50 from Amazon, I'm sufficiently impressed by the Zoom H2 to give it 5 stars and endorse it for anyone who wants professional quality results without the grief and expense of 8-16 track digital recorders or even the fuss of more complicated personal recorders"}
{"source": "  For quite a while its only competition was the Edirol-R09, but as the price has come down, the Zoom H2 stands out from its immediate competition"}
{"source": " Currently, the H2 is my \"back-up\" unit"}
{"source": "  But for convenience or stealth purposes, I often use it as my main recorder"}
{"source": "Anyone who receives this item is guaranteed to be impressed"}
{"source": "  Production values haven't been spared in terms of the packaging; the included equipment (no batteries but a power adapter, protective pouch, handy table stand, mic stand adapter, wind screen, ear buds, USB cable, and a 256mb SD card); and the manual (a quick set-up sheet plus an ample booklet with generous-sized print written in clear, idiomatic English that makes some of Sony's recent instruction manuals look torturous by comparison)"}
{"source": "The screen and controls, admittedly, are minuscule, requiring sharp eyes (though the screen is well-illuminated) and nimble fingers (I much prefer the knobs and slider switches of my Sony to the touch-pad of the Zoom)"}
{"source": "  What's encouraging about this recorder, apart from the price, is that the designers at Zoom have made the H2 with the genuine audiophile and/or all-around musician in mind"}
{"source": "  It's not simply another \"guitar player's gadget,\" loaded down with an endless supply of effects, loops, rhythm and bass tracks, files within files, programs buried within programs"}
{"source": "  The H2, unlike my pricey Sony, can handle both "}
{"source": "wav and mp3 protocol, has microphone fields ranging from 90 degrees to 360 degrees,  is capable of applying compression limiting to recorded files, offers a wide range of sensitivity and placement for recording lectures, conversations, solo performers and orchestras"}
{"source": "  In short, the device promises to deliver the quality of some of recorders costing a thousand or more--and in a practical digital storage card format"}
{"source": "Other Pluses:  Although the instructions are quick to point out the input for an external microphone (the pictured ones are the two popular stereo mics made by Sony, costing $60 and $90 respectively), the Zoom onboard mic (actually 4) is darn good"}
{"source": "  It captured the range and resonance of a grand piano and even managed to pick up a conversation in the kitchen and a grandfather clock's  chimes from upstairs"}
{"source": "  And it's reassuring to see a mic with a surface area reminiscent of the mics of the past (a single tiny hole is more common these days)"}
{"source": "  Getting the recorded signal onto a computer's hard-drive is expedited with the included USB"}
{"source": "2 cable, and from there you can edit the wave pattern in a program like Cool Edit (which I strongly recommend over editing in the recorder)"}
{"source": "  There's also a metronome on board (potentially useful for a student musician during practice sessions) and a tuner (useful for a student musician or a pro who wants his instrument to be in tune before recording)"}
{"source": "Possible drawbacks: 1"}
{"source": " Zoom admittedly has overdone things a bit with all of the audiophile bells and whistles--limiters, compressors, cut-off levels, AGC control, auto-dynamic levels, sensitivity ratios, panning effects, and the list goes on"}
{"source": "  It's too easy to miss a step, to waste precious time fumbling with the menu, to find your fingers going numb while making all of these tiny adjustments"}
{"source": "  Moreover, the instructions, while clear and abundant, omit much information that would help the beginner"}
{"source": "  The hypothetical audience keeps changing from someone who's a complete newbie to someone who's a knowledgeable aficionado"}
{"source": "  And I have great difficulty imagining a harried band director or impatient student taking the time to fiddle with scrolling through the tiny screen's menu to get to a metronome or tuner"}
{"source": " (Frankly, with 75 kids squirming in their seats I'd go to the old single-function, dial-up, block-shaped metronome without a second thought"}

{"source": "Contrary to one of the reviews, my bench came with height adjustment (it is not on-the-fly kind of thing, though)"}
{"source": " Each of the legs has 3 holes (low, middle, high)"}
{"source": " A fixing bolt goes through one of the holes for both of the legs, and the bolt becomes the crossing point of \"X\""}
{"source": " Three positions roughly correspond to 18, 19 and 20 inches"}
{"source": "For changing height, all you have to do is to loosen and remove the fixing bolt, insert it into whichever hole you like and then tighten it"}
{"source": " Don't worry, you don't need any tool to do the job,  thanks to a large plastic knob"}
{"source": " See the picture and you'll understand how it works"}
{"source": "Mine initially came with middle position"}
{"source": " I also tried high and low, but set it back to middle"}

{"source": "First, I would be extremely wary of the durability of any piano bench for under $50"}
{"source": " Second, as a professional piano player I have never found a use for a traveling \"bench\" or \"stool"}
{"source": "\" Think about it: you've got a heavy keyboard to haul plus an amp plus a keyboard stand and maybe a music stand, electric light and music, perhaps even a storage case for the cables, adapters, extra fuses, batteries, tuners, sometimes an extra keyboard or two, or a couple of tone generators with MIDI cables, or, if you still pack a Rhodes, spare tines and a pair of wire cutters--and you're going to add a bench (!) to your weekly moving equipment caravan?In 90% of the locations that I've worked, I'm able to locate a plain chair without arms (usually the kitchen crew knows where the house spartan chair can be found)"}
{"source": " Not only does it reduce by one the paraphernalia, but it helps protect against the body structure problems to which piano players, especially, are prone over the course of thousands of hours of slouching, subjecting finger joints to unhealthy amounts of pressure, too caught up in chords and scales and retrieving half-remembered melodies to register the physical-neurological effects until after the job"}
{"source": "  I've always envied the lounge act players who can stand while playing--far better for the entire musculature configuration of the human anatomy (not to mention prostate)"}
{"source": " In fact, if the club or restaurant has a regular piano bench or one of those padded, rising and lowering black Steinway cushions, try to replace it with a plain chair without arms"}
{"source": " Especially if you're doing 4-hour gigs, sometimes two in the same day, you'll notice the difference short and long term"}
{"source": "Bottom line, your back needs more pampering than your bottom, which is why you need a seat with a back"}

{"source": " This tube modeler acts first as a pre-amp, and then adds gain, volume control, \"crunch\", whatever, to the non-guitar amps to make them sound like guitar amps"}
{"source": " I don't really care what tube amps it models, or what mic placement, I just want the guitar amp sound and style"}
{"source": " I also use it in front of a Behringer Ultra-G DI box, so that the DI box splits the signal coming from the TM300 and sends half to my non-guitar amps and guitar speakers on stage, and the other half to the house PA"}
{"source": " I don't think that many people would do this"}
{"source": "The sound you get out of this box is affected by what amp, and kind of amp you are driving with it, and also what kind of speakers that amp is driving"}
{"source": " The acoustics of the space you are playing in also affects the sound, but I've used this box with all of its settings driving PA amps, home stereo amps, bass amps, and guitar amps, all of which drove PA speakers, bass speakers and Eminence Commonwealth 12 guitar speakers, all in the same acoustic space"}
{"source": " Each combination of amp and speaker with all settings on the box held constant, sound different: some more like guitar  amps and speakers, some not"}
{"source": " As I said, I don't really care about what tube amp is being modeled, only that I get an authentic guitar and speaker sound out of the box"}

{"source": "The VT999 Vintage Tube Monster has quite quickly become my go-to overdrive pedal, surpassing other OD pedals I've used, including the Digitech Bad Monkey, the Ibanez TS9 Tubescreamer, the Boss SD-1 Super Overdrive, and remarkably, the Fulltone Fulldrive 2 MOSFET"}
{"source": "The VT999 has several things going for it --- Tweakable EQ (High/Mid/Low) which allows you to run a full spectrum, from muddy, dirty low OD sounds, even from a single coil, to bright, screaming lead tones with high mids or highs"}
{"source": "- Noise gate which can not only eliminate single coil hum but can also be used to \"squeeze\" the tone for some interesting effects- Wide range gain that gets dirty around 9 o'clock and full-on distortion when crankedNow, for full disclosure sake, I did change out the tube to a JJ Tesla 12AX7, but most people who know tubes will tell you that really, tubes are often hit-or-miss, simply on account of them being analog, heater-based elements"}
{"source": " That's part of the fun of tube-based OD"}
{"source": " I have played a VT999 that had a great sounding overdrive, but mine didn't have that sound until I put in a new tube"}
{"source": " Try it out with the stock tube, and go to a different tube if you don't like it"}
{"source": " At least try a new tube before giving up"}
{"source": "There are two things that I don't like about the VT999, and I can tell you -- both gripes have nothing to do with sound or tone"}
{"source": " This pedal got it 100% right with tone after a tube switch"}
{"source": " The 2 issues are:- The housing is huge, and if you look inside, it seems like a waste of space"}
{"source": " There's a lot of open space with nothing there, and while I can concede that tubes heat up and need space to dissipate heat, it's a bit overboard"}
{"source": "- Compared to the Fulldrive, the lack of a boost switch is really a miss"}
{"source": " Especially given the large enclosure, it would make perfect sense to move the 5 knobs to the top half of the pedal and put a boost switch on the right hand side"}
{"source": " That'd take little effort, and given the independent power of this pedal, would be a piece of cake to achieve"}
{"source": " Heck, I could probably do it myself, but I don't want to ruin the good sound this produces"}

{"source": " This was a good choice"}
{"source": " Buy one!"}
{"source": "I bought the Vox Amplug AC30 and loved it so much, it probably doubled (or tripled) the amount of time I play guitar"}
{"source": "  I loved it so much I went out and got the more expensive (by $10) Joe Satriani Signature Amplug"}
{"source": "  I liked the Satriani model also because it covered a different tonal range than the AC30, and delay feature is a lot of fun"}
{"source": "  But I had serious questions about the Classic Rock Amplug"}
{"source": "  Why did have only a 4-star review on Amazon - among the lowest for any of the fabulous Amplug products"}
{"source": "  Would it be only a \"one trick pony\"?Well, I have to tell you, I was completely blown away by how great the Classic Rock Amplug is, and I'm now even more blown away by some of these negative reviews"}
{"source": "  I've tried out a number of effects pedals for plugging into an actual guitar amplifier, and many pedal users are seeking what they call a \"Marshall-in-a-box\""}
{"source": "  In other words, they want a effects pedal that will single-handedly transform whatever amp they have into the sound of a miniaturized stack of Marshalls"}
{"source": "  Believe it or not, the Vox Classic Rock on higher gain settings is about as close to a \"Marshall\" sound as I can imagine"}
{"source": "  And it comes in a small, plastic headphone amplifier that runs on 2 AAA batteries and costs all of $39"}
{"source": "99"}
{"source": "Functionally, the Classic Rock Amplug is the same as the AC30 - three dials for gain, tone, and volume, an aux in jack (for MP3 players), a headphone jack, and an on/off switch"}
{"source": "  But that's where the similarities end"}
{"source": "  While the excellent AC30 model simulates the boxy, sparkly sound of a tube amplifier, the Classic Rock packs some PUNCH"}
{"source": "  The low end presence on this thing (even through a $20 set of entry-level Sony headphones from Target) is significantly greater than on the AC30"}
{"source": "  More importantly, the sound doesn't deteriorate with higher volumes"}
{"source": "  There are plenty of ways you can try to play guitar through headphones, but most of them become a static-filled mess as soon as you turn up the volume"}
{"source": "  Amazingly, the tiny Amplug has plenty of power on tap, and the \"overdrive\" is controlled through analog circuitry, with amazing clarity"}
{"source": "But the real surprise in the Classic Rock Amplug (and the point upon which I disagree with several other reviewers here) are the clean and slightly overdrive tones as you roll back on the gain knob"}
{"source": "  Several reviewers referred to the clean tones as weak, or claimed that there were no clean tones"}
{"source": "  Yet, with both my Les Paul and a Strat, I was able to set the Volume at around 6-8 and the gain at about level 2 and get a very nice clean tone without loss of volume"}
{"source": "  If any dirt was remaining, a slight rollback on the guitar volume further cured the problem"}
{"source": "  Even better, playing a Strat into the Classic Rock with the gain set somewhere between 2 to 4 actually created a Tubescreamer-like blues tone!  This tone was one of the audio demos offered on Vox's website, but I didn't believe it for myself until I plugged the Classic Rock in and dialed in that tone"}
{"source": "Long story short, the Classic Rock is extremely powerful, but more verstaile than I thought"}
{"source": "  It can do the high-gain Marshall tones I expected, but also offers a wide array of clean or slightly-overdriven tones"}
{"source": "  It might even be more versatile than the AC30 Amplug, though I remain pretty loyal to the AC30"}
{"source": "  The good news is that the two models are different enough and cheap enough that you can own both"}
{"source": "  Highly recommend the Classic Rock - 5 stars"}

{"source": "  But as far as stage tuners go, it's got a tighter tolerance than the Boss stompbox"}
{"source": "If you want a buffer in your chain, this pedal won't supply it, as it is true-bypass"}

{"source": " Good luck guys!"}
{"source": "I've been using and abusing pedal effects since the 1970's"}
{"source": "  ["}
{"source": "] , running all sorts of things through them, chaining them in all sorts of configurations, and have endured many 'wall wart' pedal meltdowns over the years"}
{"source": " I said all that b/c I don't want to come off as condescending"}
{"source": " I've learned that the single most effective way to power pedals properly is to have an infinite number of 9v batteries, or to be very careful to match pedal inputs with correct adaptor outputs"}
{"source": " Check the polarity of the tip - is the tip positive or negative? You'll fry a Boss pedal in a flash if you plug a hot positive tip into one"}
{"source": " Make sure the polarity matches (most pedals want negative tip adaptors, except Digitech which want 1/8\" plugs)"}
{"source": " Make sure the voltage matches"}
{"source": " A 3v adaptor into a 9v pedal won't power it"}
{"source": " Checking that these things are right will save you some $, and some of the Behringer pedals (I use about six of them on my board"}
{"source": "see product links) are \"polarity fragile\", and will break right away with the wrong adaptor"}
{"source": " I fried a BBE delay the same way"}
{"source": " Happy Effecting!!Behringer SM200 Slow Motion Effects PedalBehringer DD400  Guitar Delay Effect PedalBehringer CS400 Compressor Sustainer Ultimate Dynamics Effects PedalBehringer ADI21 V-Tone AcousticBehringer PB100 Preamplifier/Volume BoosterBehringer PH9 Classic 90 Phase ShifterBehringer US600 Ultra Shifter/Harmonist Ultimate Pitch Shifter / Harmonist Effects PedalBBE TWO TIMER DUAL MODEDigiTech DGR Grunge Analog-Distortion PedalElectro-Harmonix Micro Q-Tron Envelope Follower PedalJim Dunlop M104 Mxr M104 Distortion +DigiTech RP155 Guitar Multi-Effects Processor"}
{"source": "Pros:I bought this pedal primarily in place of a volume pedal, or swell pedal, because it does that function fairly well, and a lot cheaper"}
{"source": " Aside from that, it also does nearly every other type of delay needed:*the tape/digital/analog switch slightly changes the sound of each delay*the trails feature can be useful for holding a sound (in swell mode with high repeats) when the pedal is &#34;off&#34; and then playing over it with notes or harmony*the time knob acts like an analog knob, pitch shifting when turned after playing a note*the repeats knob can go from a little more than one repeat to self oscillation (sometimes runaway) depending on the delay type*the mix knob can nearly cut out the dry signal*stereo input allows for multiple instruments to play into itWhile the pedal has small problems, it compensates by inexpensive fixesCons:The modulation is a kind of adjustable width/depth all in one knob, and isn't the best compared to a chorus pedal"}
{"source": " Just a general warbleThe blue led is VERY bright, to the point where you can't see the settings on the knobs, so I cover it with a sticker (it still shows through enough haha)*The casing is plastic, but it is thick and durable enough (maybe not for consistent gigging)*being a digital effect, the footswitch is not state dependent, in other words, if you turn off the pedal, unplug it, and plug it back in, the pedal will turn on*because it is buffered bypass, the effect will continue to draw power from a battery if a cable is plugged into it, even when off*the battery is difficult to get to because you have to press in on both sides of the switch, and then lift up*there is no noticeable &#34;click&#34; when you change delay type; however, the led flashesOther notes:almost half the weight of the pedal is the bottom metal plate"}
{"source": " The pedal without it feels shockingly lightweight, but with it has a good amount of heft"}
{"source": "For those that don't know, this pedal is a copy of the more expensive Line 6 Echo Park"}
{"source": " The two things that make it better than the real deal are the lower price and the (IMO) better tap tempo"}
{"source": " You have to do an odd sort of clicking sequence with the Echo Park, but with the Echo Machine you simply hold down the footswitch for 2 seconds, and then set your tap tempo"}
{"source": " When you're satisfied, just hold again to enter regular on/off mode"}
{"source": " Foolproof"}
{"source": "Some folks will point to superior construction with the Echo Park, and I won't totally deny that"}
{"source": " That said, the effects modules and the construction of the Behringer pedals are basically the same - plastic where you'd like metal, and surface mount construction (practical maintenance is really only possible by the manufacturer)"}
{"source": " But again, there is a switch in the tone dock that requires maintenance at some point - if it can't be cleaned up, the dock becomes a paperweight"}
{"source": "As best I can tell, all the other settings are the same between this copy and the original"}
{"source": " That makes sense, as it saves Behringer the costs of any R&D; - they just had to make it fit in the dimensions of their enclosures, and alter the tap tempo algorithm/access"}
{"source": " That's a win for the customer because it decreases the price"}
{"source": " For those who find a moral dilemma in buying a copy of something else, I'd submit that most of what is in your pedal collection has probably been either partly or wholly copied from something else"}
{"source": " Unless you want to restrict yourself to the known originals and the prices they fetch, this is oftentimes the standard option"}
{"source": " If there is a worthy improvement (IMO in a practical sense usually more than a sonic one), it would kind of behoove you to insist on the original"}
{"source": " The tap tempo on the EM600 earns its purchase, just like the lower noise floor of the Biyang Compress X earns it as a purchase over what it copies 1:1 - the venerable MXR Dyna Comp"}
{"source": "So why only 4 stars? Because it's a 2-way street - the cost cutting means that this pedal will potentially be something for the landfill in years to come"}
{"source": " There's no denying this, and to get 5 stars requires unsurpassed durability at any price point"}
{"source": " Despite what you may think, it can be done - the flipside is an ever so slightly higher cost"}
{"source": " Behringer probably decided they preferred the increased profit per unit instead, or didn't want to go above a certain price point and risk getting beat by direct competitors"}
{"source": "The other BIG reason to knock a star off is that with a little amp that you have to crank to get acceptable volumes from, there is quite a bit of audible hiss from this pedal"}
{"source": " If all I used were my bigger amps, I would have never noticed, and it wouldn't have been an issue at all"}
{"source": " But the 21st century is a time of lower playing volumes in live settings, which means the smaller amps are more popular"}
{"source": " So the hiss could absolutely be a deal breaker"}
{"source": " It might be slightly lower than the P"}
{"source": "A"}
{"source": " you're using, but I wouldn't be so sure"}
{"source": " I'd say you'd want a (true) 30 watt amp to ensure this isn't an issue, but that may be absolute overkill for the gigs you play"}
{"source": "But my aggravations are really small ones"}
{"source": " Overall, this pedal works fine through any amp I've tried it with, as some are kind of picky especially with delay pedals"}
{"source": " I've typically found digital delay to work better with drive/OD/distortion pedals as opposed to analog delay, and this pedal is no different - as much as I like my MXR Carbon Copy and BBE Two Timer, they aren't nearly as flexible"}
{"source": " This one IMO is on par with the flexibility of the old Boss DD-2/DD-3 or Danelectro Dan Echo"}
{"source": " But it surpasses them with all of the different types of delay effects"}
{"source": " Many of those are something I would never use, but I could imagine how others would absolutely love them"}

{"source": "I had some issues with my 18-watt all tube amp so I experimented and replaced all the tubes"}
{"source": "  Issues not only continued but worsened"}
{"source": "  Hum, noise, volume fade, unwanted distortion at low volumes"}
{"source": "  I eventually put back the original El84s and that didn't help"}
{"source": "  Once I removed the Tung-Sol 12AX7 preamp tubes and replaced, the hum stopped, sound quality of the amp was consistent, quiet and back to par"}
{"source": "  My experience with the Tung-Sol tubes was very, very negative"}
{"source": "  They caused me to go out and buy another amp"}
{"source": "  I had no idea that brand new tubes could sound so badly that fast"}
{"source": "  I'll never buy this brand again"}
{"source": "PEOPLE!  YOU NEED TO BE STATING WHICH AMP AND SPEAKERS YOU USE OR YOUR REVIEW IS POINTLESS!That being said, the reason is because every amp will cause the tube to react and sound differently"}
{"source": "  Speakers will also create a very different sound with each tube choice"}
{"source": " Type of pickups in your guitar will also cause a different outcome"}
{"source": "Amp:  Vox ac30hw2Speakers: Celestion Alnico Blue 8 ohmPower Tubes: JJ EL84Pre Amp Tube: Tungsol 12ax7 in V1 and the stock Ruby tubes in the other 2 spotsHow I Set My Amp: Volume just before breakup and 12o'clock with bass and treble knobs (changes per guitar but stays close)Guitars Used: Fender Telecaster Deluxe 'Chris Shiflett' with stock pups, Gretsch Silver Falcon 2010 with stock Filtertrons, Gretsch Sparkle Jet Blue Pearl with stock Filtertrons, Fender Jazzmaster 65' American Reissue with stock p90's"}

{"source": "I'm very satisfied with the performance of the CM-2"}
{"source": "  With a few tweaking, I could emulate the sound I get from my Fulltone OCD"}
{"source": "  I'd say it's very versatile because there are two seperate controls for low & high frequencies unlike most pedals with just the \"Tone\" control"}
{"source": "  A toggle switch lets you choose between \"classic\" & \"modified\" setting"}
{"source": "  A tweaker's delight!  The \"level\" knob has a lot of juice"}
{"source": "  If you set it at 10 or 11 o'clock, it's plenty loud enough"}
{"source": "  Although you can't use it as a clean boost because it gives off a little gain even if you set the \"gain\" knob to zero"}
{"source": "  If you have a single coil, it may sound like your tube amp is just breaking up, not so for humbuckers (too much gain)"}
{"source": "  You can also stack the CM-2 with other pedals"}
{"source": "  I dusted my old Boss DS-1 and run it along with the CM-2 and was able to get some good tones"}
{"source": "  The DS-1 usually hurts my ears but with the CM-2 behind it, sweet!  The Hardwire CM-2 may not be exotic as the boutique offerings from Klon, Zvex or LovePedal, but it will get the job done at a significantly lower cost"}
{"source": "  It's well built, will take the pounding a gigging musician will subject it to"}
{"source": "  There may be others better but they cost more than twice the price but not twice as good"}
{"source": "  Try it, you can't go wrong!UPDATE:  Did a full comparison between the CM-2, Fulltone OCD & Joyo Crunch Distortion"}
{"source": "GAIN:  Joyo obviously has the most gain followed closely by the CM-2 and OCD, 3rd"}
{"source": "MIX:  The CM-2 has the most amount of control with separate high & low controls, followed by the OCD with just a tone control and the Joyo Crunch more or less sounds the same no matter what position you put the tone control"}
{"source": "  Since the CM-2 has the widest tone range, I can make it behave like a Treble Booster!NUANCE:  The OCD cleans up well when you roll down the volume control on your guitar and is very dynamic"}
{"source": "  The CM-2 is a close second and the Joyo Crunch, being strictly a distortion pedal is far behind"}
{"source": "If you're anything like me, then I know what you're thinking: Digitech= Digital, fake-sounding junk"}
{"source": " Not anymore"}
{"source": " The Digitech HardWire CM-2 finishes what Digitech began with the Bad Monkey, which is a great overdrive pedal in its own right"}
{"source": " But the CM-2 offers tone quality that compares to the best on the market (and as a pedal maniac, I've owned wayyyy too many overdrive and distortion pedals, so in all humility, I know what I'm talking about) and flexibility that is rivaled by none in the market for anything close to the price"}
{"source": "What makes the CM-2 so great is that, like several other reviews have mentioned, it's not just another tube-screamer clone"}
{"source": " There is no distinct mid-range hump and slightly rolled off bass that tubescreamers (particularly the TS-9) are known to have"}
{"source": " There is a lot of range to all the knobs; the level can add some serious boost, bass and treble knobs allow you to significantly change your tone if that's what you're after, or you can dial it to be more (but never completely) transparent"}
{"source": " Also, the CM-2 has more gain on tap than most overdrive pedals; you can go from basically a clean boost to adding a surprising amount of saturation to your tone"}
{"source": " Lastly, the classic vs"}
{"source": " modified switch gives you the option of adding some gain and bass by switching from classic to modified"}
{"source": "I've tested the CM-2 as both an overdrive to a clean channel Fender Hotrod Deville, and as a front-end boost to my Bugera 1990 (basically a Marshall JCM 900)"}
{"source": " The CM-2 sounds great in both applications"}
{"source": " Over the clean channel of the Fender, it sounds very full and smooth"}
{"source": " Even turned all the way up, the overdrive never sounded very \"grainy\" or fuzzy; it maintained warmed, organic, and tube-like"}
{"source": " \"Boutique-esque\" is how I would characterize it"}
{"source": " Great for blues playing, and I'm sure that playing with the tone knobs you could dial in some good country tones as well"}
{"source": "However, I use it more as a front-end boost to my already-overdriven Bugera amp"}
{"source": " In front of the lead channel, CM-2 serves to take my tone from hard-rock crunch territory to a more metal tone, with chunky bass and roaring highs that make palm-muted riffs sound as at home as if they were coming through a Peavey 6505"}
{"source": "As a conclusion, I'm really pleased with the quality of the Digitech CM-2"}
{"source": " Both the sound and build quality are top-notch, and for a price similar to or less than most quality overdrive pedals on the market, I highly recommend checking out the CM-2"}
{"source": "This is the one pedal I can't do without"}
{"source": " You can sculpt your guitar tone before it hits your amp, and that's the key to getting a tight rhythm tone at high gain"}
{"source": " So if I encounter an amp that isn't tight enough, or the high gain distortion doesn't sound good by itself, I just turn down the gain or use a lower gain channel, and then hit it hard with this pedal"}
{"source": " Sounds so much better than the internal high gain distortion"}
{"source": "Alright, so here are some things you might want to know before you buy:* The gain knob when turned to zero still produces overdrive"}
{"source": " So you can't use this as a *clean* boost pedal"}
{"source": " With high output humbuckers, you still get some mild tube-like overdrive at zero gain"}
{"source": " But this isn't advertised as a clean boost pedal"}
{"source": "* So how much gain / distortion does this pedal have if you're going into a clean channel of an amp?  Plenty for classic rock and blues"}
{"source": " Not enough for metal, though if you crank the gain and high knob all the way you can just barely get a prog style metal tone"}
{"source": " But it's not a distortion pedal, it's just an overdrive"}
{"source": "* This thing uses tiny SMC components in the circuitry and therefore isn't really moddable"}
{"source": "* Unlike the Bad Monkey, this doesn't have an additional mixer / cabinet emulated output"}
{"source": "* Like a tube screamer, it boosts the mids and reduces the bass so that going into a mushy sounding tube channel you get a tighter distorted sound"}
{"source": " Anyone who has a nice warm amp and gets this pedal thinking they'll get more of the same, may be disappointed"}
{"source": " What they need instead is a transparent clean boost pedal that keeps their guitar the same tone just louder volume"}
{"source": "* The classic/modified switch is pretty cool"}
{"source": " I have two guitars, one is kind of bassy and scooped sounding, the other is bright and middy"}
{"source": " Well, using the switch, I can make one come out more equivalent to the other when needed"}
{"source": " This keeps me from adjusting my amp each time I switch guitars"}
{"source": " Classic is a slightly lower gain, more mid-boosted sound"}
{"source": " Quite tight"}
{"source": " Think Peavey 6505 EQ structure"}
{"source": " Modified is more scooped, saturated"}
{"source": " Think Mesa EQ structure"}
{"source": " So this switch is a useful little bonus"}
{"source": "*  It eats batteries, sucking in around 150 mA at 9V, so my 300 mAH rechargeable lasts 1"}
{"source": "5-2 hrs"}

{"source": " Instead of getting an adapter, I got an 8-battery AA clip, 9V battery clip, 12V DC plug, and 8 Sanyo Eneloop batteries"}
{"source": " Hooked it up with negative tip, positive sleeve and now I have a 16,000 mAH monster = about 100 hours play time"}

{"source": "The CM-2 is magnificent: [1] It produces beautiful overdrive (one that doesn't destroy your guitar's tone)"}

{"source": "This gizmo lets me refresh all of those pesky details with the slide of a tab"}
{"source": "I don't believe this is a tool to teach people music theory, but it is a wonderful reference once you know what you're looking for"}
{"source": "For example, I'm playing with the harmonica now"}
{"source": " Simple little instrument right? Well that simple little instrument has you thinking about major, minor, major pentatonic, minor pentatonic, and blues scales in 12 different keys! One section of this wheel lists all of these different scales"}
{"source": " Rotate the dial to the key you're interested in and the individual notes for each of these scales in the key you've selected appears"}
{"source": " Nice"}
{"source": "Although I play guitar, I find the other side of the wheel less helpful"}
{"source": " Yes it does show you how to play diatonic chords (MmmMMmD)but they are barre chords based upon the \"E\" chord"}

{"source": "g"}
{"source": " 1E, 2E, etc, CA-40 displays only displays the alphabet, E for all oactaves"}

{"source": "These hold up beautifully if used three or four times per month when a full PA is needed"}
{"source": " I am not sure I would want them for the heavier, all metal speaker stands because the weight would quickly wear the case out"}
{"source": " It has reinforced stress points, but I still feel those are not adequate for heavier stands"}
{"source": "You can easily fit the two stands that I mentioned above and aOn Stage Stands MS7701 Tripod Boom Microphone Stand"}
{"source": " The side pocket is good for incidentals like XLR to 1/4 inch adapters, patch cables and the like"}
{"source": "Bottom line: this case is for occasional use only, and even then for lighter stands"}
{"source": " I awarded it five stars because it does exactly what I need and is not touted to be anything but a light weight case"}
{"source": "Just needed a simple canvas bag to hold speaker stands on top of my pile of PA equipment on a cart"}

{"source": "The Fender Vibro Champ is a great little amp"}
{"source": " I'm amazed at how good this amp sounds"}
{"source": " A small light weight package with a good set of voices that outputs a decent amount of sound"}
{"source": "This is a 5 Watt Tube amp with enough power to fill a medium sized room or the perfect practice amp"}
{"source": " This is a much better and louder amp than the small $100 solid state starter / practice amps by all the major manufacturers"}
{"source": " Fender uses two very standard tubes for pre- and amplification: 12AX7 and 6V6 (both are Fender branded tubes)"}
{"source": " These are nice clean tubes that react consistently"}
{"source": "The amp takes about 15 seconds to warm up and draws 45 Watts"}
{"source": "The cool part of this amp is the 16 voice settings"}
{"source": " In reality the amp packs effects for 7 different amps, Tweed, Blackface, British, Hot Rod, Metal, Jazz, and Acoustic"}
{"source": " The first five have three different levels of style each"}
{"source": " Our other two amps are Marshalls, an acoustic and a half stack"}
{"source": " If I'm being really honest, I like the sound of this amp a lot more than the half stack"}
{"source": " This is a clean simple amp to use"}
{"source": " The Marshall has a ton of tweaks that are hard to get exactly right"}
{"source": "The volume level on the different voices is nowhere near matched"}
{"source": " Some voices are incredibly loud, others are really quiet"}
{"source": " Switching voices means moving that volume knob a lot"}
{"source": " Sadly, the volume only goes to 10"}
{"source": "Once the voice is selected, there are 5 effects settings possible with two or three level for each (Vibratone, Delay, Reverb, Chorus, and Tremolo)"}
{"source": " The F/X level knob adjusts the amount of the effect applied (set to 1, the effect isn't used at all)"}
{"source": " This is probably the least useful part of the amp"}
{"source": " There is no pedal selection, so once the effect is selected and volume dialed in, you're kind of stuck with that until you fiddle with the amp again"}
{"source": " There's no easy way to change the effect in the middle of a song"}
{"source": "There is a gain knob"}
{"source": "I like the speaker on this amp"}
{"source": " It is nicely detailed with a good warm sound"}
{"source": " The internal speaker is connected with a 1/4 inch jack, so it is possible to connect the amp up to another cabinet with a simple 1/4 inch speaker cable"}
{"source": " Very nicely done Fender, most cheaper amps are hard wired to the speaker"}
{"source": " The back panel also has a 1/4 inch jack Line Out"}
{"source": "This is a great small gig or practice amp"}
{"source": " The sound is outstanding"}
{"source": " The amp is used with a 1983 Gibson Lucille and a 2008 Les Paul Standard Plus"}
{"source": "Small"}
{"source": " Light weight"}
{"source": " Stunning Fender Blackface looks"}
{"source": " Warm tube power amp that is both smooth and responsive"}
{"source": " The digital voicing is direct and easy to set up"}
{"source": " The fact that Fender has discontinued this model was a shock to me"}
{"source": " It is one fine small amp that begs to be used in the recording studio"}
{"source": " The direct out provideds a simple and easy way to hook up to the board for signal to recorder/mixer and still give you the amp's skeaker as a monitor for yourself"}
{"source": " What could be easier? And it mikes well too, by the way"}
{"source": " The choice is yours there"}
{"source": "With no LED display (cost increase if one was there) and the plain use of volume and tone mixed with the drive, it's so simple to dial in a great tone that it just makes playing fun, and practicle too"}
{"source": " The voiceing models from the amp selection are quite good and true to the amp that it replecates"}
{"source": " The Tweed, Blackface, and Marshall voicing are all well done and lend to the overall tone of this fine little amp"}
{"source": "Love the reverb in the FX section"}
{"source": " The spring reverb is so well done that I bumped the amp once and was looking for the \"spring chrash\" known from amps with the real spring reverb"}
{"source": " It's that good"}
{"source": " Once again, the controls are easy and direct"}
{"source": " Never an issue to simply select a model and then dial it in with little effort"}
{"source": " Who cares if it doen't have a floorboard with dozens of switches and such for channel selection? You want that, go waste your money on a Line 6 or something"}

{"source": " And I don't even like digital! How's that for an endorsement? It's that good for what it does"}
{"source": "My Instant Order Update notice shows that I purchased this in December 3, 2010, and during the time I've owned this cable it has been heavily used and is still noise-free and perfect in all respects"}
{"source": "  For context I purchased it to connect a mic tube pre-amp to a mixer, so it has been set up and torn down many times in the past two and a half years"}
{"source": "Key points that earn the five stars is the heavy duty strain reliefs, which keep the inside conductors from bending and stressing"}
{"source": " I am guessing those are why this patch continues to be noise free and provide a strong signal"}

{"source": " In the past I have cut corners only to find that small details like connectors do not always mate well"}
{"source": " Not so with these"}

{"source": " Bear in mind that they have been in frequent use - inserted and removed hundreds of times"}

{"source": "Background:I'm a gear-head, with an affection for pedals and always looking for amps that take them well"}
{"source": "  Before my current set-up, I played a Fender Strat run through my effects into a Vox AC15"}
{"source": "  The Vox sounded great but I had two problems: 1 - The all tube amp made me worry that my amp could crap out in the middle of a gig"}
{"source": " 2 - At 15 watts, even though it was loud, I'd often have to crank my amp to keep up with the rest of the band, and as the tube amp increased, so did it's natural gain"}
{"source": "  That would normally be sweet, but it would color my effects with a different tone, and often times leave me having feedback issues"}
{"source": "Enter the Fender Frontman 212R!This thing has TONS of clean headroom, and it seems like it was built for pedals"}
{"source": "  I can crank the amp or keep it quiet, and there is no tone changes done to my effects"}
{"source": "  This is a benefit of a solid state amp with high wattage and lots of clean headroom"}
{"source": "  It makes it easy to dial in your sound every time, no matter what volume you play at"}
{"source": "Secondly, it's Fender reliable (with a 5 year warranty)"}
{"source": "  No tubes means no tube issues"}
{"source": "  Yes, it doesn't sound as good as the Vox by itself, but that's why I have pedals"}
{"source": "Other things worth mentioning:It's not as heavy as my Vox (all tube) amp"}
{"source": "  I can carry this in with one hand and my guitar case with another"}
{"source": "It's got 2x12inch speakers"}
{"source": "  They push some serious sound, and they have some low punch too"}
{"source": "  My Vox had a better speaker, but the 12 inch by itself would often get stressed at high volumes"}
{"source": "  This amp puts out a wall of clean sounds that can put you down!My Vox may be a better recording amp, but this is a better gigging amp every day of the year"}
{"source": "I had two of these and wound up selling one because I never used it"}
{"source": " The one I kept is currently serving as a keyboard amp for two keyboards (simultaneously): aRoland RD-300NX Digital Stage Pianoand aRoland V-combo 76 Key Stage Keyboard"}
{"source": " I was able to do this because there are two inputs on the front of the amp"}
{"source": " Input 1 is designed for normal sensitivity and Input 2 is designed for guitars with active pickups"}
{"source": " Thus far I have had no problems with both boards connected at the same time, and it does not seem to matter which board is connected to which input"}

{"source": " Exceptionally clean, and the amp provides controls to allow you to contour your sound, which helps significantly when running keyboards through it"}
{"source": "  Moreover, the amp is loud if you choose to make it so, and even at high-gain settings it has ample headroom"}
{"source": "If you want distortion, this is probably not the amp for you"}
{"source": " You can switch it from clean to drive to more drive, but it is essentially still a clean sounding amp"}

{"source": "POWER SWITCH IS ON THE BACK?-I find it annoying to have to reach around the back of the amp and feel for the power switch every time I turn it on"}
{"source": "  It is especially annoying if you are like me and have limited space and stack your amps on top of each other"}
{"source": "  With another amp sitting on top of my Frontman 212r, the power switch is even harder to get to"}
{"source": "EFFECTS LOOP IS ON THE FRONT?-The last thing I want to see on or around my rig is messy wires everywhere"}
{"source": "  When using the effects loop, one has to deal with looking at two more wires hanging down over the front of your amp when they could be hidden in the back"}

{"source": "  Why Fender why?FOOT-SWITCH JACK IS ON THE FRONT?-This one is not so bad, but just adds more messy wires to the picture"}
{"source": "REVERB IS NOT FOOT-SWITCHABLE"}

{"source": " This means I just need to get and buy some MIDI cables and I'll be back in business"}
{"source": "So, I'd say buy one of these, and make sure it works before you throw your packaging away! When they work they're absolutely great and they're SO cheap! If you receive a lemon, return it and order another"}
{"source": " It's worth it if you're not in a hurry"}
{"source": " If you *are* in  a hurry then order a few of them, or just get something else"}
{"source": "I'd also like to advise people that reports of MIDI latency with these devices is quite probably a misnomer"}
{"source": " I strongly suspect that the speed of transferring MIDI data into your computer through this device is much faster than you think, and the actual latency you're experiencing is that of converting your MIDI data into audio"}
{"source": " This happens inside your computer and has **nothing** to do with this device's performance; it's purely down to your hardware and software configurations"}
{"source": " All this talk of ASIO is only really going to help you on the audio side of things"}
{"source": " If you're using this device to record MIDI data then you should have no issues at all"}
{"source": " as long as you get one that works! :-)Cheers"}

{"source": "As a disclaimer, I am not a Big Muff connoisseur"}
{"source": "  I've never owned one before this"}
{"source": "  I also tend not to like fuzz as an effect"}
{"source": "  I'd characterize this box as a cross between distortion and fuzz, maintaining enough definition for chord work"}
{"source": "  If you're reading the reviews, you've probably already done your research on the features, but I'll cover them anyway"}
{"source": "Three simple controls, Volume - Tone - Sustain, with the Sustain control being more or less a Gain control"}
{"source": "  The enclosure is a smaller, pedalboard-friendly size"}
{"source": "  The pedal incorporates two of the (supposedly) most popular Big Muff mods with switches, Tone and Wicker"}
{"source": "  When Tone is switched off, the Tone control and its tone-shaping circuitry are completely disconnected"}
{"source": "  In this mode, the distortion applies to the entire tonal spectrum evenly, and it also produces a significant volume boost"}
{"source": "  The Tone knob does nothing"}
{"source": "When Wicker is switched on, it removes three high-frequency rolloff filters that were added to the original Big Muff circuit to smooth out the sound"}
{"source": "  Disconnecting these makes the sound a bit raspier and rougher, with a high-end frequency boost"}
{"source": "I use this pedal running into a mild overdrive, the Catalinbread Dirty Little Secret, which \"conditions\" the signal"}
{"source": "  I play with the Tone off and Wicker on, and even with the Volume and Sustain controls set fairly low, this combination results in a wonderfully thick, massive distorted tone that is still pretty smooth"}
{"source": "If you're looking to get a Big Muff, and you're not a snob about which version, the switchable mods on this one are really great for experimenting to find your own sound"}
{"source": "  Not to mention that, at this price point, it will be much cheaper than some vintage Muffs"}
{"source": "  Highly recommended"}
{"source": "First things first, this is a fuzz pedal (and on the heavy side) which mean it provides thick ground shaking distortion and sustain"}
{"source": "  This is very different from normal distortion so noise is to be expected whether you are playing or not"}
{"source": "Second, a true bypass switch (like in the Big Muff)is a mechanical switch as opposed to Boss type pedals that have buffers which color your sound even when they are off"}
{"source": "  Mechanical switches make noise are are louder the more durable they are"}
{"source": "Ok so now to the actual sound which is amazing"}
{"source": "  This pedal has a tone of versatility because not only do you have a lot of options on the pedal itself but it reacts dynamically to the knobs on your guitar"}
{"source": "  Since I play a Les Paul with 57 classics I will often turn the volume down to 8 when using this otherwise the bass can be overwhelming (but awesome)"}
{"source": " Strat and Tele players probably wont have the same issue with single coils"}
{"source": "  In addition the Wicker and Tone features all for more sounds that just the original Big Muff or you can just turn them off to get the original sound"}
{"source": "Great for: Black Keys (they use a big muff), Weezer (think My Name is Jonas), certain Greenday songs, and basically anything where you need thick and deep fuzz with the option to tone it down if need be"}
{"source": "It works! This guitar support couldn't be simpler"}
{"source": " The neck rest is a molded plastic cup with that soft spongy material inside the neck support"}
{"source": " The mat is a thick light weight foam mat (a bit like a yoga mat) with a hole cut in it"}
{"source": " The neck support cup goes through that hole"}
{"source": " That's it for set up"}
{"source": " The mat protects the guitar body"}
{"source": " The support cup holds the guitar at exactly the right angle to work on it, change strings, adjust the truss rod, work on the pickups, or clean the guitar"}
{"source": " The guitar can be placed in strings up or down"}
{"source": "This wouldn't be a difficult DIY project, but I'd be missing out on that cool Fender logo if I made this out of wood and a yoga mat"}
{"source": " Honestly, this looks really sharp put together"}
{"source": "The whole thing comes packaged in a clear plastic tube"}
{"source": " That tube is an excellent storage tube"}

{"source": " Meaning depending on where you grip the pick it will become more or less rigid"}

{"source": "  I usually do a two person podcast where I am in one location and the other person is brought in via Skype"}
{"source": "  Using the Aux sends of the board and the 4 track mode of the H4N I can record myself in one channel, the other person in another channel and all of the sound effects and music supplied by my iPad into its own stereo channel"}
{"source": "  This makes editing a breeze as everything is on its own track"}
{"source": "The sound quality of the H4N is excellent and it is very easy to hook up external microphones to the unit"}
{"source": "  You can hook up either two XLR microphones or two 1/4&#34; jack sources (or a combination) to the bottom of the unit and there is one 1/8&#34; input on the back of the unit that will accept a stereo microphone or any line level stereo source"}
{"source": "  It's the combination of these that lets me record the podcast onto the 4 separate tracks"}
{"source": "The H4N will also let you record using two attached microphones and the internal microphones at the same time as well, which could be useful if you're looking to capture some background noise if you are recording something on location or say to mix the crowd reaction to a soundboard feed"}

{"source": "Although the big push these days by Samson/Zoom is on behalf of their latest entry, the pint-sized H1, the H2 is still outselling it"}
{"source": "  Perhaps for good reason"}
{"source": "  Amazon's price has the H2 going for less than a 50% mark-up from the H1, yet only the H2 offers a sound stage as wide as 360 degrees and is almost as portable and easy to slip into a pocket as the H1"}
{"source": "  The latter offers the now popular X/Z mic configuration, but they're \"fixed\" mics"}
{"source": " if you wanted to ensure the widest separation, you'd be unable to aim the mics in opposing directions"}
{"source": "  Also, the H2 can be set down on a flat surface more securely and is less sensitive to microphonics from touching any part of the machine"}
{"source": "  I've owned both machines and have found the construction quality wanting, the SD door broke loose on the HD2, and the on-off switch came loose on the H1"}
{"source": "  Both are somewhat tricky to operate, with settings that are not visible in dark places and which nonetheless require agile, accurate, and quick, small fingers"}
{"source": "  (Some users are bound to react negatively to the minuscule size of the H1's micro-SDHC storage cards"}
{"source": ")  Both are capable of full-bodied, full frequencied high-fidelity audio, but you have to remember to treat them gently"}
{"source": "The Zoom Q3 video recorder strikes me as the best built of the bunch, as it's solid metal practically through and through, and the limited settings make it easier to use than either the H1 or H2"}
{"source": "  However, I found it impractical to use at a concert where where the included video component distracted the listeners behind me"}
{"source": "  Also, with its size and bright-blue color it's anything but a stealth machine"}
{"source": "This brings us to the 4th (and most expensive) Zoom, the H4n"}
{"source": "  It's the most versatile of the Zooms, not only permitting movement of the mics but the addition of external mics for authentic mixing"}
{"source": "  Still, the build quality is not notably superior to the H2, and of the 4 Zooms, it's the fussiest, intended for a user whose willing to take some time to become familiar with its versatile learning curve"}
{"source": "  After less than satisfying experiences with the first 3 Zooms, I sent the H4n back in favor of the Sony PCM-50, which is constructed like a Hummer compared to the plastic of the Zooms"}
{"source": "  I see that Amazon's description of the Sony is misleading, since the PCM-50 will NOT permit the user to record in MP3 format"}
{"source": "  WAV is the only format it offers, which simplifies the recording process, allowing the user to select file size with the software program used during the editing process"}
{"source": "  (The only down side is the limited duration of WAV, requiring the user to employ a Sony Sound Stick in addition to the built-in storage"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": "Overall, as with most Zoom products, this unit is a winner and cannot be touched by it's competition in it's price category except for perhaps the Olympus LS11 which is cheaper but the Zoom has a ton more features"}
{"source": "Build quality is good, features are good (the only unit in it's price range to have combi XLR / 1/4\" TRS inputs) and it records to a high quality"}
{"source": "However, I think Zoom almost went too far with features and perhaps they could have focused more on making it THE BEST digital recorder under a grand and making it a great USB digital interface instead of spending money on the 4 track feature and all the built in effects and other fluff that works O"}
{"source": "K"}
{"source": " but is much more easily realized in a simple digital 4 track recorder (e"}
{"source": "g a Tascam PocketStudio)The manual is a farse in Japanese /English translation and any person that does not have experience with recording devices like this might really struggle to learn how to use this unit (although it's fairly intuitive to operate if one is familiar with such devices - I gave up on the manual and just dug around in the menus, but the unit is still a little 'fiddly' to operate in advanced modes"}
{"source": "My last comment is in regards to the H4n as a USB interface"}
{"source": " I have played with it a bit and so far it does not make a good interface"}
{"source": " First of all it is only 16 bit and I can only get it to work with MME drivers"}
{"source": " I have read that there are some ASIO drivers available for Windows 7 but I use XP"}
{"source": " I may try to use ASIO4all but it is still only 16 bit and therefore not much use for serious interface work"}

{"source": "Having misplaced my Blue Snowflake USB mic, I decided to give this recently introduced, competitively priced USB mic from Samson a try"}
{"source": "  (Samson is maker of the highly popular and effective Zoom personal digital recorders--the H2 and the H4n"}
{"source": ")  It's an attractive, fully outfitted piece of equipment, with handsome packaging (a small black box and zippered carrying case with aesthetics apparently inspired by iPod)"}
{"source": "  It's smaller and lighter than the Snowflake--more diminutive than the picture would suggest"}
{"source": "  Yet the audio quality strikes me as being somewhat warmer and richer, favoring the bass frequencies of spoken narration more than the Snowflake, which has slightly cleaner and clearer definition at the treble end"}
{"source": "The Samson Go was seen instantly by my iMac, and recording was as advertised: \"Plug n' Play"}
{"source": "\"  The mic is somewhat more sophisticated than the Snowflake in terms of \"latency\" settings (it permits direct monitoring via headphones connected to the mic to insure no delay, or lag time, between transmission and reception), and there's a three-way switch for directional patterns (the manual could be clearer, however, about the difference between \"cardioid\" and \"cardioid 10 pad"}
{"source": "\")  No matter"}
{"source": " The mic performed virtually flawlessly right out of the box, with no tampering with the switch"}
{"source": "It's extremely sensitive, slightly more so than the Snowflake"}
{"source": "  Yet I was unable to avoid the \"P\" popping sounds, regardless of how close I got to the mic and muted my consonants"}
{"source": "  So be prepared for the addition of some sort of \"pop filter\" device (either one sold on Amazon or a self-designed one, using a nylon stocking)"}
{"source": "The mic can be clipped to the top of a computer screen or mounted on a mic stand (using a supplied adapter or ordering a properly sized one from Samson)"}
{"source": "  Yet with its heavy base plus the flexible, tilting mic, it can be placed on a flat surface--much like the Snowflake, but with greater stability and without any intrusive cable"}
{"source": "  (The Snowflake tends to \"flop around,\" requiring some balancing of the device by the user"}
{"source": ")My biggest disappointment thus far is that the clip, as alluded to by another reviewer, does not open far enough for attachment to a desk-top computer (it should be an ideal fit with most notebook machines)"}
{"source": "  Although the Snowflake doesn't use a spring clip, it suffers from the same limitation"}
{"source": "  If you're especially concerned about durability, the Snowflake appears to be the heavier, more rugged mic, with thick metal and no tiny switches or spring clips to wear out"}
{"source": "  The Samson is the more delicate and refined of the two"}
{"source": "  But don't kid yourself"}
{"source": "  Either mic will exceed the capabilities of your computer's built-in mic and perhaps the owner's expectations"}
{"source": " On the other hand, neither is a match for the Shure SM7B that I'm accustomed to using at a local broadcasting studio"}

{"source": "This is one great looking cable"}
{"source": " I purchased this cable December 2010 and it is still working well and stilllooks good"}
{"source": " And as Fernando Lamas says, \"it is better to look good than to feel good\""}
{"source": " Well, not when itcomes to cables"}
{"source": "This cable is 20 AWG, with an \"Ultra-Pure Copper Center Conductor\" and 100% copper and conductivepolymer shield"}
{"source": " You want a good shield if you are going to be playing loud"}
{"source": " Helps keep those ugly micro-phonics away and you want that big time"}
{"source": "The capacitance of this cable according to the manufacturer is 39 pF/ft"}
{"source": " This is the one spec you wantto pay attention to when buying instrument cables"}
{"source": " The lower the number, the least resistance whichresults in a higher performing cable"}
{"source": "Out of this cable expect a more corpulent sound and beefy output"}
{"source": " It seems the lows and mids are hugeand the highs are very nice indeed"}
{"source": " This seems to be a very nicely balanced cable for the money"}

{"source": "I've owned several multi-effect pedals in the past, even one Digitech"}
{"source": "  Up til now, they all had one thing in common: layers of menus to click thru to make any changes or adjustments"}
{"source": "  It was a pain"}
{"source": "  Then I saw this one"}
{"source": "with KNOBS! I did a lot of research, and was torn between the RP255 and the RP355"}
{"source": " I decided to go cheap and got the RP255"}
{"source": "  So far, that was an OK decision"}
{"source": "  The RP255 has plenty of features, and is a good compromise between menus and knobs"}
{"source": "  I recommend reviewing the manual for your first day or two of orientation"}
{"source": "To sum up the device quickly, the RP255 is probably capable of generating any sound or effect you want, but you may need to work at it"}
{"source": "  As with many multi-effect pedals, there is a selection of (60) factory tone/effect profiles, to save you the trouble of programming new ones"}
{"source": "  These are mirrored by 60 \"user-defined\" profiles, which are identical to the factory presets"}
{"source": "  The difference is that #1-60, can be modified by the user, or left as-is"}
{"source": "  The factory presets, # 61-120, are not modifiable"}
{"source": "  So, you can really experiment with different setups without worrying about losing what came from the factory"}
{"source": "  You can also \"reset\" the entire device if you want to, but if you do you will lose all of your modifications"}
{"source": "In addition to all the different tones and effects this unit has to offer, there are also two additional features which are very useful: a (pretty basic)drum machine and a 20 second looper"}

{"source": "  Reviewers that don't believe this is sufficiently padded are looking for something other than a \"gig bag\" and don't understand the term"}
{"source": "  You wouldn't put your reading glasses in a soft, padded case and expect to be able to sit on them would you?I don't know if some other reviewers tried to fit concert-sized ukuleles or other larger sizes into this bag, but I found that it fits the soprano size perfectly"}

{"source": "  Also, you can't play with the same nuance and control as an acoustic set, but for the price it goes a long way to making it seem real enough that I can enjoy it and feel like I'm learning the drums"}

{"source": "I am not going to say this pickup is the best thing since sliced bread, but it is built solidly and built to last"}
{"source": " It is simple, practical, and cheap"}
{"source": " There are obvious advantages and disadvantages to that"}
{"source": " You don't buy $150"}
{"source": "00 pickup for a $200-$300 instrument"}
{"source": " Being able to plug in and be self-sufficient (in most rooms, especially at open mics) is easier and better than relying on a mic, especially for beginners, because it takes skill and discipline to stay within the mic's sweet spot"}
{"source": " Also, some rooms/PA's/hosts do not work well when trying to mic an instrument"}
{"source": " At least a pickup like this has the potential for keeping the sound front and center"}
{"source": " (I will experiment with different instruments & write more about the quality later"}
{"source": ")That said, there is only one piezo element, unlike a K&K; pickup, for example"}
{"source": " So it is limited in giving you optimal sound, no matter where it is placed"}
{"source": " Also, in case you cannot tell from the image, the soldering connection and wires are exposed on the jack, so it can only be used inside your instrument, which means drilling a hole"}
{"source": "So i decided to amplify my Martin Dreadnaught (a really, really nice acoustic guitar)"}
{"source": " I didn't want to spend a lot if it just wouldn't sound good with a pickup, and saw this had consistently good ratings"}
{"source": " I can't speak for other acoustic pickups, but this far exceeded my expectations, and I don't plan on buying a more expensive piezo, or soundhole pickup"}
{"source": "ATTACHING ITUnfortunately the narrow portion of the barrel is not long enough to fit through the end/tail block; and I didn't want to drill a new hole in my not-so-cheap guitar just to test out a relatively cheap pickup"}
{"source": "So I attached the pickup in the regular position inside the body behind the bridge, and just ran the cable out from the sound hole"}
{"source": " The jack is held onto the pickguard with some scotch outdoor mounting tape (which is kind of like really strong gum, it can be removed without leaving sticky residue); which holds it in place well enough to plug in a cable and move around as long as I don't jerk the guitar quickly"}
{"source": "SOUND QUALITYI plugged it into my cheap, regular guitar amp, and whoa! The package mentions two locations you can place the pickup, and because I needed to run it through the sound hole, I could only place it where more treble is picked up"}
{"source": " So I have to compensate on my amp by turning down the treble to 7 or lowerBecause the pickup is a transducer, no electrical feedback/interference is picked up, so the sound will be very clear and crisp"}
{"source": " It would probably sound even better on an amp with better electric shielding; the only noise I get even at max gain, max input volume, is from the amp itself, heard with every instrument I plug into it if I turn the master volume up too high"}
{"source": "Another thing to consider is that transducers pickup vibrations, so it won't pick up sound when placed a millimeter away from the guitar body, but will when touching it"}
{"source": " So with that in mind, the pickup will strongly output every sound you make to the guitar body; like it brushing up against your body, a zipper hitting the guitar, your fingers sliding on the strings etc"}
{"source": "This pickup is pretty good at lower volumes"}
{"source": " But it becomes a feedback nightmare at higher volume"}
{"source": " The pickup is very, over sensitive"}
{"source": "Also, spend some time where exactly you place the pickup, it makes a big difference! Try to put it near a solid part of the instrument so it does not pickup so much and make the cound like the bottom of a cave or something"}

{"source": " I'll never buy again"}
{"source": " This is the first time in my life I wanted to change brand new strings"}
{"source": "The reason they are called silk and phosphor is that the wound strings have silk along with steel in their cores (the wire around which the windings are wound) rather than just steel"}
{"source": "  This allows them to tune to pitch with less tension, so they can be the ideal string for a beginner or someone who is moving from nylon"}
{"source": "  There are also silk and steel strings with silver plated copper windings"}
{"source": "  The lower tensions and light gauges mean that they may not drive some guitar tops hard enough to let them perform up to their capability"}
{"source": "  That is, they may sound soft and cheap"}
{"source": "  I would not put them on most Martin dreadnoughts, for example"}
{"source": "  But they may work fine on lightly braced guitars"}
{"source": " The only way to find out for sure is to experiment"}
{"source": "These are an experiment for me, I usually use silk-and-steel on my guitar banjo, it was time to change strings, and I stumbled across these"}
{"source": "  I'll have to see where things settle down, but so far I'm willing to give these silk-and-phosphor the nod over silk-and-steel"}
{"source": "  The sound is a bit brighter"}
{"source": "  My music partner says she prefers the way these silk-and-phosphor blend with her fiddle"}

{"source": " The line 6 spider IV 75-watt combo was the perfect solution"}

{"source": " Sure, the cleans are glassy and crystal-clear, and some sound ok with the gain cranked and mids scooped at super low volume, but as soon as you turn up the volume a bit or try to dial in a smooth, bluesy overdrive, the sound turns to crap"}
{"source": " Not so with the spider IV"}
{"source": " I've been extremely impressed with all the different amp models"}
{"source": " ALL of them"}
{"source": " The different amp models each have their unique sound and characteristics, which means that your tonal options are literally limitless"}
{"source": " I play mostly metal and hard rock, thougn I use less gain and more mids than is typical among players of the genre"}
{"source": "I'd describe it as a hard rock tone with a vintage edge"}
{"source": " And I was able to get that tone in less than a minute of fiddling"}
{"source": " The tone in general is surprisingly warm and organic- very tube-like, which is a comparison that I don't make lightly"}
{"source": " Additionally, the highs don't have that artificial \"tinny\" sound that so often occurs in solid-state"}
{"source": " Solos and leads have more of the natural, smooth quality that tube amps are valued for"}
{"source": "The effects are fun to play with, though I've never used many effects in my playing"}
{"source": " I really like having multiple user pre-sets, so I can dial in the tones that I use the most and then switch between them at the press of a button"}
{"source": " The artist pre-sets are cool; it's interesting to see Line 6's take on the sound of many popular bands and songs"}
{"source": " Some are surprisingly good, like Cliffs of Dover, Master of Puppets, and Sunshine of Your Love, while others don't really sound like the artist, like Killswitch Engage"}
{"source": "I'm also impressed with the quality of the celestion speaker that comes with the amp; it holds up pretty well even at higher volumes"}
{"source": " The tone has continually improved as I've broken in the speaker"}
{"source": "Just in conclusion, there's basically nothing this amp can't do at least fairly well"}
{"source": " All the amp models actually sound good (can't say the same about my roland cube), and when you combine that with all the effects, tuner, mp3 connection, and user and song & artist presets, it's a winning combination"}
{"source": " This will never be my main stage amp, but for practice purposes I couldn't be more pleased with the spider IV"}

{"source": "1"}
{"source": " First, in the setup screen do NOT enable the FBV Express"}
{"source": " Yes, I know this sounds dumb, but internet scouring shows there is a bug that this is a workaround for"}
{"source": "2"}
{"source": " Read the FBV Express users guide and calibrate the pedal"}
{"source": " there is no need to d/l the FBV software for this"}
{"source": "Now"}
{"source": " In the POD setup screens you have the option to either have the ABCD buttons as ABCD, or to be FS5-FS8"}
{"source": " This behavior is mimicked by the 4 switches on the FBV"}
{"source": "So"}
{"source": " In ABCD mode you can:a) Select preset A, B, C or D from the group you are currently in"}
{"source": "b) Insert a volume FX and use volume pedal"}
{"source": "EXP2c) Insert another FX enabled by toe switch, and controlled by pedal as EXP1d) tap temp (by tapping the currently selected preset"}
{"source": "ie the pedal that is lit)e) enable the tuner (press/hold the current selected preset pedal)f) you have some basic control of the looper, but CANNOT enable it"}
{"source": "3/10/14 EDIT :Looper control is flawed"}

{"source": "Unlike other keyboard controllers I've tried, this one plugs and plays with the iPad--no powered USB hub required"}
{"source": " (You do need Apple's Camera connection Kit, of course, to add a USB port to your iPad"}
{"source": ") It's not loaded with gimmicks--just the essentials, and the essentials work very well indeed"}
{"source": " The keys are 85% of standard width, which is large enough for fumble-free playing"}
{"source": " It's lightweight, compact and thus perfectly suited as an iPad accessory"}
{"source": "First of all, don't be \"oversold\" by the \"extraordinary value\" that some reviewers claim this fifty-buck inputting device to be"}
{"source": "  Akai is considered a budget-priced version of, and a step down, from Sony, which in the minds of some has dropped a few steps lower itself"}
{"source": "  But it's the ideal solution for many of us who may be working at a desktop computer with Garageband, Band-in-the-Box, Finale, Sibelius, Audacity or a similar program"}
{"source": "  The last thing I would do is lug a 50-pound PC or SP Kurzweil model (plus AC power transformer) upstairs to place on an over-crowded desk"}
{"source": " Even the 12-pound Yamaha NP-30, with its 76 notes, is awkward to use for this purpose"}
{"source": "  Make it nothing longer than a 41-note keyboard, but if you can get one at half the price of the E-Music 41-note, that may be the handiest, most practical device for your needs"}
{"source": "Sure, there are alternatives"}
{"source": "  You can click at a \"virtual keyboard\" that Garageband makes available for a mouse--but it's slow"}
{"source": "  Or you can download a virtual keyboard to your iPad (or iPod) for a couple of bucks, but it's limited to no more than an octave and a \"touch screen\" which, though superior to mouse-clicking, still isn't as satisfying or \"immediate\" as inputting by pressing down on actual, physical keys"}
{"source": "This cheaply-made--even \"cheap\"--but effective Akai keyboard fits the bill very nicely, especially for someone who's working in congested space"}

{"source": " Works for guitar, bass, violin, or any string instrument"}
{"source": "The Intelli IMT-500--The tuner that killed the Intellitouch!There are scores of chromatic tuners on the market"}
{"source": "  Most work by using a small built-in microphone that picks up sound waves"}
{"source": "  In order to be used effectively, the tuning space must be relatively quiet"}
{"source": "  Many of these tuners have input jacks that allow electric guitars to be connected directly and tuned by the electronic signal they produce"}
{"source": " A bunch of years ago a variety of clip-on-microphones began to be marketed"}
{"source": "  The microphone could be clipped to any instrument and its cord attach to an electronic tuner"}
{"source": "  Now, anyone could tune an instrument no matter what the background noise"}
{"source": "Then, the Intellitouch tuner hit the market"}
{"source": "  The entire tuner clipped onto the instrument"}
{"source": "  One could tune an acoustic instrument in a noisy environment"}
{"source": "  There was no cord to deal with and the instrument could stay clipped to the headstock or quickly removed and slid into a pocket or case"}
{"source": "  Talk about convenience"}
{"source": "  Jams and festivals (bluegrass, folk, whatever) became seas of Intellitouch tuners"}
{"source": "Intellitouch owned the market even though there were so many situations where they did not work well"}
{"source": " In particular, they have trouble with the bass notes of dreadnought sized guitars"}
{"source": " The more overtones an instrument produces, the worse the tuner behaves"}
{"source": " The bass string of a Martin rosewood dreadnought was near impossible to tune without using one of the many workarounds that owners developed"}
{"source": "  So, it was very much a love-hate relationship"}
{"source": "  The shortcomings were huge, but the convenience meant that they were tolerated"}
{"source": "Then, came the Intelli"}
{"source": "  It was an Intellitouch that worked, if not perfectly, then a whole lot better"}
{"source": "  The amazing thing is that the switch from Intellitouch to Intelli wasn't gradual"}
{"source": "  Within six months of its introduction, jams and festivals became seas of Intelli tuners"}
{"source": "  People were throwing their Intellitouches into drawers (if they weren't lucky enough to find a die hard holdout willing to buy one second-hand) to get the Intelli"}
{"source": "  That's a considerable investment to abandon"}
{"source": "  But, why not?  The Intelli is half the price of the Intellitouch and works a whole lot better"}
{"source": "  They are so inexpensive that it's easy to justify getting one for the practice area and one for the case so that you don't have to worry about forgetting to pack it"}
{"source": "Anyone who will ever have to tune an acoustic instrument in a noisy environment will quickly find this tuner indispensable"}
{"source": "  And it works darn well in a quiet environment, too!Highly recommended!"}
{"source": "I only have used this tuner on classical guitars (the ones with nylon strings)"}
{"source": "  I teach classical guitar and have had the opportunity to use it on many different classical guitars of varying quality"}
{"source": "  It has tuned them all very well"}
{"source": "  A great advantage I've found using this tuner (Tune Tech TT500) verses tuners which use a microphone, is that I can now talk with my students while tuning and no longer have to ask them to please be quiet while I tune their guitars"}
{"source": "  Kids especially like to talk and now I can fully engage in conversation with them while tuning their guitars"}
{"source": "  The only problem I've noticed, and thus only 4 stars, is that I usually have to begin tuning with any string other than the low E string"}
{"source": "  For some reason, the tuner seems to have trouble sensing the low E vibrations and the needle will not move"}
{"source": "  This problem has always resolved itself when I tune another string and then tune the low E"}
{"source": "PROS:1"}
{"source": "  Pitch is registered quickly with minimal needle fluctuations2"}
{"source": "  Ambient noise does not disturb tuning sensor3"}
{"source": "  Small and compact4"}
{"source": "  Swivel head for ease of viewing the screen"}
{"source": "5"}
{"source": "  The screen is very bright and is also easily seen in direct sunlight"}
{"source": "6"}
{"source": "  Rubber feet on clamp will not scratch guitar7"}
{"source": "  Clamp is strong and will open wide but easy to squeeze open with fingers"}
{"source": "8"}
{"source": "  Being a chromatic tuner means you are not stuck just tuning EADGBE"}
{"source": "  It's tuning range is 12 note"}
{"source": " A2 - B7"}
{"source": "9"}
{"source": "  Will automatically turn itself off after 3 minutes of non-use"}
{"source": "CONS:1"}
{"source": "  Delay on tuning low E string2"}
{"source": "  Buttons rattle while tuning 2nd string, B"}
{"source": "3"}
{"source": "  Plastic on screen scratches easilyI don't yet know how long the button battery will last or how much battery replacements cost"}
{"source": "  I will update this review when I have that information"}
{"source": "  But for now, I am very pleased with this tuner"}
{"source": "  I have owned many electronic tuners and this one so far beats them all"}
{"source": "  I have also used it to tune my guitarlele and it tunes it darn near perfectly!  Great chromatic tuner at a great price - I love it!"}
{"source": "This is the second tuner I have bought like this"}
{"source": " I got it because I need a second tuner"}
{"source": " They are very good tuners and I highly recomend any tuners this company makes"}
{"source": " but not great either"}
