{"source": "Here is a letter I wrote to Tascam:On humble advice I would forward this email to all of your subsidiaries any retail store that sells Tascam USB audio devices! Anywhere in the world"}
{"source": "Just today I got the new Tascam US-100 USB audio interface"}
{"source": " It of course uses the Windows audio drivers"}
{"source": " A nightmare occured"}
{"source": " When I plugged in the device Windows XP had the usual \"detect USB device\" come up"}
{"source": " But to my horror it wound up saying \"A hardware problem occured your hardware may not operate properly\" something of that sort"}
{"source": "I spent over 4 hours trying to figure this whole thing out and I read the manual it came with"}
{"source": " Tried all sorts of things oh brother! It still would not install"}
{"source": " By the way this happened with a previous USB audio device, not made by Tascam, that did the excact same thing on my computer"}
{"source": "But to my luck I found out what the problem was! Thank God for the website that had this on a blog!:In the c:\\windows\\inf folder there must exist two files:wdma_usb"}
{"source": "infwdma_usb"}
{"source": "PNFIt is really the "}
{"source": "inf file that is important"}
{"source": " Some software  seems to knock these out by renaming them to:wdma_usbinf"}
{"source": "bakwdma_usbpnf"}
{"source": "bakI simply found the files, opened them and renamed them to the proper names"}
{"source": " And lo and behold when I restarted my computer the Tascan US 100 worked!Its easy to rename the files you just open wdma_usbinf"}
{"source": "bakwdma_usbpnf"}
{"source": "bak and  then save them as wdma_usb"}
{"source": "infwdma_usb"}
{"source": "PNF"}
{"source": "Its that simple!!Anyone who works customer service for Tascam should know this"}
{"source": " Like I said it happend with a previous USB audio device that I had and I woulnd up selling it at eBay cause I was so frustrated"}
{"source": "I'm happy with the Tascam US 100"}
{"source": "I hope this helps if your audio does not work on your computer"}
{"source": " And it did the same with a USB phone"}

{"source": "The US-100 works fine for my needs: rough and ready audio tracking with 32-bit Cubase 5 on 64-bit Windows 7"}
{"source": " My PC is for general-use with a non-studio configuration (no mixer, non-phantom power mics, headphone monitoring)"}
{"source": "If you're buying for a studio setup requiring phantom power or multiple inputs, you'll need a separate mixer and/or standalone phantom supply"}
{"source": " From the mixer you can cable to the US-100's line input via RCA jacks on the back"}
{"source": "There were a couple of hiccups during setup, but I don't blame the device"}
{"source": " It uses stock O/S drivers that loaded right up"}
{"source": " The documentation is minimal and only covers up to Vista, but it's accurate and you'll manage with Win7"}
{"source": " On the Windows side make the USB AudioCodec your default recording and playback device to override any onboard or card-based audio and speakers (I have Realtek onboard and 2"}
{"source": "1 desktop speakers)"}
{"source": "I'm using ASIO4ALL with Cubase and Cubase crashed a couple of times while configuring VST connections and I/O busses"}
{"source": " Once configured however, it's been solid"}
{"source": "I'd recommend checking out user forums for your particular software/platform to find similar gotchas and to set your expectations"}
{"source": "On an XP machine, changing the default sound devices often means the hassle of toggling settings before and after launching the DAW"}
{"source": " On Win7, once I unplug the US-100, the settings revert nicely to my desktop speakers"}
{"source": " If I plug the US-100 back in, the settings revert again - very reliable"}
{"source": " Even better, if I want to use Cubase strictly for MIDI, the software detects the change and I don't have to reconfigure connections or busses"}
{"source": " That may be a function of Cubase, so again it pays to research your particular software"}
{"source": "While the US-100 is connected, you'll hear nothing from your computer speakers and have to rely upon the US-100's headphone jack or audio out RCA jacks"}
{"source": " This is where the balance control is very helpful"}
{"source": " It's not a pan, it's a center position gain mixing the computer's output (from within your DAW as well as outside system sounds) with direct monitoring of your input signal"}
{"source": " Very simple to use for overdubbing"}
{"source": " Some people may prefer a hard left/right pan while overdubbing: I can live with the center mix though a switch to toggle a true pan would have been a terrific feature"}
{"source": "If you do want desktop speaker playback after your tracks are done, there are a number ways to go: 1) Unplug the US-100 and restart your DAW"}
{"source": " 2) Run a cable from the RCA outs on the US-100 to the mini-jack aux in on your desktop speakers 3) Run a mini-jack extension cord from the headphone jack on the US-100 to the aux-in"}
{"source": "While using the headphone jack, the RCA audio outs are muted and vis-versa"}
{"source": " Rather than having to pull out the headphone I would prefer a push switch that toggles the front to back output, but I can live without it"}
{"source": "Again, the US-100 works great so long as your needs meet its capabilities"}

{"source": " Up to now I've been using a variety of microphones together with various microphone preamps and an A/D converters- a mass of cables and power supplies that bad enough on the desk, but a real hassle when trying to use with a laptop away from home"}
{"source": " The Yeti has it all in one package"}
{"source": " It may not sound quite as good as a multi-thousand dollar condenser microphone and vacuum tube preamp, but for the money it simply can't be beat"}
{"source": "I was looking for an affordable mic enabling me to make announcements from a home computer that would approximate, if not be indistinguishable from, the audio quality of the heavy-duty Shure microphones used at WGTD FM HD"}
{"source": "  All the mics that I had previously tried at this price point and lower, including Blue's \"Snow\" line, sounded overly treblish, with pronounced sibilance (listen to the comparison-contrast provided by the first reviewer in his video demonstration)"}
{"source": "  By contrast, the Yeti is rich and resonant, and its sensitivity permits using it without benefit of a pop filter"}
{"source": "  Short of spending 4-5 times more, I'm convinced this is the best option in my particular case"}
{"source": "At the same time, as a musician without a home studio I seriously doubt I'll make much use of the mic for performance or recording"}
{"source": "  As far as performance goes, the very size and conspicuousness of the unit could compromise presentation, upstaging the performer (at least a vocalist with a normal-sized head)"}
{"source": "  And for traveling purposes, I've found the Sansom Go mic to be the best fit with a laptop computer (even though Blue's literature shows the Yeti alongside a laptop)"}
{"source": "Blue appears to be trying to have it all ways with this product"}
{"source": "  Its size and weight are likely to attract buyers as well as provoke reservations--perhaps leading some purchasers to complement what strikes me as a home studio mic with one or more of Blue's lighter, more compact microphones"}
{"source": "  Its onboard amplifier and circuitry are convenient and permit unprecedented versatility"}
{"source": "  But as other reviewers have mentioned, the volume, gain, and pattern knobs are rather loose, allowing for lateral and vertical as well as the expected rotating movement"}
{"source": "  The knobs turn effortlessly but not with the ball-bearing smoothness one might associate with ultra expensive professional equipment"}
{"source": " There's the slightest hint of resistance at one point in the gain control's circular movement, but it's not at the 12 o'clock position, so it's difficult to say whether or not the knob is intended to have a mid-point for quick and easy assessment of positioning"}
{"source": "In sum, the Yeti should please anyone who wants to broadcast or record a fuller and richer sound than that previously attainable with comparably-priced mics, and it should prove a useful (not to mention handsome) addition to any home studio"}
{"source": "  It's still a bit early to make any pronouncements about the worthiness of this imposing metal humanoid as a road warrior"}
{"source": "  It's main competitor on Amazon--the Audio Technica AT2020--is pint-sized compared to the Yeti, and I'll confess I'm still not sure whether I made the best choice (the 2 mics have been alternating in the 1 and 2 slots of best-selling mics on Amazon for 3 months now)"}
{"source": "  I wish there were some direct reviewer comparisons to indicate whether the AT's relative compactness and light weight come at a compromise--however slight--to audio quality"}
{"source": "[I experienced initial hesitancy on Yeti's part to make an appearance in the Input and Output panels (in System Preferences) of my iMac"}
{"source": " Then I read the instructions, which discourage plugging the mic into a hub"}
{"source": " Plugged directly into a USB port on my computer, Yeti immediately sprang into action"}
{"source": " My hunch is that a good, powered 4-port hub would be equally effective"}
{"source": "]"}

{"source": " Repeating the process yielded identical results"}
{"source": " After rebooting the computer, the problem went away"}
{"source": " Hopefully there won't be long term issues"}
{"source": "The bottom line is that not a single problem related to the quality of the microphone itself, which works well, is very clear, and is extremely sensitive"}
{"source": " It will pick up a whisper from 15 feet away with the same clarity as if I were sitting two feet in front of it"}
{"source": " That's with volume settings that work clearly when I really am two feet in front of it"}
{"source": " The down side is that it will pick up every stray sound from letting your hand rub your shirt to letting your feet rub the carpet"}

{"source": "I normally tune to drop f on my 8 string, but even in standard, I just cant stand the strobe, and theres no other mode"}
{"source": " I ordered a pitch black for $70"}
{"source": " Im still waiting on the return for this"}
{"source": "As a musician for over four decades I've owned a number of tuners as the technology progressed"}
{"source": "  My primary instrument is electric bass"}
{"source": "  This is the finest piece of equipment I've ever purchased and used, and it has helped me solve a 'mysterious' tuning phenomenon all players apparently face without knowing it"}
{"source": "  I'll explain"}
{"source": "  But first, some details about the tuner"}
{"source": ":  it's construction is extremely solid, and it's heft gives it stability"}
{"source": "  When you place it on a surface (top of your amp, floor, your knee"}
{"source": " it stays there!)"}
{"source": "  Secondly, the large backlit display is very easy to read in all lighting conditions,"}
{"source": "no guessing"}
{"source": "  And thirdly, it is extremely sensitive and accurate, which brings me to my explanation of the 'mysterious tuning phenomenon"}
{"source": "  At issue is the inability of inexpensive tuners to properly identify frequencies/tones when setting string intonation at the octave fret"}
{"source": "  I've been using $25 to $40 tuners (Boss, Korg, etc) over the past few years that would indicate a string is in tune, both for open string and octave"}
{"source": "  But, when simultaneously plucking an 'F' note on the 'A' string, and an 'F' note high up on the 'G' string my ear would percieve that they just weren't in tune"}
{"source": "the cycles weren't matching"}
{"source": "  So, that meant my inexpensive tuner wasn't nearly discriminating enough"}
{"source": "  Once I began using this strobe tuner, it clearly showed me (with proper accuracy) graphically what my ear was trying to tell me"}
{"source": "  After setting intonation according to the strobe tuner my bass now 'performs' as it should through the range of notes/frets over the length of the neck"}
{"source": "  I guess another way of explaining it would be to say that it's like having a GPS that is accurate enough to get you to the right neighborhood, versus one that can get you to the right house"}
{"source": "  For the money, I feel I've done myself a good turn by purchasing this strobe tuner"}
{"source": "  I'm satisfied"}
{"source": "  I still keep one of my inexpensive tuners in my guitar case as it has a built in microphone and can be used by an accoustic guitar player if I'm jamming with somebody"}
{"source": "  This strobe tuner is 'cable input' only"}
{"source": "no mic, runs on a 9v battery with connectors for a power supply (sold separately)"}
{"source": "  My only 'complaint' with this device is the battery connector"}
{"source": "  It's the typical type that 'plugs' in to the top of your 9v battery with two wires leading to the internals"}
{"source": "  I hate them as a rule"}
{"source": "  I would prefer solid contact points and a compartment where you would simply insert the battery, just like inserting any other battery type (AA, AAA, C, etc)"}
{"source": "By now, you have probably read about the problem with the USB connection generating a high pitch sound during recording making the USB functionality unusable (an Amazon reviewer referred to this as a \"fatal flaw,\" and I heartily agree)"}
{"source": " I experienced this firsthand, then read folks struggling with the issue on the Mackie support blogs"}
{"source": " When I called Mackie support to seek a fix, I was told that the problem was well known and the newer lots had been corrected with new hardware"}
{"source": " They sent me a new Mackie Board from the newer lots, and I returned my old one"}
{"source": " I have not had any problems with the USB functionality since"}
{"source": " I am thankful to Mackie for the great customer service, especially since I addressed the problem after the one year warranty had expired"}

{"source": "This is my first tube amp and after doing a TON of research, I found that the VOX AC15C1 was just about perfect for me"}
{"source": "It came down to the AC15, Fender Blues Jr"}
{"source": " and the Ibanez TS15"}
{"source": " The Blues Jr"}
{"source": " has a somewhat small enclosure for a 1x12 and I felt it had a bit of a \"boxy\" tone, otherwise, it's a great amp"}
{"source": " The Ibanez has a classic Tube Screamer circuit built in and a switch which cuts the wattage in half for playing at lower volumes, but it lacked a reverb circuit, which was a deal breaker (silly reasoning, I know)"}
{"source": " The AC15 has a larger enclosure than the Blues Jr"}
{"source": ", and it has a reverb AND tremolo circuit, so it had the features I was looking for and most importantly, it produces some killer tone"}
{"source": "If you've ever seen or read a review of this amp, chances are, you've heard about the classic VOX \"chime\", which this amp has, but I fell in love with the natural tube saturation on the top boost channel right away"}
{"source": " The normal channel will break up nicely too, but I would suggest an A/B switch and run the normal channel fairly clean and the top boost pretty dirty"}
{"source": "I was worried at first that 15 watts wouldn't be enough, but fear not, this amp is LOUD"}
{"source": " maybe too loud as I'm just a hobbyist that plays in the bedroom, but that's not a bad thing"}
{"source": " It totally blows away my 100 watt Marshall solid state and I haven't put the volume much past 8 O'clock for fear that my wife may beat me to death if I do"}
{"source": "While there is no effects loop, it takes pedals well, but for distorted tones, I've found myself just plugging straight in just to get the unadulterated tube crunch, which I've come to love so much"}
{"source": " As stated above, the lack of a foot switch to change between clean and dirty tones will have to be solved by either running a dirt box in front of the amp, or as previously stated, running one channel clean and one channel dirty and us an A/B switch to go between them"}

{"source": "  You need to purchase an optional foot switch to toggle between the \"Top Boost\" and \"Normal\" channels"}

{"source": "  That overdrive does not interfere with the Vox tone at all"}
{"source": "  I used it this morning with a stratocaster loaded with DiMarzio HS series pickups and the Joyo pedal pushing the amp, and it was classic Vox chime all the way"}
{"source": "  I also used a Boss DD-5 delay (also required if you play in a Christian band - same reason as the other thing I mentioned"}
{"source": ")  Pure tone heaven"}
{"source": "Some have noted noise or \"hiss\" problems with this amp, which were usually solved by installing a better set of preamp tubes"}
{"source": "  Mine did not have this problem"}
{"source": "  Actually, I thought it did, and I was certainly getting a loud hiss out of it for a while before I realized that it was the way I had the amp set up:  As I stated earlier, this is a 2-channel amp (Normal and Top Boost), but which one you're using is determined by which input you plug your guitar into"}
{"source": "  I was plugged into the Normal channel, and didn't realize that the Top Boost volume was dimed and that's where the hiss was coming from"}
{"source": "  I just shut that volume completely off since I was not using the Top Boost channel anyway"}
{"source": "  Problem solved"}

{"source": " apparently they aren't easy to make"}
{"source": "? I've been through 4 (coun't 'em four) foot pedal compressors and wasn't at all happy"}
{"source": " an engineer mixer buddy said go try this pedal MXR CSP202 - so I did - and it's perfect"}
{"source": "Benefits:1) It's easy to match your output gain on the pedal - so when you step on it - the pedal activates quality compression and NOT output volume suppression2) It's easy to understand right away - 3 seconds of looking at the pedal and you're done - 3 minutes of fooling around with it and you get it3) It's quiet but very effective and professional sounding4) It's solid and works exactly like very expensive rack compressionNegatives:1) It's expensive considering there are compression pedals for 1/2 this price2) It's got the 9 volt power supply connector on the wrong side of the input quarter inch jackOver all the thing is a Home Run - you can work around he poorly located 9 volt connection - you can wait a few weeks and save a few more dollars if you need to, but you can't fix a bad compression pedal if you buy the wrong one"}
{"source": " I highly recommend this pedal, after a long process of searching and being disappointed I'm glad I found this pedal"}
{"source": "After trying about every comp out there for years, I came across this, I have a Wampler Ego Compressor too, it is the same quality as the Ego Compressor"}
{"source": "Better than the Script Reissue, it was too noisey for me"}
{"source": "Compression is possibly one of the most misunderstood pedal (or rack) effects for guitar players, but I can say confidently that the MXR Custom Comp gets it right, and makes it easy"}
{"source": "WHAT IT DOES - First, a quick word about compression"}
{"source": "  The easiest way to describe compression is that smooths and sustains the level and intensity of your guitar's pure tone"}
{"source": "  When you play an uncompressed guitar signal, you can experience annoying volume swells if you strum too aggressively"}
{"source": "  On the other side of the problem, you may want to use strummed chords or arpeggiated sequences for a continuous \"ringing\" effect, but find that the individual notes die out too soon"}
{"source": "  A quality compressor pedal takes those extremes and normalizes them"}
{"source": "  It also can \"sustain\" the notes by boosting the levels of individual chords or notes when they would otherwise fade away, depending on the settings"}
{"source": "BUILD QUALITY - If there are complaints to be had about the MXR Custom Comp, they aren't related to durability"}
{"source": "  MXR pedals, like BOSS pedals, are built with heavy-duty metal, yet the pedal is surprisingly light with the battery removed"}
{"source": "  Unlike BOSS pedals, the switch is in the form of a metal button that \"clicks\" when you press it"}
{"source": "  My understanding from veteran MXR users is that the switch is very reliable and long-lasting"}
{"source": "  In my case, however, I intend on having the thing on all the time, so this is not a major concern anyway"}
{"source": "One gripe with the pedal is the accessibility of the battery and internal \"Attack\" control"}
{"source": "  The pedal has knobs for Output (volume) and Sensitivity (basically, amount of compression)"}
{"source": "  The \"Attack\" knob, which is found on some rival compressors, has to do with the degree of \"pick attack\" sound you want when you first hit the note, and whether the sound comes on aggressiveness or more subtly"}
{"source": "  But on the MXR Custom Comp, you need to remove the back plate (4 Phillips screws) and adjust the Attack know with a screwdriver"}
{"source": "  You also need to remove the back plate to get to the battery, though I've switched to a power adapter/daisy chain (OneSpot) for my pedals anyway"}
{"source": "  So, yes, it's an inconvenience, but with this type of effect, it's not like you would want to adjust the Attack the way you would mess with Tone or Gain on a distortion pedal"}
{"source": "  I consider this also to be a non-issue"}
{"source": "TONE/SOUND QUALITY - The sound quality of this effect is outstanding"}
{"source": "  It is far more \"transparent\" than other pedals I've tried in terms of retaining the tonal characteristics of my guitar, but leveling everything out for a great \"finishing touch\""}
{"source": "  Whereas I used to think of compression as an \"effect\" I would turn on for a specific type of tone, I could envision always leaving this effect on with the MXR Custom Comp"}
{"source": "  It simply makes my underlying clean tone and other effects more manageable and better sounding"}
{"source": "COMPARISON TO OTHER PEDALS - The toughest question to ask about the MXR Custom Comp is whether it is worth the extra money"}
{"source": "  The top-end professional compressors (Keeley pedals, rack units, etc"}
{"source": ") are usually north of $200, which isn't practical for a casual player"}
{"source": "  Boss makes the CS-3 Compression Sustainer, which is the pedal I traded in for the Custom Comp"}
{"source": "  The CS-3 is more affordable (about $50 to $75 new) and more customizable, with 4 knobs on the exterior of the pedal, adding \"Attack\" and \"Sustain\""}
{"source": "  It definitely does the job in terms of adding sustain, and might make sense if you only want to play around with compression from time to time"}
{"source": "  But much like with MXR's entry level compressor (The Dyna Comp in the red casing), it simply isn't up to the quality of this pedal"}
{"source": "ADVICE - While compression doesn't \"color\" your guitar tone the way a distortion pedal does, it's arguably as important to your overall tone quality as any other pedal"}
{"source": "  If you're interested in compression and want the best option at an affordable price, I recommend the Custom Comp at $100 or less on Amazon, or used on eBay, where I've seen it go for about $70 to $85"}
{"source": "  It may not be \"necessary\" for everyone, but very few people who try it will come away disappointed"}
{"source": "  Turn it on, play with the settings for a minute or two, and then leave it on and strum away"}
{"source": "These days on my pedal board I have several MXR Micro pedals"}

{"source": "  The springs in the back keep it back"}

{"source": "One thing to consider is adding the matching ZT extension cabinet"}
{"source": "  It makes a big difference in two ways: two 6"}
{"source": "5\" speakers move more air and the doubled speaker cone area helps thicken the sound"}
{"source": "  Also, because the speakers can be angled and separated the area covered by the sound is increased"}
{"source": "  This is a big help at rehearsals"}
{"source": "  I point one cabinet towards myself and the other into the room"}
{"source": "  I've tried using a guitar speaker cab, a PA speaker, and a PA floor monitor as an extension speaker but the ZT extension cabinet sounds best to me"}

{"source": "*******In my mind, the only \"negatives\" (aside from trying to install the USB MIDI driver/see below) are that Yamaha sells this keyboard without the AC adapter and sustain pedal as standard accessories, and you really need both"}
{"source": " Yamaha should note that a lot of people feel burned by the non-inclusion of the AC adapter"}
{"source": "********NOTE FOR THOSE WANTING TO USE THIS KEYBOARD VIA USB/MIDI ON A WINDOWS 7 SYSTEMThe USB MIDI drivers for this instrument are provided on a CD - the disk I got only contained drivers up to Windows Vista - I tried cheating and using this driver on my WIN 7 system, but it didn't work"}
{"source": " The CD will supply you with a link that should take you directly to the latest driver downloads, but it doesn't - I ran into a lot of problems going that route - I suggest you bypass trying to use the link the CD suggests and just go directly to the Yamaha website to get the latest driver"}
{"source": " Much easier, and my YPG-235 now works fine with my computer, but still surprising since most USB MIDI keyboards are plug and play"}
{"source": "After having played the Yamaha YPG-535 88-key Portable Grand Piano Keyboard in a showroom and loving it, I was torn, wondering what all I would be missing out on if I went with the more economically priced YPG-235"}
{"source": " I now own the 235 and it appears as if I am missing out on twelve keys"}
{"source": " That is, I am not experiencing even an ounce of buyer's remorse after opting for the cheaper 235"}
{"source": " This is a lovely keyboard with more beautiful voices than I will ever know what to do with and extremely user friendly functionality"}
{"source": " Of course, my opinion should be taken with a grain of salt as I will be the first to admit that my experience with other products of this variety is extremely limited"}
{"source": " As such, it might be best to say that, for a novice, one could not ask for a better instrument for the price"}
{"source": "So what is the difference between the 235 and the 535? Based on my previous comparative shopping, I have come up with a few differences"}
{"source": " First is the obvious fact that the 535 possesses 88 keys, while the 235 has 76"}
{"source": " The 535 also includes a stand, sustain pedal, and power adapter, which must be purchased separately for the 235"}
{"source": " While I am unaware of the specifics, the 535 also has greater storage capacity and capability as well as a few more voices"}
{"source": " Beyond these definitive differences, having now played both models, the 535 also wins out with regard to aesthetics in that it looks and feels to be of a slightly higher quality, from its display to the apparent craftsmanship in assembly"}
{"source": "Why buy the YPG-235? If price is not an issue, go ahead and get he 535, it is a beautiful instrument"}
{"source": " However, for those on a budget or for those who simply do not need 88 keys, purchase the 235"}
{"source": " Like the 535, the 235 possesses piano style Graded Soft Touch (GST) keys, which are not exactly weighted but occupy that perfect gap between pure synth keys and weighted"}
{"source": " The feel is perfect for one who is used to standard synth-style keyboard keys yet longs for a little more control without sacrificing playability"}
{"source": " The 235, like the 535, also features USB connectivity and general MIDI compatibility, as well as almost all of the same high quality voices, which separate both the 535 and the 235 from many other models in their price brackets (besides the pianos, the multitude of stringed instrument voices are amazingly realistic)"}
{"source": " While it is unfortunate that Yamaha decided to not include a power adapter with the 235, theYamaha Survival Kit D - Accessory Kit for Yamaha YPG-235 & YPG-235 Keyboardswhich includes a power adaptor, extended warranty, and a couple of other low quality extras can be purchased relatively cheaply"}

{"source": "Acoustic guitar amps have more in common with stereo systems than traditional electric guitar amps: neutral full-range sound (rather than crunch & distortion), high power ratings for clean tone, full range speaker system with woofer and tweeter and sensitive preamp inputs optimized for the low output of piezo pickups"}
{"source": " Unfortunately for me, acoustic amps tend to be optimized for steel-strings and rarely get classical guitar tone right, even with dial diddling"}
{"source": " As a dedicated nylon-string player, I'm always looking for the holy grail of amps"}
{"source": " Is the Mini sent from heaven?PIEZO TONE: I jacked in my Takamine LTD2012 Classical and Hirade TH8SS (classicals with Cool Tubes preamps) and with tone controls set flat and had my ears pinned back with shockingly powerful output"}
{"source": " The master volume was barely cracked but this little guy is loud and muscular"}
{"source": " Unfortunately, that big sound wasn't natural and sounded closer to an electric guitar than a classical: big bass, bright lower trebles, weak mids, quacky tone and compressed"}
{"source": " Obviously, under-saddle piezo pickups are no studio mic but it should sound better than this"}
{"source": " So I diddled the controls and it improved a bit but I couldn't dial in a pleasing tone"}
{"source": " The best timbre with my Hirades was bass-11:00, mid-3:00 and treble-9:00 (clock face orientation)"}
{"source": "Some acoustic guitar amps allow the tweeter to be disabled and I suspect the Mini's overly bright tone would benefit from cutting that little guy from the circuit"}
{"source": " As a point of comparison, Cool Tube piezo pickup tone from my 21 year old Trace Elliot TA50R is much more natural, complex and sustained"}
{"source": " Cool Tube piezo tone from my SHEN-CPK-8T is drop-dead gorgeous"}
{"source": " Perhaps these other amps have additional processing to naturalize and de-piezo the tone? They cost more than the Mini so they gotta earn their keep somehow"}
{"source": "I plugged in my mid-1990s Trace Acoustic TAP-1 preamp into the Mini and was able to dial in better tone, albeit still not as good as my ancient TA50R"}
{"source": " I also tested my Fishman Aura Spectrum D"}
{"source": "I"}
{"source": " and it rendered more natural classical tone"}
{"source": " So you can get decent classical guitar tone if you're willing to carry another box to your gig"}
{"source": "REVERB: The single program digital reverb makes amp timbre brighter and harsher sounding, even when mixed in sparingly"}
{"source": " Wish this amp had an effects loop as any budget half rack unit will sound better"}
{"source": "MIC TONE: I don't normally use a mic for casual gigs but this is feature is handy when you need to mic a friend or blend in a small internal mic for extra ambience"}
{"source": " The Mini lacks phantom power so I installed a battery in my Shure 849 condenser mic, set tone controls flat and was greeted with surprisingly natural mic tone"}
{"source": " I also tried my ancient Shure SM57 dynamic mic with similar good results, albeit that mic needed a little treble cut"}
{"source": " As a point of comparison, the Mini whips my TA50R good in terms of mic output and tone"}
{"source": "APPEARANCE & BUILD: The Loudbox looks more attractive than the pictures"}
{"source": " And it is much lighter and slightly smaller than my TA50R"}
{"source": " If you drag it to gigs you'll find the exterior delicate: the vinyl material and underlying wood are easily damaged by gentle pressure from straps and carts"}
{"source": " It's the most delicate amp I've owned"}
{"source": "FINAL BLURB: My feelings about this amp are mixed"}
{"source": " For value and use as a wee PA it's a 5 star deal"}
{"source": " For under saddle pickup classical guitar amplification it works but is far from natural: compressed dynamics, bright lower highs (even at full treble cut) and the dreaded piezo quack"}
{"source": " So 2 stars for classical guitar reproduction"}
{"source": " The Fishman Aura Spectrum D"}
{"source": "I"}
{"source": " or similar acoustic guitar processor does significantly improve tone, but that's another 2 or 3 bills"}
{"source": " Unfortunately, straight out of the cardboard, the Loudbox is not ready for for primetime nylon string reproduction"}
{"source": " I suspected the Mini was optimized for steel-string guitar tone, so I borrowed a friend's Takamine EF341S and I was right: steel-string reproduction is significantly better than nylon-string"}
{"source": " All in all, the Mini packs a lot of punch for 3 bills and just may be the best buck to tone ratio deal for a novice coffee house artist"}

{"source": "a tip for people new to guitar, cable that have a angled jack are best for when you sit and play because when you plug a straight one into the guitar jack and you sit you actually bend the wire, and what happens is the wire actually have to be bent in a certain way to work and eventually wont work at all,just like headphone wires"}

{"source": "GOOD POINTS: [1] This cable, unlike many other coiled cables I've tried, does NOT add noise when it's moved"}
{"source": " I swung it about quite a bit while playing through it, and it made no noise at all"}
{"source": " [2] It also has good plugs in that the indentation on the male plug provides a generous gap, making it easy for the female jack to connect to the male end"}
{"source": " As a result, the cable does not slip out TOO easily; the connection between jack and plug is quite secure"}
{"source": " BAD POINTS: [1] The package it comes in says it's a 20-foot cable"}
{"source": " Not even close! Holding it up by one end, with the other end simply dangling (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": ", not plugged into anything), I saw that it measures 3 feet (again, that's when it's not stretched); when not stretched at all, it measures just 3 feet"}
{"source": " Of course, this would not result in 20 feet when it's stretched"}
{"source": " Sure enough, when I plugged it into an amp, I could COMFORTABLY stretch it to only about 6"}
{"source": "5 feet"}
{"source": " This might not bother you; it doesn't bother me since I didn't want the extra cable length"}
{"source": " But if you need anything like a 20-foot cable, you're going to have to get something else"}
{"source": " [2] Finally, a minor point: If you're using this on a guitar with a Strat-style jack, this cable will be a bit---but only a bit---more difficult than most cables to unplug from the guitar, no matter which end you plug into your guitar, because there's not much to grip when unplugging"}
{"source": " Of course, if you pull on the cable itself, instead of one of the ends, you'll ruin it in no time"}
{"source": " Overall, I am quite happy with this cable and would buy more, since I don't need more than the length it has, and since it makes no noise"}

{"source": "I've used 4 different brands of clip-on tuners to tune my Classical guitars and electric basses, but this tuner is the most accurate"}
{"source": " It captures the note immediately without errors, whether the low E on an electric bass guitar or the high E on my classical guitar"}
{"source": " It is fast enough to use real time during intonation practice/training on fretless bass"}
{"source": " It works flawlessly on solid body and acoustic instruments"}
{"source": " Takes a little getting used to but simply, if the rings spin clockwise, the note is sharp; if the rings spin counterclockwise the note is flat"}

{"source": "As my reviews demonstrate, I'm a sucker for a new tuner"}
{"source": "  Peterson has an excellent reputation for its strobe tuners"}
{"source": " I'd even tried one, once, but decided it wasn't the sort of thing to be carrying around to jams"}
{"source": "  So, when I saw that Peterson had introduced a clip on tuner, I couldn't help but salivate"}
{"source": "\"Awkward\" is a relative term, but I don't feel it's a disservice to use it here"}
{"source": "  The typical clip-on tuner has an LCD \"needle\""}
{"source": " When the needle is dead center, the string is tuner"}
{"source": "  If it's short of center, the string is flat"}
{"source": "  If it's past center, the string is sharp"}
{"source": "  The SC-1 has two sets of rings that appear to rotate, analogous to what a strobe might look like"}
{"source": "  A string is in tune when the rings stop rotating"}
{"source": "  I found that with the way the sound of strings decays, it's difficult to get the rings to stop spinning, even in the SC-1's sustain mode"}
{"source": "  (I've already returned the tuner"}
{"source": "  Otherwise, I just realized, it would have been a big help to have done a short video of tuning a guitar with the SC-1 and with a Zoid or Intelli"}
{"source": ")The SC-1 also boasts a \"sweetened\" mode for tuning guitars"}
{"source": "  However, when  I tuned my lounging-at-home guitar this way, I found the needle was dead center on every string on my Intelli tuner"}
{"source": " (For those who've read my other reviews, my preferred Zoid was in the case with my favorite guitar"}
{"source": ")It may well be, and others may report, that the SC-1's feature set make it ideal for other situations"}
{"source": "  However, if you main purpose is to keep a guitar in tune, then, with the SC-1 costing more than THREE ZoidsZoid Z-1000 Clip-On Tuner by Sabineor FOUR IntellisIntelli IMT500 Clip-on Chromatic Digital Tuner for Strings, I recommend that you consider the Zoid or Intelli"}

{"source": "USB Condenser mics and more specifically this one are great for doing Podcasts and for portability"}
{"source": " The reason being is that they are condensers for one, and the other is that this mic has a built in interface"}
{"source": " An interface is a glorified sound card with both a microphone preamp and (Analogue to digital, and digital to analogue) AD/DA converters"}
{"source": " Of course most any standalone interface is going to give you way more desirable results than just plugging a microphone into the mic jack on your computer; way, way better"}
{"source": " So this MXL Studio 24 USB even with the built in interface is going to give you quality far exceeding your computers potential"}
{"source": " So instead of having to carry a separate interface around with you having this all in one MXL Studio 24 USB all you need is a laptop with a USB input and you"}
{"source": "There are limitations though with a USB mic with the main one being that you can only record the microphone without being able to plug in any instruments"}
{"source": " (Although you could record instruments using this microphone and that way be able to layer more tracks in your DAW"}
{"source": ") Recording multiple tracks at the same time is not possible with this mic unless you are recording the same thing in multiple tracks"}
{"source": "The really good thing about this mic is that you are getting some pretty decent quality for the money"}
{"source": " So for anything that you need to do using a microphone as your one and only sound device it is ideal, quick, easy, and affordable"}
{"source": "One of the problems with using it in Pro Tools, or any DAW is that you can only use one interface at a time"}
{"source": " Since the mic has a built in interface you can't use any other"}
{"source": " Even in Garage Band for MAC, although they have the ability to use more than one interface because you can toggle between the two but not be able to use two simultaneously"}
{"source": " So in plain words if you are planning studio capabilities a USB mic is not what you need"}
{"source": " I have a couple of MXL condenser mics that I bought for my studio"}
{"source": " I have the MXL V57M which was their early offering but is no longer made and I have found the MXL V250 to be comparable to that one"}
{"source": " Some other MXL's like the 990 are muddy in the bottom end"}
{"source": " When bottom fishing for a good/decent condenser mic some of the CAD offerings are also top sellers"}
{"source": "When using the MXL 24 USB in Win 7 no driver download is necessary"}
{"source": " If your mic comes without the included CD you can download the free MXL Studio Control app which includes input controls for microphone gain and an adjustable high pass filter"}
{"source": " It also has a nose gate with adjustable threshold"}
{"source": " There are also output adjustments as well"}
{"source": "One other thing that is unique about USB mics working with your PC is that they are dependent of course on your PC"}
{"source": " So I had the hardest time trying to figure out what was wrong when I couldn't get the output from my PC or into the free Reaper DAW recording software (free 60 day trial) also downloadable from MXL"}
{"source": " So I finally gave up after trying various input options etc and discovered through the troubleshooter in Windows 7 accessible via Control panel, and then \"Sound\" and then type \"Troubleshooter\" into the search box in the upper right corner"}
{"source": " The answer was that my mic input volume inside of Windows was down to zero"}
{"source": " I moved the slider up and bang it worked"}
{"source": "So for sound quality you are getting decent quality for the price and it has a built in interface and even an output jack you can plug your headphones into; it's a mini jack like you have on your computer"}

{"source": "  One feature in the Fuse software that no one seems to mention is the ability to add an overdrive or compressor module \"post gain\" (after the preamp)"}
{"source": " This is an incredibly useful tool for controlling the overdrive characteristics of the amp models"}
{"source": "  In effect, Fender has given this amp the ability to emulate power section saturation as the overdrive module sounds very different and much mellower post gain than pre gain (before the preamp like a normal stomp box)"}
{"source": "I don't know of any other dedicated modelers that do this except maybe the Axe-FX - and that costs about 20 times more"}
{"source": "  Power section saturation is highly desirable and is the reason why we're seeing a lot of very low power tube amps like the Fender Champion 600 and Bugera V5 these days"}
{"source": " Their problem is that they're pretty much useless for clean sounds at louder volumes - they don't have enough power for that so they're really only good for overdriven sounds"}

{"source": ")So what are the presets? Each of the 9 amp models has been pre-programmed with three different presets (meaning a professional put three different combinations of effects on the amp model to showcase its best sounds)"}
{"source": "When you select a preset, like the first metal 2000 for example, the minute you touch the \"gain\" knob, the gain that was programmed for that preset now becomes whatever level you set"}
{"source": " Same with treble, bass, volume, and all other effects"}

{"source": "For those unfamiliar with Vox's amPlug products, these things are amazing"}
{"source": "  I'm just old enough to remember some of the portable options of the 1990's, and they were mostly terrible"}
{"source": "  What Vox has done with these tiny headphone amplifiers (which weigh virtually nothing, run for 10-15 hours on 2 AAA batteries, and plug directly into the guitar) is nothing short of amazing"}
{"source": "  They have incredible amp-like tone and get as loud as you can possibly want"}
{"source": "  Even through a pair of $20 Sony headphones, they sound amazing"}
{"source": "  The star of the collection, in my opinion, is the Vox AC30 amPlug, which does a great vintage tube amp ranging from sparkling cleans to Top Boost overdrive"}
{"source": "  If you haven't played an amPlug before, the AC30 one is $39"}
{"source": "99 of the best money you'll ever spend"}
{"source": "Now, getting to this specific Joe Satriani amPlug, it's impossible to talk about the tone without talking about the guitarist himself"}
{"source": "  Fans of Joe Satriani (even casual ones) will recognize elements of this sound right away"}
{"source": "  Satriani has a very distinctive sound, which he crafted over the years using a modified Boss DS-1 Distortion and (more recently) his Vox \"Satchurator\" Distortion Box"}
{"source": "  It's a thick lead tone with a nice sustain, and colored with a delay effect"}
{"source": "  Both of those elements are present on this signature amPlug"}
{"source": "  You have a level control, a gain control, and a tone control"}
{"source": "  There's also three switch positions: Off, On, and Fx"}
{"source": "  The \"Fx\" position engages the delay effect, but the tone is otherwise the same"}
{"source": "PROS:First, the price retails at $49"}
{"source": "99, whereas most of the other models are $39"}
{"source": "99"}
{"source": "  (I believe the Lead amPlug is also $49"}
{"source": "99 and also has a delay feature)"}
{"source": "  I think that the added delay feature and unique tone are worth the extra money, but this is admittedly a sort of \"niche\" product"}
{"source": "  Overall, however, you have several amPlugs to choose from, and if you choose this one, $49"}
{"source": "99 is still an incredible value for the ability to play your guitar virtually anywhere and enjoy quality tone"}
{"source": "  The tone has a real sweet spot between \"3\" and \"5\" that really makes it enjoyable to play lead notes"}
{"source": "  While it isn't necessarily and \"ideal\" rhythm guitar distortion, you can hit rich chords with nice sustain"}
{"source": "  I prefer the tone on the higher gain levels, and you can really crank it up if you want to, but it sounds great at lower volumes too"}
{"source": "  The delay is also surprisingly good - it's probably set to around the 400 milisecond gap, which is pretty standard"}
{"source": "  Adds a cool echo \"fullness\" to your solo progressions, much like a classic Satriani solo"}
{"source": "  Again, the overall tone is fantastic"}
{"source": "  With the amount of gain provided, you can play most types of rock and dabble into metal guitar a bit (though I've always thought of Satch of more a technical, melodic guitarist than a \"metal\" guitarist)"}
{"source": "CONS:There are a few things to know about the Satriani signature model, but I don't think any of them should discourage you from checking it out"}
{"source": "  While the delay is surprisingly good, you can't customize it"}
{"source": "  You can't make the repeats shorter or longer, and you can't adjust the timing of the repeats"}
{"source": "  Keep in mind that this is mostly a \"practice\" device for your personal use, however, and I still enjoy using the delay"}
{"source": "  As for the tone, which I mostly discussed as a \"pro\" in the paragraph above, you should be aware that this is not meant to be a \"clean\" signal"}
{"source": "  It is possible to get a somewhat clean tone by rolling back on the gain or lowering the volume of your guitar, but it's mostly distortion or bust"}
{"source": "  The durability of all of the amPlugs has also been questioned by some"}
{"source": "  The device is VERY lightweight and all plastic, except for the metal plug portion"}
{"source": "  I don't doubt that you could bang it on something and break it quite easily"}
{"source": "  The switches and dials may also fail over time"}
{"source": "  But frankly, at $40 or $50, it's probably a better value than making it out of heavy duty metal and charging $100 for it, which would lock more people out of the market"}
{"source": "  I would certainly buy another one (or several) if any of mine broke"}
{"source": "  Finally, there as an audible \"hiss\" noise through your headphones anytime the device is on"}
{"source": "  Slightly annoying when you're not playing, but I don't notice it at all once I start playing notes"}
{"source": "THE VERDICT:One other \"dirty little secret\" to point out about these things: in addition to the Aux jack, which allows you to plug in an MP3 player and jam along, it is possible to use a 1/8\" to 1/4\" adapter and audio cable to plug this thing directly into an amp, PA, or anything with speakers"}
{"source": "  You might be surprised how good it sounds"}
{"source": "As an after-note, I wrote most of this review playing on my Jackson DR6, which has two Seymour Duncan Humbuckers, and it sounded great"}

{"source": "For proof that it is exactly the same, I was able to modify it for different frequency response (corner frequency), and add asymmetrical clipping with the exact same components in exactly the same spot in the circuit as seen in TS9 mods"}

{"source": "  Ba-Da Bing!"}
{"source": "There is no shortage of \"Tubescreamer clones\" on the market for guitarists in search of that warm overdriven tube sound perfect for blues, jazz, and rock"}
{"source": "  The DigiTech Bad Monkey is one such example"}
{"source": "  But the Chinese-made Joyo JF-01 Vintage Distortion just be the best, and it's half the price of a TS-9"}
{"source": "About the manufacturer - Joyo hit the market a couple of years back and has now released about a couple dozen pedals that utilize their own form factor (very similar to an MXR in size and switch) but \"cloning\" the circuitry of well-known classic and modern boutique effects pedals"}
{"source": "  Some people jump to conclusions about Chinese products, but don't just take it from me - do your homework"}
{"source": "  The response to these pedals has been overwhelmingly positive, and there are great vendors/distributors within the U"}
{"source": "S"}
{"source": " that test them out and can ship them to you within a few days"}
{"source": "  I'm definitely a fan of Joyo products"}
{"source": "As for the \"Vintage Distortion\" itself, people have said it's based on either a TS-9 or the (more expensive) TS-808"}
{"source": "  Frankly, while the latter is apparently warmer (and less mid-range heavy) than the former, I'm not sure there's any significant difference"}
{"source": "  I played this JF-01 side by side with my TS-9, and it's probably one of the more exact \"clones\" in the Joyo lineup"}
{"source": "  For example, the Joyo \"Ultimate Drive\" is an excellent (higher-gain) overdrive pedal based on a Fulltone OCD, but you can still notice differences in the resulting sound and settings required to get there (some of which are arguably BETTER than the original)"}
{"source": "  With the settings matched, the JF-01 performed almost exactly like the TS-9 in level, gain, and tone"}
{"source": "  There probably is little more gain available on this pedal with that knob cranked full, which isn't a bad thing"}
{"source": "  It's very responsive to your playing style and, again, it sounds like a Tubescreamer"}
{"source": "I'll probably be keeping my Tubescreamer, if only because it's an iconic pedal that performs well"}
{"source": "  But it's superior in name only - if I had to use the Joyo Vintage Overdrive in its place, I'd be no worse for the wear"}
{"source": "  5 stars, highly recommended!"}
{"source": "I ended up returning it and bought a cheaper generic model as the other one has better effect for less than half the price"}

{"source": "  What more could you want?  The Samson Meteor Mic USB Studio Microphone is a cardioid mic that is easy to set up and use, with great pick up for desktop podcasts, user testing, screencasting and similar"}
{"source": "Being a relatively new user to anything but a basic desk mic, I had to look up what 'cardioid' meant"}
{"source": "  I found a solid explanation at a site called WiseGeek"}
{"source": "  They explain 'cardioid':  \"Several different microphones have been designed throughout the years to accomplish very different tasks"}
{"source": " Some -- such as condenser microphones -- pick up a great deal of sound from several directions, while others pick up one focused sound only from one direction"}
{"source": " Of this latter group, the cardioid microphone is perhaps the most popular, as it picks up almost exclusively the desired sound while ambient noise is hardly noticeable"}
{"source": " It gets its name because of its pattern of sensitivity, which is roughly shaped like a heart when drawn out on an axis"}
{"source": " This means that most of the sound it picks up comes from the front of the microphone, while minimal noise is picked up from the rear and only marginal noise is picked up from the sides"}
{"source": "\"  (My apologies to those pros out there who didn't need this clarification"}
{"source": ")Having used the Samson Go Mic USB Compact Mic for a few months, I was familiar with the Samson brand prior to receiving this mic through the Amazon Vine program"}
{"source": "  I had actually wanted to purchase it instead of the Go Mic, but the price difference of about thirty was a bit too much for me at the time"}
{"source": "I've been happy with theSamson Go Mic Compact USB Microphone - Plug n' Playfor use with my desktop and laptop PCs"}
{"source": "  I do a lot of usability testing for various websites, and it's imperative that clients are able to clearly hear my explanations via voice without background noise, pops, hisses or similar"}
{"source": "  I have to say that the Samson Meteor is a touch better, offering clear, crisp recording and reproduction"}
{"source": "  It also seems to pick up virtually no background noise, which is fabulous!I like the retro styling of the Meteor, and the built-in stand is great for desktops"}
{"source": "  Less portable than the Samson Go Mic, the stand does fold neatly onto the mic for easy transport in the included soft pouch"}
{"source": "  The included USB cable is also of ample length for easy set-up in a multitude of situations"}
{"source": "The mute button on the front of the Meteor is very handy"}
{"source": "  Much easier than using software to get the job done, and an amber light makes it easy to recognize it's muted"}
{"source": "The build quality of the mic is excellent! Very solid, high-end feel"}
{"source": "  You can use the integrated headset port to monitor your voice and adjust levels with a dial that rotates around the mute button on the front"}
{"source": "The Samson Meteor didn't ship with any software, which while unnecessary for installation (my Windows 7 and 8 PCs automatically installed it when hooked up via the included USB), but would have been nice to have some music mixing or other similar software bundled with it"}
{"source": "Another product I'm reviewing the:Samson C01UCW Studio USB Mic with Cakewalk Sonar LEand the Samson Go Mic both ship with Cakewalk software"}
{"source": " The Samson Go Mic with Cakewalk Music Creator LE, and the C01UCW ships with Cakewalk's SONAR LE software, so I found it kind of surprising the Meteor did not at this price point"}
{"source": "  For me it works out, as the others have the software and they work with the Meteor"}
{"source": "The included booklet includes a Quick Start guide for PC and Mac, Installation how-to, the Layout (diagrams), Specifications, Polar Patten & Frequency response, and Recording Techniques for vocals, acoustic guitar, piano, guitar amp, and overhead drum kit"}
{"source": "  The Samson Meteor Mic Warranty Card is also in the booklet"}
{"source": "Overall, I'm very pleased with this microphone and will be using it instead of the Go Mic on my desktop for daily work which will include using Dragon voice recognition software"}

{"source": "Perhaps more than anything else, it was the introduction and subsequent success of the Zoom H2 personal digital recorder that led to an explosion of interest among home audiophiles, who suddenly found themselves equipped to make quasi-professional-level recordings with their computers plus a minimum of user-friendly equipment at reasonable prices"}
{"source": "  The price of the Samson Meteor USB mic, a fairly recent entry, has come down to the point of being fairly valued (initially, I was seeing it going for prices above the better-sounding Blue Yeti mic)"}
{"source": "  It's an attractive (some would say \"cute\") little mic with its quaint \"retro\" design and deceptively fold-up, portable size"}
{"source": "  I say \"deceptive\" because, due to the non-adjustable mic stand, it can be more than a little challenging to find space for it on a desktop, next to a computer, and squarely in front of the narrator's mouth"}
{"source": "Bearing in mind the above reservation along with the actual quality of the recorded sound (it's good, but nowhere close to studio-quality), it would seem to make the most sense for those seeking \"high fidelity\" audio to spend the extra 20% for a Blue Yeti or an Audio Technica AT2020 USB (as tempting as the lower price of the non-USB version of the AT2020 is, be sure to try it out with a pre-amp supplying phantom power before going that route"}

{"source": "I bought my Yamaha guitarlele about 2 years ago from Long & McQuade located in Canada"}
{"source": "  It's the same as the one Amazon is selling here"}
{"source": "  I teach classical guitar but have always loved the sound of ukulele"}
{"source": "  My reason for buying this is because I don't have to learn how to play the ukulele and can play the guitarlele using the knowledge I already have - yea!It is very similar to a guitar in many important ways"}
{"source": "  It has the same 6 strings tuned the same way"}
{"source": "  However, and this is VERY important so please read carefully:  To get the best sound out of your new guitarlele you must tune each string up in pitch"}
{"source": "  For example, let's take the 6th string (lowest) and tune it up to A instead of E"}
{"source": "  Clip on your electronic guitar tuner and crank that string up a bit until the tuner reads \"A\""}
{"source": "  It will be the same pitch as the actual 5th string on the guitar"}
{"source": "So here's the breakdown on tuning each string:6th = A5th = D4th = G3rd = C2nd = E1st = AYou really need to to tune it this way because otherwise the strings are too floppy and you won't get that beautiful ukulele voice"}
{"source": "  The action is very good and it will not be any harder to play"}
{"source": "The instrument overall is fairly easy to play, especially in the lower positions"}
{"source": "  I have trouble holding it because I'm used to holding a classical guitar so I always have to make adjustments to get used to it"}
{"source": "  Barring chords especially higher up the neck is kind of tough because the frets are so close together so I usually play easier stuff"}
{"source": "  Also, I have discovered that certain types of music really play well and others aren't so good"}
{"source": "  Almost all Celtic music sounds great!  Christmas carols are lovely, but Spanish stuff doesn't sound so great, imho"}
{"source": "  The instrument just doesn't have enough power to carry some types of music"}
{"source": "  Blues are good, and very ancient sounding tunes like those that would have been played on a 4 course guitar from back around the 15th century sound really cool on the guitarlele"}

{"source": "Until 5-6 years ago there was a virtual void in high-quality personal digital recorders"}
{"source": "  Then the Zoom H2 came along, and numerous variations on a theme were soon to follow"}
{"source": "  I've owned both the H2 and the H1 and, though both have their strong points, the Tascam DR-05 has served me better than either"}
{"source": " The H2 has pleasing 4-point sound and the H1, at half the size of the Tascam, works well for \"stealth\" as well as video recordings when mounted on a camera"}
{"source": "  But both recorders are more complicated than necessary, with tricky menu systems, excessive tiny buttons (6 on one thin side of the H1), and dicey build quality"}
{"source": "The Tascam addresses these shortcomings with a machine that's a pleasure to use"}
{"source": "  There are no shaky, rattling parts, the controls are solid and instantly solved (easily manageable with a single thumb), and the wide-spread mic pattern is ideal for most stereo recordings of music (for dictation, I use a separate, small mic inserted in the topside input)"}
{"source": "  The machine reminds me of the far costlier Sony PCM-50 in terms of ease and convenience of operation"}
{"source": " The Tascam's 320 kbps MP3 recordings of a grand piano strike my ears as no less authentic and sonically \"present\" than its 96/24 WAV files, and tweaking is held to the absolute minimum"}
{"source": "  If you don't have $500 to spend and are looking for a woodshedding companion for day-in, day-out use, this is the one"}

{"source": "Wanted to review this pedal because I felt some of the other reviews were a little lukewarm"}
{"source": "  Distortion is incredibly subjective-it depends on your rig and your tastes"}
{"source": " But the Badass '78 by MXR is a very nice pedal for a decent price"}
{"source": "  It doesn't do metal or super high-gain, but offers some nice classic rock tones and can be quite warm if you back off on the tone knob"}
{"source": " The crunch button adds brightness and volume and may or may not be too harsh for your setup"}
{"source": "  However, the tone knob does do a pretty good job of rolling back the high end, especially if you activate the \"crunch\" button"}
{"source": "The build quality seems to be pretty good, though I should note that while the pedal is the same size as other MXR pedals, it is significantly lighter"}
{"source": "  I suppose this could make it more susceptible to denting and damage if it travels, but it should be plenty durable for 95% of users"}
{"source": "  I really like the switch on this one too, it's easy to press and clearly clicks \"on\" once depressed"}
{"source": "  One minor annoyance if you use the \"crunch\" setting is that the blue light (which is annoyingly bright like an LED headlight) stays on EVEN when the pedal itself is off"}
{"source": "  This can be quite distracting if you rely on the lights on your pedal board to tell you which effects are on"}
{"source": "  Not really a major gripe that detracts from the pedal's quality, but a frustrating design decision"}
{"source": "Basically, if you get the right setup, you'll get great tone"}
{"source": "  I got this pedal specifically to try and find a better alternative to the BOSS DS-1, which lacks mids and can sound harsh/abrasive"}
{"source": "  The MXR '78 Badass is definitely superior in that regard, but a lot will depend on your rig and settings"}
{"source": "  I find that this pedal really excels on playing single notes on the lower strings (think \"Walk this Way\" by Aerosmith, or \"Hangingaround\" intro by Counting Crows)"}

{"source": "For most guitarists, tremolo is a very simple effect"}
{"source": "  You simply want a pedal to control swells or oscillations in volume to give your tone a \"shimmering\" effect"}
{"source": "  It's used in subtle fashion in everything from to 50's/60's rock and surf guitar to modern \"indie\" rock"}
{"source": "  But most guitarists (like me) were never going to shell out $100 (or more) for a Boss or other expensive tremolo option"}
{"source": "  In fact, there really weren't that many affordable tremolo pedals on the market"}
{"source": "Enter the Joyo JF-09 Tremolo"}
{"source": "  This pedal is simple, durable, affordable ($40 - $45), and it just works"}
{"source": "  The only two controls are for Intensity (depth of the volume swells) and Rate (how fast the swells cycle)"}
{"source": "  The LED light dims rhythmically along with the \"Rate\" control, which is a nice visual indicator"}
{"source": "As for the sound - the pedal sounds great"}
{"source": "  It doesn't color or diminish your tone in any way"}
{"source": "  I'm not a \"tremolo expert\", but the effect sounds as it should"}
{"source": "  If you're the type to obsess over tremolo, then you probably aren't looking to save money anyway, and there are $200 boutique options from Catalinbread and others that have tap input and other features"}
{"source": "  I'm not particularly interested in those, so the lack of those on the Joyo won't detract from my score"}
{"source": "Regarding the quality and durability of Joyo pedals, there's a lot of discussion about that, but also some misinformation"}
{"source": "  I've personally owned 7 of them at one point or another (yes, I like them that much), and I've yet to have one fail"}
{"source": "  The early run of Joyo pedals is actually quite durable, and includes the JF-09 Tremolo and every pedal numbered from JF-01 through JF-17"}
{"source": "  The more recent models numbered higher than that are all similar in appearance, and while many of them still sound great, they feel lighter, \"cheaper\", and the switch is a little more suspect"}
{"source": "  I recommend ordering through a vendor that ships from the U"}
{"source": "S"}
{"source": ", rather than trying to save a few bucks on a direct shipment from China"}
{"source": "  Many of the U"}
{"source": "S"}
{"source": " vendors will test the pedal out before shipping it, which is a huge advantage"}
{"source": "Highly recommended!"}

{"source": "  I've used both of these similarly priced tuners and have found them both to be excellent"}
{"source": "  I can't really tell any difference in the accuracy of either one"}
{"source": "  They are both contact tuners, meaning that they pick up the vibration of the instrument rather than relying on an external microphone"}
{"source": "The Hola! is definitely the best choice of the two in that it's more versatile, easier to use, more durable looking, and easier to store"}
{"source": "  The Hola! lies virtually flat and takes up less space in every dimension than the snark"}
{"source": "  It comes in a plastic sales container that can be reused to offer further protection if you feel the need"}
{"source": "  The Snark's curved display arm (which you can't really see in the photo) is slightly more delicate looking, in addition to the fact that it extrudes farther"}
{"source": "  I found the Hola! display to be bigger, brighter and generally easier to read"}
{"source": "  Honestly, most of these differences are minor especially when considering how inexpensive these tuners are"}
{"source": "  The really important difference is the &#34;tuning mode&#34; feature on the Hola!"}
{"source": "Hola! offers very simple operation with one button for power and for switching between its 4 modes of function"}
{"source": "  You can select &#34;chromatic&#34;, &#34;guitar&#34;, &#34;bass&#34; and &#34;ukulele&#34; modes by briefly pressing the power button (as opposed to a long-press for power on/off)"}
{"source": "  This is an especially important feature if the user is not an experienced and knowledgeable musician"}
{"source": "  Imagine trying to tune with a an 88-key piano if you don't know anything about the notes on the piano"}
{"source": "  &#34;Ukulele&#34; mode is like using a piano with only 4 notes"}
{"source": "  Use &#34;chromatic&#34; to tune your uke differently than standard or tune other instruments"}

{"source": "If you are like me, my research for a guitar connection to my iPad left me with choosing between the iRiffport and the Jam"}
{"source": "  I recently purchased, and then returned, the iRiffport"}
{"source": "  I am very pleased that I purchased the Apogee Jam as a replacement"}
{"source": "  Here are the reasons why:1) The connector on the iRiffport (the one that goes into the iPad) is not a strong connection at all; it feels as though it could disconnect at any time"}
{"source": "  I have a stand to put my iPad on when jamming such that the iPad is in landscape mode, so the cord feels as though it will come out of moved the wrong way"}
{"source": "  With the Apogee Jam, the connector is just like the iPad's connector, except it ALSO has the \"prongs\" that come out of it, securing the connector into the iPad"}
{"source": "  To remove the connector from the iPad, you need to squeeze the buttons on the connector to make the \"prongs\" go in so it can be removed"}
{"source": "very, very secure"}
{"source": "  I use the \"Gumdrop\" case on my iPad, which has a flap that goes over the charging port when not being used"}
{"source": "  This flap feels pretty tawt when it is open while the charging port is being used"}
{"source": "  IMPORTANT:  if you have such an iPad case, like me, I certainly feel that the Jam will provide a much more secure connection to your iPad over the iRiffport"}
{"source": "  In fact, the structure of the iRiffport connector was so large, that I felt that it did not fit well through my case"}
{"source": "  On the other hand, the Jam's connector is the same small size as the iPad's original connector"}
{"source": "  This is also something to consider if you intend to use your iPad in portrait mode on a stand with the connector on the bottom of the iPad"}
{"source": "2) Probably the largest reason I prefer the Jam over the iRiffport:  you can hear sound directly from the iPad"}
{"source": "  With the iRiffport, you MUST use headphones or attach external speakers"}
{"source": "  I tried headphones with the iRiffport and playing the guitar was very awkward"}
{"source": "  Nonetheless, with the Jam, I could attach headphones or external speakers to the iPad if I chose to do so"}
{"source": "  I wanted something that could make my iPad an amplifier for easy mobility around my house, without having to purchase another amplifier or external speakers"}
{"source": "  With the Jam, I have this"}
{"source": "3) The Jam has a gain meter (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": ", an LED) and a gain control"}
{"source": "  The iRiffport does not"}
{"source": "  When not being used to measure the level of the incoming audio, the LED lets you know if you are connected to the iPad, but not to any software (blue light), or if you are connected to the iPad AND to a software application (green light)"}
{"source": "  There are no batteries needed for the Jam or the iRiffport"}
{"source": "4) I personally like that I can use my own guitar cord with the Jam"}
{"source": "  If the cord breaks, I simply replace the cord, not my iPad connection device"}
{"source": "  The iRiffport uses its own cord, and the connection to my guitar did not feel as strong as my \"normal\" guitar cable I used with the Jam"}

{"source": " I had previously used a variety of input devices from a JamHub to a Behringer USB line input device to an Art audio preamp to even going low-budget with just a cable directly into the microphone input of the (ThinkPad) laptop"}
{"source": " This cable provides as high quality of an audio signal as any other reasonably priced device I have used"}
{"source": "There are, however, a few limitations"}
{"source": "- This cable is mono only, i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": " not for stereo recording"}
{"source": " This seems obvious, but is worth mentioning for those who have less experience with this type of stuff"}
{"source": "- This cable only works with Dynamic Microphones"}
{"source": " If your microphone is a Condenser microphone, you either need a battery powered microphone or some type of 'phantom' power source to power the condenser microphone"}
{"source": "The really good things?- This cable works excellent at providing a good signal level to the Audacity software"}
{"source": " Some input devices are either very hot (too much level) or have hardly any gain at all, so this cable works very well by providing just the right level"}

{"source": "After having collected a few guiters through the years I needed the kind of stand to hold certain ones in particular"}
{"source": "Good for any beginner, but consultation with a teacher, if you have one, is recommended"}
{"source": "  For ham fisted persons, positioning is not easy; for lossening strings, proper bridge resetting, and exact measuring of string length from the nut to the bridge is required"}
{"source": "  Measuring requires a hard ruler with a full 330 milimeters (325 required) - bet you don't have one - or a technician's measuring tape and confident measuring skill"}
{"source": "  Measuring is best with a cooperative assistant"}
{"source": "  Bridge distance can be first set by good measurement and tightening the D string to hold the bridge position, measurement check, tightening the A string, measurement check, removal of the backing material and good positioning of the guide while eliminating the bubbles followed by tightening the 1st and 4th strings and tuning the instrument"}
{"source": " Do it!  You'll appreciate your instrument a lot more than it takes to just pick it up and start practicing"}
{"source": "  If you ain't intelligent, Good Luck!  You'd best be served with dot stickers"}
{"source": "Excellent picks, with nicely rounded corners to the essentially triangular shape and nicely beveled edges to make tremolo playing easy and smooth"}
{"source": "  The only problem I have is that I keep changing my mind between whether I want a crisp corner for my picking for clarity or a pick like these for smoother playing"}
{"source": "  These are a great addition to any mandolin player's case because they give the player a nice alternative to trying to use one of the rounded corners on a pick like a Fender heavy"}
{"source": "These picks are comparable in shape and feel to Grisman's Dawg Picks (and frankly, cheaper)"}
{"source": " The thickness and rounded bevel will absorb a lot of high end from your tone and, depending on how you play, this may or may not be acceptable"}
{"source": "In my opinion, if you play with a relatively free and loose wrist, without anchoring your fingers or palm on the mandolin face or bridge, you'll get a woody, warm tone with plenty of definition and good volume"}
{"source": " Varying the horizontal contact point along the strings can bring out a bit more high end"}
{"source": " I play this way and am more than satisfied with the picks"}
{"source": " (For guitar I prefer a 1 mm traditional tri-corner shape but that's a different review)"}
{"source": " If, however, you're really a fan of a biting high treble sound, these picks are probably not your best choice unless you're willing to put a sharper edge on the bevel with a file and fine sandpaper"}
{"source": " In fact, a pack of 12 three corner picks can be an economic way to experiment with pick shape and bevel angle if you're searching for your ideal tone"}
{"source": "If you support your hand by resting your palm or fingers on the mandolin, chances are your attack, tone and volume are generally softer and I think these picks will produce an unacceptably dull tone"}
{"source": " Tweaking the shape may still leave you feeling as though you're not benefiting from the large mass of the pick and it's just slowing you down"}
{"source": " For such a lighter stroke, I'd recommend the 1 mm tri-corner I use for guitar"}
{"source": "Picks are personal thing and even then everyone seems to change once in a while"}

{"source": "I just received my Blue Radius Shock Mount, and I was immediately floored by the the size and looks of the unit"}
{"source": " It reminds me a set piece from Fritz Lang's \"Metropolis\", the rings around Saturn or something built by Tesla"}
{"source": " It's a beautiful thing, certain to impress anyone who might sit in front of it to be recorded"}
{"source": " Certainly beats the homemade 4 inch PVC pipe and bungee cord shock mount I previously had made and my Yeti mounted to"}
{"source": " What is impressive about this mount is you have full and clear access to the the Yeti's 3 knob's, mute switch and USB/Headphone plugs on the bottom of the mic, whereas my homemade version gave me fits with knob access"}
{"source": " Once you screw the Yeti into the machined shock mount base, there are teflon or maybe white delrin washers which allow you to swivel the mic easily to access the back knobs or move it toward any position, say a guest speaker with great ease"}
{"source": " The build is hefty, machined aluminum rings with stainless steel mounts and screws"}
{"source": " The elastic suspension bands are not going to fly across the room, as they do on most shock mounts, because they are not threaded on hooks, but securely fastened to brackets, then the holding screws"}
{"source": " The Radius also allows you to mount the Yeti on a boom stand, upside down, which I have always been told is the best way to mount a condenser type mic so dust and moisture (spit) does not build up near the capsules or internal electronics, it just falls, as gravity allows"}
{"source": "Does a shock mount make a difference in sound? To my ears, yes, especially if you are recording into say, a laptop on a table, the fans and hard drive are going to vibrate, coloring your overall sound with unwanted hum"}
{"source": " Although the mic stand the Yeti comes with does an O"}
{"source": "K"}
{"source": " job of dampening vibration, it is not going to give you as much isolation as the Radius, which will be noticed when the gain controls are turned up"}
{"source": " There is also the science of unwanted resonance from instruments, rooms or cabs vibrating your stands, that's why you see most professional studios using shock mounts, you just get a cleaner sound"}
{"source": " In a test, the Radius works like a charm, even from pounding on my mixing desk"}
{"source": " A 9"}
{"source": "0 earthquake is not going to cause any vibration"}
{"source": "On the down side, just to play Devils Advocate, The Radius is huge, and may nor be suitable for tight spots or portability"}
{"source": " That said, the Yeti is also a big microphone, and once mounted, may add six inches to the overall space you will need to use this setup properly"}
{"source": " Next, when you un mount the Yeti from it's built in stand, you are going to have gaping screw holes in the side of the mic"}
{"source": " I fixed that by screwing the old Yeti stand screws back into the holes, which actually looks kind of neat to me"}
{"source": " To some maybe, it will look like bolts in the Frankenstein Monsters neck, but I think it all fits together"}
{"source": " Next, smaller base microphone stands will want to tip, either angle the Yeti plus Radius back, or get a bigger stand, this is the one I have and would highly reccomend, theSamson SAMD5 MD5 Desktop Mic Stand"}
{"source": " Lastly, this mount will only work, as far as I can see, with a Blue Yeti or Blue Yeti Pro microphone, maybe some other mics will work, but not likely"}
{"source": "In conclusion, the Radius is an easy set up, works great and makes a Yeti look retro/futuristic sexy! Yeah it actually looks really cool, like a spaceship blasting off or landing, take your pick, I know people coming into my studio are going to say, \"What The heck is that, and where can I get one!?\" I may tease and say it's and award or art piece"}
