{"source": "Apple threw a curve at me when, with the new \"thin\" iMac, the company eliminated not only the Superdrive but the 3"}
{"source": "5mm \"Audio In\" port that had been highly useful on previous models, especially for recording computer sounds with a single patch cord"}
{"source": "  After trying a Griffin and Logitech device, I finally found a useful workaround with the Behringer UFO202 interface (there are 2 other very similar models by Behringer--the UCA202 and the UCA222)"}
{"source": " What sets these interfaces apart from the 302USB is a smaller footprint and a permanently-attached, \"dedicated\" USB cord"}
{"source": "  Simply by plugging the USB cord into the USB port on my iMac I was able to record all of the broadcasts, tapes and LPs just as I had done with my old iMac (though monitoring required more cords in back--ugh!)"}
{"source": "For a committed neophyte like me, the UFO202 was probably sufficient"}
{"source": "  I miss the permanently attached USB \"out\" cable and, moreover, am questioning whether I'll ever use the mixing capabilities of the 302USB, which to my eyes has a bit of a \"learning curve"}
{"source": "\"  The problem for the impatient beginner begins with the instruction manual"}
{"source": "  Instead of separate sections, the manual uses small, thin font and mixes English with Spanish instructions--a minor but unnecessary inconvenience"}
{"source": " (But give Behringer credit for providing a manual!)I thought I was investing in more versatility (for a modest price increase) than what the Behringer UFO/UCA line of interfaces offered me"}
{"source": "  But a friend tells me that GarageBand has the capability of recording sound-on-sound"}
{"source": "  My present programs (Sound Studio and Toast) can't do it, but if GB can layer 2 or more sound sources, then the question becomes whether an external mixer does it better"}
{"source": "  If not, the Behringer UFO202 is not only adequate to serve my needs, but its tiny footprint makes it especially welcome on a new iMac's desk space (Apple's elimination of the internal burner gives the company \"thin screen\" bragging rights while robbing the user of both money and space--thanks to the new requirement of an external burner)"}
{"source": "Behringer has presented the best solution I've been able to find to Apple's surprising (and dubious) omissions with the latest iMac"}
{"source": "  If your uses include mixing, and if you have the space (we're talking a mere inch or two), the 302USB is no doubt worth an extra ten bucks"}
{"source": "  But if you have a UFO or UCA interface, your needs may already be covered"}
{"source": "I bought the smaller Behringer 302usb mixer for a small home recording setup with a budget target of &#60;$125, but had to move up to this model for and additional cost of about $12 due to the fact that the 302usb doesn't provide adequate phantom power for a Condenser Microphone (not properly disclosed by the company)"}
{"source": " The simple setup I have also includes the Behringer C-1 Condenser Microphone and a Hosa XLR cable"}
{"source": "I was looking to improve the quality of voice recordings for podcasts, interviews, etc"}
{"source": ", over a simple USB headset, without &#34;breaking the bank&#34;"}

{"source": "HINTS AND TIPS:Two good hints on this one:* Another user and I put our heads together and realized one can use a 6-volt lantern battery (or 3 to 4 AA cells), hook them into a USB printer cable and power this via battery"}
{"source": "  It works great and makes this unit PORTABLE"}
{"source": "* There are reports of this mixer interfering with the way the Windows handles sound"}
{"source": " I have found this to be true"}
{"source": " It pretty much takes over your entire sound system"}
{"source": " For some folks this will be fine"}
{"source": " For others, they may not appreciate this"}
{"source": " So what I did was uninstall the drivers, remove it from the computer USB (which seems to defeat the purpose, but wait"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": " and plugged it into one of those new portable-USB power supplies you plug right into the wall (they're available all over for between $5 and $10)"}
{"source": " This powers the system without hooking it into the USB system of your computer"}
{"source": " What this does is allow you to use the functions of the mixer without altering how Windows handles sound, the programs it uses, or causing problems with programs like Audacity"}
{"source": "You then run a LINE IN from your computer speaker output, a LINE OUT to your computer speakers or headphones, and you can still use microphones or whatever else you want"}
{"source": " This is an excellent alternative to using it as a USB device"}
{"source": " You are instead powering it from a USB wall-socket and simply using it as a quality mini-mixer (which function it performs very well)"}
{"source": " That's what I finally did and am still most happy with this device"}
{"source": "In addition by using it in this manner you pretty much eliminate the relevance of what OS you use"}
{"source": " You could use this with Windows, Mac, Linux or pretty much anything, because all you're really doing is setting it up as a mixer using standard line-in / out cables"}
{"source": " Works very well in this capacity"}
{"source": " Gotta love those new external USB power nodes"}
{"source": " : )"}
{"source": "Each bx5 d2 speaker has its own amp onboard and power supply"}
{"source": "  Want a 5 channel system - buy 5 speakers and run xlr audio to each one"}
{"source": "  No noise or hum"}
{"source": "  Has both trs and xlr inputs - has a knob for gain control on back"}
{"source": "  Most importantly each speaker has an IEC connector for power to JUST that speaker"}
{"source": "  Mine sit left and right of my mixing panel using TRS outputs which copy the XLRs - those go to my Marantz PMD 580 digital recorder w/ 32 GB of datacard memory onboard and a nice set of vu meters"}
{"source": "  Speakers include a foam stick on bottom to prevent buzzing against hard surfaces"}
{"source": "  There is, however, no mounting point - no captive nuts or such"}
{"source": "You'll need to adopt a philosophy on gain"}
{"source": "  You can crank the speaker gain to 100% and use your mixer to set the levels but ensure that your recorder gets enough signal to be in the -15 to -6 dB0 range"}
{"source": "  It may be a tad loud - in that case you may want to set both speakers to their 12 oclock position which is 50% power approximately"}
{"source": "You could alternately use the mixer to run near 0 dB and turn it way down on the speakers"}
{"source": "  I like to use mine to listen to talk shows before falling asleep at night so I turn the volume way down but drive them with -6 dB0 off the mixer"}
{"source": "Having a separate power supply and amp for each speaker makes for some great isolation"}
{"source": "My **FIRST** nitpick is there is no grill cover on these like other maudio products have"}
{"source": "  I will have to fabricate some protection"}
{"source": "  My second nitpick is i owned the smaller m-audio 4\" monitors where the amps were in the left speaker and the right speaker connected with twin lead speaker wire to the left i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": " not true bi amping but smaller spkrs for my mixer"}
{"source": "  The speaker w/ 2amps died at 15 mos after buying it"}
{"source": "  It was not the power supply as being on made the box warm, but the led surround around the vol knob would not light and you could barely hear the audio even with -3dB0 into the trs line in"}
{"source": "  Thats a different cheaper model by maudio but i had to trash it and buy these which are much nicer!I do like this set of speakers"}
{"source": "  From stereo to 5"}
{"source": "1 surround they do the job with differential audio inputs"}
{"source": "  I may get 3 more for 5 ch as i have a sub already"}
{"source": "SOUND QUALITY: The BX5 sounds neutral and balanced"}
{"source": " Compared to similar sized consumer speakers, they are a bit understated and without bass bloat or exaggerated highs (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": ", teen EQ)"}
{"source": " The even keeled tonal signature is pleasing and easy to listen to for hours"}
{"source": " It also lacks a midrange bump, and sounds a bit recessed or laid-back compared to average earbuds or home speakers"}
{"source": " In fact the BX5 sounds similar to my Sennheiser 580HD headphones, but with less lower bass"}
{"source": " And that's a good thing for mixing as you don't want speakers that add color and/or bumps in the frequency response"}
{"source": "Unlike typical passive stereo speakers, the BX5 is powered with separate amplifiers for the tweeter and woofer, i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": ", bi-amped"}
{"source": " This design allows for accurate reproduction as amplifiers are optimized for each driver"}
{"source": " The downside to this design is each speaker needs both input and power cables, so not convenient for living room use but not a problem for nearfield computer based editing"}
{"source": "At first the BX5 struck me as underpowered for a 70 watt rating, at least with a signal directly from my Mac Pro"}
{"source": " However, once jacked into the hotter signal from my MOTU Ultralite the true power of the BX5 was revealed"}
{"source": " It was loud and could be painfully so if cranked"}
{"source": "These are directional speakers and render placement of instruments in a stereo soundfield accurately as long as you sit in the sweet spot a couple feet out (your head should form a triangle with the two speakers)"}
{"source": " That diffuse room filling tone of home theatre speakers is MIA"}
{"source": " In fact, unlike most speakers, there is little rearwards projection"}
{"source": " Perfect for not bothering family or neighbors but bad for parties"}
{"source": " So don't buy these for standard stereo or home theatre use"}
{"source": "I mainly mix classical and acoustic guitar solo and ensemble recordings, live and multitrack, so the bass range is perfect for me"}
{"source": " The bass extends down to a clear 60Hz, so plenty ump for drop-D and drop-C tuning"}
{"source": " If you mix bass guitar and kick drum you'll want larger speakers (BX8) or a sub but these are great for guitar"}
{"source": "I'm used to mixing with neutral speakers and headphones but it would be nice if you could adjust bass, mid and highs for different room responses and taste"}
{"source": " Oddly, the PDF instructions show EQ switches for the prior version of this model but they are missing from my speakers"}
{"source": " I assume they were omitted as a cost cutting measure"}
{"source": "RFI RESISTANCE: I'm an inner city dweller and live in a high RFI area"}
{"source": " Cheap audio gear acts like a radio receiver and injects a local classic rock station into my mixes"}
{"source": " So one of the major selling points for me was M-Audio's claim of RFI shielding"}
{"source": " Luckily that was no mere marketing jive"}
{"source": " They really are well shielded against RFI"}
{"source": " Not a single wayward drum loop or DJ in my tracks, not even when cranked"}
{"source": " I can't make that claim for prior speakers I've owned"}
{"source": "HEAT: These speakers run on the warm side: the upper back is fairly warm just idling and can get hot to the touch after a long session"}
{"source": " Not egg frying hot but a wee bit uncomfortable to the fingertips"}
{"source": " It has a sensor to shut it down in case of excessive heat"}
{"source": " However I have not seen it shutdown even after all day editing sessions"}
{"source": " I live in the balmy tropics so cold weather dwellers may not see as much heat build up"}
{"source": " Not a deal breaker but it's wise to turn them off when not in use (I use a power strip so I don't have to flip two separate switches)"}
{"source": "CONSTRUCTION: These are handsome units in a blend in your your gear sort of way: the black finish matches perfectly with my black trimmed Cinema Display and MOTU Ultralite"}
{"source": " Construction appears very good with dense particle board (MDF) cabs, metal back plate (heat sink benefit) and matching plastic front molding around the drivers"}
{"source": " The cabs are covered with a satin black vinyl"}
{"source": " These monitors are petite and smaller than most speakers with the same sized bass driver"}
{"source": "The bass drivers are Kevlar with rubber surrounds (tougher than foam!) and the tweeters sport silk domes"}
{"source": " No protective grill or covers as usual for mixing monitors"}
{"source": " So the nekid drivers can be easily damaged by a careless finger or chopstick"}
{"source": "CONNECTIONS: Like most studio monitors, the BX5 comes with pro audio style jacks for 1/4 inch phone plug/TRS and XLR"}
{"source": " If you're a novice recordist or a civilian buying these for general computer use, be forewarned there are no stereo mini jacks, RCA or USB"}
{"source": " So you will need to pay extra for a set of special cables and adapters"}
{"source": " If you're an experienced recordist, you should have plenty of these cables laying around but, otherwise, be prepared to reach for your wallet"}
{"source": "One of the things I like about the BX5 is both the TRS and XLR connections are active at the same time, allowing the monitors to receive signals from two different sources without messing with cables or switches"}
{"source": " I have an Audioengine D1 DAC connected to the TRS/phone input (for iTunes, movies, games, etc"}
{"source": ") while a MOTU Ultralite (for mixing & tracking) is plugged into the XLR connection"}
{"source": "LAST BLURB: Yes, the small Focal speakers I listened to were better sounding and louder than the BX5 but cost a couple toes and a month of lunches"}
{"source": " However, a perfect monitor for a home studio isn't only about a good neutral sound, but also about compactness, appearance and value"}
{"source": " And the BX5 nails all of these while still sounding pretty dad burn fine"}

{"source": "  Get one of these and you'll soon have guitar picks coming out of your ears"}
{"source": "  My only issue is that a pick punched from, say, an old credit card isn't going to replace my favorite picks"}

{"source": " These are the original pick punches, by the company from the guy who invented them"}
{"source": " At least that's what it says on his website"}
{"source": " The others are knockoffs"}
{"source": "  They probably all work about the same, and they're all about the same price now, so why not support the dude who invented them"}
{"source": " He's really into making picks, and has some pretty cool ideas and instructions on his website"}
{"source": " I'm pretty crafty, and really like this"}
{"source": " Bummed about rough edges? Buy a fine sanding sponge at any hardware store, sand the edges for a few seconds, and be done with it"}
{"source": " He also sells sheets of plastic from his website, at quite good prices, and ink for stamping them"}
{"source": " I got a cheap rubber stamp made with my URL for about $10 online, and make my own \"business card\" picks now"}
{"source": " I also found some cool sheets of celluloid on eBay, it's not easy to find the right stuff but the picks I make now are just as good as any you would purchase, and the cost is way less for personalized pics anyway"}

{"source": " Everybody knows that picks just evaporate when you lose them anyway, what could possibly be greener?"}

{"source": "The NS Mini chromatic headstock tuner quickly recognized twelve pitches across a multi-octave range of electric bass, guitar and mandolin"}
{"source": " The accidentals appear as sharps or flats toggled using the alternate functions of the frequency button"}
{"source": "The tuner's view window is slightly larger than a Chiclet but brightness and resolution are fine for dimly-lit spaces"}
{"source": "  One thing that's less than ideal is the charcoal color of the tuner itself"}
{"source": " If you've ever dropped stuff on dark stages you know what I mean"}
{"source": " I'd wager the back of most headstocks skew to lighter tones than darker, so if discretion is what the manufacturer is emphasizing, a lighter color may work better"}
{"source": "The notes appear red when out of tune; their color changes to green as a `rough marker'"}
{"source": "  You then continue fine tuning using the vertical bars that appear on both sides of the note"}
{"source": "  They've gone to lengths to make the tuner stage-friendly, but I'd much prefer the green color mean ` fine tuned and done'"}
{"source": "  That way I can look from a distance"}
{"source": " I should only have to bother with the bars if I'm struggling to home in (and in my experience that's the exception rather than the rule and usually caused by: new strings, slack under the bridge pins, a slipping tuner, etc"}
{"source": "  Mid-life strings tend to stretch and loosen predictably, so long as you don't use a lot of altered tunings"}
{"source": "The NS is designed to be clipped discretely to your instrument headstock and viewed from the back"}
{"source": " I'm a lefty and, unlike some other tuners, I appreciate the swiveling base that allows me to view the screen right-side up"}
{"source": "The viewer doesn't extend far above the headstock surface and felt a bit cramped on my L4 with large New Yorker-style tuners"}
{"source": "  On headstocks with more bare wood like a Strat, or even my A-style mandolin, it was easier to find a comfortable spot for viewing that didn't obstruct my hand while turning keys"}
{"source": "At first I didn't like the ratchet clamp that attaches to the headstock"}
{"source": " I could attach the tuner with one hand by squeezing the clamp tight but it felt like I needed two to remove it: one to press the release and another to pull the clamp out"}
{"source": " After a little practice, however, I found this wasn't the case and the touch required isn't difficult at all"}
{"source": "The tuner's constructed in a high-impact composite, similar to those parachute-style clamps you see on backpacks"}
{"source": " It feels durable and very unlikely to break, although I didn't try stomping on it"}
{"source": "I was impressed the battery comes uninstalled in a separate small bag"}
{"source": "  The battery door has a concave slot for easy opening with a pick or a coin"}
{"source": " The tuner has an auto-shutoff function to preserve battery life"}
{"source": "The power and frequency buttons are just nibs really; I'd prefer they be larger with more surface and a bit of click to them"}
{"source": " The tuner can be calibrated in integer steps from 430 to 450 if 440 doesn't work for you"}
{"source": "One advantage of a chromatic tuner is you can tune to a chord and aren't limited to (usually) diatonic open strings"}
{"source": "  For myself, I only use tuners to set the pitch of one string, usually the low A for guitar or bass and low G for mandolin"}
{"source": " In my opinion, tuning a fretted instrument completely by open strings is only slightly better than tuning it completely with harmonics - and neither does the job well"}
{"source": " Intonation is subject to a bunch of variables: string action and thickness, neck relief, fret condition, nut and bridge condition"}
{"source": "Once I have a single string to pitch I match fretted and open string unisons and octaves"}
{"source": " After a while you learn which combination works best for each instrument"}
{"source": "I used to love staring at those Pignose-sized 'strob-a-tuners' sitting on amps and never faulted a musician who took their time to tune accurately (I wish many more did)"}

{"source": "  The first was slightly larger than a paperback book and cost what a cheap guitar sells for today"}
{"source": "  But it was a godsend tuning up backstage while another band was playing"}
{"source": "  Over the years tuners have gotten smaller, cheaper, and easier to use"}
{"source": "  The Planet Waves PW-CT-12 is my new favorite"}
{"source": "It is very small - a little bit larger than a grape"}
{"source": "  Despite some of the other reviews I have used it with good results on a Strat, Tele, Les Paul, and ES-335 electrics and on acoustics from Martin, Gibson, National Resophonic, and Voyage Air"}
{"source": "  I clamp it on the headstock between the nut and the low-E tuner"}
{"source": "  I didn't expect it but it is out of the way enough to leave on while playing"}
{"source": "  Previous to this my favorite tuner was a chromatic ukulele tuner built to clamp on the top of the headstock"}
{"source": "  Small and accurate but to use it behind the headstock I have to read it upside down"}
{"source": "  The PW-CT-12 is nicely out of the way even when I play an F chord with my thumb on the low E string"}
{"source": "  It's so light I don't notice it's there"}
{"source": "The display is bright and easy to see in most light"}
{"source": "  A bit hard to read in direct sunlight but I do my best to avoid playing without shade anyway"}
{"source": "  The display is small - a dime can cover most of it - but the characters are large enough to read in normal playing position"}
{"source": "  The '#' sharp symbol is small but once you are familiar with the display you recognize it"}
{"source": "  (No flat symbol"}
{"source": "  Bb is displayed as A#"}
{"source": ")  The tuner has auto shutoff to make the battery last longer"}
{"source": "  The display uses bars to the side of the note letter and color to indicate tuning"}
{"source": "  It's red until you get close then green with a bar on each side when you are in tune (for example, |E|)"}
{"source": "  I found it to be stable enough to be easy to use for quick tune ups between songs"}
{"source": "These are inexpensive and intended to be discrete so the clamp is small and thin"}
{"source": "  Rough handling will probably break it"}
{"source": "  I notice that the clamp is easily removed so I'm guessing Planet Waves may sell replacements"}
{"source": "  The clamp was not intuitive the first time but the instructions do cover it"}
{"source": "  It is a ratchet rather than a clamp"}
{"source": "  You press a small tab and gently pull the clamp out then push it down on the guitar neck"}
{"source": "  For this reason this is not a tuner to pass around"}
{"source": "  It's meant to be left on an instrument"}
{"source": "  (It's small enough that you can leave it on in the case"}
{"source": ")  If you need a tuner that is moved frequently there are better (and larger) choices"}
{"source": "  It can be moved but it is a good tuner to set and forget"}
{"source": "  I'm going to buy a couple more to leave on my most frequently used guitars"}
{"source": "Other reviewers commented on accuracy"}
{"source": "  If you want strobe accuracy there are better choices"}
{"source": "  For that kind of accuracy you also need a larger display"}
{"source": "  This tuner will get you close quickly and you can use your ears to fine tune if necessary"}
{"source": "  I haven't had a problem except with guitars that have built-in intonation problems (like old Nationals) and they need tweaking even after a Peterson Strobe"}
{"source": "Soapbox: especially if you are a new player, do yourself a favor and learn to tune your guitar by ear!  Try tuning the strings to a reference pitch or each other then use the tuner to check"}
{"source": "  Learning to tune by ear will help you in more ways than I have time to list"}
{"source": "  Being able to hear the intervals in a chord and know which string is off is an invaluable skill"}
{"source": "  People that can only tune with a tuner will take much longer to develop that, if ever"}
{"source": "The device itself is difficult to read in bright light"}

{"source": " What? After three days the battery goes out"}
{"source": "I would have returned it, but lost it because it doesn't adhere to the headstock very well"}
{"source": " You've been warned"}
{"source": "I tried this after I lost my planet waves ns design mini tuner"}
{"source": " Not sure if I lost it at a gig, or my three-year-old son got his hands on it, I'd bet the latter"}
{"source": "This micro tuner is smaller and lessobtrusive than the mini, which is nice"}
{"source": " That's about the only Pro"}
{"source": " There are a few other features I guess, like being able to select the instrument used, but I don't need that"}
{"source": "Cons: The readout is smaller, duh, but does not seem to be as bright"}
{"source": " I play a lot of outdoor weddings, in bright sun, and this one is much harder to read than the mini"}
{"source": "This micro tuner does not seem to tune as responsively as the mini"}
{"source": " As you move closer to In tune, the bars do not smoothly move towards the center, so it's easy to over or under tune, and can take a few more seconds then the mini to get the job done"}
{"source": " And those seconds can count when a bride is waiting for you to play her song to walk down the aisle and you're trying to get your tuning absolutely perfect"}
{"source": " I'm also trying to tune my semi-acoustic guitar as quietly as possible, so using my ear for fine tuning is not a viable option"}
{"source": "Does it get the job done? Yes"}
{"source": " But there is a product that's almost the same size that works a little better, for a negligible price difference"}
{"source": " It might even be cheaper"}

{"source": "I'll be upfront and honest right away and say that I'm not the biggest fan of headstock tuners"}
{"source": "  I love the idea, but usually I feel the execution leaves a bit to be desired"}
{"source": "  But when this popped up on my Vine newsletter I thought I'd give it a go and see if this one fixed any of the things I don't like about the other ones (*COUGH*snark*COUGH*)"}
{"source": "A little background first, I guess"}
{"source": "  I've been playing guitar for the last 9 years, and I currently have two other tuners"}
{"source": "  I have a little Korg plug in type,  where you can have it pick up your signal with an instrument cable or just use the microphone on the front to tune up"}
{"source": "  I also have a Boss TU-3 pedal tuner"}
{"source": "  If I'm jamming with friends or playing a show, the TU-3 is what I'll use to stay in tune"}
{"source": "  Its very durable and accurate, and I like how I can step on it to engage both the tuner and cut out my guitar signal, so I can tune in silence and not annoy my friends and/or the audience"}
{"source": "  For home practice I use the Korg, as I usually tune up before I start playing, then just plug into my practice amp and blast away"}
{"source": "  The Korg is nice and accurate, easy enough to use for alternate tunings, and in 9 years of having it around (including in and out of jam sessions before buying the TU-3) I've only had to buy one replacement"}
{"source": "I first saw a headstock tuner a year ago when a friend went to get an electronic tuner and the guy at the guitar store talked him into that blue Snark that everyone seems to have these days"}
{"source": "  He was not incredibly pleased with it"}
{"source": "  Not only was it somewhat garish to have a big blue ball sitting on your headstock, it seemed kinda flimsy to me and it wasn't exatly easy to tune up with it"}
{"source": "  While I thought the idea of having a tuner that worked off the resonation of your guitar would be cool, it seemed like the design had a bit of a ways to go before it was something I'd want on my headstock"}
{"source": "Enter this Mini Headstock Tuner by Planet Waves"}
{"source": "  Does it fix the problems that made the Snark so unappealing to my friend and me?1"}
{"source": "  Accuracy:  It does seem to tune accurately, that's a good thing, and it already puts this ahead of the Snark"}
{"source": "  Its not easy to use for alternate tunings however, so do keep that in mind"}
{"source": "  Also, the letters take some getting used to, as they use that kind of chunky LCD block style that you find on some DVD players"}

{"source": "  Looks/Ease Of Use:  It's quite a bit more subtle than the Snark, able to hide behind your headstock, which is quite preferable to having a blue ball sitting on the end of your guitar"}
{"source": "  The only problem with it hiding behind the back of your headstock is if you have a Les Paul style headstock where you have three tuners on each side, you may have trouble finding a spot where the tuner actually fits and can be seen"}

{"source": "3"}
{"source": "  Durability:  This is where the main drawback to these types of tuners are"}
{"source": "  The Snark is very easy to break, as it rests on a small ball joint"}
{"source": "  This Planet Waves mini isn't going to lose its head too easy, but the ratcheting clip is made of plastic and I don't expect it to hold up under too much use"}
{"source": "  The tuner itself is made of fairly light duty plastic too, so as nice as it would be to keep this in your pocket on the way to a jam session, I still think it would be easy enough to break"}
{"source": "  I haven't had it long enough for this to happen yet, so I can only give you my initial impressions"}

{"source": "  Very Nice!!"}
{"source": "Item came with two sets of screws, a long set and a shorter set"}
{"source": " Looks good on my Yamaha acoustic guitar"}
{"source": " Holds my strap well"}
{"source": " I am happy I bought this"}
{"source": "I must first state for the record, I hate strap locks"}
{"source": " Hate may be a bit shy of the mark, actually"}
{"source": " I've never met a set I liked in any single way"}
{"source": "  I've only ever dropped an instrument that HAD strap locks on it"}
{"source": " In fact, EVERY instrument I've owned with strap locks has suffered a gravity attack caused by the very device intended to prevent such misfortune"}
{"source": " Schaller type strap locks tend to come unscrewed- even with Locktite"}
{"source": " When you install them, you are compressing the nut and washer against a compressible material (leather, nylon, etc), so it is never really tight"}
{"source": " Plus there's only about two threads on the slim little nut, and if they aren't a really tight match to the other half, wear very quickly (especially since you have to tighten them so often)"}
{"source": " Duncan type often suffer from 'non-positive lock syndrome' if not regularly cleaned and lubed"}
{"source": " Then there's the fact that unless all of your instruments are equipped with the same brand of lock buttons, your strap is only compatible with the ones which match"}
{"source": " And then there is the the metal-on-metal clankyness"}
{"source": " Yuck"}
{"source": " Oh, and and the cost"}
{"source": " Moving on"}
{"source": "Why are these little Elliptical End Pins so brilliant? They are NOT strap locks"}
{"source": " If you orient the widest points horizontally when you install them - as you should, then in order to put your strap on and take it off, you will need to turn the strap 90 degrees to the instrument"}
{"source": " This isn't something you are likely to do inadvertently while reaching for your beer onstage"}
{"source": " Sometimes the simplest design is the best design"}
{"source": " And they're pretty, too"}
{"source": "Downsides? I will say the screws supplied with these are pretty short, but then I would also argue there is no reason to not use the screws holding in the original strap buttons as long as they fit tightly"}
{"source": " If they don't, using smaller or shorter screws is not the answer- especially considering if the screws cut new threads, you're pretty much- uh, screwed"}
{"source": " The washers these come with are pretty small too, so I just used the screws and felt washers that came with the factory buttons"}
{"source": " With a brand new strap, they can be a bit tricky to get on, but just as tricky to get off (which is good)"}
{"source": " That tight fit could cause some increased wear on the strap, especially if it is made from cheap materials"}
{"source": " With older straps, just as with any traditional strap button, you need to develop a good habit of always checking the positive seat of the strap, but it is very easy to verify, and again much less likely to slip than a traditional button"}
{"source": " Mechanical strap locks actually require just as much diligence to ensure they are still securely fastened and working properly"}
{"source": " But with strap locks, if there's a problem, you'll have to grab some tools to fix it - or replace it entirely"}
{"source": " Talk about a false sense of security"}
{"source": " With PE's Elliptical End Pins, you just put the strap where it should be and you're set"}
{"source": "If you are one who is taken to doing back-flips, or find yourself frequently using your strapped instrument like a hula-hoop onstage, then these probably won't save your precious instrument from the gravity goblin or inertia monkey's worst intentions"}
{"source": " But if either of these antics are your norm, you might be better served by a permanently attached strap, or perhaps therapy"}
{"source": "Since writing the review above, I've ordered several more sets to use on all of my basses"}
{"source": " I'm done with traditional strap buttons and don't imagine ever going back to metal on metal strap locks"}
{"source": "It works and cleans the strings, but its durability is a little low, for about 2 months"}

{"source": "I've reviewed several Joyo pedals now and have loved almost all of them"}
{"source": "not just because of the price ($40 to $50), but also because of their (apparent) durability and tone quality that would be appreciated at any price"}
{"source": "  But ultimately, I decided that this is somewhere between a 4* and 5* review, and I just can't give it the 5* review I've given the other Joyo products I've tried out thus far"}
{"source": "* Extremely high output and high sustain *When I first plugged this thing in, I had it set up similar to any other distortion pedal I would try out with my Les Paul and VOX combo amp - with the dials all at 12 o'clock (50%)"}
{"source": "  Big mistake"}
{"source": "  This pedal has an EXTREMELY high output"}
{"source": "  Depending on the Gain setting, I was achieving output parity with the clean signal with the Volume set at around 25%"}
{"source": "  This isn't necessarily a bad thing, and it's certainly better than having no headroom to set the pedal louder (a frequent criticism of the BOSS DS-1), but it's something to be aware of"}
{"source": "Also, I read several comments here that this \"isn't a high gain distortion\""}
{"source": "  I couldn't disagree more"}
{"source": "  This thing has TONS of gain"}
{"source": "  I think people are thrown off by two things: (1) The name, which pays tribute to the MI Audio Crunchbox it clones; and (2) The clarity/transparency of the tone, particularly the higher-end range, that shines through at all Gain levels"}
{"source": "  \"Crunch\", in my mind, refers to a punchy, cleanish tone that has just a little bit of breakup in its character"}
{"source": "  The Crunch Distortion has a tone that doesn't really breakup or get \"fizzy\" as you turn up the Gain, but that's not what \"Gain\" really is"}
{"source": "  The Gain knob increases the saturation and sustain of the note(s), but I think people are fooled by the fact that the sound doesn't crack up"}
{"source": "  Hit a barre chord and see how long the note holds with the gain turned up"}
{"source": "  This actually makes the pedal very useful for lead work, also, which is one of the JF-03's strengths"}
{"source": "* The setup is weird, but workable *Because of everything I described above, you may use some weird dial configurations to get the tone you want"}
{"source": "  My level is usually around 25% to 40%, and is still very loud"}
{"source": "  The \"crunchy\" classic rock tone that other reviewers talked about does exist, but only at around 5% to 15% of the gain setting"}
{"source": "  And I had the tone knob generally working from 9 o' clock to 12 o'clock, as it got a little too bright to go any higher"}
{"source": "  (Again, this is with Les Paul humbuckers"}
{"source": ")  Ultimately, what I decided was that this pedal has enough bass, not too much in the midrange, and very distinct high end frequencies that come through very clearly"}
{"source": "  If you play gigs and are having trouble cutting through the other instruments, I'd imagine this pedal would do the trick!* It's costs less than half of many of it's true \"competitors\" *While the affordability aspect is distinct from \"quality\", it cannot be ignored"}
{"source": "  Part of my initial disappointment was based on a side-by-side comparison with my MXR '78 Custom Badass Distortion"}
{"source": "  The latter did have a fuller sound to it, and was arguably better for rhythm work"}
{"source": "  But that's an $80 custom shop pedal from MXR"}
{"source": "  Try comparing this pedal to a $40 Boss DS-1 or MXR Distortion + and it blows them out of the water (in my opinion)"}
{"source": "  I'm not sure want to roll with the Crunch Distortion being the only dirt box on my board, but if you used it with a specific purpose in mind (like a lead/gain boost), you could afford this and Joyo's excellent \"Ultimate Drive\" overdrive pedal for still less than most boutique or even BOSS distortion pedals go for"}
{"source": "UPDATE - About a week into owning this pedal, I did revise this score from a 5* to a 4* rating"}

{"source": "Let's get a few things straight from the start - I love effects pedals"}
{"source": "  I love the idea of a handcrafted boutique pedal (and have owned a few), and I'll also play the mass-produced BOSS and Ibanez stuff"}
{"source": "  And if you put foreign/no-name brand in front of me, but the pedal is made well and sounds GOOD, I'll play that too"}
{"source": "  All you need to know is that this pedal is well-constructed and sounds darn good for 40 dollars"}
{"source": "Joyo is a Chinese company that essentially has makes their own form factor (a heavy-duty metal box with an MXR-like button switcher), and then clones/mimics/copies circuitry of popular boutique pedals that cost anywhere from $100 to $250"}
{"source": "  And they've figured out how to ship them to the U"}
{"source": "S"}
{"source": " and sell them for $40 to $60 each"}
{"source": "  I've recently discovered these pedals, and if money/pedalboard space were no issue, there's probably 8 to 12 of them I'd like to own"}
{"source": "The \"star\" of the Joyo lineup, however, is arguably the JF-02 Ultimate Drive"}
{"source": "  This pedal got some notoriety a few years back when an American company bought them in bulk, repainted them, and tried to sell them for almost $200"}
{"source": "  The fact that they thought they could get that much for it tells you something about the quality"}
{"source": "The pedal this is supposedly clone off of is the Fulltone OCD Overdrive, a boutique pedal that came out several years ago, and usually sells from around $150"}
{"source": "  I own that pedal, and I've done a side by side comparison on my pedal board"}
{"source": "  And while tone is EXTREMELY subjective, I'm not sure that I wouldn't go with the Joyo Ultimate Drive in a blind test"}
{"source": "  While the 3-knob, Lo/Hi switch are clearly inspired by the Fulltone OCD, the pedals actually sound quite different"}
{"source": "  With the exact same settings, the Fulltone will actually sound much brighter"}
{"source": "  That's really saying something because the Fulltone is known as having a very well-rounded tone with a defined base"}
{"source": "  Well, the Ultimate Drive offers even more bass and mids, yet the Tone knob can brighten it up quite a bit without losing that bottom end"}
{"source": "It's actually extremely versatile"}
{"source": "  I'm not sure that it would do low-gain \"crunch\" sounds very well, but if that's what you want, consider the Joyo Vintage Overdrive, the Joyo Crunch Distortion, or a Tubescreamer"}
{"source": "  Right now, I have three pedals that are fairly similar and offer a great \"overdriven Marshall\" tone: The Fulltone, the Ultimate Drive, and the Marshall GV-2 Guv'nor"}
{"source": "  While they are all great pedals, the Joyo really hits the sweet spot on my Vox Combo amp (using a Gibson Les Paul)"}
{"source": "As for soloing/lead play, I'm noticing all types of pick attack/harmonic response with the Joyo that I don't get with other stompboxes"}
{"source": "  It really does act and feel like an onboard overdrive channel"}
{"source": "  If you point all the knobs at 12 o' clock, some people may think it is muddy, but that Tone knob really does change the character quite a bit"}
{"source": "  Sorry for the long rant, but I want people to know that just because you can't afford $150+ on a single pedal doesn't mean you can't enjoy a great overdrive stomp box"}
{"source": "  Check the JF-02 out - it just might be your \"gateway drug\" to other Joyo pedals!"}
{"source": "Until today"}
{"source": "  I do not own the Fulltone pedal that this product was designed to replicate, but you can search YouTube and see several comparisons and there is no audible difference"}
{"source": "  Aside from that, this pedal is quite awesome on its own merit"}
{"source": "  It's not a \"metal\" type distortion, but it nicely covers everything else"}
{"source": "  I play an Ibanez Artcore through a Vox AC15 in a Christian band and set with just a small amount of drive, at about the 9:00 position, this pedal does not add color to your signal and the sound of your amp shines through nicely"}
{"source": "  That's the whole point - the reason we choose a certain amp is because we like the way it sounds, so when we push it with an overdrive pedal we don't want it to change the sound of the amp, we simply want to kick it in the rump a little"}
{"source": "  Or a lot"}
{"source": "  And the Ultimate Drive does it nicely"}
{"source": "  The drive could best be described as somewhat gritty and smooth at the same time, like sand in a smoothie"}
{"source": "  Driven hard it gives plenty of nice harmonic overtones"}
{"source": "  But I think it sounds best with just a small amount of kick, right into a tube amp"}
{"source": "  I'm not exactly bringing home tons of money, so it's nice to see that there are pedals designed to give great tone to even tightwads like myself"}

{"source": "I revised a previous 4-star review after playing with the Joyo British some more and especially after using it for direct line-in recording"}
{"source": "  I now rate it at 5 stars"}
{"source": "The phrase \"Marshall in a box\" gets thrown around a lot, but usually the people using it have a particular Marshall amp in mind"}
{"source": "  For example, the Wampler Plexi-Drive sounds like an older Plexi, while a MI Audio Crunch Box will do that 80's JCM compressed high gain tone"}
{"source": "  On the recommendations of several people, I picked up the Joyo British Sound hoping it could clone the full spectrum of those different amps"}
{"source": "Does the British Sound succeed at that goal?  Yes and no"}
{"source": "  On certain settings, the British Sound does offer a convincing, tube-like sound reminiscent of a Marshall cabinet"}
{"source": "  You can clean it up quite a bit, and it works very well as a \"foundation\" pedal, placed last in your effects chain to give the amp Marshall \"character\", but boosted by other overdrive and distortion pedals"}
{"source": "(Note: The pedal is actually its own preamp, so the recommended use of it is to plug it directly into the power amp section of a combo amp, or into a PA system or mixer directly"}
{"source": "  You can use it in  the effects chain into another preamp, but that will diminish its effectiveness)But despite those good traits, there's just a few things \"off\" about it"}
{"source": "  First, it seems to add quite a bit more noise (\"hiss\") than some of the other Joyo Sound pedals"}
{"source": "  Or perhaps it's just more noticeable due to the fact that this is supposed to be a \"Marshall\", so i turned it up"}
{"source": "  Second, as several other reviewers noted, the Voice control seems exactly backwards of what it should be - turning clockwise makes it sound thinner"}
{"source": "  On the other three Joyo Sound pedals, the opposite is true"}
{"source": "  Functionally, this really should mean nothing, but it does make it a bit more confusing to dial in"}
{"source": "If you read the manual for the Tech21 British (upon which this pedal is supposedly cloned), they claim that 9:00 on the Voice/Character knob would be JTM/Bluesbreaker territory, 12:00 would be Plexi, and anything above that gives you the \"presence boost of a 70's Metalface\""}
{"source": "  I haven't tried all those amps, but perhaps it's meant to brighten up as you turn it up, and that's just a design choice"}
{"source": "I think it's possible to get the \"Marshall\" tone you want out of this thing, but you have to work the EQ knobs with each adjustment of the Voice knob"}
{"source": "  At this price, hard to complain too much"}

{"source": " I intentionally got the JF-02 after reading positive reviews all over the net"}
{"source": " The JF-15 was a curiosity purchase"}
{"source": " I was able to dial in sounds of Anthrax, Stryper, stratty Buddy Guy blues(remember he uses a metal finger tip clip at times-works with Pickboy metal picks), the 'dad friendly' radio rock sounds of Nickelback, Daughtry; Foo Fighters"}
{"source": "to get your Marshall sounds takes a bit of work, but I use their Blues Breaker II reissue, Reflector and sometimes the crushing JackHammer(a BBII with more options and gain)"}
{"source": " I also use a digitech valve Hardwire for vintage 70's rock or switched to 'saturation' and mid scooped for the Pantera sounds"}
{"source": " So, in closing, this pedal can do a lot to change the character of your amp to a Boogieish sound if you know what you're doing for the sound your leaning to"}
{"source": "I was very anxious to get this pedal in the mail and try it out so that I could write a review of my own"}
{"source": "  The reviews on all Joyo products are extremely polarizing"}
{"source": "  Some people love them and think they're every bit as good as boutique pedals costing three times as much, while other people (including a significant portion of the hardcore techie community) despise the whole concept and wish they didn't exist"}
{"source": "  Having tried out this specific product - the Joyo JF-15 California - I can tell you that I'm extremely impressed for only having spent $40 to $50"}
{"source": "First, a word about Joyo"}
{"source": "  Joyo is a Chinese company, which for a lot of people loyal to American products, starts them off on the wrong foot"}
{"source": "  Further adding to the controversy is the fact that many Joyo pedals appear to have virtually copied the circuitry of well-known Western boutique pedals, such as the Fulltone OCD (\"Joyo Ultimate Drive\"), Ibanez Tubescreamer (\"Joyo Vintage Overdrive\"), and MI Audio Crunchbox (\"Joyo Crunch Distortion\")"}
{"source": "  If you find that disturbing or appalling, I won't try to change your mind, but consider the following:  Joyo has found a way to manufacture surprisingly faithful \"clones\" of these very successful pedals at a price that even entry-level casual players can afford"}
{"source": "  Larger companies, such as BOSS, DigiTech, and Ibanez, openly copy ideas, clone sounds, or borrow inspiration from other successful pedals"}
{"source": "  Finally, if you want to pay more the boutique pedal, nobody is stopping you from doing that"}
{"source": "  There are certainly areas where Joyo cuts costs by using cheaper materials, and the Joyo is absolutely not a one-for-one clone"}
{"source": "  My personal opinion is that if Joyo has found a way to take the concepts of these pedals and make them cheaper"}
{"source": "power to them"}
{"source": "  But again, reasonable minds can differ"}
{"source": "  My primary concern is: \"How does the pedal SOUND?\"The answer to that question is \"surprisingly good\"!  The specific pedal \"cloned\" by the Joyo California (from what I'm told) is the Tech 21 NYC \"Character\" series, which was a pedal series (apparently now discontinued) that modeled popular amps, such as Marshall, Fender, VOX, and Mesa Boogie"}
{"source": "  Like the Tech 21 pedal, there are 6 on-board knobs, including one called \"Voice\", which essentially a transparency control - the more you turn it up, the less is sounds like your original amp, and the more it sounds like a Mesa Boogie"}
{"source": "  There is also a 3-band EQ (Low, Mid, High), which seems to do a pretty good job crafting your tone"}
{"source": "  Finally, there are Level and Gain knobs that work as if they were the corresponding knobs on your amp"}
{"source": "  Fortunately, I find with the level gain at 12 'o clock, the volume is basically on par with your original signal"}
{"source": "Trying to describe the tone in writing is difficult, and is obviously going to vary a great deal depending on your guitar, amp, and other cables and effects"}
{"source": "  I run a Gibson Les Paul through a small VOX Valvetronix combo, and the resulting tone was good"}
{"source": "  Most importantly, it sounded very different than the normal tones I would get through that amp"}
{"source": "  Admittedly, I do not have much experience with using an actual Mesa Boogie amplifier, but I think people get a little too wrapped up in making that direct comparison anyway"}
{"source": "  Obviously, if want the true sound of a Mesa Boogie half stack, you're going to have to go buy the real equipment"}
{"source": "  But the tone that I found with this pedal was very full-bodied, yet still retaining clarity on the high strings"}
{"source": "  The \"Drive\" knob works better at the lower and mid-level gains - it is capable of higher gains, though I did find the pedal to become somewhat noisy with the Drive knob past 3 'o clock"}
{"source": "There are two ways to think of this pedal"}
{"source": "  First, you could use it as an \"always on\" amp modeler if you really like the tone it produces"}
{"source": "  In that case, you could turn the \"Voice\" up and keep the \"Drive\" low, while adding other distortion pedals effects to that base sound"}
{"source": "  Second, you could think of it strictly as a \"distortion/overdrive\" pedal, and turn it on only for parts of songs where you want that effect"}
{"source": "  However, one very nice (and very \"amp-like\") feature of the overdriven tone provided by this pedal is that the tone cleans up very nicely when you turn the volume down on your guitar"}
{"source": "On a final note, the build quality on the Joyo California \"out of the box\" looks to be fantastic"}
{"source": "  The switch is a \"click\" metal button similar to those used on MXR pedals"}
{"source": "  There is a back cover for a 9V battery, or there is a well-placed DC 9V adapter jack, which works with standard 9V adapters such as BOSS and OneSpot"}
{"source": "  Sorry for the length of the review, but I wanted to provide some good information based on my experiences, since I struggled to find honest reviews while I was doing research"}
{"source": "  I can't promise everyone will like it, but considering the poor quality of the $40 pedals I used to buy from DOD, Danelectro, and Ibanez SoundTank growing up, it's pretty hard to regret giving the Joyo California a serious look at that same price"}
{"source": "  Enjoy!"}

{"source": " I didn't realize everything else this pedal can do"}
{"source": " You can get a very heavily distorted full on rock crunch out of it no problem"}

{"source": " Phantom Power would be nice then also"}

{"source": "  I have been thinking of trying the Joyo DI wit speaker simulation for this purpose, but I just haven't gotten around to buying it yet"}
{"source": "In my opinion you should at least check this thing out, I mean its $40"}
{"source": "I bought this pedal to use in a min rig as an experiment and I love it"}
{"source": "  I use the pedal as a preamp going into a PA or poweramp"}
{"source": "  The pedal is hyper versatile going from clean to heavy grind"}
{"source": "  I use a classic box clean tone with a little bit of bite"}
{"source": "  It is quite responsive to the volume knob on the guitar"}
{"source": "  I have a VFE Alpha Dog and an MXR Custom Badass OD before the pedal"}
{"source": " After the pedal I use an MXR phase and Flanger, VFE Blueprint Delay and then a Byang Triverb"}
{"source": "  When all is said and done my tone is phenomenal and no one can tell when I am not going through a more traditional amp rig"}
{"source": "  Buy the pedal, it's great!"}
{"source": "I'm going this stompbox as I always do, based on the quality of the pedal and what it does - not necessarily whether than tone is \"useful\" for my particular setup"}
{"source": "  Viewed in that objective light, the Joyo JF-13 AC Tone is an excellent pedal for $40 to $45"}
{"source": "There are two ways to think of the JF-13 and the other \"Tech 21 clones\" in this line (California, American, British Sound, etc"}
{"source": ")"}
{"source": "  The first is the obvious one, which is to use it as a stomp box at the end of you signal chain"}
{"source": "  This box basically takes your guitar input and any other effects you add and then tries to \"clone\" a VOX AC30 amplifier into the speaker"}
{"source": "  How effectively it does this really depends on your settings and the quality of the amplifier it self"}
{"source": "  At the end of the day, if your amplifier (particularly the budget, solid state ones) has certain limitations that you don't like (too bright, not loud enough, too muddy, breaks up too easily"}
{"source": "), no pedal (including a $200 boutique one) is going to fully overcome those deficiencies"}
{"source": "But the second way to think of the JF-13 is as a preamp, where the output would go directly into a recording device, PA system, computer, or tablet"}
{"source": "  I don't have enough experience trying that (though I did a little bit with the Joyo California) to say how well that works, but I've heard great examples of it online"}
{"source": "  Also, having the convenience of amp-like controls (with 6 knobs) is certainly very convenient if you like to play/record in that manner"}
{"source": "As for the sound of the pedal, it's very good"}
{"source": "  I've heard complaints about the pedal being noisy if you turn the gain all the way up, but I wouldn't let that concern you"}
{"source": "  That's true of virtually any distortion/overdrive pedal, it can be cleaned up with a noise gate/suppressor, and I think the better use of this pedal is on the low- and mid-gain settings anyway"}
{"source": "  The \"Drive\" knob is like the gain knob on an overdriven tube amp"}
{"source": "  It's a very nice tone, responds well to picking, and cleans up well if you reduce guitar volume (which many pedal distortions do not do)"}
{"source": "  The \"Voice\" knob is hard to describe"}
{"source": "  Basically, it morphs the tone into something deeper and \"punchier\" as you turn it up"}
{"source": "  But that also changes the impact of all your other settings, including drive, EQ, and level"}
{"source": "If I had one complaint about this pedal (even compared to the California, also a very cool pedal), I was a little surprised how much this pedal \"wants to be dirty\""}
{"source": "  It's tough for me to envision leaving it on all the time if it overdrives so easily"}
{"source": "  But, again, I think part of that is you're basically running through two preamps if you play it through a combo"}
{"source": "  Check out some of the YouTube recordings as to how it sounds directly into a speaker or recorder - it could be completely different in that context"}
{"source": "  At any rate, it's a very intriguing device at only $40, and I could see finding new uses for it in the future I haven't envisioned yet"}
{"source": "UPDATE (April 2013): I actually sold this pedal, instantly regretted it, and then bought it back"}
{"source": "  Now that I understand how to use it properly (by bypassing the preamp of my combo amp, through the effects loop), I am able to get some great sounding clean tones out of the pedal"}
{"source": "  It really is an excellent value, either as a \"foundation pedal\" or as an emergency tool for musicians who might end up somewhere they need to plug directly into a PA/Speaker system"}
{"source": "  I won't be letting the AC Tone go this time :)"}

{"source": "I'm using this unit to set up a Linux Digital Audio Workstation"}

{"source": " You will probably want a realtime kernel and use jackd to take full advantage of this device"}

{"source": "The following settings are the best I've been able to manage in jackd2 without and xruns on a realtime kernel(using qjackctl) (I'm also no expert)Frames / Period: 128Sample Rate: 96000Periods / Buffer: 3Which gives a predicted latency of 4msWith a 10ft 1/4 inch patch cord (to run jack_iodelay) I got a consistent 8"}

{"source": "  It's plug-and-play"}
{"source": "I have some good things to say about the Focusrite Scarlett 2i2 (all about the hardware) and some bad things (all about the software)"}
{"source": "  I've tried using the driver version 2"}
{"source": "1, which came with the disk, and the udpated 2"}
{"source": "2, which I downloaded from Focusrite's website"}
{"source": "To let you know what I need in an interface:1"}
{"source": " Balanced stereo in/out2"}
{"source": " High quality headphone amp3"}
{"source": " Volume knobs for headphone amp and for the main line4"}
{"source": " Good digital-to-analog conversion5"}
{"source": " Low output latency (input latency not important to me)I don't use the Mic preamps, which is one of the big selling points of this device"}
{"source": "================ The Good ====================This box is simple and well-designed"}
{"source": "  It does what you want, has very convenient controls, and has high build quality"}
{"source": "  I'm pleased with the digital-to-analog conversion"}
{"source": "  It has a great big volume knob and another for the headphone amp"}
{"source": "  It has switches so each input can be a line-in or microphone pre-amp"}
{"source": "  It has a switch for zero-latency monitoring (of whatever is coming in)"}
{"source": "* The headphone amp was of particular concern for me"}
{"source": "  I use headphones a lot and a poor headphone amp can be quite a problem"}
{"source": "  The Behringer headphone amp was only ok"}
{"source": "  Specifically, it has an output impedance of 50 ohms"}
{"source": "  The rule of thumb for good headphone/amp matching is that the output impedance should be 1/8 the impedance of the headphones--my hd 595's have 50 ohms of impedance"}
{"source": "  Breaking this rule you get distortions of the frequency response"}
{"source": "  In my case mostly this meant attenuation of the bass"}
{"source": "  Most manufacturers don't list their output impedance, possibly because they are embarrassed"}
{"source": "  Anyway, Focusrite does, which is one reason I trust them a little more"}
{"source": "  The output impedance is less than 10 ohms--respectable but not amazing"}
{"source": "  Still not as low as I would need in principle but I can notice an improvement in the bass response in my headphones"}
{"source": "  There's plenty of extra voltage here too, so I could drive higher impedance cans if necessary"}
{"source": "  Anyway, good headphone amp"}
{"source": "  Check"}
{"source": "* Balanced ins and outs work very well,  The ins accommodates a 1/4 TRS style in and XLR"}
{"source": "  The light around them shows when something's actually coming in and shines red when it's in danger of clipping"}
{"source": "  There's lots of gain available"}
{"source": "  I have them turned all the way down almost"}
{"source": "  The outs are TRS style (balanced or unbalanced) and are located on the back"}
{"source": "* I like the look of the box, with a red metal case, and the front and back are sturdy and attractive as well"}
{"source": "* The USB cable is just a type B port"}
{"source": "  This means you can replace it if it gets damaged or whatever"}
{"source": "  The Behringer, for example, was hard-wired to its cable"}
{"source": "king of annoying"}
{"source": "* It's bus-powered"}
{"source": "  I actually would have been fine with a wall-wart, but this is even more simple"}
{"source": "I really have no complaints whatsoever about the hardware"}
{"source": "===================== The Bad =========================The driver for this thing is horrible under Windows XP"}
{"source": "  I have a clean installation with nothing installed except my DAW software, acrobat reader, and this driver"}
{"source": "  I mean, my computer is really stripped down"}
{"source": "  Performance using the Behringer was good"}
{"source": "  The latency (time between playing a note and hearing it out the speakers) was 8 ms using the Behringer, which isn't really perceptible"}
{"source": "Unfortunately the focusrite driver, though it's technically ASIO apparently, doesn't have anything like an acceptable latency"}
{"source": "  The lowest latency I could set it at and get sound out instead of crackles and pops was 23 ms"}
{"source": "  At that level the instrument begins to sound very sluggish and laggy"}
{"source": "  It's very difficult, at least for me, to work with a large latency like that"}
{"source": "I was ready to return this device when I decided as a last ditch effort to install ASIO4ALL"}
{"source": "  That's sort of an ASIO driver to use if you absolutely cannot make the manufacturer's driver perform at a decent level"}
{"source": "  I installed it and it worked"}
{"source": "  The output latency was a tiny 4"}
{"source": "3 ms (only "}
{"source": "3 of which are actually output latency, so this is REALLY impressive)"}
{"source": "  I conclude that the hardware is very, very good in this machine, but the software is horrible"}
{"source": "Unfortunately, you can't actually uninstall the focusrite driver because otherwise windows doesn't recognize the device and it never even turns on--it's not class compliant, unlike the Behringer"}
{"source": "  So now I have two drivers for it installed, only one of which I use"}
{"source": "The bad news is that this configuration is very buggy"}
{"source": "  In general when I just turn the computer on and try and play my VST instrument, all I get is crackles and pops until I open the ASIO configuration panel and increase the buffer"}
{"source": "  The funny thing is that it doesn't matter where the buffer starts out, I always have to increase it before I get any good sounds out"}
{"source": "  I can start it out with a huge buffer--lots of latency--and it will crackle until I open it and increase the buffer yet more"}
{"source": "  I have to do this every time I turn on the computer"}
{"source": "  Also, sometimes if I leave it on for a while and come back, it will be crackly again until I increase it yet another step"}
{"source": " We are talking about major bugs here"}
{"source": "I decided to try ditching ASIO4ALL and trying to make the focusrite drivers work again--maybe there was a setting I was missing"}
{"source": "  As I was trying to set the buffer size, I heard the sound of an explosion and then my computer rebooted"}
{"source": "  When it came back I couldn't get good sounds out, even when I turned the buffer way up"}
{"source": "  Tried rebooting a few more times, still didn't work"}
{"source": "  So I uninstalled and re-installed the focusrite software"}
{"source": "  At first it didn't work"}
{"source": "  I had to install ASIO4ALL as well, and now I can sort of get sounds out of it, half the time"}
{"source": "I hope you are getting the idea"}
{"source": "  These drivers are terrible"}
{"source": "  Awful"}
{"source": "  A monkey could have written a better driver"}
{"source": "  I would give it 1 star if it wasn't for the fact that the device works very, very well when all the stars align and the driver recognizes the drive and allows it to play"}
{"source": "  I guess I'm willing to sacrifice convenience and stability for nice hardware when it works"}

{"source": "================ Closing Thoughts =======================Unfortunately, there really isn't a USB interface that has a good driver"}

{"source": "0 standard has been around"}

{"source": "  There's not enough throughput in USB 1"}
{"source": "1"}

{"source": "UPDATED 3/16/2014After owning the 2i2 for over a year and encountering many difficulties I am revising my once gleaming review"}

{"source": "Having to send the first Snark SN-8 back, but the replacement, thus far, has been flawless"}
{"source": "I made a slight adjustment to my guitar's truss rod and now the intonation is pretty spot on"}
{"source": "A couple tips to tuning a guitar: tune it like you play it"}
{"source": " If you strum & play softly, then pluck & tune each string softly"}
{"source": "However, most people don't play softly, so they make the mistake that almost everyone makes: they pluck each string and wait like 15 seconds till the ringing fades out, & so they are generally tuning each string as it begins \"softly\" resonating"}
{"source": "So, in essence, what happens is people are generally tuning each string flat"}
{"source": "To tune your guitar correctly, you really ought to pluck each string hard, like every 2 seconds and tune it that way - rather than waiting for the sound to fade out"}
{"source": " If you do it this way, you might be surprised at how good it sounds when you're strumming the living daylight out of it!Also, please check your intonation"}
{"source": " Your 12th frets should be in tune same as your open strings"}
{"source": " You pluck your open string (hard) & tune as described above"}
{"source": " Then you check intonation by pressing VERY LIGHTLY (with JUST the TIP of your FINGER and DON'T TOUCH ANY OTHER PART of the NECK), on the same string, but 12th fret - and BOTH should be in tune the EXACT same"}
{"source": "If they are off (12TH & open), then your intonation is probably in need of adjustment"}
{"source": " Please don't pay someone to setup your guitar! You can do it yourself so easily"}
{"source": " Go on u toob and search \"scott grove tuning your guitar wrong\" and u will find a video of a guy that claims to have owned over 3,000 guitars - & he spends almost an hour explaining all the details"}
{"source": " Also, watch his video on how to setup: adjust intonation, truss rod, action, etc"}
{"source": "Btw, if you can't get your Snark to tune your guitar: hint - it's not the tuner's fault"}
{"source": " The first 3 saddles (e, b, g) should look like a staircase going down"}
{"source": " Then, your next 3 strings (d,  a, e) should also look like another staircase going down"}
{"source": " If not, break out your philips head & tweak your intonation"}

{"source": "Edit: I've had to downgrade my star rating a bit, so I've revised my review- full explanation below, but in short, this just doesn't work as well for me as the SN-1"}
{"source": "Background- I have the original SN-1 as well, and have had it for a couple years"}
{"source": " The ball socket on the back of the tuning head broke fairly quickly when I forgot to remove it from the headstock before putting it in the gig bag (Protec Contego semi-rigid hybrid case with a little more room around the headstock than your average padded bag)"}
{"source": " I rigged a repair that has worked OK, but figured a replacement was in order"}
{"source": " However other than the broken socket, this has been one of the best tuners I've ever used"}
{"source": " Very quick and intuitive"}
{"source": " Bright and easy to read in all lighting conditions"}
{"source": " Fast response on all strings, including the low B on several five string basses"}
{"source": " Despite what I feel is a weakness in the design (the fragile socket), I still felt so good about the functionality of the product that I ordered another, this time the SN-8(B) \"Super Tight\" tuner"}
{"source": " I decided to go with another model in the hopes that a newer model might be a little better reinforced at the ball sockets (hence the \"super tight\", perhaps?)"}
{"source": "Out of the box, the SN-8 is almost identical to the original, save for the obvious color differences"}
{"source": " Then clamp appears the same and doesn't seem to have any greater clamping force that I could detect"}
{"source": " Turning it on though, the display is quite different"}
{"source": " Basically, it is much more \"to the point\""}
{"source": " The indicator bars either side of the center pitch (\"in-tune\", dead center) are much wider and fewer, meaning a less granular and less precise display, but one that is very easy to read at a glance in any light"}
{"source": " This could be a mixed blessing, but the up side is it is brighter, simpler, and potentially quicker for on the fly tuning"}
{"source": " The downside is it is not granular enough to say, intonate an instrument's bridge"}
{"source": " It also seems to respond much quicker, which I am realizing is also mixed blessing, and here we have the missing star"}
{"source": " The speed also means it responds really quickly to all input, meaning it seems to want to constantly change the note it is sensing"}
{"source": " It seems much more twitchy than the sn-1"}
{"source": " Unless you are able to mute every other string fully, it will jump between notes frequently"}
{"source": " This is also one of my (many) complaints about the Planet Waves Mini-Headstock Tuner too"}
{"source": "  I've found that attempting to tune with loud background music or other instruments blasting through a PA will cause my instrument to vibrate at other frequencies - even if I successfully mute all other strings, making tuning with the SN-8 that much more difficult"}
{"source": " The differences here between the SN-8 and SN-1 are quite noticeable"}
{"source": " For that reason, I just ordered another SN-1"}
{"source": "I can't say how this tuner would work for other instruments, as I am a bass player"}
{"source": " I'm not sure there is or isn't a defect or flaw here, perhaps it just didn't live up to my expectations (set high by my awesome experience with the original)"}
{"source": " Simply put, my sampling size is too small to say for sure or proclaim this a bad product"}
{"source": "  All I know is that it just isn't working very well for me"}
{"source": " If I saved the packaging for this one, I may consider sending it back in exchange for a second SN-1 or perhaps another model"}
{"source": " If not, it'll probably be the one I hand others when they want to borrow my tuner ;)"}
{"source": "If an initially unfavorable opinion changes, I owe it to the maker to say so, so I'm saying so!For me, the hardest part of adjusting to a new tuner is throwing out preconceived notions of how it should be used"}
{"source": "It's not always easy getting vibration sensing tuners to settle down"}
{"source": " In many cases, they jump around until, by the time they settle down, the vibration has decayed to the point where it no longer registers"}
{"source": " So, a bit of subjective judgment is sometimes involved"}
{"source": "As far as the SN-8 is concerned"}
{"source": "WRONG!I've found the SN-8 to, in fact, be Super Tight, BUT one has to insure that there isn't even a HINT of red or yellow on either side of the center green bar"}
{"source": "This is what I don't like about the other type of Snark display"}
{"source": "  It's not symmetric!  It requires all of the red bars to be lit along with the green, and none of the yellow bars to be lit"}
{"source": "  If the rad bars are illuminated constantly, how can you tell if the string is a hair flat?  When I'm on pitch I want *all* indications of sharpness and flatness to vanish"}
{"source": "In that regard, the image shown here is wrong! It shows the Super Tight behaving like the other tuners with all of the red bars illuminated along with Green and even a yellow"}
{"source": " Uhm"}
{"source": "no"}
{"source": "The SN-8 is Super Tight, has a touch metronome, and lets you set it down a few semi-tones if that's what floats your boat and, as they say on TV, \"All for an incredibly low price!\"I keep a tuner on each guitar and one in my gig bag, just in case"}
{"source": "  At this price, I already have a half dozen Super Tights with two more on the way"}
{"source": "I will keep my review short as there have been MANY factual and well written reviews for the various Snark tuners over the years"}
{"source": "  Quickly though, I will start by also agreeing that for the price, it is hard to beat"}
{"source": "  This is mostly why I have given it 4 stars and just bought a sixth one"}
{"source": "  It is accurate, reliable for tuning, and affordable"}
{"source": "  All that said, here is why I decided to write a review"}
{"source": "  I have owned about 5 of these Snarks and every single one has broken after about 3-4 months use"}
{"source": "  The unit itself is great"}
{"source": "  Here is the problem"}
{"source": "  Where the tuner attaches to the guitar and where the tuner attaches itself to it's own clip is where this little gem falls short"}
{"source": "  Sure, if you put it on a guitar and leave it there at home, it will likely last at least a year and maybe longer requiring a battery change one day if you are lucky"}
{"source": "  However, if you travel with it, take it on or off a few guitars a day, or frequently adjust it, it will likely eventually break"}
{"source": "  Either the \"rubber feet\" that come into contact with the head stock of the guitar will come off and get lost or the little ball joint that connects the tuner's head to the clip part will break"}

{"source": "Oh, I almost forgot one important note to all owners: IT IS POSSIBLE TO REMOVE THE STUPID, UGLY PICK GUARD! Since ukulele players rarely use picks, and when we do, we use soft rubber or felt ones, there's no need to protect the finish from scratching, and that white pick guard really detracts from the instrument's looks"}
{"source": "I applied gentle heat from a hair dryer on its low power setting for about ten minutes, and very slowly and gently pried up the edges of the pick guard with my fingernails--no sharp tools! It came off pretty cleanly, leaving only a few small spots of adhesive residue"}
