{"source": "  But considering the price, that's understandable"}
{"source": " There's no reason to include those if most people are not going to use them"}
{"source": "  You'll only want the cover and footswitch if you're playing in a band"}
{"source": "I have owned many solid state and modeling amplifiers, including a few of the Vox Valvetronix series"}
{"source": "  However, this is both my first Fender amp, as well as my first true &#34;tube&#34; amp"}
{"source": "  First, some clarification is needed on &#34;tube&#34; vs"}
{"source": " &#34;modeling&#34; amp"}
{"source": "  The Fender Super Champ X2 is absolutely a tube amp - it has one 12AX7 and two 6V6's, and they are involved in both the preamp and power amp stages"}
{"source": "  However, the amplifier has a modeling component on top of that true tube tone, which is what allows it to project different &#34;voices&#34;"}
{"source": "  Contrary to what some posters have written, Channel 1 does also have some front-end modeling, except that the the model is fixed for &#34;Blackface&#34; tone and controlled by a separate volume know (no gain control)"}
{"source": "  Channel 2 offers 16 different &#34;Voice&#34; presets and 10 of these model a variety of vintage Fender amplifiers, including the Tweed Deluxe, Bassman, Deluxe, Princeton, and Twin"}
{"source": "  Settings 9-15 model a variety of other popular amps, including the Vox AC30 and Marshall"}
{"source": "Overall, I found the available tones to be excellent"}
{"source": "  Unlike my Valvetronix, where I more or less settled on a particular setting and used it at all times, I could really see myself flipping between the different models and seeing how they respond to different guitars"}
{"source": "  One thing that should be noted if you plan on changing models frequently - you may have to adjust volume, gain, bass, and treble to dial in the same amount of volume as you move from amp to amp"}
{"source": "  However, I found the levels to be much more uniform in output than in other amps with a modeling component"}
{"source": "  Also, the X2 does not suffer from a lot of the excess noise or &#34;hissing&#34; you hear with digital modeling amps"}
{"source": "The tones that come out of the 10&#34; speaker of the Super Champ X2 are very rich and touch-responsive, as you'd expect from a tube amp"}
{"source": "  The amp has TONS of high-end sparkle, but some of the settings only start to open up if you increase the volume (true of many amps)"}
{"source": "  The stock speaker, which is Fender's own design (and has a ceramic magnet, I believe), is frequently criticized as a weak point"}
{"source": "  However, it is certainly passable and if you are new to tube amps (or only intend on playing at bedroom levels), you're unlikely to take issue with it"}
{"source": "  The Eminence Ragin' Cajun is a commonly suggested replacement that apparently adds significant amounts of output and low end"}
{"source": "  But, again, the amp is plenty loud and full-sounding for its size"}
{"source": "  Better intended for home/studio use than most gigs, but it excels at what it does"}
{"source": "That brings us to the effects section and the Fender FUSE software that works with the amp via USB cable"}
{"source": "  Frankly, I'm not a fan of most on-board effects with combo amplifiers"}
{"source": "  I prefer to use pedals for modulation, delay, and some overdrive/distortion"}
{"source": "  The good new is that the on-board reverbs (which include spring, room, hall, and a few others if you install them from the software) are quite good"}
{"source": "  You can also reassign the presets to different effects"}
{"source": "  So, if you want a flanger with a reverb, you can have a setting for that"}
{"source": "  If you want a different type of delay mixed with a particular reverb, you can do that too"}
{"source": "  The Tap Tempo button is a great modern convenience to go with those effects"}
{"source": "  But, as I said, while they represent a good value for players that don't want to invest in pedals, I'm more likely to use my Boss DD-3 than the on-board delay, and so on"}
{"source": "The build quality of the Super Champ X2 is largely excellent"}
{"source": "  The grill is wound tightly and with the same convincing shimmer of some of Fender's more expensive amps"}
{"source": "  The amp weighs in at 24 pounds and is extremely portable with the handle on top"}
{"source": "  One thing I did note, however, is that the knobs protrude and seem like they would be very easy to damage while transporting, so I will have to be careful about that"}
{"source": "  Also, there are a couple of seams for the tolex material on top of the amp that look like they could have been hidden better"}
{"source": "  But overall, the amp looks very well constructed"}
{"source": "  I was initially concerned about the digital aspects taking away from the tube amp aesthetic, but everything is mapped to vintage-looking knobs, and from a few feet back, the amp looks just as much at home in the 60's as it does post-2000"}
{"source": "Overall, I think this is an excellent value and a quality amp that I hope to enjoy for years to come"}
{"source": "  I'm only really scratching the surface of its potential, but it makes great Fender tone sound easy"}
{"source": "  The Fender FUSE software could be a little more intuitive to work with, and I wish there were a better way to know what each of the Voice and F/X settings correspond to without consulting a chart"}
{"source": "  But it's a great little amplifier that's all the power you'd need for hobbyists and studio recording, and it could probably handle some smaller gigs as well"}

{"source": " I could never quite get the fine tune I was looking for, and I have a little bit if a pitch issue trying to tune by ear"}
{"source": " These little tuners are amazing"}
{"source": " So easy to use, and portable, and cheap"}

{"source": "Ukulele straps are a rare thing and I've yet to find the perfect one"}
{"source": "  This one gets close"}
{"source": "  Not all uke players use straps, some do and some don't"}
{"source": "  Purists say not to use one and that using one makes you look lazy or inexperienced"}
{"source": "  However I have two acoustic-electric ukes and they are heavier than the non-electrified ones the purists use"}
{"source": "  I've found that using a strap on my electric ukes helps with right arm fatigue from clutching the thing"}
{"source": "  A preamp and battery adds a surprising amount of weight percentage wise to a uke when compared to a guitar"}
{"source": "  This Neotech strap frees me up to worry about my strumming and fingering techniques more and dropping the instrument less"}
{"source": "There is another device called a Uke Leash that also works well"}
{"source": "  It ties onto the headstock"}
{"source": " I like this Neotech better because even though the instrument isn't balanced perfectly, it is balanced better than with the Uke Leash"}
{"source": "  The Uke Leash is easier to get on and off my body so it has some advantage over the Neotech Simple Sling"}
{"source": "This Neotech Simple Sling soundhole clip strap works on my Concert and Tenor ukes equally well, but I have to adjust it some when switching it between the two"}
{"source": "The wide clip is felt lined and it does not scratch the instrument"}
{"source": "  I don't know how long this felt lasts but it seems well attached"}
{"source": "  This strap should work fine on any number of various stringed instruments"}
{"source": "You have to use reasonable care with a soundhole clip strap on a ukulele or you can damage the top by jerking down on the instrument"}
{"source": "  The clip on the Neotech Sling is wider than most I've seen and this extra width reduces, but does not completely eliminate, that risk"}
{"source": " The wider clip spreads the stress out"}
{"source": "  I've seen other soundhole clip straps with much narrower clips and I'm afraid to try them on a ukulele"}
{"source": "  I like this one with the wide clip and will keep it"}
{"source": "The Uke Leash type strap that ties on the headstock still requires full right arm pressure to hold the instrument in place, so I like this Neotech soundhole clip device better"}
{"source": "The only thing I don't like about it is putting it on is a little clumsy when compared to a traditional guitar strap"}
{"source": "  But once on it is great!  You look a little dorky slipping your arm into it and then over your head and you can't do it with a hat on"}
{"source": "  It gets easier the more you do it"}
{"source": "I'd buy the Neotech Simple Sling again"}
{"source": "  I recommend it to electric ukelele players who want to use a strap but don't want to drill holes for strap buttons on their ukes"}

{"source": "The US Dream is supposed \"clone\" of the Suhr Riot, and is the only one of the \"new\" model Joyo pedals that I own"}
{"source": "  This is a high-gain distortion pedal that covers the gain range of something like a ProCo Rat, but retains its clarity even at higher gain settings"}
{"source": "When I first pulled it out of the box and plugged in, it sounded great, but I wondered if it might be a little bright"}
{"source": "  I was pleasantly surprised when I rolled back the tone knob to around 10 o'clock, and it rolled off the harsh high end while retaining clarity and fullness"}
{"source": "  At least with my setup (Les Paul into a Vox Valvetronix 40-watt), this is one of the few distortion pedals capable of full-sounding power chords and singing high leads"}
{"source": "  Unlike some distortion pedals that have a \"fizzy\" (DS-1) or \"cocked wah\" sound (Boss Power Stack), I was really pleased with the tone all over the neck of my guitar"}
{"source": "While Joyo makes several dozen effects pedals at good prices, this is one of the first three I would recommend, along with the outstanding Ultimate Drive and the warm-sounding Vintage Overdrive"}
{"source": "However, it's worth noting that the build quality is a bit suspect on the \"new\" model Joyo pedals, which are notably lighter than those numbered JF-17 and lower"}
{"source": "  The weight is comparable to an MXR '78 Badass Distortion, except the switch and output jacks are more suspect"}

{"source": "As the description says, this is a \"mild overdrive\""}
{"source": "  It won't give you the \"Brown Sound\""}
{"source": "  It's not meant for metal"}
{"source": "  It's almost like adding a tube-amp \"gain\" knob to your existing rig, add subtle yet dynamic saturation and sustain to an otherwise clean tone"}
{"source": "  Chords and notes blend together beautifully without crunching up or fizzing out"}
{"source": "  Unlike many \"tube\" overdrive pedals, this thing has tons of volume on tap"}
{"source": "  You can set the \"Drive\" to 0 and still have a nice loud clean boost"}
{"source": "  Turn up the drive and it can do blues and rock"}
{"source": "  But I think of it more as an enhancement to your clean tone, as opposed to an \"effect\" that transforms it"}
{"source": "  In that respect, it actually reminds me of the BOSS OD-3 Overdrive, which is a vastly underrated pedal (though the OD-3 probably offers more gain)"}
{"source": "The Focus knob is interesting - it doesn't act exactly like a tone knob"}
{"source": "  As you turn it up, it doesn't remove bass, but changes the gain structure a little and opens up the tone"}
{"source": "  The lower settings are bluesy - the higher settings are bright and dynamic"}
{"source": "  But chances are, both will sound good"}

{"source": "As thrilled as I have been with the Chinese-made Joyo overdrive and distortion pedals I've tried out in the recent past, I felt like the JF-10 Dyna Compressor was somewhat of a risk"}
{"source": "  I had been using the very excellent MXR Custom Comp already, but was frustrated with its lack of external controls and versatility"}
{"source": "  Also, it's one thing thing for Joyo to \"clone\" the circuitry of a distortion pedal, but could they do it accurately with an \"always on\" effect like compression?Well, Joyo has absolutely done it, and they've done it well enough that I'm selling my MXR"}
{"source": "  Compressors are hard to explain, and even harder to demonstrate on a YouTube video, so let me offer my explanation of what this pedal does, and why you should give it a try for only around $40"}
{"source": "The primary effect of compression is to \"level\" or normalize the output across frequencies"}
{"source": "  Particularly with a clean signal, aggressive playing can lead to annoying volume swells"}
{"source": "  Also, certain notes sustain, while others seem to die out too early"}
{"source": "  Compression \"smooths\" over these problems and levels everything to a polished, presentable sound"}
{"source": "The secondary effect of compression is that the pedal can sustain single notes and chords by increasing their level after they would normally die out"}
{"source": "  In this area, the Joyo JF-10 is superior to many other compressors because it gives you \"Attack\" and \"Sustain\" knobs"}
{"source": "  \"Attack\" refers to how soon the compression effect kicks after the note is struck"}
{"source": "  Turning the knob up produces a \"chicken picking\" effect where the note is very clear and pronounced"}
{"source": "  Adjusting the \"Sustain\" knob, obviously, increases the length of time that the note or chord continues to play at volume"}
{"source": "  Like most compressors, there is also a \"Level\" control to change the volume of the compressed sound"}
{"source": "Of the compressors you can actually find under $100 (such as the MXR Dyna Comp and BOSS CS-3 Compression Sustainer), I like this one the best"}
{"source": "  The MXR models have a good clarity of tone, but with only two knobs, the lack of customization is a problem"}
{"source": "  You may want high sustain or attack for playing U2-type guitar parts, but might find excess sustain too \"messy\" for punchy AC/DC riffs"}
{"source": "  The Joyo allows you to make this change easily"}
{"source": "The BOSS CS-3 is a good pedal that has controls for attack, sustain, and also tone, but the pedal produces a lot of noise, and the resulting tone sounds too digitized"}
{"source": "  Also, a \"tone\" knob on a compression pedal strikes me as an admission that the pedal is CHANGING your tone, which good compression really shouldn't do"}
{"source": "  The Joyo Dyna Compressor sounds like MY guitar and amp, it just puts some polish on the final product, and allows me to add sustain and \"punch\" if I see fit"}
{"source": "  Great pedal, and amazing value!"}
{"source": "I have a love/hate relationship with compressors"}

{"source": "Long story short is this neck looks better than many I've had that cost 2X as much, or more"}
{"source": " Unless it has a twist or hump, it actually earns the 5th star"}
{"source": " Even if the frets need a little cleanup, it still earns the 5th star"}
{"source": " While some may not like the flatter radius, I'd argue that it makes it easier to get the frets in so that they aren't as much of an issue"}
{"source": " And it is clearcoated - maybe not a nice amber finish, but most more expensive necks may have no finish at all"}
{"source": " So again, another reason for the 5th star"}
{"source": "I recently ordered 5 different ukulele models while researching products for my senior adult choir at church as I wanted to give them a few options"}
{"source": "Okina UK100 Soprano Ukulele with Rosewood Fingerboard - NaturalDiamond Head DU-150 Ukulele, NaturalMahalo U-30OR Painted Economy Soprano Ukulele (Orange)Lanikai LU-11 Soprano UkuleleKala KA-15S Mahogany Soprano UkuleleThe Okina, Diamond Head and Mahalo were all under $30 at the time and within $2 price of each other"}
{"source": "  Of the three, I thought that the Mahalo was the best offering both visually and in terms of tone quality"}
{"source": "  The Okina had a poor sound quality even compared to my own 20- and 40-year-old ukuleles (which had the original strings)"}
{"source": "  A string upgrade to Aquila strings helped significantly, but even then, the Okina still had a far worse sound quality at this price level"}
{"source": "The Diamond Head and Mahalo both sounded better even with the stock strings, and each includes a nice (for this price) little gig bag"}
{"source": "  The Mahalo has the most \"island\" look to my eyes and the best sound"}
{"source": "  Much of the sound can probably be attributed to the strings which are more substantial than the Diamond Head's"}
{"source": "  That being said, it still makes financial and practical sense to get the Mahalo since it's so near the same price (compared to the  Diamond Head) and has heavier strings already installed"}
{"source": "  I've also reviewed the Lanikai and Kala on their own pages"}
{"source": "On an almost irrelevant note, the Diamond Head was the only instrument of the 5 to arrive in something close to actual tuned-up string tension"}
{"source": "  It takes several days for these nylon strings to stretch and settle in, but I didn't have to retune the Diamond Head so much because it was already virtually in tune"}
{"source": "  This would not be my primary concern with purchasing an instrument for myself but may be a significant headache-saver for a non-musician parent purchasing a ukulele for a young child"}
{"source": "The cradle guitar stand was for a friend"}
{"source": " He was happy with the cradle guitar stand"}
{"source": " Hasn't had any problems with it"}
{"source": "This is a solid stand, with good adjustability and a thick, decent quality foam to cushion your guitar/bass"}
{"source": "its only fault is its price"}
{"source": " Amazon sells cheaper versions that are just as good"}
{"source": " Simply search  for guitar stands on here and see for yourself"}
{"source": "I have been playing guitar for longer than I care to admit"}
{"source": " Back in 1966 I went into the music store with my Dad and cherry picked the finest Fender Telecaster in the whole store"}
{"source": " Back then they were all handmade, so there were variations, and by spending some time, would yield you an incredible find"}
{"source": " So I am not a newbie to playing, or working on guitars"}
{"source": " I didn't use this capo on my 66 because I have it apart in order to make exact vintage reproductions of the body"}
{"source": "Today's modern guitars use medium jumbo frets"}
{"source": " My 66 had thin frets"}
{"source": " With the medium jumbo frets they are sufficiently high, that if you check them once fretting a note with something as accurate as the Snark SN 2 All Instrument Clip on Chromatic Tuner you will see that the note moves up one or two bars on the tuner once you fret it"}
{"source": " (That is one or two bar above the note you are then fretting) So I must admit my quest for the perfect capo would enable me to adjust it so that the guitar doesn't go out of tune when using a capo"}
{"source": "I compared the G7 Performance Capo the Six String Silver, with the Schubb S1 Stainless Steel Guitar Capo for Steel String Guitars, and this Planet Waves NS-Tri-action capo"}
{"source": " Although the G7 was substantially built and looked rather impressive, I found it to be too bulky, so it kept getting in the way while trying to play chords"}
{"source": " So I sent it back"}
{"source": " So now it comes down to the Shubb 1 Deluxe and the Planet Waves"}
{"source": " I went back and forth with these two tuners a whole lot of times"}
{"source": " I would perfectly tune the guitar with the Snark and then apply the capo"}
{"source": " I tried to discern the difference between which one of these would make the guitar go out of tune more than the other"}
{"source": " I finally concluded that there was no difference"}
{"source": "The Schubb S1 had the ability to be adjusted so fine that it would barely be holding on to the neck"}
{"source": " If you set that one at its gentlest setting you could get it to be almost perfectly in tune even with the capo on, but set it that softly, and it would just about fall off the guitar"}
{"source": " So that is the last thing that you want to happen in the middle of a performance"}
{"source": " The Planet Waves Capo in contrast, even at the lightest setting, was still a solid grip on the neck"}
{"source": " I also noticed that the planet waves had a wider spread across the strings and therefore was less critical of the positioning in order to get it right"}
{"source": "The Schubb S1 is a well-made product, it has nicely finished metal components, but with its roller ball system of fastening, when you loosen it, for sure you're going to occasionally be dropping it in on the floor"}
{"source": " You could say that requires two hands in order to remove it"}
{"source": " The Planet Wave on the other hand is a true one-handed tool that makes it easy to remove and to put back on"}
{"source": " I tried both of these on one of my other Fender telecasters, as well as on one of my acoustics"}
{"source": " I got the same tuning results on all of them"}
{"source": " I am very critical and exact so when I say that the tuning results would change when you put on the capo you must understand, that the tuner was only moving one line"}
{"source": " Most people wouldn't even bother with that much of an adjustment but I know that there is nothing to compare to a guitar with good strings on it, and to hear the tone and the blend of those strings in perfect tune; perfect harmony rules"}
{"source": " You know that feeling when you come to the end of a great song, and you hit your last note and finish with a full chord that is perfectly in tune; there is nothing to compare to it"}
{"source": "The planet wave is a little bit bulkier and if I had to get critical of it I would say it does get in the way a tiny bit more than the Schubb S1; although this factor is not such a great difference, as to preclude me choosing one over the other"}
{"source": " The way each of them mount and dismount to the guitar does make me lean more strongly to the Planet Waves"}
{"source": "I saw other reviews that commented that one type of capo provided a better tone than another type of capo"}
{"source": " Tried as I might I could not reproduce the differences that they spoke of"}
{"source": " There are so many factors affecting the tone, such as after changing the capo was a guitar body leaning a little bit more one way, then it was the last time"}
{"source": " For example was the face of the guitar a little closer to the ear range as compared to the last capo you tested that might've been projecting more from the side of the guitar"}
{"source": " I also felt that once the capo squeezes the string down the only thing that is creating tone is the fret line between it and the bridge"}
{"source": " So at least between these two I found no total differences"}
{"source": "I wanted to say that if you are using medium sized jumbo frets and high action you are really bending the string in order to fret it thereby changing the pitch"}
{"source": " I love low action with no buzzing on lighter gauge strings"}
{"source": " I'd rather dance across the top like a ballet dancer then scrub heavy gauge strings"}
{"source": " To each his own they say"}
{"source": " I just consider it important to let you know that I'm conducting this experiment with 8 gauge strings on the Tele electric and 9 gauge on the acoustic"}
{"source": " So if you're running a much heavier gauge string with lower action, you would of course have less tuning shift going on, because you could adjust the capo (and both of these have a round adjusting knob for fine-tuning) and be able to adjust it to the point where you are pressing just beyond the level of the frets and not really squeezing it all the way down on the fret board and therefore have less of a challenge in trying to keep it in tune while using a capo"}
{"source": " (Although I doubt many are setting it that way but rather squeezing it down to the fret board instead"}
{"source": ") Although it is possible with heavy gauge strings that you can fine tune the pressure sufficiently that it will yield a tuned instrument while under the load of the heavier gauge strings creating a strong enough grip at this finer setting so it won't slide off of the guitar like the Shubb does at its lighter setting"}
{"source": "Of course all this is predicated upon you not re-tuning the guitar when you change the capo position"}
{"source": " That really is the only way to create a perfectly tuned instrument and that is to do a little tweaking when you change the capo position"}
{"source": " I'm sure most people ignore that and consider the ever so slightly out of tune instrument is something that is not objectionable and doesn't impede the overall quality of their performance"}
{"source": " I find on the other hand, that a guitar which is perfectly in tune takes the music to a level that is not possible no matter how little or much it is out of tune"}
{"source": "So I conclusion I find the planet waves easier-to-use and with its longer arm capable of a wider fret board, while at the same time capable of the thinner fret boards as well, as being the one that I highly recommend"}
{"source": " Notwithstanding the Shubb places a very close second, and with its slightly smaller size, it does in fact get in the way a little less than the Planet Waves"}
{"source": " All in all they both are the best of all the ones I've tried"}
{"source": "I use a variety of guitars, from an old '50s gibson acoustic to a new nylon string acoustic"}
{"source": " I expected the capo to work well on the narrower neck Gibson, but I was pleasantly surprised to find that it worked well on the 2-inch nut width guitars as well"}
{"source": " It has a spring-loaded clamping arm that can have the clamping strength increased or decreased, and this works well"}
{"source": " Above the adjustable clamping device is a narrow slit to hold a guitar pick, and there's also a holder for a tuner"}
{"source": " I use neither of these, so I have no comment on their usability"}
{"source": " But for my use the capo is thoughtfully engineered, and is an excellent product"}

{"source": "I have been using an old elastic-bar capo for years because the last spring capo I used did not have nearly enough tension"}
{"source": " When I first applied the Planet Waves Tri-Action Capo I thought \"here we go again"}
{"source": "\" There was ample tension E-G but B and E were buzzy as all get out"}
{"source": " Not expecting much, I adjusted the tension"}
{"source": " It took a couple of tries to get it just right, but now the capo works as if it was made specifically for my guitar"}
{"source": " zero buzz across the board"}
{"source": " That in and of itself, makes this capo a five in my book"}
{"source": " Add in the facts that the release mechanism is a breeze (on and off), it looks nice (I have the black version), as well as its comparative ease on the wallet, and this capo is a rock solid five star product"}
{"source": "This capo also has a pick holder"}
{"source": " The feature can actually be a little awkward because of its placement in the context of the capo's overall size and shape, but it is there if you need it and it does not detract from the functionality of the capo itself"}
{"source": "Get this capo!"}
{"source": "I did some research on capos and decided to give Planet Waves a try"}
{"source": " I previously had one of those bungie cord like capos, which was fine but it is a bit cumbersome"}
{"source": "The other capos I looked into were Kyser and Schubb"}
{"source": " Kyser is great because of its easy trigger grip"}
{"source": " It's disadvantage however is that it has a lot of weighted tension on one side so it can knock your strings out of tune"}
{"source": " The Schubb deals with this issue by having an adjustable tension spring that will adjust pressure according to the thickness of the neck"}
{"source": " The problem with the Schubb, however, is that it can't really be manipulated with one hand and it can easily fall of the guitar"}
{"source": "In comes the Planet Waves"}
{"source": " It has a trigger grip so technically you can easily move it around the fretboard"}
{"source": " However, because of the adjustable tension, you do need to adjust it when moving to a different neck thickness"}
{"source": " It might rule out the one-handed ease but it does take care of Schubb's problem of falling off"}
{"source": " In reality, I only found that I need to adjust the tension when switching between guitars or if I move up way up the fretboard"}
{"source": " Between the 1st and 5th fret, I don't really need adjust"}
{"source": " However, if for some reason I want to capo at the 7th, I do need to adjust the tension because it's too tight"}
{"source": " In all, it's not that big a deal and it's nice to have the option to adjust the capo"}
{"source": "In all, I'm happy"}
{"source": " No capo is perfect"}
{"source": " You can do partial capos with this one"}
{"source": " Another review complained that it created buzz but all you need to do it adjust the tension"}
{"source": "In case you aren't aware, this particular capo model only works on six string steel guitars"}
{"source": " I have an electric guitar, a nylon and a Recording King ROS-06 with a chunky neck"}
{"source": " Works great on the electric with the skinny neck and the ROS-06 with that chunky neck"}
{"source": " Since the capo was built for guitars with a radius fretboard, it does not work on classical guitars (or anything with a flat fretboard)"}
{"source": " The capo will not reach across the entire fretboard and since the cap is curved, it will not apply pressure on the middle strings"}
{"source": "It's a nice capo but it may not be what you're looking for so I recommend looking into the other two big hits in capos"}

{"source": " Got good gear?  This little amp will sound great"}
{"source": "The DetailsThe amp itself is tiny"}
{"source": "  I have an Electro-Harmonix pedal that's bigger than this amp! Still, it packs a punch"}
{"source": "  With the gain at about 1/3 up and the volume at half, I get great clean tone and enough volume for a small venue"}
{"source": "  Crank the gain up more and it gets louder and more distorted as you go"}
{"source": "  Yes, this little amp will go from Jazz & Country to Rock & Metal with a twist of a dial"}
{"source": "The line in and headphones jacks are a nice touch that none of my other amps have"}
{"source": "  If you want to quietly play along with some tunes, you can"}
{"source": "  Practice time just got better for your neighbors"}
{"source": "The one lone tube in the Micro Terror is the pre-amp tube"}
{"source": "  Mine came stock with a JJ Tubes 12AX7"}
{"source": "  I understand that's standard"}
{"source": "  A JJ is nice, but it will *not* warm up this little hybrid enough for you to get even a whiff of tube tone"}
{"source": "  Dig out an old Phillips, RCA, Sylvania, or GE to get this guy to sound a bit like its big brother"}
{"source": "  I had an old GE made in Great Britain lying around and popped it in my Micro Terror: warmed it right up; cleaned up a bunch of high-end tinniness"}
{"source": "Still, compared to my two-tube BH5H or my all tube Champ, this guy does sound more solid state than anything"}
{"source": "  BUT, compared to a buddy's Roland and solid state Ampeg, it's downright mellow"}
{"source": "No effects loop means that your time-based effects (reverb, echo, chorus) can get noisy"}
{"source": " So, if you like pedals, stock up on 9 volt batteries to avoid power adapter noise add in"}
{"source": "Speaking of power adapters: a previous reviewer is right"}
{"source": "  The external power brick for this guy seems fragile"}
{"source": "  I'm not a fan of the thin line from the brick to the amp"}
{"source": " It's holding up, but one round with my cat and I'll be looking for a new power supply"}
{"source": "The RubAnnoyance #1:  One cheap cable anywhere in the mix will result in annoying HISS even at low volumes"}
{"source": "  I found that out quickly"}
{"source": "  So, get a proper speaker cable and a high end instrument cable or you will hate this amp"}
{"source": "  I'm running it with a GLS 12 gauge speaker cable and a Planet Waves American Stage instrument cable - both available here at Amazon or any good guitar shop"}
{"source": "Annoyance #2:  This is a 20 watt amp, right?  WELL"}
{"source": " if you don't run a 4ohm speaker, you won't get all 20 watts"}
{"source": "  The Micro Terror self-adjusts to the power needed to drive your speaker by stepping down output"}
{"source": " (Yes yes"}
{"source": " don't quote physics to me"}
{"source": ")  At 8ohms, I still get good volume"}
{"source": "  But at 16ohms (like my BH110) it sounds like a 5 or 7 watt amp"}
{"source": "  That said, I'm actually a fan of the tone I get with my 8ohm Weber in its pine cab"}
{"source": " The 8 inch Jensen speaker in my Champ, while nice, can't put out the low notes like I'd prefer and the Jensen Mod 10-50 is TOO clean"}
{"source": "  But the Weber 10A125 sounds fantastic to my ears; even with the loss in volume"}
{"source": "Annoyance #3: The Micro Terror is so small and so light, it'll tumble right to the floor if anyone kicks your chord"}
{"source": "  Unlike a nice 20 pound amp, the chord won't pull out"}
{"source": "  So: BE CAREFUL"}
{"source": "Mitigation for Annoyance #3: The all steel chassis can handle a tumble from three feet up onto hardwood floors"}
{"source": " though, it will gouge your floor"}
{"source": "And then there's the standard annoyance that comes with owning any guitar amplifier: if the power is noisy or ungrounded, you will wind up with hiss no matter what"}
{"source": "  I always carry a Monster HTS 350 and run my amp through it; that REALLY helps in cleaning up signal noise"}
{"source": "  (If you don't have one, get one"}
{"source": "  The 300 & 350 are cheap and they work"}
{"source": ")The SummaryAfter all that, I can still say:  I love this little amp!  I've gigged with it and it sings well"}
{"source": "  Plus, the added gag of tiny ukulele + tiny amp always draws a laugh"}
{"source": " until I crank the dial over and shred some faces"}
{"source": "For the price, you can likely afford to pick up $40 worth of guitar/speaker chords and wind up with a healthy rig"}
{"source": "  And, for the price, this is a solid 4 star amp"}
{"source": "  I know I'm happy"}
{"source": "BOTTOM LINE: The Orange Micro Terror is powerful hybrid amp head capable of driving any number of speakers you throw at it"}
{"source": " It's low wattage guarantees crushing tube overdrive and classic British tones in the palm of your hand"}
{"source": "WHY ONLY 3 STARS? For starters, this is what I would consider a \"novelty-boutique amplifier\", because it recreates vintage British sounds like a boss, but it's lack of clean headroom is evident"}
{"source": " It's an Orange after all, and so if you want a dirty Plexi sound with only 1-channel to work with - this head is for you"}
{"source": " Playing with a Les Paul, I tested it through a Marshall 1960A 4x12 and it sounds amazing"}
{"source": " I also tested it through my custom 1x12 cabinet loaded with a Celestion G12H30"}
{"source": " I was able to find the \"sweet spot\" on the Tone knob, which for me was around 1 o'clock, and with the Volume at noon and the Drive at max"}
{"source": " I had entered a very musical, lush, and totally gig-worthy tone zone that Jimi Hendrix, Angus Young, and Jimmy Page would have loved to go on tour with"}
{"source": " However, as much as I love eating British Crunch for breakfast, I consider myself a versatile player who needs a bright and heady clean channel AND that classic punch'n'crunch we all know and love AND a solid distortion for metal and beyond"}
{"source": " Unfortunately, the Micro Terror is a ONE TRICK PONY in the Tone category, and for this (if we're starting at 5 stars) I have to subtract one star"}
{"source": " I feel confident subtracting a star for tone because the Micro Terror doesn't exactly take pedals well either without generating too much noise, which leads to feedback"}
{"source": " I subtract another star because this head is really only usable if you're in a rock band, already own a 2x12 or 4x12, and want something quick and small to use to rock out with"}
{"source": " The problem is, if you're one of those people, you probably already have a solid amp head to drive that 2x12 or 4x12 in the first place"}
{"source": " This puts the Micro Terror into Secondary status or useful as an emergency head during a gig if things take a turn for the worse"}
{"source": " This leads me to my final point: if the intent is to purchase this as a bedroom practice or garage rehearsal head, then for the price you could get a much better product that has two GOOD channels instead of one simple (but GREAT) one"}
{"source": "WHAT I LOVE about the Micro Terror is that it is something you can always keep in your arsenal"}
{"source": " Having owned several different combo amps and head/cabinet variations over the years, the Micro Terror could fill that niche because it can be scaled according to your performance or rehearsal needs"}
{"source": " If I were starting over from scratch, I'd probably buy two 2x12 cabs, a Micro Terror, and a bigger and more powerful tube head to drive both cabs if needed"}
{"source": " This would give you perfect flexibility for band rehearsal, studio recording, small bar, big bar, club, or concert stage venues"}
{"source": "(TO THOSE WHO THINK THIS REVIEW WAS UNHELPFUL: I've noticed this review, and pretty much any review of this amp with anything bad to say about it is getting unhelpful votes"}

{"source": "I ordered the Hola! and the Snark SN-6 to preview for my senior adult ukulele players at church"}
{"source": "  I've spent the last week or so tuning a large group of 20 or so ukuleles twice a day to allow them to &#34;settle in&#34;"}
{"source": "  I've used both of these similarly priced tuners and have found them both to be excellent"}
{"source": "  I can't really tell any difference in the accuracy of either one"}
{"source": "  They are both contact tuners, meaning that they pick up the vibration of the instrument rather than relying on an external microphone"}
{"source": "The Hola! is definitely the best choice of the two in that it's more versatile, easier to use, more durable looking, and easier to store"}
{"source": "  The Hola! lies virtually flat and takes up less space in every dimension than the snark"}
{"source": "  It comes in a plastic sales container that can be reused to offer further protection if you feel the need"}
{"source": "  The Snark's curved display arm (which you can't really see in the photo) is slightly more delicate looking, in addition to the fact that it extrudes farther"}
{"source": "  I found the Hola! display to be bigger, brighter and generally easier to read"}
{"source": "  Honestly, most of these differences are minor especially when considering how inexpensive these tuners are"}
{"source": "  The really important difference is the &#34;tuning mode&#34; feature on the Hola!"}
{"source": "Hola! offers very simple operation with one button for power and for switching between its 4 modes of function"}
{"source": "  You can select &#34;chromatic&#34;, &#34;guitar&#34;, &#34;bass&#34; and &#34;ukulele&#34; modes by briefly pressing the power button (as opposed to a long-press for power on/off)"}
{"source": "  This is an especially important feature if the user is not an experienced and knowledgeable musician"}

{"source": " The on-board monitor volume and headphone is fantastic"}
{"source": " I thought it only would play back what was being input at that moment, but it does more than that"}
{"source": " It's a real monitor (the GarageBand software recognizes it's the monitor output), and when you have a multi-track recording that you're working on, the software allows you to pass back other tracks from the computer while recording a new track"}
{"source": "For example, I recorded a track with just the guitar (track 1), I was using the 1/4\" input channel, and laid down that track"}
{"source": " Then I created a second guitar track and recorded a second guitar part (headphones plugged into iTrack Solo) and I was able to hear both the current track I was recording, and the first track"}
{"source": " Lastly, I plugged in a mic into the first input, and created a 3rd vocal only track"}
{"source": " When I was singing, I was able to hear both guitar parts with the headphones still plugged into the iTrack Solo as well as my vocals recording in real-time"}
{"source": " I wasn't expecting this level of capability, and was very impressed by the lack of any noticeable latency in both the backing tracks and the vocals I was recording with all 3 going at the same time"}

{"source": "The DP-008EX Pocketstudio is the next generation design of the DP-03 Digital Portastudio"}
{"source": " I have access to both units and hope to compare them as well as describe the DP-008EX on its own terms, pointing out features and issues important to me (mostly workflow-related) as someone who grew up home-recording with analog equipment"}
{"source": "(If you want all the details of the full functionality I'd recommend downloading the manual from TASCAM or a dealer site that offers it"}
{"source": ")Speaking of the manual I found it to be essential, at least at first"}
{"source": " There are so many features that it will likely take some time to explore and incorporate them so having a copy handy (or better yet downloading a second copy) is a good idea"}
{"source": "This is picky but I found the larger size of the DP-03 manual easier to read and handle than the smaller DP-008EX"}
{"source": "I've used software-based DAWs for years and, while I enjoy MIDI recording, mixing, and editing with them, basic audio tracking never felt as comfortable or spontaneous as when I used analog equipment"}
{"source": " I have a one-room home studio with minimal acoustic treatment and, aside from PC noise, I miss the simplicity and tactile response of my old MK-II cassette 4-track:  Instant power on, press record/pause, ready-set-go"}
{"source": "  Granted, I don't miss the `wall of hiss' that plagued those recordings but I had fun capturing a lot of musical moments"}
{"source": "Using a hardware control surface with my DAW didn't solve the problem - I just find the reality of booting Windows, dealing with the inevitable patching and other software distractions to be too toxic to the creative moment - especially when recording acoustic instruments"}
{"source": "I hoped the DP-008EX would provide some of that older experience - with digital audio quality in a size that would integrate easily with my existing setup"}
{"source": "The bottom line for me is: It does and it doesn't"}
{"source": "First some comparison points that may not be obvious from the product images in the descriptions:Size-wise, the difference between Porta and Pocket studios is roughly 11 1/2 x 2 x 8 inches versus 8 3/4 x 1 3/4 x 5 inches"}
{"source": " TASCAM doesn't provide a case or cover for the DP-008EX but a larger eReader or tablet case should do fine and I'd recommend one if you plan on portable use - the plastic appears fairly durable but it's still plastic"}
{"source": "The knobs on the DP-008EX are smaller in diameter, lower, and have rounded tops compared to those on the DP-03"}
{"source": " However, I find their slightly `rubbery' matte finish just as easy to grip"}
{"source": " I also find the smaller, circular pushbuttons on the DP-008EX don't protrude above the surface as much as the larger bar-shaped buttons on the DP-003 and are less comfortable to use"}
{"source": "The data wheel is identical in size and has a bit less resistance on the DP-008EX which I prefer - the wheel gets a workout and you want responsiveness when selecting from menus"}
{"source": "You'll need the dedicated PS-P520 5v power supply for the DP-008EX; the 12v PS-1225L for the DP-03 can't be shared"}
{"source": " (The plug won't fit so you can't fry it - and don't even think of using batteries when recording anything you take seriously)"}
{"source": "  On the other hand, the Teac RC-3F footswitch is sharable - you'll need a mini plug to phone adaptor - but I think it's indispensable if you're working alone"}
{"source": "Speaking of power, a strong plus for both recorders (and for me a deal-breaker were it not present) is phantom mic power so you're not limited to the built-in stereo condensers"}
{"source": " They're not bad for rough work but, unlike mic stand-mounted portables, it would be a challenge to position this unit close to some instruments and vocals"}
{"source": " I can get a decent acoustic piano recording in a good-sounding room but for close mic recording of guitar (acoustic or electric amp), violin, or percussion I want the flexibility of a mic stand and better quality mics"}
{"source": "I like the resistance of the faders on the DP-03, but I can understand how the lack of real estate kept them off the DP-008EX"}
{"source": " There's no CD burner either on the smaller unit but with USB 2"}
{"source": "0 transfer capability, that's not an issue for me"}
{"source": "Having similar XLR, phono and RCA jacks along the back edge of both units is an acquired taste"}
{"source": " I'm not  bothered by it because I have space to run the cables but it's worth considering your physical layout and whether that works for you"}
{"source": "The LED screen appears to be identical in size on both units and that leads me to my main workflow issues:The flat positioning of the screen makes using the unit on a flat surface less comfortable than it should be - especially since the menu is used so much"}
{"source": " A slanted or adjustable screen mount would probably be asking for design trouble:  I do woodworking and made myself a simple stand that slants at 25 degrees and doesn't interfere with jack access - it makes a tremendous difference on my neck and upper back while reading the screen and for general use"}
{"source": " TASCAM should consider a similar accessory"}
{"source": "The software is largely the same for both units, aside from additional mastering `tools' (essentially packaged presets), and here lies my major criticism: I feel a real conflict between directly accessing functionality (i"}
{"source": "e"}
{"source": " levels, EQ, arming tracks) with dedicated knobs and buttons, and being forced to indirectly access other functionality using what I see is an inflexible, constraining menu  system"}
{"source": "If there were some way to customize the menu navigation (the equivalent of software hot-keys) it's possible the frequent repetition of non-functional steps such as pressing the home button and selecting with the wheel would not wear on me as much as they do"}
{"source": "The best evidence of an unbalanced design I see is the dedicated Phantom power button on both units whose purpose is - to display the \"Phantom\" screen where you then make a selection to turn the power on and off! That crystallizes for me the hybrid character and compromises made here between software-based recording and using a dedicated hardware recorder"}
{"source": "When space for knobs and buttons is severely limited I can understand the design thinking and trade-offs that drive having so much functionality accessible through the menu"}
{"source": " But the DP-008EX is stuffed with knobs and buttons and even my first multi-tracker, a Fostex X-15, effectively doubled-up the functionality of two tracks to cover four"}
{"source": "  So I have to question whether the trade-offs TASCAM made here in fact diminish the user experience"}
{"source": "With connectivity and software-based recording using even smaller devices rapidly improving, I believe the market for dedicated hardware recorders such as the DP-008EX will be largely made up of people like me who grew up with older recorders and are looking to recapture some of that experience"}
{"source": " I think TASCAM would be well-served taking that into account"}
{"source": "I've always liked the design of TASCAM gear; it just looks and feels well-made, and that's still in large part true of the DP-008EX"}
{"source": " But I can't help believing that a simple digital equivalent of my old MK-II cassette 4-track would satisfy a lot of people out there (and not to mention make a terrific hack for someone with the electronics chops to pull it off!)"}
{"source": "As with any new device or toy we buy we discover the good and bad points"}
{"source": "first the good"}
{"source": "THE GOOD: 8 tracks that can be recorded 2 at a time"}
{"source": "has RCA outs which is good for monitors and or headphone amp as well as a 1/8\" headphone out"}

{"source": "Jim"}
{"source": "Tascam had the first inexpensive multitrack recorder on the market, and even as competitors entered the market they've managed to stay on top"}
{"source": " I've owned or borrowed models from Fostex and Korg going back several decades but Tascam always seems to be out in front when it comes to ease of use and value"}
{"source": " Even as the market evolved from cassette to digital, Tascam recorders have kept the same feel and ease of use"}
{"source": " I had a Boss Micro BR-80 for a while, but I found the all-menu interface annoying and difficult to use"}
{"source": " I kept forgetting the sequences to set up rhythm tracks, record, and mix down, and ended up having to repeat things over and over"}
{"source": " I soon sold it, and then replaced it with a Tascam DP-004 when that appeared on the market"}
{"source": " The Tascam wasn't really any more powerful than the Boss, and lacked the built in rhythm tracks, but it had fewer menus and more actual switches and knobs that made it more intuitive in use, and more like an actual mixing board or traditional cassette-based recorder"}
{"source": "After the DP-004 Tascam produced a follow-on six track unit and this recorder, the 8-track DP-008"}
{"source": " When it was first introduced a couple of years ago it really was a revolutionary unit"}
{"source": " There were plenty of 8-track recorders out there, but none that were that small and that inexpensive"}
{"source": " It's also more than just a DP-008 with more tracks"}
{"source": " The DP-008 has a much improved mastering ability that allows you to adjust EQ, compression, and effects individually on tracks for the mix down, while leaving the original tracks unaffected"}
{"source": " Like the DP-004, it has built in microphones and can also be used for direct stereo recording"}
{"source": " Unlike the DP-004, it comes with an external power supply in the box (a $24 option with the original 004) and can use an external battery pack"}
{"source": "I've been playing with my 008 all weekend, doing a mixture of stereo and multitrack recordings"}
{"source": " One thing I noticed right off was that there's a significant amount of noise in the monitor mix while multitracking"}
{"source": " I was afraid this would translate into noisy recordings, but the noise isn't there in the finished playback"}
{"source": " I also noticed that while the basic recording functions are more or less unchanged from those on the 004, the new mixdown functions are much more complex and required constant reference to the manual"}
{"source": " As mentioned previously, there's an awful lot of capability there and it's going to take some time to be able to use it effectively"}
{"source": " Most of that functionality is menu-based, rather than being accessibly directly from the front panel, and I have to say that's one thing I don't really care for"}
{"source": " The only input device you have to select functions and parameters and menus is a scroll wheel that's not nearly as comfortable as a knob or a mouse or touchpad"}
{"source": "Most of my recording lately has been done with various Apple platforms"}
{"source": " At home, I use Garage Band on my iMac and a USB-equipped Alesis console for input"}
{"source": " Away from home I use Garage Band on my iPad and (for ultimate portability) iPod Touch"}
{"source": " All of these platforms are much more intuitive to use than the DP-008 and much more powerful"}
{"source": " Of course, they're also a lot more expensive, and lack the built-in stereo microphones and ability to plug instruments and microphones directly in without some sort of additional interface"}
{"source": " Having XLR connectors as well as 1/4\" inputs is a really nice touch, something you never saw on portables from a few years ago"}
{"source": " I like the old-school approach of the DP-008 as well as the all-in-one package approach"}
{"source": "If I was just starting out in home multitrack recording and didn't have a lot to spend, I think the DP-008 might be a good choice"}
{"source": " It's really good enough to produce music for a band's first CD releases, and costs less than a decent microphone"}
{"source": " WIth 8 full tracks there's no need to do track bouncing to get four instruments and four voices down, and if you really need to, you can bounce and add a further six tracks, giving you 14 in all"}
{"source": " I don't think it's going to replace my iPod for pocket portability or my iPad for functionality (Garage Band gives me a full orchestra, keyboards and drums as well) but having the microphones and instrument preamps built in does make it much easier to set up and use for live recording"}
{"source": " It should get a lot of use at my home and elsewhere in the coming year"}
{"source": "Everything keeps improving, and getting better, faster, and cheaper, but at this price point their isn't one available that isn't a compromise in one way or another"}
{"source": " First off if you are planning on buying the US-322 don't"}
{"source": " Buy its bigger brother the US-366"}
{"source": " Getting an optical connection and additional ins and outs for such a little bit more money, as well as 192k makes it a no-brainer"}
{"source": " To get optical (on the 366 only) at this price is great, but the A/D D/A converters leave a bit to be desired"}
{"source": " On the other hand the mic pres are pretty good, have distortion ratings, THD of only 0"}
{"source": "0045% and with 24 Bit/192KHz recording make these the best sounding interfaces put out by Tascam to date"}
{"source": "What I meant by a compromise is that even with interfaces that cost 3 to 5 times this price most of them have either good mic pres, and weak clocks, or vice versa, and some work with Windows but not so well with MAC and once again vice versa, etc"}
{"source": " I researched interfaces for a long, long time, and considering non-crash reliability and a dozen other factors I finally sprung for anRME Fireface UFX USB 2"}
{"source": "0 or Firewire High Performance audio interface 30 in, 30 out"}
{"source": " Now that's an interface"}
{"source": " I have been running it with Pro Tools 9 since 2011"}
{"source": "Pro Tools 10- Professional audio recording and music creation softwareis out and Pro Tools 11 is now being released"}
{"source": "So if you are looking for an inexpensive interface expect some compromises in one area or another"}
{"source": " Rather than slam it out with performance specs under a microscope, I would rather provide a review helping those who are interested in setting up this Tascam US-322 or 366 so you can save a lot of time trying to figure it out"}
{"source": " Sometimes a little help makes a huge difference in the amount of time saved"}
{"source": " So what I did was load, and register the free and included Cubase LE6 complete with activation and eLicense registration and installation as well as installing the Tascam driver, and doing updates for both"}
{"source": " I know a lot of the reviews here just downloaded a driver and used their existing DAW in order to test out the interface, and therefore they didn't need to spend much time with it"}
{"source": " I don't blame them; the shortest distance between two points is a straight line"}
{"source": " So get out a cup of coffee because installing this complete package doesn't happen in just one hour"}
{"source": " So here goes"}
{"source": "If you have Windows Vista you are probably out of luck because the system requirements list Windows XP, 7, and 8"}
{"source": " I am sure the omission of Vista is not a mistake"}
{"source": " I know myLogitech AudioHub Notebook Speakersare non-functional in my Vista laptop if you are running Windows Media Center in it as well"}
{"source": " It works in Win 7 just fine"}
{"source": " So I installed it in my desktop running Windows 7 64 bit and it gives you the option of installing in 32 or 64"}
{"source": " In addition to Cubase LE 6 it also installed AI Elements 6 as well as Agent One Content, Groove Agent One, Vintage Beat Boxes, Steinberg Drum Loop Expansion 01 which took a good amount of time to load, as well as Steinberg Halion Sonic SE 64 bit for AI Elements"}
{"source": " I then had to activate and register Cubase LE6 which involves installing the latest eLcc, creating a Steinberg account (which is free and they don't ask you for a credit card)"}
{"source": " They provide you with an activation code after you register"}
{"source": "I have an iLok for Pro Tools which is a USB device that enables you to run the program"}
{"source": " Cubase does not require that you have one, although they have an equivalent looking device, but fortunately they have a software based equivalent"}
{"source": " They do this with an eLicense which you will then update to version 6"}
{"source": "5"}
{"source": "4"}
{"source": "1122"}
{"source": " There is an eLicense control setup and you have a Soft eLicenser number that you will use in order to generate the Activation Code generated at the Steinberg site"}
{"source": " What came on my disc was version 6"}
{"source": "05 which they instruct you to immediately do an update, which I did to version 6"}
{"source": "07"}
{"source": "So we install the Tascam interface next which comes on a separate DVD"}
{"source": " Included with the interface is a 5 foot USB printer style cable"}
{"source": " You will need to install the driver disc before connecting it to your computer"}
{"source": " Windows 7 recognizes it but fails to automatically load a driver"}
{"source": " So install the driver off of the disc first, and then do the update"}
{"source": " It took at least 15 minutes to do that update"}
{"source": " What flashed on the screen was 154 megabytes and then all you see is an install screen with a scrolling series of round objects moving"}
{"source": " At first it says, \"This is going to take a long time\", and they were exactly right"}
{"source": " It almost tempts you to think something is wrong, because nothing is happening other than the scrolling, and then finally after ten minutes or so a dialogue box comes up and says, \"Do you want to install?\" and you click continue, and then it comes up again in another minute, and this happens a few times, and then finally it changes over to an installation finished box"}
{"source": " (I have Verizon FIOS and usually download huge amount of data in a flash)"}
{"source": " Then you reboot"}
{"source": "Now this is important"}
{"source": " Plug the US-322 directly into an available USB 2"}
{"source": "0 port and not into a hub, even if it is a powered hub"}
{"source": " It simply won't work"}
{"source": " I tried it and the light wouldn't even come on indicating USB"}
{"source": " When I went direct the interface lit up and it worked"}
{"source": " The manuals also warn you not to use it with USB 1"}

{"source": " The US-322 comes with a printed Quick Start Guide"}
{"source": " There is also an owner's manual for both the Interface, and Cubase that are available either on the DVD, or by Googling the same and they come up as a PDF download"}
{"source": " If you are new to setting up interfaces be prepared to do a good deal of reading"}
{"source": " There is a driver to choose, input and output settings, as well as going into Windows Control Panel/Sound in order to choose the interface for playback, and recording"}
{"source": " If you're new to these kinds of setups just take your time, and don't be dismayed if something doesn't work"}

{"source": "Then there are the generic problems with software interfaces replacing hardware"}
{"source": " With a hardware mixer, I can access as many controls as my fingers can handle (3 or 4 on some mixers) at the same time"}
{"source": " Computerized mixers can only do 1 thing at a time, and one must be constantly moving the cursor from one thing to another to access controls"}
{"source": " The controls on  this interface were very fussy, and you have to position the cursor just exactly on a very small portion of a button to get it to react"}
{"source": " I found it very tedious, and again, no actual instructions were included to help with that process"}
{"source": " With a touch screen, it might be easier, but then why not just use buttons on a real mixer in that case? (Yeah, I know, touch screens are COOL"}
{"source": ")Also, software based functions are always limited by your computer and OS, and that means everyone can have a different experience - consistency is much harder to maintain"}
{"source": "I am old school, and find hardware mixers far more responsive and useful"}
{"source": " I know that lots of people are all excited about having software versions of hardware in their computers, and saving space, etc"}

{"source": "I received a MIM Stratocaster as a gift a year ago"}
{"source": " Recently, I noticed the occasional moment where no signal would make it to the amp"}
{"source": " After tracing the issue, I discovered there was some play in the Strat's jack and the right angle of pull on the cable would keep it from making a positive connection with the tip"}
{"source": " A quick fix was to bend the jack's connector end, but the root of the problem was substandard metal that had too much flex and would permanently open, making a minor gap where there wasn't that positive connection"}

{"source": "To describe my impressions of the TH-2000-S versus my well-used Sennheiser HD-201s I chose a few favorite reference tracks that illustrate different instrumental timbres and production values:  I like to use recordings I know well so I can quickly detect varying emphasis in frequency response and clarity"}
{"source": "Andres Segovia - `Variations on a Spanish Folk Tune - Narvaez' from `My Favorite Spanish Encores'"}
{"source": "In my opinion one of the finest recordings of solo classical guitar I've ever heard, both for the performance and the sheer beauty of sound"}
{"source": "  The distinguishing points of this opening piece are the bass notes that Segovia's arrangement of the original vihuela-texture really emphasize"}
{"source": " For me there's a difference between bass presence and bass clarity: I'll gladly trade less `oomph' in the gut for the kind of definition the Tascam's bring out:  warm, well-defined, with a crisp and clear treble edge"}
{"source": " The Sennheisers, while equally balanced, were far muddier and less defined at the low end with less presence and sparkle on top"}
{"source": " They were also considerably quieter and this applies across the board - the TH-2000-S just puts out a lot more sound at similar volume settings"}
{"source": "Jeff Beck `You Know What I Mean' from `Blow By Blow'"}
{"source": "The George Martin production remains for me one of the most colorful instrumental electric guitar records ever made"}
{"source": "  The clean separation and space in the mix between guitar, electric piano, clavinet, bass and drums is always a joy to hear on a good sound system"}
{"source": " The TH-2000s again demonstrated more punch in the mids and bottom end than the Sennheisers and overall more presence"}
{"source": " It's a 24-bit recording and this is the first time I can honestly say I hear the difference - like being there in the control room, seriously"}
{"source": " There's a greyness to the Sennheisers that frankly never bothered me before, but after hearing the Tascam phones, I doubt I'll ever be satisfied with less again"}
{"source": "Stravinsky Violin Concerto - Anne Sophie Mutter from `Mutter Modern'"}
{"source": "The words I keep coming back to are `presence' and `clarity'"}

{"source": "As far as craftsmanship, the TH-2000-S weighs more than my other phones and much of that weight is in the band rather than the cups"}

{"source": " The cup mounts are really well-designed and allow fine-grained 4-way rotation that guarantees a snug fit regardless of the size and shape of your head and ears"}
{"source": " I like the balanced feel and snug fit on my admittedly large head"}
{"source": " The 2-3\" cushion along the inside of the band and in particular the adds comfort"}
{"source": "The cord is a hybrid - the 2-3' closest to the phones is flat 1/8\" diameter, well-insulated 'matte-finish' and flexible"}
{"source": " Beyond that there's another foot of coiled wire that will comfortably expand another 3-4 feet"}
{"source": "  I think it's a nice compromise that's probably biased towards most users sitting fairly close to an output jack - you can avoid having to deal with excess cord unless you need to"}
{"source": "As we get older our hearing changes: for most people it's a decrease in high-frequency response but it also occur across the entire spectrum"}
{"source": "  Simply listening louder isn't always the best solution and it can be a tremendous ear-opening experience to try a pair of better quality headphones"}
{"source": " I'd encourage anyone excited by quality sound to experiment and these Tascam TH-2000-S are a good place to start"}
{"source": "The TASCAM TH-2000 headphones are like putting a pair of studio monitors on your ears! They are great! Excellent bass response (not muddy at all), tight mids, and clear highs"}
{"source": " To boot, they are extremely comfortable as well"}
{"source": " The foam fits nicely around your ears, conforming to the contours of your face"}
{"source": " They are adjustable, so if you have a huge head you can still wear these"}

{"source": "The EXH Hot Tubes compact pedal offers a very unique sound and is difficult to review from an objective standpoint"}
{"source": "  I had no knowledge of or experience with the original full-sized Hot Tubes pedal from the late 1970's"}
{"source": "  And, frankly, many of the reviews I read online about both the original and the reissue were less than flattering"}
{"source": "  I think part of that hatred comes from the fact that you have an analog pedal without actual tubes that claims (both in the name of the device and in the artwork on the casing) to sound like an overdriven tube amplifier"}
{"source": "  Really, though, if you think about it, doesn't EVERY overdrive pedal (including the venerable Tubescreamer) make that same claim?When I plugged into the Hot Tubes, I was surprised, but immediately intrigued"}
{"source": "  I actually ended up purchasing this over the excellent East River Drive, which was very good, but also a very &#34;familiar&#34; sounding clone of a TS-808"}
{"source": "  What the Hot Tubes does is anything but &#34;familiar&#34; from an affordable OD pedal"}
{"source": "This pedal has a significant amount of output, and (unlike many other overdrives) it has considerable low end"}
{"source": "  In fact, it likely even adds bass to your sound"}
{"source": "  There is a tone circuit bypass switch that I do not fully understand"}
{"source": "  Basically, with the switch off, there is no tone control, and they advertise this sound as &#34;powerful&#34; and touch-responsive"}
{"source": " Since the pedal trends to the darker side of things, however, I actually left it in the &#34;on&#34; position and worked the tone from the 12:00 to 1:30 settings"}
{"source": "The gain structure is as bizarre as it is unique, though it actually starts to make sense if you think about how gain responds on an actual vintage tube amp"}
{"source": "  From the 7:00 (0%) setting up to around 12:00, your tone basically remains clean, provided you started with a clean signal"}
{"source": "  My setup was a Strat into a Fender Super Champ X2, which is a tube/hybrid amp with a great clean &#34;Blackface&#34; setting"}
{"source": "  However, the Hot Tubes completely transforms that tone"}
{"source": "  That setting on my amp is normally bright with some great upper end chime, but the Hot Tubes offered a thick, smokey tone that was mostly clean, with maybe a bit of muffled grit mixed into it"}
{"source": "As you start get past 12:00 on the overdrive knob, the amount of gain increases exponentially"}
{"source": "  At this point, the pedal behaves more like an overdrive, though the gain is almost fuzz-like"}
{"source": "  Some people have described it as a &#34;Jack White&#34; type of sound, but I'll really leave it to individual users to decide if they &#34;like&#34; it or not"}
{"source": "There are aspects of this pedal you could be objectively critical about"}
{"source": "  First, I want to make clear that this is a DARK, bassy pedal"}
{"source": "  In that respect, it is completely different from the EXH Soul Food and East River Drive, both of which have some measure of bass drop"}
{"source": "  The tone circuit only helps to open up the tone a slight bit, but it could do more"}
{"source": "  I do not believe this is the type of overdrive you would stack with - it might actually benefit from a brighter overdrive stacking INTO it"}
{"source": "  If your rig is already on the dark or muffled side, you may want to stay away from this pedal"}
{"source": "  That being said, I would definitely recommend &#34;try before buy&#34; with this one because it is different in hard-to-describe ways"}
{"source": "For now, my rating is 5 stars - solid EHX construction, very compact, accessible 9V jack (on the top where it I like it), and a unique overdrive sound at an affordable price that doesn't sound at all like the other overdrives I have"}
{"source": "  It certainly won't be for everybody, but so far, I like what I hear"}
{"source": "THIS is truly the bestest bangest for your buckest! I've tried dozens of od pedals in the past, (I hate this term) boutiques and non boutiques before I finally stick with SS/BS Mini OD as my always-on pedal cos that thing is a supersonic bad ass since it could cover my needs on clean boost, edge-of-breakup \"clean\" sound, distortion, or even a messed up broken speaker fuzz tonez"}

{"source": "This thing is incredibly cool"}

{"source": "remember those little sticky gummi hand things that you used to get out of the quarter machine at the grocery store?Sticky Hands - 12 per unitThese are kinda like that, but a little thicker and shaped into blue rectangles that are approximately 1\" x 2\""}
{"source": "you can stick them to any part of your drum head to dampen sound as needed"}
{"source": " They even work on cymbals if you're looking for a quicker decay!The closer to the center (or more pads you use), the more dramatic the effect"}
{"source": " You can also cut them to get more pieces out of them if needed"}

{"source": "This works well"}
{"source": "  Has nice ergonomics, fits all of my acoustic guitars, and is easy to use"}
{"source": "  No adjustments are required for my guitars, but it is nice to know that the options is available for this capo"}
{"source": "This capo comes with a pick holder"}
{"source": "  And, it is expandable with aD'Addario NS Micro Clip-On Tunerthat attaches onto the lower arm"}
{"source": "  I do not use a pick, and I use my own tuners, so neither of these two features is applicable for my needs"}
{"source": "This capo has moved up as one of two highly used capos for my guitars, the other one being theG7th Performance Capo"}
{"source": "  The G7 capo goes with my Takamine New Yorker, and this Planet Waves goes on everything else"}
{"source": "  If anyone needs to use a capo, I loan out myKyser Capo"}
{"source": "Recommended"}
{"source": "I have the original version of this capo and it works just fine as does this one"}
{"source": "  However, it seems theu have made a slight modification which increases its value from my viewpoint"}
{"source": "  Yhey have added a channel on the capo onto which slides a bracket which is included"}
{"source": "  This bracket holds the NS micro tuner, of which I have 3"}
{"source": "  I had considered anther capo which came with a tuner for certain applications"}
{"source": "  However, now, this ingenious little bracket enables me to use a tuner in tandem or not depending on my need"}
{"source": "  A simple modification, but bordering on genius"}
{"source": "  The capo itdelf id wuite capable as it is a spring attached capo with a micro adjustment screw/spring which can be helpful with guitars that go sharp when a capo is employed"}
{"source": "  Highly recommended"}
{"source": "I have been playing guitar for more years than I care to admit"}
{"source": " Okay I bought a 1966 Telecaster brand new back then"}
{"source": " Still have it and love it"}
{"source": " I have a lot of different guitars, mostly electric, and 4 acoustics"}
{"source": " On my electrics I love extra light 8 gauge strings"}
{"source": " (Only about 5% of us do) I can fly on those and do things at a pace this is a lot more difficult with heavier gauge strings"}
{"source": " Anyhow I digress, but for a reason"}
{"source": " Light gauge strings are subject to tuning problems if you have big fat frets like the "}
{"source": "050&#34; found on Gibons and ESP-LTD's"}
{"source": " When you squeeze the string to fret it, with light gauge strings it is all too easy to squeeze it all the way to the fret board"}
{"source": " With X-Large jumbo frets that can be quite a distance making the guitar go out of tune"}
{"source": " The cure for that is using heavier gauge strings such as 10's or more so it makes it possible to determine quite easily just where the top of the fret is without doing the full squeeze all the way to the fret board"}
{"source": " So most capo's work with 10's and on up because there is a lot more tension on the strings"}
{"source": " So a lot of capos can create a comfortable fit fully fretting the strings without them going into the sharp note zone"}
{"source": "So since I use lighter gauge strings, and even 9's are subject to the same limitation, I have had a hard time finding a capo that would sit comfortably at the top of the range between the fret and the board, and still squeeze the string sufficiently so as to not create any buzz and do so without making the string too sharp"}
{"source": " Guess what? Now I found it"}
{"source": " I have several capos and none of them make the grade for light gauge strings except this one"}
{"source": " To be honest with you I was surprised when it worked"}
{"source": "Okay so here is how I put it to the test"}
{"source": " I used the Snark headstock tuner which is a great little tuner if you know the secret to using it"}
{"source": " I also have the Peterson HD tuner bench model which is fodder for another post with its one tenth of one cent tuning accuracy"}
{"source": " Okay back to the explanation"}
{"source": "With the Snark you tune the open string until the line stays in the center without wavering off to one side"}
{"source": " The only problem is that most any headstock tuner I have seen they aren't superbly accurate"}
{"source": " (The Peterson headstock tuner I sent back because it was acting crazy"}
{"source": " Anyhow"}
{"source": ") So the secret to using the Snark which I like best out of the headstock tuners I have tried is to tune the open string first, and then fret the string on let's say the 5th fret"}
{"source": " You will occasionally find that a string in the open position registers as being in tune, even though it may be a little sharp, or a little flat, so when you strum the whole chord you will get a desire to tune it, so your ears can hear it, in order to get it spot on"}
{"source": " There is nothing more beautiful than a perfectly tuned guitar, and nothing worse than one that is well out of tune"}
{"source": "So by tuning the open string, and then tuning the fretted string, once both are in tune it is right on"}
{"source": " So in the open position if by chance it is a tiny bit sharp, not enough to register on the tuner, when you fret that string, for example on the 5th fret that naturally stretches the string a little bit, making it sharper, which will now show on the Snark as a note that is too sharp"}
{"source": " Once you balance the open string, and the fretted string you really have a wonderfully tuned instrument"}
{"source": " You don't even need to hear it"}
{"source": " So your audience is not listening to you tune up, yet you get it right in the sweet spot that we all love and know so well"}
{"source": "So with that being said you can more fully understand why this D'Addario NS Artist Capo is the cat&#8217;s meow"}
{"source": " It is the first tuner that I ever used that kept the guitar perfectly in tune after clamping it on the neck"}
{"source": " (It is adjustable like the others are, but this one is sensitive for light gauge strings as well)You often see artists trimming up their tuning after putting on the capo; not with this one even with light gauge strings"}
{"source": " I must admit I was surprised taking it right out of the wrapper, after going through the above tuning procedure to get the guitar spot on, that it immediately did the job just right"}
{"source": " It wasn't even a little bit sharp"}
{"source": "To be super critical here is another tip"}
{"source": " When using this capo put it closer to the fret, rather than in the middle between two frets"}
{"source": " For some reason it stretches the string less in doing so"}
{"source": " It has to do with the tension resistance at a steeper angle right alongside of a fret, rather than farther way like in the middle between the two frets"}
{"source": " I did get a tiny bit of sharpness when positioned between the two frets"}
{"source": " (With 8 gauge strings)Since the two most important factors are that it is comfortable to use, not getting in the way when playing open chords and keeping the guitar in tune"}
{"source": " The best way to use this capo is to simply clamp the strings right above the second fret for example, rather than right below the third one"}
{"source": " Right below the third one gives you that perfect tune also, just like right above the second one does, but it keeps the capo way out of your way"}
{"source": " As a matter of fact I am so accustomed to using the capo position to know where to finger the chords, that I sometimes make a mistake and fret them one lower than they belong"}
{"source": " With a little practice, or not even looking at the guitar instantly corrects that"}
{"source": " To say this quite simply is to say use this capo farther away from your hand"}
{"source": " You just slide it down to being right above the fret below it, rather than right below the fret above it"}
{"source": "So there it is"}
{"source": " This Capo does the job perfectly and is light and easy to clamp"}
{"source": " Of course if it can accurately handle 8's it will breeze through anything thicker"}
{"source": " Out of the box it is set at its lightest setting, and that is perfect for 8's on the Telecaster I tried it on"}
{"source": " Teles and Strats really have the same neck just with different head stocks"}

{"source": "  I've been using simple devices like the 1K that  split the headphone/microphone jack into two separate cords, one for headphone, and one for guitar"}
{"source": " The problem with this sort of configuration is that it's very easy to overload the microphone input, and the recording quality done this way is not very good"}

{"source": " First, it contains its own dedicated preamp and A/D, and because of that it delivers a wide dynamic range and excellent fidelity"}
